THE CONSERVATION SURVEY WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION TREATMENT PLAN TO ALLOW THE FUTURE DISPLAY OF THESE RARELY SEEN OBJECTS.

THE MEMORIAL ART GALLERY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER WILL IMPLEMENT THE SECOND PHASE OF AN INSTITUTION-WIDE STORAGE RENOVATION PROJECT TO IMPROVE CARE FOR ITS COLLECTIONS AND INCREASE ACCESS FOR BOTH STAFF AND THE PUBLIC. THE MUSEUM WILL REHOUSE 2,500 SMALL OBJECTS, SCULPTURES, AND ARTIFACTS BY INSTALLING A CUSTOM HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE STORAGE SYSTEM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL RESEARCH AND UPDATE THE CATALOGING INFORMATION FOR OBJECTS THAT ARE CURRENTLY NOT ACCESSIBLE VIA THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO COMPLETE AN ONGOING INITIATIVE TO LINK DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHS OF EACH OBJECT TO CATALOG RECORDS THAT WILL BE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE. THE NEW SYSTEM WILL STORE NEWLY HOUSED OBJECTS, INCREASE THE STAFF'S ABILITY TO ACCESS WORKS SAFELY AND WITH MINIMAL HANDLING, AND PROVIDE FOR INCREASED GROWTH OF THE COLLECTION.

THE BALTIMORE MUSEUM OF INDUSTRY WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO THE EARLIEST KNOWN MOVING PICTURE FOOTAGE OF THE PORT OF BALTIMORE. LOCALLY BROADCAST FROM 1950 TO 1965, THE PORT THAT BUILT A CITY AND STATE TELEVISION PROGRAM DOCUMENTED THE WORKING LIVES OF MEN AND WOMEN WHO DEPENDED UPON THE PORT OF BALTIMORE FOR THEIR LIVELIHOODS. THE MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE 425 REELS OF EDITED 16 MM ACETATE FILM THAT CORRESPOND TO 30-MINUTE EPISODES OF THE PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO CATALOG AND REHOUSE 540 REELS OF UNEDITED FOOTAGE AND DIGITIZE, INDEX, AND CATALOG A 300-PAGE EPISODE GUIDE ALONG WITH ASSOCIATED SCRIPTS, PRODUCTION NOTES, AND PROMOTIONAL MATERIALS AND PHOTOGRAPHS. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS WHILE PROVIDING A NEWLY ACCESSIBLE RESOURCE FOR RESEARCHERS INTERESTED IN MARITIME HISTORY AND THE IMPACT OF DEINDUSTRIALIZATION.

THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT IMPROVEMENTS IN COLLECTIONS DOCUMENTATION AND STORAGE SYSTEMS TO ENHANCE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS FOR RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC. THE MUSEUM WILL INSTALL COMPACTORS TO HOUSE EXISTING CABINETS AND A BACK-UP CLIMATE MONITORING SYSTEM TO PROVIDE BETTER PROTECTION FOR THE SPECIMENS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO INVENTORY AND CATALOG ITS TAXIDERMY BIRD AND MAMMAL MOUNTS AND EGG AND MOLLUSK COLLECTIONS. THE CATALOG RECORDS AND ASSOCIATED IMAGES WILL BE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE IN SYMBIOTA/IDIGBIO. THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO ACCESS SPACE FOR A DEDICATED PUBLIC GALLERY WHILE ACCOMMODATING GROWTH IN ITS COLLECTIONS AS WELL AS PROVIDING A FOUNDATION TO SUPPORT FUTURE CONSERVATION NEEDS.

PETTIGREW STATE PARK WILL CONSERVE TWO AMERICAN INDIAN CANOES TO PREPARE THEM FOR EXHIBITION IN A NEW VISITOR CENTER SLATED FOR COMPLETION IN 2021. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NEED TO MITIGATE DEGRADATION TO THE OBJECTS INCURRED SINCE AN EARLIER CONSERVATION TREATMENT. A PROJECT CONSERVATOR WILL STABILIZE AND RE-TREAT THE CANOES BASED ON A DETAILED CONSERVATION PLAN. THE TREATMENT PLAN WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR OTHER CONSERVATORS ADDRESSING DAMAGE FROM SUCROSE APPLICATIONS THAT HAVE UNDERGONE RE-CRYSTALLIZATION AS A RESULT OF TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY FLUCTUATIONS. THE TWO CANOES WILL BE DISPLAYED AS PART OF A STATEWIDE INTERPRETIVE PLAN TO IMPROVE THE INTERPRETATION OF THE LIVES AND CULTURES OF AMERICAN INDIANS LIVING IN WHAT IS NOW NORTH CAROLINA.

THE FLATEN ART MUSEUM AT ST. OLAF COLLEGE WILL CONTRACT WITH EXTERNAL CONSERVATORS TO PERFORM CONSERVATION TREATMENTS TO EXTEND THE LIFE OF 21 CULTURALLY AND HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT GERMAN PROPAGANDA POSTERS AND BROADSIDES FROM WORLD WAR II. THIS TEAM WILL ALSO PHOTOGRAPH AND CREATE HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGES OF EACH POSTER FOR SHARING ONLINE AND FRAME THE POSTERS FOR EXHIBITION AND SAFE STORAGE. THE MUSEUM'S PARTICIPATION IN THE COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION PROGRAM IDENTIFIED THESE MATERIALS AS THE INSTITUTION'S HIGHEST PRIORITY CONSERVATION NEED. A CONSERVATOR WHO SPECIALIZES IN PAPER PRESERVATION WILL PRESENT AT THE MUSEUM ABOUT THE CONSERVATION TREATMENT. THE PROJECT WILL MAKE THESE HISTORICAL RESOURCES DISCOVERABLE AND FREELY AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS, AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS, SCHOLARS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE BURKE MUSEUM WILL REHOUSE A PORTION OF ITS MYCOLOGY AND FISH COLLECTIONS TO SECURE THEIR LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND TO IMPROVE ACCESS FOR THE BENEFIT OF RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, GOVERNMENT BIOLOGISTS, AND CITIZEN SCIENTISTS. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL STEEL CABINETS FOR THE MYCOLOGY COLLECTION AND COMPACTOR SHELVING FOR THE FISH COLLECTION'S OTOLITH AND EGG SPECIMENS. STUDENT EMPLOYEES AND A MOVING SERVICE WILL ASSIST MUSEUM STAFF IN COORDINATING THE MOVE OF THE SPECIMENS TO A NEW, MORE SECURE, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND LOCATION. THE PROJECT WILL PROTECT THESE COLLECTIONS FROM IMMEDIATE SECURITY, FIRE, AND PEST RISKS WHILE PROVIDING THE SPACE AND INFRASTRUCTURE FOR LONGER-TERM GROWTH.

THE SMITH COLLEGE MUSEUM OF ART WILL IMPROVE AND EXPAND STORAGE FOR ITS COLLECTION OF MORE THAN 28,000 WORKS OF ART. THE MUSEUM WILL APPOINT AN ASSOCIATE REGISTRAR WHO WILL ORGANIZE AND OVERSEE THE TEMPORARY RELOCATION AND PERMANENT REHOUSING OF ARTWORKS AND UPDATE FOUR EXISTING STORAGE SPACES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL REPAIR DETERIORATED EQUIPMENT, INSTALL MORE EFFICIENT AND APPROPRIATE STORAGE UNITS, AND RECONFIGURE SPACES TO IMPROVE ACCESS AND LEARNING. THE ASSOCIATE REGISTRAR WILL HELP ENSURE THE SAFETY AND PROPER CARE OF THE COLLECTIONS WHILE THE PROJECT IS UNDERWAY, ALLOWING THE MUSEUM TO CONTINUE ITS REGULAR EXHIBITION AND TEACHING ACTIVITIES. THE PROJECT WILL RESOLVE ISSUES OF OVERCROWDING AND INAPPROPRIATE STORAGE, ENABLING THE MUSEUM TO HOUSE ITS ENTIRE COLLECTION ON-SITE. THIS WILL OPTIMIZE ACCESS, PROVIDE MORE APPROPRIATE STORAGE, AND ENSURE PROPER CARE AND PRESERVATION.

THE COLORADO SPRINGS FINE ARTS CENTER AT COLORADO COLLEGE WILL IMPLEMENT THE SECOND PHASE OF A LONGER-TERM PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE DOCUMENTATION, PRESERVATION, AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTION OF NATIVE AMERICAN, HISPANIC, SPANISH COLONIAL, AND 20TH CENTURY AMERICAN ART. THE MUSEUM WILL LAUNCH THE PROJECT BY IDENTIFYING PRIORITY ITEMS FROM ITS COLLECTIONS FOR DIGITIZATION BASED ON INPUT FROM A COMMUNITY SURVEY. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A DIGITAL COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT AND A PHOTOGRAPHER TO WORK WITH DESIGNATED STAFF. BASED ON SURVEY RESULTS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH, RESEARCH, AND PREPARE RECORDS FOR 3,000 PIECES FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION. MULTIPLE IMAGES OF THE FULLY CATALOGUED WORKS OF ART WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH A COLLECTIONS PORTAL ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW FACULTY, SCHOLARS, TEACHERS, CULTURAL GROUPS, AND TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS TO ACCESS THE COLLECTIONS FOR TEACHING AND LEARNING.

IN PREPARATION FOR A MOVE TO A NEW FACILITY, THE YORK COUNTY HISTORY CENTER WILL INVENTORY, CATALOG, RECONCILE, AND REHOUSE ITS COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO COLLECTIONS ASSISTANTS TO WORK WITH THE DIRECTOR OF COLLECTIONS AND VOLUNTEERS. THIS PROJECT TEAM WILL COMPLETE THE INVENTORY AND REHOUSING OF APPROXIMATELY 12,000 ARTIFACTS INCLUDING COSTUMES, ART, AND 3D OBJECTS. THE TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE OBJECTS AND UPDATE COLLECTIONS RECORDS WITH LOCATION AND CONDITION INFORMATION. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO PURCHASE PACKING MATERIALS NECESSARY TO REHOUSE SENSITIVE OBJECTS IN PREPARATION FOR THE MOVE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY OBJECTS THAT SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE COLLECTION AND IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE OBJECTS IN NEED OF CONSERVATION. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTIONS AS WELL AS IMPROVING COMMUNITY ACCESS BY ALLOWING STAFF AND RESEARCHERS TO SEARCH FOR AND LOCATE OBJECTS MORE EFFICIENTLY.

THE GENEVA HISTORY MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY IMPLEMENTING A REDESIGN OF ITS STORAGE AREAS TO OVERCOME OVERCROWDING AND ACCOMMODATE FUTURE GROWTH. THE MUSEUM WILL REPLACE INDUSTRIAL METAL SHELVING AND WOODEN PEGBOARDS WITH HIGH-DENSITY CUSTOM MOBILE STORAGE SYSTEMS. MUSEUM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL MOVE OBJECTS TO TEMPORARY STORAGE LOCATIONS DURING THE INSTALLATION AND REDESIGN OF ITS 2,000-SQUARE-FOOT COLLECTIONS ROOM AND 468-SQUARE-FOOT ARCHIVES STACKS ROOM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL RETURN OBJECTS TO THE NEWLY DESIGNED ROOMS, CREATE NEW SHELVING LABELS, AND UPDATE LOCATIONS IN THE ELECTRONIC DATABASE. THE MUSEUM WILL COMPLETE A COLLECTIONS INVENTORY AND UPDATES TO ITS COLLECTIONS PLAN. THE PROJECT DESIGN IS BASED ON RECOMMENDATIONS FROM A VARIETY OF ASSESSMENT REPORTS PRIORITIZING A NEED TO MINIMIZE THE RISK OF DAMAGE TO THE COLLECTIONS AND MAXIMIZE THE MUSEUM'S LIMITED ON-SITE STORAGE AREAS.

THE MUSEUM OF ART AT THE RHODE ISLAND SCHOOL OF DESIGN WILL MAKE ITS DIGITAL CONTENT MORE ACCESSIBLE TO BOTH INTERNAL USERS AND ONLINE AUDIENCES BY UPGRADING ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. BASED ON THE RESULTS OF A TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT, THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON REPLACING AN OUTDATED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND IMPLEMENTING A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE NEW SYSTEMS WILL ENABLE THE INTEGRATION OF OBJECT-BASED INFORMATION ACROSS THESE PLATFORMS AND THE MUSEUM'S PUBLIC-FACING WEB INTERFACE. PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE A STREAMLINED WORKFLOW FOR STAFF, THE ABILITY TO UPLOAD ASSETS AND METADATA TO THE SYSTEMS DAILY, AND THE CREATION OF EASY SEARCH, VIEW, OUTPUT, AND DOWNLOAD FUNCTIONALITIES.

THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF TOYS AND MINIATURES WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY REHOUSING 12,000 OF ITS MOST VULNERABLE OBJECTS. STORED IN AN OFFSITE LOCATION DURING THE MUSEUM'S RENOVATION, THE OBJECTS WILL BE MOVED TO AN EXISTING ONSITE STORAGE SPACE TO PROVIDE A CLEAN AND STABLE ENVIRONMENT FOR THEIR LONG-TERM PRESERVATION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A COMPACT STORAGE SYSTEM TO HOUSE FINE-SCALE MINIATURES, CUSTOM-MADE DOLLHOUSES, AND DOLLS COMPOSED OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS. THE MUSEUM WILL ADD A DEDICATED COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF TO MOVE AND REHOUSE THE COLLECTIONS, WHICH WILL BE MORE EASILY ACCESSIBLE FOR INCORPORATION INTO THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITION PROGRAM.

THE CHRYSLER MUSEUM OF ART WILL IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS AND ACCESSIBILITY FOR ITS SMALL- AND MEDIUM-SIZED PAINTINGS BY CREATING A MORE FUNCTIONAL WORKSPACE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE TEMPORARY RELOCATION OF WORKS IN THE PAINTING STORAGE AREA, REMOVAL OF OLD STORAGE UNITS, THE INSTALLATION OF NEW RACKS AND STORAGE SYSTEMS, AND REHOUSING WORKS IN THE NEW STORAGE AREA. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE PAINTING STORAGE SYSTEMS THAT WILL ENHANCE SECURITY AND ACCESSIBILITY FOR THE PAINTINGS. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO OBSERVE, ASSESS, AND PRIORITIZE WORKS FOR POTENTIAL CONSERVATION AND STABILIZATION TREATMENT; DETECT AND RECORD CONDITION CHANGES TO WORKS OF ART AND THEIR FRAMES THROUGH REGULAR CONSERVATION ASSESSMENTS; ALLOW FOR GREATER VISIBILITY AND MINIMIZE VIBRATIONS SO THAT MOVEMENT WILL NOT ENDANGER THE ART; AND BENEFIT SCHOLARLY STUDY.

THE CHESTER COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPROVE ARTIFACT CARE AND INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP BY CREATING A VISIBLE STORAGE SPACE. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL LARGE GLASS CASES AND FLAT FILE CABINETS WITH GLASS-COVERED DRAWERS TO INSTALL IN THE 2,000-SQUARE-FOOT CLIMATE-CONTROLLED PUBLIC SPACE. NEARLY 5% OF THE MUSEUM COLLECTION WILL BE REHOUSED, INCLUDING FURNITURE, CERAMICS, SILVER, PEWTER, PAINTINGS, AND TEXTILES. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO INSTALL FURNITURE TO SUPPORT THREE COMPUTER WORKSTATIONS FOR VISITORS TO ACCESS THE ENTIRE COLLECTIONS DATABASE ELECTRONICALLY. THE PROJECT IS PART OF A LONG-TERM COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP PROJECT AND PERMANENT GALLERY REINSTALLATION.

IMPROVEMENTS TO ZOO NEW ENGLAND'S TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE WILL ENHANCE ANIMAL CARE AND MANAGEMENT AND INCREASE STAFF EFFICIENCY IN RECORDING DATA IN THE ZOOLOGICAL INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE (ZIMS) GLOBAL DATABASE. THIS SOFTWARE DOCUMENTS SPECIMEN DEMOGRAPHY, PEDIGREE, AND HUSBANDRY AS WELL AS NUTRITIONAL, WELFARE, AND MEDICAL INFORMATION. THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND BOTH WIRED AND WIRELESS INTERNET CONNECTIVITY THROUGHOUT THE ZOO AND ACQUIRE ADDITIONAL MOBILE COMPUTERS AND VIDEO CAMERAS IN ANIMAL AREAS. THE NEW ANIMAL CAMERAS WILL ENABLE ZOO STAFF TO MONITOR AND RECORD OBSERVATIONS ABOUT THE DAILY ACTIVITIES OF THE ANIMALS MORE EFFICIENTLY. THE DATA GATHERED BY ANIMAL CARE STAFF WILL BE USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT BREEDING, DIET, ENRICHMENT, AND MEDICAL CARE.

THE SAN FRANCISCO BOTANICAL GARDEN SOCIETY WILL ENHANCE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY IMPROVING ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS. THE GARDEN WILL ESTABLISH A PLANTS RECORDS MANAGER POSITION TO SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A NEW PLANTS RECORDS MANAGEMENT DATABASE. THE GARDEN WILL ALSO UPDATE ITS COLLECTIONS POLICIES AND PROCEDURES THROUGH A STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN PROCESS. ONCE THE PLANTS COLLECTION IS PUBLISHED ONLINE, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONDUCT OUTREACH TO HELP VISITORS AND STAFF MEMBERS USE WEB TOOLS TO SEARCH FOR PLANTS AND GARDEN FEATURES, VIEW IMAGES, AND CREATE TRAIL MAPS FOR SELF-GUIDED TOURS.

THE UNIVERSITY MUSEUM AT SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AT EDWARDSVILLE WILL LAUNCH THE FIRST PHASE OF A MULTI-YEAR COLLECTIONS INVENTORY PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE PRESERVATION AND EXPAND ACCESS FOR ITS COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY 10,000 OBJECTS FROM ITS FINE ARTS AND ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS WHILE IDENTIFYING AND RECORDING OBJECTS FOUND WITHOUT DOCUMENTATION. AS PART OF THE INVENTORY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO GATHER LIMITED CONDITION INFORMATION FOR THE OBJECTS AND DIGITALLY PHOTOGRAPH EACH ITEM. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AND TRAIN TWO COLLECTIONS TECHNICIANS TO ASSIST STAFF IN CONDUCTING THE INVENTORY.

THE MUSEUM OF VERTEBRATE ZOOLOGY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY, WILL IMPROVE THE STEWARDSHIP OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY REHOUSING ITS NON-PASSERINE BIRD SKINS. THE MUSEUM WILL REPLACE EARLY 1900S-ERA CASES THAT DO NOT ADEQUATELY PROTECT THE SKINS FROM POTENTIAL PEST DAMAGE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL 74 NEW CASES AND 400 ALUMINUM TRAYS TO PROVIDE BETTER PEST CONTROL, AS WELL AS IMPROVED WEIGHT LOADING AND SPACING FOR THE SPECIMENS. AS PART OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL RELABEL TAGS, TRAYS, AND CASES BASED ON A RECENTLY UPDATED ORGANIZATION AND TAXONOMY. BY FOCUSING ON THESE LARGER SPECIMENS (E.G., PENGUINS, LOONS, GULLS, ALCIDS, AND HAWKS), THE MUSEUM WILL BE ABLE TO ADD SPACE FOR RECENTLY RECEIVED ACQUISITIONS OF LARGE-BODIED BIRDS. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY AND PRESERVATION OF THESE SPECIMENS FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATION RELATED TO BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION.

THE MINERALOGICAL AND GEOLOGICAL MUSEUM AT HARVARD UNIVERSITY WILL IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS FOR ITS COLLECTION OF 1,300 METEORITES TO PROTECT THEM FROM LONG-TERM DECAY. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE CUSTOMIZED STORAGE EQUIPMENT AS WELL AS SPECIMEN-LEVEL STORAGE SUPPLIES NEEDED FOR INDIVIDUAL REHOUSING. THE MUSEUM WILL APPLY NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED STANDARDS TO GUIDE THE REHOUSING OF THE SPECIMENS. METEORITES THAT ARE SUSCEPTIBLE TO DECAY UNDER THE EARTH'S ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS WILL BE INDIVIDUALLY STORED IN NYLON BAGS INSIDE NITROGEN-PURGED DESICCATORS. MORE STABLE METEORITES WILL BE STORED IN CLAMSHELL BOXES INSIDE INERT DUST-TIGHT CUSTOM CABINETS WITH HUMIDITY CONTROL. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE ONGOING GROWTH OF THE COLLECTION AND THE ACCESSIBILITY OF THE METEORITE COLLECTION FOR A BROAD RANGE OF RESEARCHERS.

THE LONG BEACH MUSEUM OF ART WILL CREATE AND MAINTAIN DIGITAL ASSETS FOCUSING ON THE INSTITUTION'S PERMANENT COLLECTION OF WORKS BY WOMEN ARTISTS IN CALIFORNIA, MID-CENTURY TO PRESENT. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHER TO PRODUCE HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGES OF WORKS BY 271 ARTISTS IN ALL MEDIA, INCLUDING WOOD, ENAMEL, PAINTING, SCULPTURE, PHOTOGRAPHY, AND ARTIST BOOKS. STAFF WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH AND CREATE BIOGRAPHICAL/CONTEXTUAL INFORMATION ABOUT EACH WORK AND ARTIST. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN FREE, ONLINE ACCESS TO 515 DIGITAL IMAGES VIA THE MUSEUM'S SEARCHABLE ONLINE WEB KIOSK. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO NEARLY 70 YEARS OF ARTISTIC OUTPUT BY CALIFORNIA WOMEN FROM 1950 TO THE PRESENT, THEREBY INCREASING ITS VISIBILITY AND APPRECIATION.

ANDREW JACKSON'S HERMITAGE WILL ENSURE BEST PRACTICES FOR THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY DEVELOPING A LONG-RANGE COLLECTIONS AND CONSERVATION PLAN. THE PROJECT WILL BEGIN WITH A REVIEW OF ALL EXISTING POLICIES AND DOCUMENTS RELATING TO COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL THEN CONTRACT WITH SPECIALIST CONSERVATORS TO UPDATE THE INSTITUTION'S CONSERVATION SURVEY OF COLLECTIONS, EXAMINE CURRENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, AND CONDUCT A DETAILED CONSERVATION SURVEY OF SELECTIONS FROM THE TEXTILES COLLECTION. ADDITIONAL CONSULTANTS WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE ON CURRENT PRACTICES IN THE MANAGEMENT OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS AND RECORDS, AND STAFF WILL INVENTORY THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION OF ARCHITECTURAL FRAGMENTS AND ASSESS AND DEFINE THE INSTITUTIONAL ARCHIVES. THE WORK WILL RESULT IN THE CREATION OF THE NEW COLLECTIONS AND A CONSERVATION PLAN AS WELL AS PROVIDING INFORMATION TO GUIDE FUTURE COLLECTIONS STORAGE IMPROVEMENTS.

MONTPELIER WILL CREATE AN ONLINE ARCHIVE OF THE 2003-2008 RESTORATION OF PRESIDENT JAMES MADISON'S HISTORIC HOUSE. DURING THE RESTORATION, ARCHAEOLOGISTS AND ARCHITECTURAL HISTORIANS PRODUCED MORE THAN 125,000 PHOTOGRAPHS, 1,500 DRAWINGS, AND HUNDREDS OF REAMS OF NOTES THAT DOCUMENTED THE PHYSICAL EVIDENCE USED TO RESTORE THE HOUSE TO ITS 1810S APPEARANCE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL SCAN, DIGITALLY TAG, AND LINK THE RECORDS TO AN EXISTING 3D MODEL OF THE MAIN HOUSE, FORMING A GEOREFERENCED DATABASE OF THE RESTORATION. THIS WILL BE ADAPTED INTO A WEB-FRIENDLY FORMAT USING GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS) SOFTWARE. MUSEUM STAFF WILL CREATE A SERIES OF ONLINE EXHIBITS THAT HIGHLIGHT COMPELLING CASE STUDIES FROM THE RESTORATION.

THE MISSOURI HISTORY MUSEUM WILL PROCESS, SURVEY, AND MAKE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE THE 1,894 OBJECTS IN ITS CHARLES A. LINDBERGH COLLECTION. OBJECTS INCLUDE DIVERSE PERSONAL ITEMS, GIFTS ASSOCIATED WITH LINDBERGH'S 1927 TRANSATLANTIC FLIGHT AND PUBLICITY TOURS, AND WEDDING GIFTS PRESENTED TO CHARLES AND HIS WIFE ANNE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO COLLECTIONS SPECIALISTS AND ONE SPECIAL PROJECTS PHOTOGRAPHER, OVERSEEN BY ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGER, TO PERFORM THE WORK. CONSERVATORS SPECIALIZING IN OBJECTS, PAINTINGS, PAPER, AND TEXTILES WILL PERFORM DETAILED CONSERVATION SURVEYS. FULL RECORDS WITH DIGITIZED IMAGES WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE VIA THE MUSEUM'S ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL. THE PROJECT WILL BE THE FIRST PHASE OF AN EIGHT-YEAR, MULTISTAGE COLLECTIONS INITIATIVE CULMINATING IN 2027 WITH THE CENTENNIAL OF LINDBERGH'S LEGENDARY TRANSATLANTIC FLIGHT.

THE MOHONK PRESERVE WILL IMPROVE ACCESS TO NATURAL HISTORY OBSERVATIONS RECORDED IN THE 20TH CENTURY BY ITS CO-FOUNDER, DANIEL SMILEY, AND OTHER RESEARCH ASSOCIATES. THE COLLECTIONS OF BIODIVERSITY, PHENOLOGY, AND GENERAL ECOLOGY DATA ARE STORED IN THE PRESERVE'S DANIEL SMILEY RESEARCH CENTER ON MORE THAN 10,000 NOTE CARDS. THIS FORMAT LIMITS BOTH ACCESS AND ANALYSIS. THE CENTER WILL DIGITIZE THE CARDS AND 3,669 ITEMS FROM ITS SPECIMEN COLLECTION AND UPLOAD THEM INTO OPEN ACCESS WEBSITES. CITIZEN SCIENCE VOLUNTEERS, TRAINED AND SUPERVISED BY THE CENTER'S PROFESSIONAL STAFF, WILL PERFORM THE DIGITIZATION WORK. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN COLLECTIONS THAT ARE MORE EASILY ACCESSIBLE. THEY WILL BE USED BY MULTIPLE ORGANIZATIONS AND SCIENTISTS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH ON CLIMATE CHANGE, BIODIVERSITY, BIRD MIGRATION, AND HUMAN IMPACTS ON THE ENVIRONMENT.

THE DENVER ART MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE COLLECTIONS PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT BY PROVIDING COOLER, DRIER CONDITIONS FOR VULNERABLE COLLECTION OBJECTS. THE MUSEUM WILL INSTALL A 1,000-SQUARE-FOOT COLD STORAGE VAULT AND ACCOMPANYING STORAGE FURNITURE. THE NEW STORAGE SYSTEM WILL IMPROVE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION FOR MATERIALS OR COMPONENTS THAT ARE AT-RISK FOR NATURAL OR CHEMICAL AGING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INVENTORY AND REHOUSE OVER 2,800 ARTWORKS, INCLUDING TRADITIONAL PHOTOGRAPHIC PRINTS, 35MM COLOR TRANSPARENCIES, MAGNETIC MEDIA, AND FURS. THE MUSEUM WILL UPDATE ASSOCIATED INSTITUTIONAL COLLECTIONS AND CONSERVATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AND PROVIDE TRAINING FOR STAFF REGARDING COLD STORAGE AND PROCEDURES FOR ACCESSING THESE COLLECTIONS.

THE MCLEAN COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND PROFESSIONAL MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTION OF PHOTOGRAPHIC NEGATIVES DOCUMENTING LOCAL HISTORY. THE PHOTOGRAPHS WERE TAKEN BY REPORTERS FOR THE PANTAGRAPH, MCLEAN COUNTY'S OLDEST NEWSPAPER, AND THE VAST MAJORITY DO NOT EXIST IN ANY OTHER FORMAT. THE PROJECT WILL DIGITIZE AND STABILIZE 50,000 NEGATIVES FROM 1940-1955. THE SELECTION OF THESE NEGATIVES IS BASED ON A PRIOR ASSESSMENT, WHICH IDENTIFIED THEM AS HIGH-RISK FOR LOSS DUE TO DEGRADATION. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH A DIGITIZATION FIRM AND HIRE TWO PART-TIME EMPLOYEES TO ASSIST WITH THE CREATION OF ASSOCIATED METADATA. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO ENGAGE FOUR INTERNS, WHO WILL BE TRAINED IN DIGITIZATION PROCEDURES. AS PART OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL UPGRADE ITS SERVER SPACE TO HOUSE THE NEW DIGITAL FILES AND MOVE THE ORIGINAL NEGATIVES INTO ONSITE COLD STORAGE TO MINIMIZE FURTHER DEGRADATION.

THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA POETRY CENTER WILL IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM CARE OF ITS COLLECTIONS OF CONTEMPORARY POETRY BY PURCHASING AND INSTALLING A MECHANICAL-ASSIST HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE STORAGE SYSTEM IN ITS CLOSED-STACKS ARCHIVES ROOM. THE SHELVING SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE 1,149 LINEAR FILING FEET TO THE CENTER'S STORAGE CAPACITY, WHICH EQUATES TO 15 TO 20 YEARS OF SUSTAINABLE COLLECTIONS GROWTH. STAFF MEMBERS FROM THE UNIVERSITY LIBRARY WILL ASSIST WITH RELOCATING AND REHOUSING THE COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT REPRESENTS THE FULFILLMENT OF A KEY GOAL IN THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION PLAN FOR THE CENTER'S COLLECTIONS.

THE MICHIGAN IRON INDUSTRY MUSEUM WILL CONSERVE THE YANKEE, AN 1868 STEAM LOCOMOTIVE THAT MECHANIZED MICHIGAN'S IRON INDUSTRY. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A CONSERVATION FIRM TO CONDUCT OR UPDATE A CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT OF THE LOCOMOTIVE AND PRODUCE A TREATMENT PLAN. THE FIRM WILL ARRANGE TRANSPORTATION FOR THE YANKEE TO ITS WORKSHOP, CARRY OUT THE TREATMENT, AND FABRICATE ANY SMALL PARTS THAT NEED TO BE REPLACED. THE TREATMENT GOAL IS TO STABILIZE ORIGINAL COMPONENTS AND REPLACE MISSING AND SEVERELY DETERIORATED COMPONENTS WITH ACCURATE REPRODUCTIONS TO SHOW VISITORS HOW THE YANKEE LOOKED DURING THE PERIOD OF ITS OPERATION. ONCE CONSERVED, THE YANKEE WILL BE RETURNED AND PLACED ON EXHIBIT INSIDE THE MUSEUM INTO A BUILDING ADDITION SPECIFICALLY BUILT TO HOUSE AND INTERPRET IT FOR VISITORS.

THE MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY, ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, AND HOUSING FOR MORE THAN 5,000 VERTEBRATE SPECIMENS, INCLUDING RARE, ENDANGERED, AND THREATENED SPECIES. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE RELOCATING OR REPLACING OLD CABINETS TO ACCOMMODATE NEW STORAGE FURNITURE AND SHELVING THAT CAN PROPERLY HOUSE AND PROTECT THE DIVERSE COLLECTION OF SPECIMENS INCLUDING STUDY SKINS, TAXIDERMY MOUNTS, AND SKELETONS. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE CABINETRY AND ARCHIVAL SUPPLIES; INSTALL ARCHIVAL DRAWER OR SHELF LINING MATERIALS; REHOUSE SPECIMENS INTO NEW CABINETS OR ONTO NEW MOBILE SHELVING UNITS; AND CONSTRUCT AND INSTALL PROTECTIVE DUST COVERS ON THE SHELVING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL UPDATE TAXONOMIC NOMENCLATURE AND STORAGE LOCATIONS AND PRODUCE NEW LABELS FOR THE COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO INSTALL A SMALL TEMPORARY DISPLAY TO ACQUAINT THE PUBLIC WITH COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES.

THE EMILY DICKINSON MUSEUM AT AMHERST COLLEGE WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS ENTIRE COLLECTION OF 7,000 ARTIFACTS ENCOMPASSING THE PERSONAL EFFECTS OF 19TH CENTURY POET EMILY DICKINSON AND HER FAMILY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CATALOGUE, NUMBER, AND PHOTOGRAPH THE ARTIFACTS. THE COLLECTIONS RECORDS AND IMAGES WILL BE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE AND SEARCHABLE ONLINE THROUGH AN INTERFACE ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME COLLECTIONS MANAGER AND PART-TIME COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO EXECUTE THE PROJECT. CONSULTING CONSERVATORS WILL PROVIDE TRAINING FOR PROJECT AND MUSEUM STAFF IN OBJECT HANDLING, NUMBERING, AND PREVENTIVE CARE TECHNIQUES. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTION, GENERATE BROADER INTERPRETIVE USE OF THE OBJECTS FOR EXHIBITIONS, AND INCREASE ACCESS FOR RESEARCHERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE NORMAN ROCKWELL MUSEUM WILL PROCESS AND DIGITIZE FIVE ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS THAT ADDRESS HOW ILLUSTRATION ARTISTS AND THE COMPANIES AND AD AGENCIES THAT EMPLOYED THEM SHAPED IDENTITY IN MID-20TH CENTURY AMERICA. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A TEMPORARY CATALOGUER TO ASSIST STAFF IN IMPLEMENTING PROJECT ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS DETAIL-PROCESSING OF EACH COLLECTION, RE-HOUSING MATERIALS, DIGITIZING, AND WRITING FINDING AIDS. THE MUSEUM WILL ANNOUNCE FREE ACCESS TO THE DIGITAL MATERIAL ON ITS WEBSITE, POST FINDING AIDS TO ONLINE LIBRARIES, AND PUBLISH A WEB ARTICLE. THE PROJECT WILL REVEAL THE IMPACT OF PERIODICALS AND ILLUSTRATION ART ON CULTURAL STEREOTYPES, RACIAL AND CULTURAL BIASES, AND PERCEPTIONS OF SUCCESS AND ACHIEVEMENT.

THE IMPERIAL VALLEY DESERT MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY RENOVATING ITS STORAGE AREAS. THE MUSEUM WILL RESTRUCTURE THE INTERNAL LAYOUT OF ITS STORAGE SPACES FROM A GROUPING OF FOUR SEPARATE ROOMS INTO A SINGLE INTEGRATED SPACE. THE SPACE WILL BE FURTHER EXPANDED BY REPLACING FIXED-SHELF STORAGE WITH ROLLING SHELF STORAGE UNITS. COLLECTIONS WILL BE REBOXED AND RELABELED AS PART OF THE REHOUSING PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO ADDRESS PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED IN EARLIER ASSESSMENTS THROUGH BOTH THE MUSEUM ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION PROGRAMS. THE NEW STORAGE AREA WILL SUPPORT ENHANCED ENVIRONMENTAL AND PEST CONTROL MONITORING IN ADDITION TO ALLOWING THE MUSEUM TO ACCOMMODATE LARGER GROUPS OF VISITING RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS.

THE LIGHTNER MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT, PRESERVATION, AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY UPGRADING THE STORAGE ENVIRONMENT FOR ITS FRAMED WORKS ON PAPER, TEXTILES, AND CHANDELIERS. THE MUSEUM WILL COMPLETE THE RENOVATION OF SIX STORAGE ROOMS AND PURCHASE NEW STORAGE FURNITURE AND ARCHIVAL MATERIALS TO REHOUSE 3,000 OBJECTS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A COLLECTIONS CONSULTANT TO REHOUSE AND UPDATE CATALOG RECORDS. THE PROJECT WILL BE THE SECOND PHASE IN A LONG-TERM PLAN TO IMPROVE OBJECT ACCESSIBILITY AND COLLECTIONS CARE PRACTICES AND DOCUMENTATION. OBJECTS WILL BE MORE READILY ACCESSIBLE FOR SCHOLARS AND STUDENTS, AND STAFF WILL BE ABLE TO RESEARCH AND INCORPORATE OBJECTS INTO EXHIBITS, PUBLIC PROGRAMS, AND SPECIAL PROJECTS.

THE MUSEUM OF THE EARTH WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO SPECIMENS IN THE RECENTLY-DONATED CORNELL UNIVERSITY MALACOLOGY COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE THE SPECIMENS, GEO-REFERENCE ASSOCIATED LOCALITIES, PHOTOGRAPH PRIMARY AND SECONDARY TYPE SPECIMENS, AND DIGITIZE THE ORIGINAL LABELS. THE MUSEUM WILL THEN PHYSICALLY INTEGRATE THE CORNELL COLLECTION INTO ITS EXISTING MODERN MOLLUSK COLLECTION. ALL SPECIMEN DATA, INCLUDING IMAGES, WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH THE INSTITUTION'S SEARCHABLE DATABASE AND OTHER DATA AGGREGATORS. COMPLETION OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ENHANCE THE COLLECTION'S LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS, MAKING IT EASIER TO USE THE SPECIMENS IN EXHIBITS, TEACHING, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND RESEARCH.

THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL DEVELOP AN UPDATED COLLECTIONS DATABASE FOR ITS DIVISION OF ANTHROPOLOGY COLLECTION TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY AND EXPAND USE BY RESEARCHERS, LAY AUDIENCES, MUSEUM STAFF, INDIVIDUALS AT OTHER INSTITUTIONS, AND MEMBERS OF COMMUNITIES OF ORIGIN. FOLLOWING A DISCOVERY PHASE TO IDENTIFY A FULL LIST OF FUNCTIONALITY NEEDS FOR THE DATABASE, THE MUSEUM WILL WORK IN CLOSE PARTNERSHIP WITH AN OPEN SOURCE SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT FIRM TO DESIGN AND DEVELOP A SIMPLIFIED DATABASE INFRASTRUCTURE TO OPTIMIZE FUNCTIONALITY; INCREASE CROSS-REFERENTIAL SEARCHABILITY; AND ENABLE STAFF TO EASILY MANAGE CONTENT. THE PROJECT TEAM, WORKING WITH A GROUP OF EXPERTS IN THE FIELD, WILL CONDUCT MONITORING AND PROTOTYPING TO EVALUATE PROGRESS AND THE NEW SYSTEM'S EFFECTIVENESS, ALLOWING IMPROVEMENTS TO BE MADE THROUGHOUT EVERY PHASE OF THE PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL REVITALIZE THE STEWARDSHIP OF THE COLLECTION WHILE PROVIDING GLOBAL ACCESS FOR A DIVERSE ARRAY OF AUDIENCES.

THE LINDNER CENTER FOR CONSERVATION AND RESEARCH OF ENDANGERED WILDLIFE AT THE CINCINNATI ZOO AND BOTANICAL GARDENS WILL IMPROVE COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP OF ZOO POLAR BEARS BY CONSERVING GENETICS, ENHANCING REPRODUCTION, AND IMPROVING ANIMAL WELFARE. THE CAPTIVE POPULATION OF POLAR BEARS IS IN DECLINE GLOBALLY DUE PRIMARILY TO A LOW REPRODUCTIVE RATE, AND THERE ARE ONLY 66 INDIVIDUALS IN THE NATION'S ZOOS. THE ZOO WILL CREATE A PERMANENT POLAR BEAR SPERM BANK BY COLLECTING AND CRYOPRESERVING SEMEN; MONITORING AND DOCUMENTING THE SEXUAL MATURATION IN THE SPECIES TO BETTER DRIVE BREEDING RECOMMENDATIONS; AND CREATING AND EMPLOYING A NON-INVASIVE PREGNANCY TEST TO BETTER MANAGE THE COLLECTION AND PROVIDE ENHANCED ANIMAL WELFARE. MEASURES OF PROJECT SUCCESS WILL INCLUDE THE NUMBER OF SEMEN SAMPLES COLLECTED AND CRYOPRESERVED, THE NUMBER OF JUVENILES MONITORED FOR SEXUAL MATURATION, AND THE EMPLOYMENT OF A METHODOLOGY TO DIAGNOSE PREGNANCY IN BOTH PREGNANT AND NON-PREGNANT INDIVIDUALS. A MINIMUM OF THREE MANUSCRIPTS IN OPEN-ACCESS JOURNALS WILL SUMMARIZE PROJECT RESULTS FOR THE FIELD.

THE PEABODY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AT YALE UNIVERSITY WILL CONSERVE AND REHOUSE A PORTION OF ITS ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS FROM NORTH, CENTRAL, AND SOUTH AMERICA TO ENSURE THEIR LONG-TERM PRESERVATION, INCREASE THEIR USE IN THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITION AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS, AND ENHANCE THEIR RESEARCH POTENTIAL FOR SCHOLARS STUDYING ANCIENT PEOPLE AND ENVIRONMENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL PACK THE ARTIFACTS AND MOVE THEM FROM AN EXISTING, OVERCROWDED, AND SUBSTANDARD STOREROOM IN THE PEABODY MUSEUM TO THE UNIVERSITY'S CONSERVATION LAB, WHERE STAFF WILL CREATE STORAGE MOUNTS FOR THOSE REQUIRING SUPPORT. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL NEW CABINETS AND SHELVING IN A COMPLETELY RENOVATED ANTHROPOLOGY STOREROOM EQUIPPED WITH ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS AND A 24-HOUR MONITORED SECURITY SYSTEM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INVENTORY, CLEAN, CONSERVE, PHOTOGRAPH, AND REHOUSE THE COLLECTIONS BEFORE MOVING THEM TO THE NEW LOCATION.

THE RUTH CHANDLER WILLIAMSON GALLERY AT SCRIPPS COLLEGE WILL CONSERVE FIVE CHINESE PAINTINGS IN ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION, RENDERING THEM BENEFICIAL AS TEACHING RESOURCES AND SUITABLE FOR EXHIBITION. THE 15TH-19TH CENTURY PAINTINGS FROM THE MING AND QING DYNASTIES WILL BE CLEANED, REMOUNTED, AND RESTORED TO THEIR ORIGINAL HANGING SCROLL FORMAT BY A CONSULTING CONSERVATOR AT HIS STUDIO LOCATION. WHEN THE CONSERVATION IS COMPLETED, THE CONSERVATOR WILL DELIVER A PUBLIC LECTURE TO AN AUDIENCE INCLUDING ART CONSERVATION INTERNS; STUDENTS IN ART HISTORY, ART CONSERVATION, AND ASIAN STUDIES; FACULTY; AND OTHERS. THE FINISHED WORKS WILL BE DISPLAYED IN A PUBLIC EXHIBITION AT THE CLARK HUMANITIES MUSEUM AT SCRIPPS COLLEGE.

THE MUSEUM OF INDIAN ARTS AND CULTURE WILL IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS FOR ITS WHOLE VESSEL AND SPECIALTY CERAMIC COLLECTIONS, AND MAKE THEM MORE ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCH, EXHIBITS, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CONSERVATOR AND SUBJECT AREA CONSULTANTS TO MOVE MORE THAN 6,000 OBJECTS TO CENTRALIZED STORAGE IN A NEW ARCHAEOLOGICAL REPOSITORY AT THE CENTER FOR NEW MEXICO ARCHEOLOGY. THE OBJECTS WILL BE PLACED IN OPEN STORAGE ON NEWLY PURCHASED HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE SHELVING. THE MOVE WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO CAPTURE DIGITAL IMAGES OF THE ARTIFACTS AND TO UPDATE INFORMATION IN THE MUSEUM'S CATALOG RECORDS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL MOVE ARTIFACTS PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED AS NAGPRA-SENSITIVE FUNERARY OBJECTS INTO A SPECIALLY DESIGNATED VAULT IN THE NEW REPOSITORY. THE MUSEUM WILL LINK THE DIGITIZED IMAGES TO OBJECT CATALOG RECORDS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE ONLINE, FACILITATING ACCESS AND REDUCING THE NEED TO PHYSICALLY HANDLE THE OBJECTS.

THE MICHIGAN HISTORY MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT ITS INSTITUTIONAL PLAN FOR IMPROVEMENTS TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR ITS COLLECTIONS BY RETROFITTING A NEW STORAGE SPACE IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND PROVIDE GREATER ACCESS TO THE ARTIFACTS THAT TELL MICHIGAN'S STORIES. THE MUSEUM WILL PLAN FOR THE NEW STORAGE INFRASTRUCTURE, CLEAN AND SEAL FLOORS IN THE NEW SPACE, WORK WITH A MOVING CONTRACTOR, AND HIRE A TEMPORARY MOVE COORDINATOR TO PHYSICALLY MOVE THE COLLECTIONS, INSTALL COMPACT SHELVING, AND THEN MOVE COLLECTIONS BACK INTO THE NEW STORAGE FURNITURE. UPON THE PROJECT'S COMPLETION, THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE DETAILS ABOUT THE UPGRADE AS AN EXAMPLE OF A SUCCESSFUL RETROFIT OF AN EXISTING WAREHOUSE INTO A COLLECTIONS FACILITY THAT MEETS PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS OF CARE.

THE BAILEY-MATTHEWS NATIONAL SHELL MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY AND EXPAND THE USE OF ITS COLLECTION THROUGH A COMPREHENSIVE DIGITIZATION PROJECT THAT WILL INCREASE ITS VISIBILITY AND STRENGTHEN ITS ABILITY TO SERVE ITS CONSTITUENCY. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO PART-TIME COLLECTION ASSOCIATES TO WORK WITH VOLUNTEER CURATORIAL ASSISTANTS TO FACILITATE THE PROCESSING, STORAGE, AND DISTRIBUTION OF IMAGES OF SELECTED BIOLOGICAL SPECIMENS AND RELATED OBJECTS FROM THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE SPECIALIZED PHOTOGRAPHIC EQUIPMENT, COMPUTER HARDWARE, AND SOFTWARE TO SUPPORT THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WHICH REPRESENT THE CONTINUATION OF A TWO-PHASE CATALOGING PROJECT FUNDED BY PREVIOUS IMLS GRANT AWARDS. UPON COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE POSTED ONLINE 50,820 IMAGES OF 9,240 SPECIMENS REPRESENTING 6,851 SPECIES. THE IMAGES WILL INCLUDE, FOR EACH SPECIMEN, SEVERAL VIEWS OF THE SHELL, PRESERVED ANIMALS, AND ORIGINAL COLLECTION LABELS AND NOTES.

CORNELL BOTANIC GARDENS WILL IMPLEMENT A FIFTEEN-MONTH PROJECT TO ENHANCE ITS COLLECTIONS DATABASE AND DIGITIZE ITS INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) DATA AND TREE RISK ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (TRAP) DOCUMENTATION. THE GARDEN WILL PURCHASE NEW SOFTWARE AND DATA MIGRATION SERVICES FOR ITS PLANT RECORDS DATABASE, HIRE CORNELL'S INTEGRATED WEB SERVICES TEAM TO FORMAT THE PLANT RECORDS DATABASE WEB INTERFACE TO FUNCTION ON A NEWLY AND RESPONSIVELY DESIGNED WEBSITE, PURCHASE NEW SOFTWARE TO MANAGE THE IPM AND TRAP DATA, AND ACQUIRE COMPUTERS AND IPADS FOR THE IPM AND ARBORIST TEAMS NEEDING MOBILE DEVICES FOR DATA INPUT AND RETRIEVAL IN THE FIELD. BY DIGITIZING DATA HELD IN PAPER DOCUMENTS DATING BACK TO THE EARLY 2000S, PERFORMING DIAGNOSTIC TESTS FOR MORE THAN 1,800 TREES, UPDATING THE EXISTING PLANT RECORDS DATABASE TO ONE WITH THE SAME MAPPING PLATFORM, AND INTEGRATING IT WITH A NEW WEBSITE, THE GARDEN WILL IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY TO INFORMATION FOR THE PEOPLE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN COLLECTIONS CARE.

THE UNI GALLERY OF ART AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTHERN IOWA WILL PROVIDE CONSERVATION TREATMENTS FOR WORKS ON PAPER FROM THE UNI PERMANENT ART COLLECTION AS THE NEXT STEP IN THE MUSEUM'S LONG-RANGE CONSERVATION PLAN. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A REGIONAL CONSERVATION CENTER TO OVERSEE, SCHEDULE, AND IMPLEMENT THE TREATMENT OF EACH OF THE 44 OBJECTS THAT WERE IDENTIFIED AS THE HIGHEST PRIORITY ITEMS IN NEED OF CARE THROUGH A PREVIOUSLY FUNDED CONSERVATION SURVEY. OBJECTS LONG HELD FROM PUBLIC VIEW DUE TO PERVASIVE CONDITION ISSUES WILL ONCE AGAIN BE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC EXHIBITION, SCHOLARLY RESEARCH, AND LOANS TO PEER INSTITUTIONS.

THE JOSEPH MOORE MUSEUM AT EARLHAM COLLEGE WILL CATALOG AND DIGITIZE ITS ENTOMOLOGY COLLECTION WITH A LONG-TERM GOAL OF IMPROVING ACCESS FOR FACULTY, STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT WILL ASSIGN UNIQUE IDENTIFIERS AND CAPTURE LABEL DATA FROM APPROXIMATELY 38,000 PINNED AND FLUID-PRESERVED SPECIMENS. THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS MANAGER WILL SERVE AS PROJECT DIRECTOR AND WILL TRAIN AND SUPERVISE AT LEAST 20 UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO COMPLETE THE MAJORITY OF THE CATALOGING, PHOTOGRAPHY, AND RELATED DIGITIZATION ACTIVITIES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A SEARCHABLE ONLINE DATABASE OF THE ENTIRE ENTOMOLOGY COLLECTION, MAKING IT MORE READILY AVAILABLE FOR LOAN TO SCHOLARS AND PROVIDING THE COLLEGE FACULTY WITH FULL ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH.

THE WESTERN GALLERY AT WESTERN WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY WILL CONSERVE UNTITLED 1982, AN OUTDOOR SCULPTURE BY ARTIST DONALD JUDD. THE SCULPTURE IS IN CRITICAL NEED OF REPAIRS DUE TO SERIOUS RUSTING DAMAGE AND WAS REMOVED FROM PUBLIC DISPLAY IN 2013 DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS. A FINE ARTS CONTRACTOR WILL PROVIDE TREATMENT, INVOLVING REPAIR AND REFABRICATION OF THE SCULPTURE'S SIX COR-TEN STEEL PANELS ACCORDING TO A PLAN ENDORSED BY THE JUDD FOUNDATION. THE MUSEUM WILL THEN MOVE THE SCULPTURE TO A NEW DRIER LOCATION WITH FAVORABLE WATER RUN-OFF AND AIRFLOW CONDITIONS. A NEW BASE DESIGN AND A FRENCH DRAIN WILL FACILITATE INTERMITTENT DRYING OF THE COR-TEN AND SUPPORT THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE SCULPTURE.

DENVER BOTANIC GARDENS WILL INCREASE THE ACCESSIBILITY AND DISCOVERABILITY OF ITS NON-LIVING COLLECTIONS BY REHOUSING THEM IN ITS NEW FREYER-NEWMAN CENTER FOR SCIENCE, ART AND EDUCATION. THE GARDEN WILL MOVE, REHOUSE, AND CATALOG HOLDINGS FOR THREE COLLECTIONS: NATURAL HISTORY (PLANT, FUNGAL, ARTHROPOD, AND ETHNOBOTANY COLLECTIONS), LIBRARY (RARE BOOKS, ARCHIVES, AND SPECIAL COLLECTIONS), AND ART. THE GARDEN WILL PURCHASE NEW SHELVING, CABINETS, AND ARCHIVAL SUPPLIES, AND THE STAFF PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH THREE GRADUATE STUDENTS FOR EACH OF THE THREE COLLECTIONS. THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SKILLS WHILE PROVIDING ESSENTIAL SUPPORT. SELECT COLLECTIONS WILL SHIFT FROM 30 TO 100 PERCENT PROPERLY HOUSED; 10 TO 100 PERCENT CATALOGED; AND 5 TO 100 PERCENT ACCESSIBLE AND DISCOVERABLE. THE GARDEN WILL SHARE PROJECT RESULTS THROUGH ITS SOCIAL MEDIA, BLOGS, QUARTERLY MAGAZINE, QUARTERLY E-NEWSLETTERS, AND PRESS RELEASES. IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE BEHIND-THE-SCENES TOURS AND OTHER OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC TO PARTICIPATE IN HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES WITH APPROPRIATE OBJECTS.

THE MUSEUM OF INDIAN ARTS AND CULTURE WILL IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION TREATMENT PROJECT TO CONSERVE SUBSETS OF ITS HISTORIC COLLECTION OF BASKETS, SILVERWORK, AND POTTERY. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE WITH AN EXTERNAL CONSERVATOR AND ASSISTANT CONSERVATOR, AND CONSULT WITH SIX NATIVE AMERICAN ARTISTS AND CULTURAL LEADERS, EXPERT IN THE ARTISTIC TRADITIONS REPRESENTED IN THE COLLECTIONS. WHILE THE STABILIZATION OF THE OBJECTS WILL ALLOW THEM TO BE SAFELY HANDLED, STUDIED, EXHIBITED, LOANED, AND PHOTOGRAPHED, THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO ACHIEVE A LARGER PROJECT GOAL OF ARRIVING COLLABORATIVELY AT SCIENTIFICALLY AND CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE TREATMENT PROTOCOLS THAT IMPROVE PHYSICAL AND VISUAL ACCESS. THROUGH CONSULTATIONS, MULTIPLE PERSPECTIVES AND SOURCES OF INFORMATION WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO CONSERVATION TREATMENT DECISIONS AND DOCUMENTED. THE CONSERVATION TREATMENT OF THESE PUEBLO, APACHE, AND NAVAJO COLLECTIONS WILL ULTIMATELY INCREASE ACCESS FOR STUDY, EXHIBITS, AND PUBLICATION, WHILE FULFILLING ONE OF THE MUSEUM'S HIGHEST CONSERVATION PRIORITIES.

THE MARSHALL M. FREDERICKS SCULPTURE MUSEUM AT SAGINAW VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY WILL IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION MEASURES TO EXTEND THE LIFE OF ITS COLLECTION OF THE LIFE FIGURE DRAWINGS OF MARSHALL FREDERICKS TO PROVIDE GREATER ACCESSIBILITY FOR ART SCHOLARS, HISTORIANS, STUDENTS, AND ARTISTS. THE MUSEUM WILL TRANSPORT 25 OF THE MOST VULNERABLE OF THE WORKS TO A CONSERVATION CENTER WHERE CONSERVATORS WILL ADDRESS EACH DRAWING'S SPECIFIC TREATMENT NEEDS. FOLLOWING THE CONSERVATION TREATMENT, THE MUSEUM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE DRAWINGS AND ADD THE RESULTING FILES TO ITS EXISTING ONLINE DIGITAL ARCHIVE WHERE THEY WILL BE ACCESSIBLE FOR THE FIRST TIME. THE MUSEUM WILL CONCLUDE THE PROJECT BY MOUNTING AN EXHIBITION WHICH WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR TRAVEL NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY.

THE MEMORIAL ART GALLERY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER WILL CONSERVE, PHOTOGRAPH, AND DOCUMENT WORKS ON PAPER BY LOCAL ARTISTS, HARVEY ELLIS AND M. LOUISE STOWELL. A PAPER CONSERVATOR WILL PROVIDE CONSERVATION TREATMENT FOR 24 OF THE MOST DAMAGED AND UNSTABLE OF THESE EXAMPLES OF THE AMERICAN ARTS AND CRAFTS MOVEMENT, WHILE ALMOST 200 OTHERS BY THE SAME ARTISTS WILL BE PHOTOGRAPHED BY A PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHER. THE MUSEUM'S CURATORIAL STAFF WILL WORK ON DOCUMENTATION THROUGHOUT THE TWO-YEAR PROJECT, EXAMINING ARCHIVAL MATERIALS, CONTEMPORARY EXHIBITION REVIEWS, AND ARTICLES AND ESSAYS WRITTEN BY THE ARTISTS. THEY WILL ALSO GATHER INFORMATION ON THEIR CREATIVE TECHNIQUES, MATCH ARTWORKS WITH THE PROPER TITLES, AND CROSS-REFERENCE THE WORKS OF ART WITH THEIR EXHIBITION HISTORIES. THE INFORMATION COMPILED WILL BE ADDED INTO CURATORIAL FILES AND INTO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS DATABASE RECORDS WHICH POPULATE ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS WEBSITE.

THE PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY CREATING NEW AND NEWLY DISCOVERABLE MULTIMEDIA RESOURCES FOR MORE THAN 1,400 OBJECTS FOR UNIVERSITY CLASSES, K-12 TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS, REGIONAL VISITORS, NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM COLLEAGUES, AND WEB-BASED USERS. THE COLLECTIONS DISCOVERIES PROJECT WILL DEVELOP THE DIGITAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND INTERPRETIVE RESOURCES TO EXPOSE AND DELIVER A WIDE VARIETY OF INTERPRETIVE CONTENT INCLUDING VIDEO, AUDIO, AND ANIMATIONS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INDEX AND MIGRATE EXISTING VIDEO, AUDIO, AND OTHER NARRATIVE RESOURCES (INCLUDING INSIGHTS INTO COLLECTION OBJECTS FROM MULTIPLE PERSPECTIVES, SUCH AS THOSE OF CURATORS, FACULTY FROM A WIDE RANGE OF DISCIPLINES, AND ARTISTS) FOR ACCESS, REUSE, AND PRESERVATION. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DESIGN AND DEVELOP NEW MULTIMEDIA INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS AND INTERFACES TO ENHANCE VISITOR EXPERIENCE IN THE GALLERIES AND ONLINE. THE PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE MUSEUM'S EXISTING AUDIO AND VIDEO STORAGE STANDARDS, AND WILL INCORPORATE ESTABLISHED METADATA DESCRIPTIVE PRACTICES.

THE NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM OF LOS ANGELES COUNTY WILL IMPROVE THE PRESERVATION OF ITS INVERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGY AND MALACOLOGY TYPE COLLECTIONS AND INCREASE THEIR ACCESSIBILITY TO RESEARCHERS, VOLUNTEERS, MUSEUM STAFF, AND STUDENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY THE ENTIRE TYPE COLLECTIONS; REHOUSE ALL SPECIMENS INTO NEW, UPDATED CABINETS AND NEW, ARCHIVAL BOXES AND VIALS; AND DIGITALLY CATALOG AND PHOTOGRAPH ALL SPECIMENS. AS PART OF THE DIGITIZATION PROCESS, THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE THE SPECIMEN DATA AND PHOTOGRAPHS THROUGH ITS WEBSITE AS WELL AS ONLINE BIOLOGICAL DATA REPOSITORIES. MUSEUM STAFF WILL LEAD THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES, ALONG WITH MULTIPLE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT COLLECTIONS ASSISTANTS AND VOLUNTEERS AND AN ASSISTANT COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO BE HIRED FOR THE PROJECT.

THE BERKELEY ART MUSEUM AND PACIFIC FILM ARCHIVE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO ITS BROAD SPECTRUM ART COLLECTION FOR STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, SCHOLARS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC BY ADDING NEARLY 2,000 IMAGES TO ITS PUBLIC ONLINE DATABASE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FINE ART PHOTOGRAPHER AND A DIGITAL IMAGE PROCESSING SPECIALIST TO CREATE HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGES OF THE WORKS AND TO ENHANCE CATALOG RECORDS FOR EXISTING IMAGES, ENSURING LONG-TERM USE OF THE MATERIALS ACROSS MULTIPLE PLATFORMS. THE CREATION OF PROFESSIONAL QUALITY HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGES WILL REDUCE THE NEED TO RE-PHOTOGRAPH THE WORKS FOR OTHER PURPOSES IN THE FORESEEABLE FUTURE, RESULTING IN LESS HANDLING AND RISK TO DELICATE WORKS.

THE CUSTOMS HOUSE MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER WILL FACILITATE THE PRESERVATION OF AND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY MINIMIZING POTENTIAL DAMAGE AND MAXIMIZING SPACE TO ACCOMMODATE FUTURE GROWTH. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL NEW ARCHIVAL QUALITY STORAGE UNITS TO REPLACE ACIDIC STORAGE UNITS IN ITS OFFSITE COLLECTIONS FACILITY; REMOVE 28 LARGE ITEMS FROM THE FACILITY'S FLOOR AND RELOCATE THEM TO THE NEW STORAGE UNITS; RELOCATE 432 INAPPROPRIATELY STORED OBJECTS FROM THE MUSEUM TO THE MORE APPROPRIATE OFFSITE LOCATION; AND PURCHASE AND INSTALL DATA LOGGERS TO TRACK ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AN INTERN TO ASSIST WITH THE PROJECT WHICH WILL PROVIDE GREATER USE AND PHYSICAL ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS FOR PUBLIC BENEFIT.

THE BOSTON ATHEN?UM WILL CATALOG POSTERS FROM THE RICHARD W. CHEEK WORLD WAR II GRAPHIC ARTS COLLECTION, WHICH DOCUMENTS THE ROLE DOMESTIC PROPAGANDA PLAYED IN EVOLVING CIVILIAN AND MILITARY PERCEPTIONS OF WORLD WAR II. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME VISUAL MATERIALS CATALOGER TO CREATE THE METADATA NEEDED FOR THE DISCOVERABILITY OF THE DIGITAL IMAGES AND WORK WITH OTHER MEMBERS OF THE PROJECT TEAM TO PROCESS THE COLLECTION OF 1,959 POSTERS. THE MASSACHUSETTS HUB OF THE DIGITAL PUBLIC LIBRARY OF AMERICA WILL CONTRIBUTE ITS FACILITY, EQUIPMENT, AND EXPERTISE TO DIGITIZE THE POSTERS. ONGOING ACCESS TO THE MATERIAL WILL BE PROVIDED THROUGH INVENTORIES, FINDING AIDS, IN-DEPTH CATALOG RECORDS, WIDELY AVAILABLE DIGITAL SURROGATES, EXHIBITIONS, AND PUBLICATIONS.

THE MINERALOGICAL AND GEOLOGICAL MUSEUM AT HARVARD UNIVERSITY WILL UPGRADE THE DATA MANAGEMENT AND PHYSICAL STORAGE OF ITS EARTH HISTORY ARCHIVE COLLECTIONS TO ALIGN THEM WITH THE INSTITUTIONAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICY AND RELATED STANDARD PROCEDURES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A TEMPORARY COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT WITH GEOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE TO ASSIST STAFF WITH THE CATALOGING, INVENTORYING, AND REHOUSING OF THE COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IMPROVE THE PHYSICAL STORAGE OF THE COLLECTIONS BY PURCHASING HEAVY METAL DRAWERS TO REHOUSE THE 114,000 SPECIMENS FROM THEIR CURRENT CARDBOARD BOXES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO INCLUDE EXPANDING EXISTING AND CREATING NEW RECORDS IN THE INTERNAL DATABASE AND SHARING THE RESULTING OBJECT METADATA WITH RESEARCHERS AND EDUCATORS VIA THE MUSEUM'S ACCESSIBLE DATABASE AND OTHER PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DIGITAL CATALOGS.

THE PHILLIPS COLLECTION WILL ESTABLISH AN ARCHIVAL DIGITIZATION PROGRAM IN COLLABORATION WITH ITS ACADEMIC PARTNER, THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, COLLEGE PARK. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A DIGITAL ASSETS LIBRARIAN AND PROCESSING ARCHIVIST TO WORK WITH THE LEAD PROJECT ADVISOR AND OTHER STAFF TO PROCESS AND DIGITIZE 105,310 ITEMS (62 LINEAR FEET) OF PRIORITY ARCHIVAL MATERIAL; CREATE A DIGITAL REPOSITORY WITH AN ASSOCIATED ARCHIVES CATALOG; ESTABLISH THE MUSEUM'S FIRST DIGITAL PRESERVATION PLAN; AND MAKE THE DIGITIZED MATERIAL ACCESSIBLE ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. THE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE ACCESS AND DISCOVERY OF THE MUSEUM'S MOST-REQUESTED PRIMARY SOURCES FOR SCHOLARLY RESEARCH WHILE BUILDING STAFF CAPACITY FOR DIGITAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT.

THE WEISMAN ART MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT A DETAILED COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT AND A COLLECTION FACILITY ASSESSMENT TO INFORM PLANS TO REDESIGN STORAGE SPACES FOR ITS COLLECTIONS AND UPDATE CLIMATE CONTROL SYSTEMS. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH AN EXPERIENCED ARCHITECT/STORAGE SPACE CONSULTANT AND CONSERVATOR TO OUTLINE AND EXPLORE EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS TO INCREASE THE STORAGE CAPACITY OF THE EXISTING STORAGE FACILITY ON-SITE AND PROVIDE ESTIMATES AND SOLUTIONS FOR OFF-SITE NEEDS TO SAFELY HOUSE ITS COLLECTION WHICH HAS EXPANDED SINCE THE OPENING OF ITS NEW MUSEUM BUILDING. A CLIMATE SYSTEM ENGINEER WILL REVIEW THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS IN STORAGE AND EXHIBITION GALLERIES TO DETECT ANY DEFICIENCIES IN THE BUILDING ENVIRONMENT AND TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE CONTINUING TO MEET INDUSTRY STANDARDS.

THE STRONG NATIONAL MUSEUM OF PLAY WILL IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTIONS FOR RESEARCHERS, SCHOLARS, AND STUDENTS BY ENHANCING THE DOCUMENTATION AND PRESERVATION OF ITS 30,000-VOLUME COLLECTION OF TOY TRADE CATALOGS. THE MUSEUM WILL REHOUSE AND CATALOG A GROUP OF 5,000 RARE AND EPHEMERAL TOY TRADE CATALOGS FROM THE TOY, DOLL, PUZZLE, AND GAME INDUSTRIES AND WILL SCAN AND DIGITIZE A SELECTION OF 2,500 HIGH PRIORITY CATALOGS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE UPLOADING ASSOCIATED CATALOG RECORDS TO WORLD'S LARGEST LIBRARY CATALOG (WORLDCAT), PLACING CATALOGS IN APPROPRIATE ARCHIVAL ENCLOSURES AND STORING THEM ON POWDER-COATED STEEL SHELVING UNITS, AND ACQUIRING SPECIALIZED SCANNING EQUIPMENT AND TRAINING STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS IN DIGITIZATION AND METADATA PROCESSES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A REHOUSED, CATALOGED, AND DIGITIZED TOY TRADE CATALOG COLLECTION THAT WILL BE A MORE FULLY ACCESSIBLE ASSET TO DOCUMENT THE HISTORY OF PLAY.

THE ARIZONA STATE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE ITS ONGOING WORK TO STABILIZE ITS BASKETRY COLLECTIONS WHICH REPRESENT ITS HIGHEST INSTITUTIONAL CONSERVATION PRIORITY. THE MUSEUM'S CONSERVATORS AND CURATORIAL STAFF WILL WORK WITH A PART-TIME SPECIALIST CONSERVATOR, A RECENT CONSERVATION GRADUATE, AND A TRIBAL PRE-PROGRAM INTERN TO PROVIDE CONSERVATION TREATMENT OF 150 ETHNOLOGICAL AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL CRADLEBOARDS AND 50 BASKETRY HATS FROM TRIBES OF THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST AND NORTHERN MEXICO. THE TREATMENT PROJECT IS THE FINAL STEP IN A COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR THE 35,000-ITEM BASKETRY COLLECTION WHICH INCLUDES A NEW STORAGE VAULT, OBJECT STABILIZATION, AND PREVENTIVE CONSERVATION FOR A RECENTLY OPENED INTERPRETIVE GALLERY. A TRAINING COMPONENT IN THE TREATMENT PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE MUSEUM'S COMMITMENT TO EDUCATION AND OUTREACH THROUGH THE REGULAR AND ONGOING INCLUSION OF CONSERVATION PROGRAM INTERNS AND UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA STUDENTS OF DIVERSE DISCIPLINES.

THE MAINE HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTION OF MAINE-RELATED CLOTHING AND ACCESSORIES DATING FROM THE LATE 1700S THROUGH THE 20TH CENTURY. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PROFESSIONAL COSTUME CURATOR AND CURATORIAL ASSISTANT TO FACILITATE THE PROJECT, AND THEY WILL BE ASSISTED BY THREE PAID INTERNS. PROJECT STAFF WILL REHOUSE AND IMPROVE CATALOGING OF 1,200 PIECES CONSIDERED MOST AT-RISK, AND MOVE THEM TO A NEW OFFSITE STORAGE FACILITY PROVIDING OPTIMUM ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE PROCESSED PIECES AND ADD THE DIGITAL FILES TO THE CATALOGING RECORDS. AN ONLINE GUIDE TO THE COLLECTION WILL PROVIDE GREATER CONTEXT FOR THE MATERIALS AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC TO BROWSE BY THEMES OR REVIEW THE ENTIRE COLLECTION THROUGH THE MAINE MEMORY NETWORK.

THE ARCHAEOLOGY CENTER AT STANFORD UNIVERSITY WILL ADDRESS A HIGH PRIORITY RECOMMENDATION FROM ITS RECENT PARTICIPATION IN THE MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM BY CONDUCTING THE FIRST COMPLETE BASELINE INVENTORY OF ITS ACCESSIONED COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL ESTABLISH INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL BY PRODUCING A COMPLETE, RELIABLE INVENTORY AND ADDING VERIFIED RECORDS TO ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE. BASED ON THE FINDINGS OF A PILOT INVENTORY CONDUCTED TO GENERATE A QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE UNDERSTANDING OF INVENTORY NEEDS, THE MUSEUM DETERMINED THAT THE PROJECT WILL REQUIRE TWO YEARS FOR TWO FULL-TIME PROJECT STAFF. THE INVENTORY PROJECT WILL IMPROVE STEWARDSHIP OF THE MUSEUM'S 35,000-ITEM ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS, AND FACILITATE ACCESS FOR CAMPUS, TRIBAL, AND PUBLIC CONSTITUENCIES.

THE DURHAM MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTION IN RESPONSE TO A SERIES OF RECOMMENDATIONS FROM ITS PARTICIPATION IN THE COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO NEW COLLECTIONS STAFF TO FACILITATE THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND COORDINATE THE ASSISTANCE OF STUDENT INTERNS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE CATALOG AND INVENTORY OF THE MATERIALS IN THE HISTORY OBJECT COLLECTION, REHOUSE OBJECTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF A CONSULTING CONSERVATOR, PURCHASE AND INSTALL NEW STORAGE EQUIPMENT, AND PLACE THE OBJECTS INTO AN IMPROVED AND REORDERED ENVIRONMENT.

THE NORTH CAROLINA STATE MUSEUM OF NATURAL SCIENCES WILL INCORPORATE THREE ORPHANED COLLECTIONS INTO ITS SCIENTIFIC COLLECTION TO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO A TIMELINE OF MARINE FISH COLLECTION EFFORTS OVER THE LAST CENTURY IN RAPIDLY CHANGING MARINE ENVIRONMENTS. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION NEEDS OF THE SPECIMENS AND ASSOCIATED PAPER RECORDS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCES, STOCKTON STATE UNIVERSITY, AND WESTERN CAROLINA UNIVERSITY. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES TO ENSURE THE LONG TERM STORAGE AND HANDLING OF DIGITAL AND PAPER DATA, AND WILL HIRE 15 INTERNS TO ASSIST WITH PROJECT ACTIVITIES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO OFFER TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS, AND ENABLE CITIZENS TO AID IN THE DIGITIZATION EFFORT THROUGH A VIRTUAL TRANSCRIPTION PORTAL. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE INCORPORATION OF APPROXIMATELY 160,536 SPECIMENS INTO THE MUSEUM'S FISHES COLLECTION, WITH GLOBAL ACCESS TO ALL ASSOCIATED DATA ACROSS MULTIPLE ONLINE DATA PORTALS.

THE LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF ART WILL IMPROVE THE STEWARDSHIP AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS MARK AND CAROLYN BLACKBURN COLLECTION OF PHOTOGRAPHY. THE COLLECTION CONSISTS OF MORE THAN 6,600 HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHS, GLASS NEGATIVES, LANTERN SLIDES, STEREOGRAPHS, CARTES-DE-VISITE, AND CABINET CARDS FROM THE 1860S TO THE PRESENT, DEPICTING POLYNESIAN, MICRONESIAN, AND MELANESIAN GEOGRAPHY AND LIFE. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE CATALOGING, PROCESSING, REHOUSING, AND DIGITIZATION OF THE COLLECTION AS WELL AS IN-DEPTH RESEARCH, RESULTING IN ACCURATE AND UPDATED METADATA. THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE THE DIGITAL IMAGES AND FINDING AIDS ONLINE ON ITS WEBSITE, AND THROUGH THE ONLINE ARCHIVE OF CALIFORNIA AND WORLDCAT.ORG, THE ONLINE FREE LIBRARY CATALOG.

MORTON ARBORETUM WILL DOCUMENT, EVALUATE, AND MANAGE THE CONSERVATION VALUE OF FOUR OF ITS HIGHEST PRIORITY COLLECTIONS OF LIVING PLANTS: OAK, CRABAPPLE, ELM, AND LINDEN. THE DOCUMENTATION OF CONSERVATION VALUE WILL BENEFIT A VARIETY OF STAKEHOLDERS WHO ACCESS, STUDY, AND LEARN FROM THE ARBORETUM'S COLLECTIONS. THE STUDY WILL FOCUS ON FIVE CRITERIA TAILORED TO THE ARBORETUM'S MISSION: PHYLOGENETIC, ENVIRONMENTAL, GENETIC AND HORTICULTURAL DIVERSITY, AND ENDANGERMENT STATUS. THE ARBORETUM WILL APPLY DATA-DRIVEN METHODOLOGY TO QUANTIFY THE CONSERVATION VALUE OF THE FOUR COLLECTIONS, CONTAINING 2,281 TREES. THE ARBORETUM WILL IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO SUSTAIN AND STRENGTHEN THAT VALUE, AND USE THAT KNOWLEDGE TO CREATE SCIENTIFICALLY INFORMED MANAGEMENT, ACCESS, AND CURATION PLANS FOR THE NEXT DECADE. PROJECT RESULTS WILL BE SHARED THROUGH MULTIPLE CHANNELS FOR THE BENEFIT OF RESEARCHERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA STATE MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE STEWARDSHIP OF ITS COLLECTIONS THROUGH A TWO-YEAR COLLECTIONS INVENTORY AND DIGITIZATION PROJECT. FOLLOWING A COMPREHENSIVE EXAMINATION OF ITS STORAGE AND EXHIBITION SPACES AND THE RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, THE MUSEUM IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR A DETAILED INVENTORY AS ITS NEXT HIGHEST PRIORITY IN COLLECTIONS CARE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME INVENTORY COORDINATOR AND FOUR PART-TIME PROJECT ASSISTANTS WHO WILL WORK UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE REGISTRAR. PROJECT STAFF WILL INVENTORY THE COMPLETE ART COLLECTION ACROSS THREE STORAGE ROOMS, RESULTING IN 3,500 NEW OR REVISED ENTRIES FOR THE MUSEUM'S 80,000-PIECE OBJECT COLLECTION. EACH OBJECT WILL ALSO BE PHOTOGRAPHED AS AN IMPORTANT STEP IN DIGITIZING THE COLLECTION AND DEVELOPING AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL.

THE KENTUCKY GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL IMPROVE ACCESS TO ITS GEOLOGIC CORE SAMPLE COLLECTION FOR USE BY ENERGY AND MINERAL INDUSTRY SCIENTISTS, ENGINEERS, RESEARCHERS, AND STUDENTS. ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION IS CURRENTLY LIMITED TO PHYSICAL VISITS TO VIEW SPECIMENS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PURCHASING, LABELING, AND TRACKING EQUIPMENT, AND HIRING STUDENT INTERNS TO ASSIST WITH RE-LABELING AND RE-BOXING THE SPECIMENS. THIS WILL IMPROVE THE LONGER TERM CARE OF THE COLLECTION. THE SURVEY WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE CONTENTS OF 10,000 BOXES, INCLUDING THE 1,000 CORE SAMPLES SET TO BE RE-BOXED, AND AN ADDITIONAL 9,000 OF THE MOST USED AND AT-RISK CORES. THE RESULTING HIGH RESOLUTION DIGITAL CORE IMAGES WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH THE SURVEY'S WEBSITE AND IN THE ONLINE PLATFORMS OF THE INTERNATIONAL GEO SAMPLE NUMBER DATABASE.

THE MATTHAEI BOTANICAL GARDENS AND NICHOLS ARBORETUM, UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, WILL ENHANCE THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF ITS LIVING PLANT COLLECTIONS BY IMPLEMENTING IMPROVEMENTS IN ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS FOR ITS CONSERVATORY. THE GARDEN WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A VARIETY OF EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING CLIMATE SENSORS, SIDE VENTS, AND CIRCULATION FANS, TO SUPPORT THE COORDINATED MANAGEMENT OF TEMPERATURE, LIGHT, AND HUMIDITY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF NEW CONSERVATORY PLANTS AS OUTLINED IN AN UPDATED COLLECTIONS PLAN, AND THE INSTALLATION OF NEW INTERPRETIVE SIGNS, MAPS, AND OTHER MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE CONSERVATORY TO FEATURE CONSERVATION THEMES IN THREE DISTINCT BIOMES (TROPICAL, TEMPERATE AND DESERT) THAT APPROACH THE TAXONOMIC COMPLEXITY SEEN IN NATURE.

THE MILDRED E. MATHIAS BOTANICAL GARDEN AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, LOS ANGELES, WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF ITS EXISTING PLANT RECORDS BY DIGITIZING AND VERIFYING ITS LIVING COLLECTION HOLDINGS AND MAKING THEM AVAILABLE ONLINE. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW DISPERSED RECORDS TO BE COLLECTED FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES, UPDATED, DIGITIZED, AND MADE AVAILABLE ONLINE, AS WELL AS IN THE BOTANIC GARDENS CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL PLANTSEARCH DATABASE. SUPPORT FOR THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE PURCHASE OF A DOG-TAG PRINTER, DATABASE SOFTWARE, A DIGITAL CAMERA, AND A NEW COMPUTER. THE GARDEN WILL HIRE A CURATORIAL ASSISTANT WHO WILL PRINT ACCESSION TAGS, FIELD CHECK PLANTS, AND PERFORM DATA ENTRY, WHILE RECEIVING TRAINING IN BOTANICAL CURATION FROM GARDEN STAFF AND UNIVERSITY FACULTY. THE GARDEN WILL ALSO ENGAGE A FACULTY BOTANIST TO WORK ON IDENTIFICATION OF UNKNOWN SPECIMENS AND TO HELP OVERSEE THE PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM CURATION OF THE COLLECTION AND INCREASE ITS ACCESSIBILITY TO THE BOTANICAL COMMUNITY AND THE PUBLIC.

THE MUSEUM OF NORTHERN ARIZONA WILL ENHANCE THE SECURITY, ACCESSIBILITY, AND PRESERVATION OF ITS PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTIONS BY IMPROVING ENVIRONMENTAL STORAGE CONDITIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PALEONTOLOGY PREPARATOR AND WORK WITH A CONSERVATION CONSULTANT TO STABILIZE SPECIMENS AND REHOUSE THEM IN ARCHIVAL STORAGE MOUNTS PRIOR TO THEIR INSTALLATION IN NEW COMPACTOR STORAGE CASES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL VERIFY CATALOG RECORDS AND UPDATE STORAGE LOCATIONS FOR MORE THAN 9,000 FOSSIL SPECIMENS, AS WELL AS PUBLISH DIGITIZED IMAGES AND CATALOG DATA ON TYPE AND CITED SPECIMENS IN IDIGBIO. AN INDUSTRIAL HYGIENIST WILL ASSESS RADIOACTIVITY AND/OR RADON GAS LEVELS IN THE PALEONTOLOGY STORAGE AREAS, AND THE MUSEUM WILL INTEGRATE RELEVANT FINDINGS INTO ITS PRESERVATION PLAN AND COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICY WHILE DEVELOPING HEALTH AND SAFETY PROCEDURES TO COMPLY WITH REGULATORY STANDARDS. THE IMPROVED PRESERVATION ENVIRONMENT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTIONS AND PROVIDE GREATER ACCESS FOR MUSEUM STAFF, VISITING SCHOLARS, GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND PROFESSIONAL AND EMERGING MUSEUM COLLEAGUES.

THE VIRGINIA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS TRIASSIC AND PALEOZOIC GEOLOGIC ROCK CORE FROM THE VIRGINIA PIEDMONT BY MOVING IT TO A NEW STORAGE FACILITY. THE 75,000 LINEAR FEET OF 2-INCH ROCK CORE IS CURRENTLY STORED IN WAX-IMPREGNATED CORE BOXES AND HOUSED IN A PRIVATELY OWNED, OFF-SITE FACILITY WITH LIMITED ACCESS. PRIOR TO THE MOVE, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A RADIATION SAFETY FIRM TO SURVEY AND EXAMINE THE CORE AND RECOMMEND SAFETY MEASURES FOR MOVING, HANDLING, AND STORING IT. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PREPARE THE NEW STORAGE SPACE, MOVE THE COLLECTION, CLEAN BOX INTERIORS, MATCH LABEL DATA TO THE MUSEUM'S CATALOG RECORDS, AND UPDATE STORAGE LOCATIONS IN THE CATALOG WITH ROOM AND SHELF NUMBERS. UPON COMPLETION OF THIS WORK, THE MUSEUM WILL UPLOAD THE UPDATED CATALOG RECORDS TO ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE, AND THE DATA WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ON ITS WEBSITE.

FORT TICONDEROGA WILL INVENTORY, CATALOG, AND STORE 30,000 ITEMS FROM ITS OBJECT COLLECTIONS. THE WALL-TO-WALL INVENTORY WILL BE COMPREHENSIVE AND TAKE 36 MONTHS TO COMPLETE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE CATALOGING OF 200 BOXES OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL ARTIFACTS EXCAVATED FROM THE SITE FROM 2000-2007. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO FULL-TIME PROFESSIONAL COLLECTIONS INVENTORY SPECIALISTS TO ASSIST STAFF WITH THE COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT, WHICH WILL RESULT IN AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE WITH GREATER ACCESS FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC, RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND STAFF. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, FORT TICONDEROGA WILL GAIN GREATER INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTIONS AND MAKE THEM MORE READILY AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH AND FOR USE IN EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMMING.

THE MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK WILL INCREASE ONLINE ACCESS TO ITS LOOK MAGAZINE COLLECTION FOR THE BENEFIT OF SCHOLARS, CURATORS, EDUCATORS, AND GENERAL HISTORY ENTHUSIASTS. THE PROJECT WILL CONTINUE AN ONGOING ENDEAVOR TO DIGITIZE THE LOOK COLLECTION BY FOCUSING ON THE COMPREHENSIVE CATALOGING OF THE WORKS OF STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER JOHN VACHON (1914-1975) AND CREATING ACCESS THROUGH THE MUSEUM'S ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL TO AN ESTIMATED 11,100 DIGITAL IMAGES FROM 54 OF HIS ASSIGNMENTS FOR THE MAGAZINE. THE COLLECTION EXISTS PRIMARILY AS NEGATIVES, A FORMAT THAT RENDERS THE MATERIAL NEARLY INACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCHERS AND CURATORS ALIKE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE A SYMPOSIUM FOR COLLEAGUES IN THE FIELD, WHERE THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE ITS METHODOLOGY, PROCESS, AND WORKFLOW FOR IMPLEMENTING LARGE-SCALE DIGITIZATION PROJECTS.

THE MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO AND ENHANCE THE STEWARDSHIP OF ITS THEATRICAL DESIGN RENDERINGS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROCESS, DIGITIZE, AND CATALOG APPROXIMATELY 8,000 ORIGINAL COSTUME AND SET RENDERINGS FROM MORE THAN 410 NEW YORK CITY THEATRICAL PRODUCTIONS, AND MAKE THEM PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL. CREATING ONLINE ACCESS TO THE PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN MATERIAL WILL PROVIDE A USER-FRIENDLY VISUAL RESOURCE FOR THE MUSEUM'S OWN STAFF MEMBERS, PERFORMING ARTS SCHOLARS, THEATER PROFESSIONALS, AND THEATER ENTHUSIASTS ACROSS THE NATION, CONTRIBUTING TO SCHOLARSHIP ON THE PERFORMING ARTS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO CREATE A FREE RESOURCE FOR THEATER EDUCATORS WORKING IN ELEMENTARY, MIDDLE, AND HIGH SCHOOLS WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR INFORMING PERFORMING ARTS CURRICULUM AT THE GRADE SCHOOL LEVEL.

THE TEXTILE MUSEUM AT GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY WILL BROADEN ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY IMPLEMENTING AN ACCESSIBLE DATABASE WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGES AND COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON COLLECTION OBJECTS REPRESENTING TEXTILE ART THAT SPANS FIVE CONTINENTS AND FIVE MILLENNIA. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE A FULL-TIME PHOTOGRAPHER TO SET UP A NEW PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIO AT THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS CENTER AND CAPTURE HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGES OF 25 PERCENT OF ITS COLLECTION. ADDITIONALLY, IT WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEXT GENERATION OF MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS BY HIRING UNIVERSITY GRADUATE STUDENTS AS COLLECTIONS AND CURATORIAL ASSISTANTS AND PROVIDING THEM WITH VALUABLE HANDS-ON MUSEUM EXPERIENCE. THE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE BROAD ACCESS TO OBJECTS OF GLOBAL CULTURAL HERITAGE BY STUDENTS, FACULTY, SCHOLARS, ARTISTS, COLLECTORS, AND CONNOISSEURS.

THE UNIVERSITY AND JEPSON HERBARIA AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY, WILL INCREASE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTION BY PRODUCING A SET OF SHORT-FORMAT VIDEOS THAT DESCRIBE THE TECHNIQUES AND CHARACTERS NEEDED TO IDENTIFY 500 COMMON AND CHARACTERISTIC PLANTS OF CALIFORNIA. THE VIDEOS WILL BE FREELY ACCESSIBLE ON YOUTUBE, INCORPORATING SCANS OF SPECIMENS AND ILLUSTRATIONS AND MAPS FROM THE JEPSON EFLORA, A PRIMARY AUTHORITY ON THE NATIVE AND NATURALIZED PLANTS OF CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP 350 VIDEOS DESCRIBING HOW TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL PLANT SPECIES. COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE AN ADDITIONAL 150 VIDEOS FOLLOWING STANDARD FORMAT GUIDELINES AND A THOROUGH SET OF TRAINING MATERIALS. THE VIDEOS WILL SERVE AS AN INTENSIVE STUDY AID FOR THE CALIFORNIA BOTANIST CERTIFICATION PROGRAM AND BROADEN THE HERBARIUM'S OUTREACH TO A NEW, LESS FORMALLY TRAINED, AND YOUNGER AUDIENCE. THE HERBARIUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE LAWRENCE HALL OF SCIENCE TO CONDUCT A TWO-PHASE EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT.

THE MUSEUM OF PALEONTOLOGY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY, WILL PRESERVE AND DIGITIZE ITS COLLECTION OF EARLY MIOCENE AMBER FROM CHIAPAS, MEXICO. WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, THE MUSEUM WILL EMBED 1,500 SPECIMENS IN A CLEAR, PROTECTIVE RESIN IN ORDER TO SEAL FRACTURES AND STABILIZE EACH PIECE IN A SOLID AIRTIGHT ARCHIVAL MEDIUM. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CREATE HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL IMAGES OF THE CHIAPAS SPECIMENS AND UPDATE THEIR METADATA RECORDS FOR POSTING ONLINE VIA VARIOUS WEB-BASED PORTALS AND DATABASES CURRENTLY PROVIDING PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTION'S DIGITAL DATA. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO UPLOAD THE COLLECTION'S ASSOCIATED PAPER ARCHIVES TO THE UNIVERSITY DATABASE, FURTHER DOCUMENTING THE ARTHROPOD AND PLANT DIVERSITY OF THE COLLECTION THROUGH MANUSCRIPTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND MAPS. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE ACCESS FOR THE ACADEMIC COMMUNITY AND SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF K-16 EDUCATIONAL AND PUBLIC OUTREACH MATERIALS.

THE ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTION OF 3,824 OBJECTS OF AMERICAN ART OF THE 20TH AND 21ST CENTURIES AND 4,098 ARCHITECTURAL DRAWINGS AS PART OF ITS MOVE TO A NEW FACILITY WITH EXPANDED ART STORAGE AND RELATED COLLECTION AREAS. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL UPGRADED STORAGE FURNISHINGS INCLUDING A PAINTING STORAGE SYSTEM, FLAT FILES FOR WORKS ON PAPER, OPEN SHELVING UNITS FOR THREE-DIMENSIONAL OBJECTS, PLATFORM TRUCKS/DOLLIES, AND MOBILE TABLES. PROJECT TEAM MEMBERS WILL PACK THE COLLECTION AND COORDINATE ITS MOVE FROM CURRENT ART STORAGE TO THE MUSEUM'S RENOVATED COLLECTIONS STORAGE AREA. THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT WILL STREAMLINE RECEIVING AND ACCESSIONING NEW ART ACQUISITIONS, SECURE THE LIFESPAN OF THE COLLECTION, AID IN EXHIBITION AND PROGRAMMING PREPARATION, AND ENHANCE SCHOLARLY ACCESS.

THE MCKISSICK MUSEUM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA WILL COLLABORATE WITH FIVE UNIVERSITY UNITS AND THE CHARLESTON MUSEUM TO DIGITIZE, BUILD A CROSS-REFERENCED AND SEARCHABLE WEBSITE, AND CREATE ONLINE EXHIBITIONS OF NATURAL HISTORY OBJECT AND ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS. THE ACTIVITIES WILL EXPAND THE HISTORIC SOUTHERN NATURALISTS PROJECT, INITIALLY FUNDED THROUGH AN INTERNAL RESEARCH SEED GRANT. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE STUDENT ASSISTANTS TO DIGITIZE APPROXIMATELY 35,000 OBJECTS, MANUSCRIPT VOLUMES, AND ARCHIVAL DOCUMENTS FROM DIVERSE HIGH-PRIORITY COLLECTIONS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AND THE CHARLESTON MUSEUM. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN ANTICIPATED 45,000 DIGITAL IMAGES TO AUGMENT INSTITUTIONAL COLLECTION DATABASES AND FOR USE IN ONLINE PORTALS.

THE FLEMING MUSEUM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTION OF AMERICAN AND EUROPEAN GARMENTS AND ACCESSORIES DATING FROM 1790-1987. THE PROJECT REPRESENTS A DIRECT RESPONSE TO A RECOMMENDATION FROM THE AMERICAN ALLIANCE OF MUSEUMS ACCREDITATION VISITING COMMITTEE. THE MUSEUM WILL INITIATE THE PROJECT BY CONSULTING WITH A TEXTILE CONSERVATOR TO ASSESS THE CONDITION AND CARE NEEDS OF 1,709 ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE NEW ARCHIVAL STORAGE BOXES FOR REHOUSING THE ITEMS, AS WELL AS MANNEQUINS SO THAT GARMENTS CAN BE PHOTOGRAPHED ON FORMS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE MATERIALS TO SUPPORT THE MUSEUM'S EFFORTS TO MAKE ITS COLLECTIONS SEARCHABLE AND ACCESSIBLE ONLINE.

THE BURKE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AND CULTURE WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM CARE, CONSERVATION, AND ACCESS TO ITS ETHNOLOGY TEXTILE COLLECTIONS BY REHOUSING THEM IN ITS NEW FACILITY IN A STORAGE SYSTEM THAT MEETS ACCEPTED PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE MOVING EXISTING COMPACTORS, AND PURCHASING ADDITIONAL NEW TEXTILE COMPACTOR UNITS WITH RODS FOR ROLLED TEXTILES AND FLAT SHELVING TO HOLD GARMENT STORAGE BOXES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO PART-TIME ASSISTANTS TO FACILITATE THE WORK OF STAFF IN PREPARING AND IMPLEMENTING THE WORK. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH A CONSERVATOR TO DEVELOP A PRIORITIZED PLAN FOR FUTURE CARE, CONSERVATION, AND TREATMENT. THE MUSEUM WILL EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF ITS REHOUSING EFFORTS AND SHARE THE RESULTS WITH COLLECTIONS-BASED MUSEUMS AROUND THE COUNTRY.

THE DENVER ZOO WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS ANIMAL POPULATIONS BY PURCHASING CRITICAL CARE EQUIPMENT AND VIDEO TECHNOLOGY FOR ITS NEW ANIMAL HOSPITAL. THE EQUIPMENT WILL SUPPORT A LARGE ANIMAL INTENSIVE CARE UNIT AND A SMALL ANIMAL INTENSIVE CARE UNIT, BOTH VIDEO-ENABLED, ALLOWING VETERINARIANS TO REMOTELY MONITOR ANIMAL PATIENTS AND PROVIDE LIFE-SAVING CARE FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE-THIRD OF THE ANIMALS IN THE COLLECTION, MANY OF WHICH ARE THREATENED OR ENDANGERED SPECIES. IMPROVEMENTS IN STAFF SAFETY AND EFFICIENCY WILL BE MEASURED WITH THREE STAGGERED SURVEYS DESIGNED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE ZOO'S RESEARCH AND EVALUATION TEAM.

THE COUNTRY MUSIC HALL OF FAME AND MUSEUM WILL PRESERVE AND PROVIDE FREE PUBLIC ONLINE ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 10,000 RARE, FRAGILE, AND ORIGINAL POSTERS IN ITS HATCH SHOW PRINT (HSP) COLLECTION. THE HSP COLLECTION IS COMPOSED OF MORE THAN 70,000 ARTIFACTS, INCLUDING POSTERS, RELATED PRINTS, DOCUMENTS, PROOFS, TRACINGS, TYPE, BLOCKS AND PHOTOBLOCKS, THAT CHRONICLE 138 YEARS OF AMERICAN HISTORY THROUGH HSP'S POSTER DESIGN AND PRINTING. A NEWLY HIRED PRINT COLLECTIONS DIGITIZATION AND METADATA SPECIALIST WILL COORDINATE REHOUSING, DIGITIZING, AND CATALOGING OF THE POSTERS. DIGITIZATION WILL ALLOW FOR EASY PUBLIC ACCESS TO AND DISSEMINATION OF THIS MATERIAL, REACHING A WIDE RANGE OF RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS. THE METADATA AND FINDING AIDS CREATED DURING THE PROCESS WILL ENABLE COMPARATIVE AND CONTENT-BASED ORIGINAL RESEARCH.

THE MISSOURI HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL ASSESS, REHOUSE, AND CREATE AN INDEX FOR 65 LINEAR FEET OF ORIGINAL NEGATIVES AND PRINTS PRODUCED DURING THE 1940S BY THE SIEVERS COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIO. THE INDEX WILL CATALOG AN ESTIMATED 9,100 PHOTOGRAPHIC JOB ASSIGNMENTS, AND SELECT 3,000 NEGATIVES FOR ITEM-LEVEL CATALOGING AND DIGITIZATION. SELECTION FOR DIGITIZATION WILL BE BASED ON BOTH SUBJECT MATTER AND CONDITION, WITH THE MOST ENDANGERED NEGATIVES THEN PLACED IN FREEZER STORAGE. THE STAFF ARCHIVIST FOR PHOTOGRAPHS AND PRINTS WILL OVERSEE PROJECT ACTIVITIES, AND THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME TEMPORARY PROJECT ARCHIVIST AND A PART-TIME TEMPORARY DIGITIZATION AND CATALOGING SPECIALIST TO ASSIST WITH THE WORK. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO AND PROMOTE THE USE OF THE MATERIAL BY PUBLISHING THE INDEX, ALL JOB AND ITEM-LEVEL RECORDS, AND ALL DIGITIZED IMAGES TO ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS SITE, AND BY MAKING ALL THE IMAGES FREELY DOWNLOADABLE.

"THE MISSOURI STATE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT THE FIRST PHASE OF A PROJECT TO INITIATE THE INSTALLATION OF COMPACT SHELVING UNITS IN ITS RIVERSIDE COLLECTIONS FACILITY-A RETROFITTED WAREHOUSE WITH FIXED SHELVING, TEMPORARY STORAGE RACKS AND PALLETS, AND LACK OF A FIXED CONDITIONED WORKSPACE. TEMPORARY PACKING AND REHOUSING OF THE COLLECTIONS WILL ALLOW MUSEUM STAFF TO IMPLEMENT ADDITIONAL CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING ASSESSING ARTIFACT CONDITION, EVALUATING CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, AND ENCLOSURE OF SMALLER ARTIFACTS IN ARCHIVAL STORAGE BOXES FOR BETTER PROTECTION AND EASIER HANDLING. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE STORAGE CAPACITY, IMPROVE COLLECTION ACCESS AND PROTECTION, AND ALLOW FOR EXPANSION."

"THE MILWAUKEE PUBLIC MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THE FIELD MUSEUM AND THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-MILWAUKEE'S GREENE GEOLOGICAL MUSEUM TO CONVERT 60,000 PAPER?BASED ORDOVICIAN AND SILURIAN FOSSIL COLLECTION CATALOG RECORDS TO DIGITAL FORM, GENERATING MORE THAN 50,000 IMAGES. DATA ENTRY TECHNICIANS WILL BE HIRED TO WORK DIRECTLY WITH THE COLLECTIONS AT EACH INSTITUTION, AND RECEIVE TRAINING IN THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM? WORKING WITH MUSEUM SPECIMENS? PHOTOGRAPHY? ORDOVICIAN PALEONTOLOGY? AND GEOLOGY. THE COOPERATIVE EFFORT WILL CREATE AN ONLINE DATABASE WITH LOCATION, STRATIGRAPHIC DATA, SYSTEMATIC DATA, AND SELECTED PHOTOGRAPHS OF FOSSILS THAT CHRONICLE THE GREAT ORDOVICIAN BIODIVERSIFICATION EVENT AND THE ORDOVICIAN MASS EXTINCTION. THE DATABASE WILL MAKE THE COLLECTIONS DISCOVERABLE TO RESEARCHERS, TEACHERS, AND STUDENTS. THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO USE THE DATABASE AND COMPANION WEBSITE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE DIVERSIFICATION OF ANIMAL LIFE ON EARTH AND A MAJOR EXTINCTION EVENT."

"THE MUSEO DE ARTE DE PONCE WILL UPGRADE ITS EXISTING COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO IMPROVE DATA MANAGEMENT AND CONTENT IN ORDER TO BROADEN PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE A DIGITAL PLATFORM THAT WILL BE LINKED WITH THE COLLECTION DATABASE AND WILL IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF OBJECT PHOTOGRAPHS. A PHOTOGRAPHER WILL WORK WITH THE MUSEUM'S ART HANDLER AND ASSISTANT REGISTRAR TO COORDINATE PROJECT ACTIVITIES, WHICH INCLUDE DATA REVISION AND CLEANUP AND UPLOADING IMAGES TO THE WEB. BY THE END OF THE PROJECT, THE PAPER COLLECTION WILL BE AVAILABLE AND ACCESSIBLE TO ALL OF THE MUSEUM'S CONSTITUENTS AND A COLLECTION PREVIOUSLY ENCLOSED IN STORAGE AND INACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC WILL BE THE FIRST TO BE SHARED ON THE INTERNET."

"THE DAVISON ART CENTER (DAC) AT WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY WILL CONTINUE ITS MOMENTUM IN RAPIDLY DIGITIZING ITS COLLECTIONS, CONSISTING MOSTLY OF WORKS ON PAPER. DURING THREE 6-WEEK SUMMER PERIODS, THE MUSEUM WILL CONVERT ITS GALLERY SPACE INTO A TEMPORARY STUDIO TO EXECUTE HIGH-QUALITY, RAPID DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY OF KEY PARTS OF ITS HOLDINGS, PREPARE 4,000 NEW IMAGES FOR COLLECTION MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATIONAL ACCESS, AND PLACE AS MANY AS POSSIBLE ONLINE FOR PUBLIC USE AS DAC OPEN ACCESS IMAGES. BEFORE EACH SUMMER, AND WITH AN AIM OF PROVIDING EARLY-CAREER EXPERIENCE FOR QUALIFIED EMERGING MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS, THE FULL-TIME STAFF PROJECT DIRECTOR WILL HIRE FIVE TEMPORARY STAFF TO CREATE A TEAM OF SIX-A PROJECT PHOTOGRAPHER, TWO PROJECT IMAGING SPECIALISTS, AND TWO STUDENT ASSISTANTS-WHO WILL WORK TOGETHER TO CREATE AND PREPARE THE DIGITAL IMAGES, WHICH WILL BE USED EXTENSIVELY FOR TEACHING AND STUDY."

"THE PEABODY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS AND ACCESS TO 13,650 SETS OF EGGS AND 2,000 NESTS IN ITS ORNITHOLOGY COLLECTION. THE PURCHASE OF NEW CABINETS WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO UPGRADE OLD CABINETS, ALLEVIATE OVERCROWDING, AND GENERATE GROWTH SPACE. EGGS WILL BE PROPERLY IMMOBILIZED WITH NEW PADDING, WHILE DAMAGED OR PARTICULARLY DIRTY SPECIMENS WILL UNDERGO APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION TREATMENT. ORPHAN COLLECTIONS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO THE MAIN COLLECTION AND ORGANIZED TAXONOMICALLY TO IMPROVE BROWSABILITY AND RETRIEVAL. ALL SPECIMENS WILL BE INVENTORIED AND PHOTOGRAPHED, MINIMIZING THE NEED FOR FUTURE HANDLING. THE ASSOCIATED DATA SLIPS AND HANDWRITTEN LEDGER ENTRIES WILL BE SCANNED AND THE DATA TRANSCRIBED INTO THE COLLECTIONS DATABASE ALONG WITH PHOTOGRAPHS OF SPECIMENS, ALL OF WHICH WILL BE LINKED TO SPECIMEN RECORDS. IN ADDITION TO ENSURING THE LONG TERM PRESERVATION OF THESE COLLECTIONS, THE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE THEIR USE IN RESEARCH, EXHIBITION, AND TEACHING."

"THE MISSOURI HISTORY MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY, CATALOG, REPAIR, AND REHOUSE THE EPSILON-DALZELL PREMIER COLLECTION, CURRENTLY HOUSED IN THE MUSEUM'S MOVING IMAGE AND SOUND ARCHIVE. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE TWO FULL-TIME, TEMPORARY FILM PRESERVATIONISTS, OVERSEEN BY ITS MANAGER FOR MEDIA AND DIGITAL ASSETS, WHO WILL GUIDE PROJECT ACTIVITIES. THE COLLECTION CONTAINS APPROXIMATELY 2,345 CANS OF FILM THAT HOLD AN ESTIMATED 5,174 ROLLS OF FILM. FULL CATALOG RECORDS WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE, FOR VIEWING AT NO CHARGE, THROUGH THE MUSEUM'S ONLINE CROSS COLLECTIONS SEARCH. THE COLLECTION INCLUDES ADVERTISEMENTS, COMMERCIALS, INDUSTRIAL FILMS, AND SHORT FILMS PRODUCED DURING THE RISE OF TELEVISION ADVERTISING IN THE 1950S BY PREMIER FILM AND RECORDING CORPORATION, A COMMERCIAL FILM STUDIO ONCE LOCATED IN ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI."

"THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL UNDERTAKE THE CONSERVATION OF SIX MONUMENTAL TOTEM POLES AND CARVINGS ON DISPLAY IN ITS HALL OF NORTHWEST COAST INDIANS IN CONNECTION WITH A PLANNED RENOVATION OF THE EXHIBIT AREA. FOUR POSTS WILL BE TREATED IN THEIR VERTICAL INSTALLATION POSITIONS, AS THEY ARE ATTACHED TO BUILT-IN ELEMENTS OF THE HALL CONSTRUCTION. THE TWO OTHER OBJECTS WILL BE RIGGED DOWN FROM THEIR CURRENT VERTICAL INSTALLATION FOR TREATMENT IN A HORIZONTAL POSITION. IMLS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT TWO CONSERVATORS WORKING FULL-TIME FOR UP TO 18 MONTHS UNDER STAFF SUPERVISION, NECESSARY CONSULTATION FEES, EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES, AS WELL AS CONSERVATION TRAINING FOR NATIVE AMERICAN INTERNS. TREATMENT STEPS FOR ALL SIX OBJECTS WILL INCLUDE DRY SURFACE CLEANING AND PHOTO-DOCUMENTATION, COATING REMOVAL, REMOVAL OF OLD FILLS AND STRUCTURAL REPAIRS, FILL REPLACEMENT AND INPAINTING, AND FINAL DOCUMENTATION OF TREATMENT. A VIEWING WINDOW WILL ENGAGE VISITORS IN THE CONSERVATION PROCESS, AND LESSONS LEARNED WILL BE BROADLY DISSEMINATED DURING AND AFTER THE PROJECT."

"THE BIRMINGHAM CIVIL RIGHTS INSTITUTE WILL DIGITIZE INTERVIEWS FROM ITS ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS TO ALLOW BROADER ACCESS TO THE PUBLIC AND ENCOURAGE SCHOLARSHIP AND NEW INTERPRETATIONS OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT. A DIGITAL ARCHIVIST WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERALL COLLECTIONS METADATA AND AUTHORITY CONTROL, QUALITY CONTROL, AND OTHER DUTIES RELATED TO THE PROJECT. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO WORK WITH A LEADING PROVIDER OF AUDIO AND MOVING IMAGE PRESERVATION DIGITIZATION WITH EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE CREATING DIGITAL ASSETS FOR USE IN MANAGED INFRASTRUCTURES AND EXPERTISE IN HANDLING AND REFORMATTING UNIQUE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS. DIGITIZED CONTENT WILL BE UPLOADED AND ASSETS WILL BE TAGGED WITH EMBEDDED KEYWORDS AND METADATA. THE CONTENT WILL BE SEARCHABLE BY KEYWORD AND AVAILABLE ON THE MUSEUM WEBSITE AND IN ITS COMPUTER RESOURCE GALLERY, AND ON OTHER SITES SUCH AS ALABAMA MOSAIC AND THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA'S CIVIL RIGHTS DIGITAL LIBRARY. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION WHILE PRESERVING THE MATERIALS THROUGH TRANSFER TO CURRENT DIGITAL FORMATS."

"THE EARTH AND MINERAL SCIENCES MUSEUM AT THE PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL IMPLEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FROM A COLLECTIONS SURVEY BY UPGRADING THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS GEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A CURATORIAL ASSISTANT TO HELP MOVE THE COLLECTIONS OUT OF OLD CASES, MANY OF THEM WOODEN, INTO NEW STATE-OF-THE-ART METAL CASES. THE NEW AIRTIGHT CASES WILL FACILITATE THE CREATION OF MICROENVIRONMENTS FOR MINERAL SPECIMENS THAT REQUIRE SPECIAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS WHILE PROTECTING THE COLLECTIONS FROM LIGHT AND DUST. BY ENSURING THE PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTIONS, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GRADUATE STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY AND THE BROADER MUSEUM COMMUNITY OF CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS FROM CONTINUED RESEARCH AND USE OF THE COLLECTION."

"THE ROSE ART MUSEUM WILL MAKE ITS COLLECTIONS MORE ACCESSIBLE TO FACULTY, STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE WIDER PUBLIC, BY VERIFYING DATA AND DIGITALLY CAPTURING IMAGES FOR 2,287 OBJECTS. THE SELECTED WORKS AMOUNT TO ALMOST 20 PERCENT OF THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND REPRESENT ART COLLECTED DURING THE EARLY YEARS OF BRANDEIS UNIVERSITY AND THE FIRST DECADE OF THE ROSE ART MUSEUM. STAFF MEMBERS WILL WORK WITH A PROJECT PHOTOGRAPHER, AND ART HANDLERS WILL ASSIST WITH ART MOVEMENT AND INSTALLATION. WHILE ACCESSING THESE OBJECTS, THE MUSEUM WILL AMELIORATE POOR HOUSING, REMOVE AND REPLACE ACIDIC OR INADEQUATE SUPPORTS, AND MAKE CONDITION ASSESSMENTS TO INFORM FUTURE CONSERVATION PRIORITIES.
