PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A NEW COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT MANAGER WHO WILL OVERSEE THE PROGRAM, DEVELOPING CURRICULUM AND STAFF TRAINING MATERIALS FOR THE NEW PROGRAMS, IMPLEMENTING THE OUTREACH PROGRAMMING AT OFF-SITE LOCATIONS, AND EVALUATING THE NEW PROGRAM MODELS. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES COVID-19 PANDEMIC-RELATED LOSSES IN LEARNING AND SOCIAL EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WHILE INCREASING THE MUSEUM’S CAPACITY TO MEET THE GROWING DEMAND FOR OFF-SITE STEM ENRICHMENT OPPORTUNITIES.

THE CAMERON ART MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, PARTICULARLY THOSE LIVING WITH VISUAL, HEARING, AND COGNITIVE DIFFERENCES. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS ACCESSIBILITY FOR PROGRAMS, EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, EXHIBITIONS, AND VIRTUAL INITIATIVES. PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE ARTISTS AND MUSICIANS WORKING WITH PARTICIPANTS LIVING WITH DISABILITY, ASL INTERPRETATION, AND INCORPORATE NEW MEANS OF ACCOMMODATION SUCH AS SENSORY BAGS AND SOUND BLOCKING HEADPHONES. STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING ON ACCESSIBILITY BEST PRACTICES, AND PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE INFORMED BY A NEWLY FORMED ADVISORY COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY WHO HAVE LIVED EXPERIENCE IN EACH AREA OF ACCESSIBILITY FOCUS. THIS COLLABORATIVE, INSTITUTION-WIDE INITIATIVE WILL REMOVE BARRIERS TO ENGAGEMENT AND BUILD THE MUSEUM’S CAPACITY TO BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF VISITORS OF ALL ABILITIES.

THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL BROADEN ACCESS TO ITS VERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGY ARCHIVE BY CREATING DETAILED FINDINGS AIDS FOR EIGHT OF ITS COLLECTIONS. THE ARCHIVE CONSISTS OF 820 LINEAR FEET OF MATERIALS IN 43 COLLECTIONS, INCLUDING PHOTOGRAPHS, CORRESPONDENCE, AND FIELD NOTES. BUILDING ON WORK FUNDED BY PREVIOUS IMLS GRANTS, THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PROJECT ARCHIVIST AND TWO PAID STUDENT INTERNS TO PROCESS, REHOUSE, AND DIGITIZE COLLECTIONS MATERIALS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, RESEARCHERS FROM A VARIETY OF DISCIPLINES WILL BE ABLE TO DIRECTLY ACCESS CATALOG RECORDS DESCRIBING THE CONTENTS OF THE VERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGY ARCHIVE COLLECTIONS. PROJECT STAFF WILL SHARE THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT ONLINE AND AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES.

THE MORRIS CENTER FOR LOWCOUNTRY HERITAGE WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL EDUCATORS TO CREATE A NEW FOURTH-GRADE SCHOOL FIELD TRIP PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES MUSEUM VISITS AND PRE- AND POST-TRIP LESSON PLANS SERVING EVERY FOURTH-GRADE STUDENT IN THE MUSEUM’S FOUR SURROUNDING COUNTIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RECRUITING AND ONBOARDING A NEW SCHOOL PROGRAMS COORDINATOR, DEVELOPING FIELD TRIP RESOURCES; TRAINING DOCENTS; PILOTING, EVALUATING, AND REFINING PROGRAMS; AND IMPLEMENTING IMPROVED FIELD TRIP PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT WILL SERVE 3,400 FOURTH-GRADE STUDENTS AND 120 TEACHERS BY PROVIDING INTERACTIVE AND ENGAGING CROSS-DISCIPLINARY PROGRAMS COVERING THE LOCAL HISTORY, ARTS, AND CULTURE OF THE AREA.

CLOCKSHOP WILL ENGAGE IN A CULTURAL ASSET MAPPING PROCESS TO DOCUMENT THE DIVERSE AND CHANGING NEIGHBORHOODS NEAR THE SITE OF A PLANNED 18-ACRE STATE PARK IN NORTHEASTERN LOS ANGELES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL GATHER ORAL HISTORIES, WRITE NEIGHBORHOOD NARRATIVES, CAPTURE PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHIC IMAGERY, AND PRODUCE MINI DOCUMENTARIES TO RECORD UNDERREPRESENTED CULTURAL PRACTICES, PERSONAL HISTORIES, AND LIVED EXPERIENCES OF LOCAL WORKING-CLASS COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. CLOCKSHOP WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME COMMUNITY PROGRAMS MANAGER AND WILL ENGAGE ARTISTS, PROGRAM FACILITATORS, LANGUAGE INTERPRETERS, AND A PROJECT ARCHIVIST TO PRODUCE THE BILINGUAL CULTURAL ASSET MAP AS WELL AS SUPPORT PUBLIC PROGRAMS AND TEMPORARY PUBLIC ART PROJECTS. A NEIGHBORHOOD ADVISORY COUNCIL COMPRISED OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL INFORM STRATEGIC PLANNING AND PROGRAMMING, WHILE ONGOING COLLABORATION WITH CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS WILL RESULT IN THE INTEGRATION OF THESE COMMUNITIES’ STORIES AND CULTURES INTO THE INTERPRETATION OF THE FUTURE PARK.

THE PILGRIM HALL MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF FOUR CENTURIES OF PLYMOUTH, MASSACHUSETTS HISTORY REPRESENTED IN ITS ARCHIVAL COLLECTION OF 35,000 MANUSCRIPTS, DOCUMENTS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS. PROJECT STAFF, INCLUDING A FULL-TIME ARCHIVIST HIRED FOR THIS EFFORT, WILL IMPLEMENT A NEW DATABASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM WITH AN ONLINE CATALOG COMPONENT AS WELL AS REHOUSE COLLECTION OBJECTS AND STORE THEM IN NEW CABINETS. THE IMPROVED PHYSICAL CONDITION OF THE COLLECTION WILL BENEFIT STUDENTS AND PUBLIC RESEARCHERS.

THE PAINE ART CENTER AND GARDENS WILL USE FUNDS TO CREATE A HISTORIC PRESERVATION PLAN TO HELP SUSTAIN THE LONG-TERM CARE OF THE HISTORIC ESTATE’S ARCHITECTURE AND COLLECTIONS. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORT THAT RECOMMENDED PRIORITIZING THE NEED FOR PRESERVATION AND MAINTENANCE PLANS, THE ORGANIZATION WILL WORK WITH AN HISTORIC PRESERVATION ARCHITECT AND A HISTORIC RESTORATION FIRM TO ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION PLAN AND A CYCLICAL MAINTENANCE SCHEDULE. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE NEW PRESERVATION PLAN WILL GUIDE THE CURATORIAL AND FACILITIES STAFF IN PLANNING FOR FUTURE PRESERVATION AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES OF THE ESTATE’S ARCHITECTURE AND COLLECTIONS.

THE LONG ISLAND CHILDREN’S MUSEUM WILL LAUNCH THE THIRD PHASE OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF “SALTWATER STORIES: THE SEA AND ME,” A NEW PERMANENT EXHIBITION THAT WILL ENGAGE FAMILY AND SCHOOL AUDIENCES IN AN EXPLORATION OF THE LOCAL MARITIME TRADITIONS THAT HAVE SHAPED THE HISTORICAL, CULTURAL, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF LONG ISLAND. BUILDING ON PREVIOUS GRANTS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INCORPORATE FINDINGS FROM THE SECOND PHASE TO FABRICATE EXHIBITION COMPONENTS WITH AN OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR, DEVELOP SEASONALLY INFORMED PROGRAMS AND MATERIALS FOR FAMILIES, DEVELOP WEBSITE CONTENT, FINALIZE AND IMPLEMENT THE EXHIBITION MARKETING PLAN, AND UTILIZE A REMEDIAL EVALUATION OF THE INSTALLED EXHIBITION TO MAKE ADJUSTMENTS. EXHIBITION CONTENT WILL CORRELATE TO SEVERAL NEW YORK STATE NEXT GENERATION LEARNING STANDARDS, AND WILL EXTEND THE REACH OF HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING TO KEY AUDIENCES, INCLUDING UNDERSERVED OR RECENTLY IMMIGRATED POPULATIONS FROM COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN MEXICO, CENTRAL AMERICA, AND ASIA. AS A RESULT, VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM WILL INCREASE THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF LONG ISLAND’S MARITIME HISTORY AND CULTURE THROUGH PARTICIPATING IN EDUCATIONAL AND INTERGENERATIONAL EXPERIENCES.

THE STRONG NATIONAL MUSEUM OF PLAY WILL USE FUNDS TO IMPROVE THE DOCUMENTATION, PRESERVATION, AND ACCESSIBILITY OF 15,000 TRADE CATALOGS FROM THE TOY, DOLL, PUZZLE, AND GAME INDUSTRIES. PROJECT STAFF WILL MAKE COLLECTIONS-RELATED INFORMATION ACCESSIBLE AND SEARCHABLE ONLINE THROUGH ITS OWN WEBSITE AS WELL AS THROUGH AN EXTERNAL COLLECTION WEBSITE. ENHANCED DOCUMENTATION, PRESERVATION, AND ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTION WILL ADVANCE THE MUSEUM’S MISSION AND BENEFIT HISTORIANS AND RESEARCHERS OF AMERICAN TOY AND GAME PRODUCTION.

CINCINNATI NATURE CENTER WILL DEVELOP A PLAN TO AMPLIFY THE IMPACT OF ITS CONSTITUENTS TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL CHALLENGES THROUGH THE PRACTICE OF CIVIL DISCOURSE. EXPERT CONSULTANTS AND STAFF WILL ENGAGE IN DIALOGUES WITH MUSEUM STAKEHOLDERS TO CO-CREATE AND BETA-TEST NEW PROGRAMS, PROJECTS, TRAINING, AND COMMUNICATION TOOLS. STAFF WILL EVALUATE THE NEW INITIATIVES, WHICH WILL INFORM FUTURE PROGRAMS WITH THE GOAL TO MOVE CONVERSATIONS BEYOND OUTDOOR RECREATION TO CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTION. PROJECT RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH OTHER NATURE CENTERS SEEKING GREATER RELEVANCY WITHIN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BETTER WAYS TO ACTIVATE CIVIC ENGAGEMENT FOR SUSTAINABILITY, PROVIDING A PATH FORWARD FOR CONNECTING PEOPLE NOT JUST TO NATURE, BUT TO ONE ANOTHER.

THE WILLOWBROOK WILDLIFE CENTER WILL DESIGN AND DEVELOP A PLAN TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL AND ACTION-ORIENTED MESSAGES TO ADDRESS GAPS IN PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE MEDICAL SCIENCE BEHIND WILDLIFE REHABILITATION, THE IMPACT OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON HABITAT, AND PROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO HEALTHY CO-EXISTENCE OF PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE THAT CAN CONTRIBUTE TO A SUSTAINABLE FUTURE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE GRAPHIC DESIGN AND PRODUCTION OF INTERPRETIVE PANELS FOR THE VISITOR CENTER AND OUTDOOR INTERACTIVE TRAILS EXPERIENCE; DEVELOPMENT OF CURRICULUM-BASED GUIDED AND SELF-GUIDED SCHOOL FIELD TRIPS; A CLASSROOM LOAN BOX WITH LESSON PLANS, AND A FAMILY DISCOVERY BACKPACK FOR VISITORS; AND EVALUATION OF BOTH THE INTERPRETIVE VISITOR EXPERIENCE AND THE CURRICULUM-BASED AND FAMILY LEARNING MATERIALS. THE RESULTING NEW VISITOR EXPERIENCE WILL ENCOURAGE INFORMED ACTION SO LOCAL AND REGIONAL VISITORS CAN LEARN WHAT THEY CAN DO TO HELP PREVENT AND RESPOND APPROPRIATELY TO HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT.

FORD’S THEATRE WILL EXPAND ITS EDUCATIONAL REACH BY DEVELOPING AND EXPANDING A SUITE OF PROGRAMS INCLUDING A NEW TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITY; EXPANDED EDUCATIONAL PUBLIC PROGRAMS; AND NEW DIGITAL RESOURCES AND TOOLS FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING A NEW SUMMER TEACHER INSTITUTE ROOTED IN PLACE-BASED LEARNING, UPDATING EDUCATIONAL CONTENT AND CREATING NEW ONLINE LEARNING RESOURCES, AND EXPANDING THE CABINET CONVERSATIONS ON CREATIVITY, HISTORY, AND LEADERSHIP PROGRAM TO TRANSFORM THE PROGRAM FROM BEING PURELY VIRTUAL TO A NEW HYBRID MODEL THAT OFFERS OPPORTUNITIES FOR BOTH IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL ENGAGEMENT. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, FORD’S THEATER SOCIETY WILL ENGAGE AUDIENCES IN INFORMED CIVIC DEMOCRACY HELPING PARTICIPANTS DEVELOP CRITICAL THINKING AND MEDIA LITERACY SKILLS WHILE DEEPENING THEIR APPRECIATION FOR THE POWER OF PLACE AND A SENSE OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND BELONGING.

THE JUDD FOUNDATION WILL IMPROVE ACCESS TO A COLLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 21,000 IMAGES RELATED TO THE LIFE AND WORK OF AMERICAN ARTIST DONALD JUDD. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DIGITIZING IMAGES THAT DOCUMENT THE ARTIST’S WORK, ARCHITECTURE, FURNITURE, DESIGN PRACTICES, AND EXHIBITIONS, AS WELL AS HIS PERSONAL LIFE AND TRAVELS. BY SUPPORTING THE CATALOGING, DATABASE MANAGEMENT, AND IMPROVED DIGITAL IMAGE FILE PRESERVATION, THIS PROJECT LAYS ESSENTIAL GROUNDWORK FOR THE STAFF TO EXPAND AND DIVERSIFY ITS AUDIENCE THROUGH DIGITIZATION INITIATIVES, ONLINE ACCESS, PUBLIC PROGRAMS, AND TO FACILITATE SCHOLARLY RESEARCH.

THE MUSEUM OF ARTS AND DESIGN WILL USE FUNDS TO UPGRADE ITS PRIMARY CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (CMS) AND PHOTOGRAPH, REVIEW, AND UPDATE ITS COLLECTION RECORDS TO SUPPORT GREATER ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL CONVERT THEIR CURRENT SYSTEM TO A CLOUD-BASED CMS, PHOTOGRAPH NEW ACQUISITIONS, AND SUPPORT A FULL INVENTORY OF THEIR COLLECTIONS TOWARD COMPLETE RECORD CONSOLIDATION. AT THE END OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE A FUNCTIONAL AND USER-FRIENDLY, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE OF ITS COLLECTION WITH ARTIFACT-BASED PROGRAMMING FOR K-12 AUDIENCES AND LIFELONG LEARNERS OF ALL AGES.

THE BOTANICAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF TEXAS, A SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND CONSERVATION CENTER THAT ALSO MANAGES THE FORT WORTH BOTANIC GARDEN, WILL MIGRATE LIVING COLLECTION RECORDS FROM THEIR CURRENT COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE TO AN ENHANCED PLATFORM TO FACILITATE THE ACCESSIONING OF EXISTING AND FUTURE PLANT MATERIALS. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO HIRE A PLANT RECORDS MANAGER WHO WILL CONDUCT PLANT INVENTORIES, CATALOG MATERIAL, PERFORM DATA VALIDATION, AND TRAIN STAFF. THIS PROJECT WILL FACILITATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A LIVING COLLECTIONS STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE ADVANCEMENT OF AN INTEGRATED, COLLECTIONS-FOCUSED APPROACH TO PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND SPECIES CONSERVATION.

THE NEW ENGLAND AQUARIUM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A NEW APPRENTICE PROGRAM TO PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND CAREER PATHWAY ACCESS TO STEM CAREERS BY REDUCING ACCESS BARRIERS FOR HISTORICALLY UNREACHED AND UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES IN THE GREATER BOSTON AREA. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IDENTIFYING AND ENGAGING A VARIETY OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO DEVELOP THE PROGRAM AND REACH NEW AUDIENCES, EVALUATING INTERNAL CULTURE TO ENSURE THAT THE AQUARIUM IS READY TO ENGAGE APPRENTICE COHORTS, DEVELOPING CURRICULUM AND TRAINING FUTURE MENTORS, RECRUITING AND TRAINING APPRENTICE COHORTS, AND CONDUCTING PROGRAM EVALUATION. THE EIGHT APPRENTICES WHO GRADUATE FROM THE PROGRAM WILL DEVELOP THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE REQUIRED TO START A STEM CAREER INCREASING THE LIKELIHOOD OF VIABLE EMPLOYMENT AT THE AQUARIUM OR BEYOND.

CANTERBURY SHAKER VILLAGE WILL IMPLEMENT A THREE-YEAR COLLECTIONS INVENTORY AND CATALOGING PROJECT TO STRENGTHEN THEIR MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF THEIR OBJECT COLLECTIONS. THE ARCHIVES AND MUSEUM COLLECTIONS ARE CONSIDERED ONE OF THE LARGEST AND MOST COMPREHENSIVE OF ANY EXTANT IN AN ORIGINAL SHAKER COMMUNITY. THIS STEWARDSHIP PROJECT WILL FULFILL A MAJOR INSTITUTIONAL NEED AND RESOLVE COLLECTION ACCESS AND USE PROBLEMS FOR 40,000 THREE-DIMENSIONAL ITEMS. ENHANCED PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR THE BENEFIT OF STAFF AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS OF SHAKER HISTORY AND MATERIAL CULTURE.

THE CARNEGIE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL CONSERVE, REHOUSE, AND DIGITIZE 15,000 ARCHIVAL LETTERS AND DOCUMENTS THAT COMPOSE THE HOLLAND CORRESPONDENCE ARCHIVE. SPANNING FROM 1896 TO 1913, THE ARCHIVE INCLUDES CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN THE MUSEUM’S FIRST DIRECTOR, WILLIAM J. HOLLAND, AND COLLEAGUES, PARTNERS, AND RESEARCHERS. STAFF WILL WORK WITH CONSERVATORS TO ADDRESS IMMEDIATE THREATS TO THE ARCHIVE AS WELL AS REHOUSE AND STORE THE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A FULLY DIGITIZED, SEARCHABLE, PARTIALLY TRANSCRIBED, AND PROPERLY SECURED ARCHIVE THAT WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE MUSEUM’S EARLIEST YEARS, COLLECTING IDEOLOGIES AT THE TURN OF THE 20TH CENTURY, AND FOUNDATIONAL MUSEUM OPERATION PRACTICES.

THE SAN FRANCISCO BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL EXPAND PUBLIC ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS OF THE GARDENS OF GOLDEN GATE PARK, A NEW ENTITY LAUNCHED TO ELEVATE THE EXPERIENCES OF VISITORS TO THE THREE BOTANICAL GARDENS IN GOLDEN GATE PARK. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CREATING A UNIFIED COLLECTIONS POLICY FOR ALL THREE GARDENS, EXPANDING THE CAPACITY OF THE COLLECTIONS TEAM, AND INTEGRATING AND EXPANDING THE COLLECTIONS DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC, INCLUDING VISITORS, STUDENTS, AND RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, WITH REAL-TIME AND ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT THE LIVING AND HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS IN THE CONSERVATORY OF FLOWERS, JAPANESE TEA GARDEN, AND SAN FRANCISCO BOTANICAL GARDEN.

THE SHELBURNE MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT CONSERVATION SURVEYS IN THE ELECTRA HAVEMEYER WEBB MEMORIAL BUILDING, WHICH HOUSES IMPRESSIONIST PAINTINGS, ASIAN ART, AMERICAN AND ENGLISH DECORATIVE ARTS, AND HISTORIC INTERIORS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATOR WHO WILL CONDUCT CONDITION AND ILLUMINATION SURVEYS, CONSIDER ENERGY AND VISIBILITY IMPROVEMENTS, UPDATE CONDITION INFORMATION FOR THE COLLECTIONS, AND CREATE A PLAN FOR PROTECTING THE COLLECTIONS WHILE WORK IS UNDERTAKEN ON THE BUILDING. THE ILLUMINATION SURVEY WILL INFORM FUTURE PLANNING FOR LIGHTING IMPROVEMENTS TO BALANCE PRESERVATION AND VISITOR ACCESS.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN MUSEUM OF ART WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMMING TO EDUCATE YOUNG VOTERS WITH THE GOAL OF ENGAGING THEM IN DIALOGUE ACROSS DIFFERING IDEOLOGIES AND INCREASING CIVIC UNDERSTANDING AND PARTICIPATION. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CITY OF ANN ARBOR, THE NON-PARTISAN UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN CREATIVE CAMPUS VOTING PROJECT, ARTIST PHILIPPA PHAM HUGHES, AND OTHER CAMPUS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO ENGAGE STUDENTS AND THE PUBLIC ON VOTING RIGHTS. PAID UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS AND GRADUATE STUDENT ASSISTANTS WILL WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF TO PRODUCE PROGRAMS, INCLUDING CROSS-POLITICAL DINNERS, DISCUSSIONS, LECTURES, AND INTERACTIVE ART EXPERIENCES, INFORMED BY A COMMUNITY ADVISORY GROUP. THE PROJECT WILL DEMYSTIFY THE VOTING PROCESS, ENERGIZE VOTERS, AND ENCOURAGE MEANINGFUL DIALOGUE ACROSS THE POLITICAL SPECTRUM WHILE EXPANDING THE MUSEUM’S COMMITMENT TO CIVIC RESPONSIBILITY.

ZOO ATLANTA WILL ADVANCE THE MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF ITS ANIMAL COLLECTION BY UPGRADING ITS CURRENT ANIMAL MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION VAN TO A CUSTOMIZED VETERINARY SERVICES VEHICLE. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NEED FOR IMPROVED TRANSPORTATION FOR ANIMALS UNDERGOING ROUTINE CARE AND OFF-GROUNDS SPECIALIZED TREATMENTS AS WELL AS IMPROVED RESPONSE TIMES FOR STAFF ADDRESSING ANIMAL EMERGENCIES. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE NEW VEHICLE WILL IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY OF THE VETERINARY MEDICINE TEAM AND RESULT IN SAFER METHODS FOR THE ZOO TO TRANSPORT ANIMALS.

THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM WILL SUPPORT 55 PAID INTERNSHIPS FOR STUDENTS AND EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONALS INTERESTED IN CAREERS IN THE ARTS AND CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES, THAT PUT THE LIVED EXPERIENCES OF THESE YOUNG PEOPLE, WHOSE IDENTITIES ARE OFTEN UNDERREPRESENTED IN THE ARTS AND MUSEUM SECTOR, AT THE CENTER OF THEIR WORK. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE FACILITATING DEPARTMENTAL PLACEMENTS, WHERE INTERNS WILL DEVELOP HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE THROUGH REAL-WORLD PROJECTS WITH THE GUIDANCE OF MUSEUM STAFF; CONDUCTING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SEMINARS; AND DEVELOPING AN INTERN MENTOR PROGRAM TO HELP INTERNS ACHIEVE THEIR CAREER GOALS. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL DEVELOP THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE NECESSARY FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT AND LEAVE WITH NEW PROFESSIONAL RELATIONSHIPS AND A STRUCTURE TO FOSTER THEM.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE WILL EXPAND ITS WELLNESS INITIATIVE PROGRAMMING TAILORED FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF VARYING PHYSICAL AND MENTAL ABILITIES, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, AND SENIORS. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS CONVENING OF COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS FOCUSED ON HEALTH, ARTS, NATURE, ACCESSIBILITY, AND WELLNESS NEEDS, THE MUSEUM WILL SCALE UP AND REFINE ITS CURRENT PROGRAMMATIC OFFERINGS AND PARTNERSHIPS UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF ITS WELLNESS ADVISORY COUNCIL. A NEW WELLNESS PROGRAM MANAGER WILL BE HIRED TO SUPERVISE, MANAGE, AND GROW THIS INITIATIVE AND WORK WITH AN EVALUATION CONSULTANT TO ASSESS PROGRAM SUCCESS. BY OFFERING A BROAD SUITE OF WELLNESS-CENTERED PROGRAMS AND EVENTS, SUCH AS AN ANNUAL WELLNESS FAIR, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE TO SERVE THE NEEDS OF ITS DIVERSE PUBLIC AS A CORNERSTONE FOR WELLNESS IN THE COMMUNITY.

THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER'S MEMORIAL ART GALLERY WILL CONTINUE ITS ROBUST ARTS-BASED PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ROCHESTER CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT TO BRING STUDENTS IN GRADES 2-4 FROM FIVE CITY SCHOOLS TO THE MUSEUM FOR FOUR WEEKLY SESSIONS OF INTERACTIVE, GUIDED GALLERY ACTIVITIES FOLLOWED BY ART-MAKING EXPERIENCES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING CURRICULUM AND ACTIVITIES, RECRUITING TEACHING ARTISTS AND TEACHING ASSISTANTS, TRAINING STAFF, AND ORDERING SUPPLIES, HOLDING SESSIONS FOR FIVE CITY SCHOOLS; AND PROJECT EVALUATION. THE RESULTING PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE PARTICIPANTS WITH ACCESS TO ARTS AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, COMPLEMENT AND ENHANCE CLASSROOM LEARNING, ENCOURAGE POSITIVE BEHAVIORS, SUPPORTS SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND EMPOWER STUDENTS WITH A SENSE OF PURPOSE AND BELONGING WITHIN THE MUSEUM AND THEIR COMMUNITY.

THE WISCONSIN VETERANS MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE AND CATALOG POST-CIVIL WAR THROUGH WORLD WAR I STILL IMAGES FROM ITS COLLECTION, INCLUDING PHOTOGRAPHS, SCRAPBOOKS, CHARCOAL AND PASTEL PORTRAITS, AND OTHER IMAGES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AND TRAIN A DIGITIZATION SPECIALIST TO WORK WITH STAFF TO DIGITIZE APPROXIMATELY 2,200 OBJECTS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, ACCURATE METADATA AND OBJECT PHOTOGRAPHY WILL IMPROVE COLLECTION MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS PROVIDE INCREASED PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION ONLINE THROUGH THE MUSEUM’S SEARCHABLE COLLECTIONS DATABASE. DIGITIZATION OF OBJECTS WILL ALSO REDUCE OBJECT HANDLING FOR DELICATE AND LIGHT-SENSITIVE MATERIALS AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTION.

THE BURKE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AND CULTURE WILL CATALOG AND REHOUSE APPROXIMATELY 9,000 PALEOBOTANICAL SPECIMENS IN THE COLLECTION, INCLUDING FOSSIL LEAVES, FLOWERS, SEEDS, FRUITS, WOOD, PLANT MICROFOSSILS, AND FOSSIL INSECTS, AND WILL UNDERTAKE DATA CLEANUP OF APPROXIMATELY 20,000 SPECIMENS. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT A PAID INTERN, SEVERAL WORK STUDY POSITIONS FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND A GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANT POSITION. STAFF WILL ALSO BUILD NEW AND STRENGTHEN EXISTING RELATIONSHIPS WITH REGIONAL TRIBES THROUGH ENGAGEMENT AND CONSULTATION FOCUSED ON LEARNING AND KNOWLEDGE SHARING OF WASHINGTON STATE’S PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES.

THE SOLOMON R. GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS AND ONLINE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES FOR VISITORS WITH DISABILITIES THROUGH A TWO-PRONGED APPROACH: CREATION OF A NEW DIGITAL MUSEUM MAP OF THE FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT BUILDING, AND AN IN-DEPTH REVIEW AND REMEDIATION OF THE WEBSITE DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, AND CONTENT TO ENSURE USABILITY. THE MUSEUM’S DIGITAL EXPERIENCE TEAM WILL START THE MAP REDESIGN PROCESS WITH USER RESEARCH BEFORE PROCEEDING TO DESIGN AND RELEASE. A PART-TIME PROJECT MANAGER WILL BE HIRED TO OVERSEE THE WEBSITE REMEDIATION, AND WILL CONDUCT WEBSITE QUALITY ASSURANCE FROM AN ACCESSIBILITY STANDPOINT, ADD ACCESS CONTENT, PROVIDE CROSS-DEPARTMENTAL TRAINING, AND SERVE AS THE POINT OF CONTACT FOR BEST PRACTICES IN USER ACCESSIBILITY. AS A RESULT, VISITORS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO A VARIETY OF DIGITAL PLATFORMS, SUCH AS WEBSITES AND APPS THAT SUPPORT USE BY SCREEN READERS OR OTHER ASSISTIVE TECHNOLOGY; AND ACCESSIBLE CONTENT, SUCH AS VERBAL DESCRIPTION AUDIO AND AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE VIDEO.

SAVE THE BAY WILL IMPLEMENT A FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES HANDS-ON TRAINING AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AT THE AQUARIUM CREATING A SCHOOL-TO-CAREER PATHWAY FOR THOSE UNDERREPRESENTED IN ENVIRONMENTAL CAREERS FOCUSING ON THE OCEAN. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RECRUITING AND ONBOARDING TWO NEW FELLOWS ANNUALLY, TRAINING AND MENTORING FELLOWS, AND WORKING WITH EACH FELLOW TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A YEAR-LONG PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A ROBUST SUSTAINABLE CAREER PATHWAY THAT EXPANDS ORGANIZATIONAL INCLUSION AND ENCOURAGES GREATER INVOLVEMENT IN AQUARIUM CAREERS FOR THOSE WHO ARE NOT WELL-REPRESENTED IN THE FIELD.

THE CAPE ANN MUSEUM WILL PLAN AND PILOT A MULTIYEAR INITIATIVE IN COLLABORATION WITH NATIVE AMERICAN INSTITUTIONS, ARTISTS, AND SCHOLARS IN ORDER TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS OF NATIVE PERSPECTIVES AND EXPERIENCES IN MASSACHUSETTS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL BUILD ON EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS WITH TRIBES INDIGENOUS TO THE AREA, INCLUDING THE WAMPANOAGS, NIPMUC, AND MASSACHUSETT, TO RESEARCH AND PRESENT ACCURATE, AUTHENTIC INFORMATION ABOUT THEIR ART, HISTORY, AND CULTURE TO THE PUBLIC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HOSTING A PLANNING CONVENING; A LONG-TERM INSTALLATION OF A TRADITIONAL DOMED DWELLING KNOWN AS WETU; A NATIVE ARTIST AND SCHOLARS IN RESIDENCE FELLOWS PROGRAM; COMMISSIONED ART SHOWS AT THE MUSEUM AND AT HISTORIC NEW ENGLAND'S SLEEPER-MCCANN HOUSE; AND A COMMISSIONED PHOTOGRAPHY EXHIBITION BY A NATIVE ARTIST. AS A RESULT OF THIS INITIATIVE, THE MUSEUM WILL EMBED NATIVE KNOWLEDGE AND CULTURE INTO ITS OPERATIONS, STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS WITH NATIVE PARTNERS, AND INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF NATIVE LIFE IN MASSACHUSETTS FROM PRE-CONTACT TO TODAY.

THE SANTA CRUZ MUSEUM OF ART AND HISTORY WILL PARTNER WITH THE LONDON NELSON LEGACY INITIATIVE AND THE SANTA CRUZ BLACK HEALTH MATTERS INITIATIVE TO RESEARCH AND SHARE THE STORIES OF TWELVE PRE-1900S BLACK PIONEERS BURIED AT EVERGREEN CEMETERY IN SANTA CRUZ COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PRODUCE AND ORGANIZE HISTORY AND ART EXHIBITIONS, DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE OF THE RESEARCH PROCESS, AND PUBLIC MURALS. ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE A PANEL DISCUSSION, AN HISTORIC WALKING TOUR, A COMMUNITY EVENT, AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A RELATED K-12 CURRICULUM. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE RESIDENTS OF SANTA CRUZ COUNTY WILL HAVE INCREASED ACCESS TO LOCAL HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE, A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TO RESEARCH OTHER HIDDEN HISTORIES, AND A STRONGER SENSE OF CROSS-CULTURAL CONNECTIONS AMONG COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

PERALTA HACIENDA HISTORICAL PARK WILL DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND INSTALL NEW INTERPRETIVE EXHIBITS ABOUT THE OHLONE, THE ORIGINAL PEOPLE IN THE HUCHIUN AREA WHERE THE PARK STANDS TODAY. EXHIBITS WILL WEAVE TOGETHER THE HISTORY OF THE LANDOWNING PERALTA FAMILY WITH THAT OF THE INDIGENOUS WORKERS ON THE SPANISH AND MEXICAN-ERA RANCHO, AND THEIR PAST AND CURRENT PRESENCE IN THE REGION. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH OHLONE ARTISTS AND DESIGNERS TO FINALIZE DESIGNS AND FABRICATE AND INSTALL INTERPRETIVE ELEMENTS, INCLUDING OBJECTS, SCULPTURES, VIDEOS, TEXT, AND IMAGES. THE MUSEUM WILL INCORPORATE NEW RESEARCH TO REVISE, FIELD-TEST, AND LAUNCH ITS SCHOOL FIELD TRIP PROGRAM TO BETTER REFLECT INDIGENOUS AND LATINX COMMUNITY VOICES. THE EXHIBITS ARE DESIGNED TO HELP INDIGENOUS GROUPS UNDERSTAND AND CELEBRATE THEIR OWN CULTURES, WHILE HELPING NON-NATIVES LEARN ABOUT INDIGENOUS HISTORY AND ITS IMPACT ON THE REGION TODAY.

GOGGLEWORKS CENTER FOR THE ARTS WILL IMPLEMENT THE “COMO CRECEMOS (HOW WE GROW)” PROJECT, EXPANDING ON ITS SUCCESS SERVING HISPANIC AND LATINX AUDIENCES BY DESIGNING EQUITABLE, INCLUSIVE EXHIBITIONS, PROGRAMS, AND COMMUNICATIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THREE COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS—BARRIO ALEGRÍA, CENTRO HISPANO, AND THE READING ARTIST COLLECTIVE—WHO ARE COMMITTED TO SUPPORTING THE LATINX POPULATION AND ADVANCING DIVERSITY IN THE LOCAL ARTS COMMUNITY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CREATING TWO MAJOR EXHIBITIONS FEATURING THE WORKS OF CONVENTIONALLY MARGINALIZED ARTISTS AND A COMMUNICATIONS PROGRAM DESIGNED TO ENGAGE NEW AUDIENCES FROM HISPANIC AND LATINX BACKGROUNDS BY PRIORITIZING LISTENING, STORYTELLING, GRASSROOTS OUTREACH, AND INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO HIRE A MANAGER OF INCLUSIVE PROGRAMS TO IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS SUCH AS OUTDOOR ARTS ACTIVITIES, EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, AND A PUBLIC FASHION SHOW. THE PROJECT WILL FOSTER CROSS-CULTURAL COLLABORATION, AMPLIFY MARGINALIZED VOICES, AND EXPAND LATINX ARTS ACCESS AND REACH.

THE INSTITUTE OF CONTEMPORARY ART, BOSTON (ICA) WILL DEEPEN AND EXTEND ITS ENGAGEMENT WITH YOUNG PEOPLE IN GRADES 6–12. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE WORKING WITH OVER 2,000 BOSTON-AREA TEENS THROUGH SCHOOL PARTNERSHIPS AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL PROGRAMS THAT EMPOWER THEM TO DEVELOP AS CREATIVES, INDIVIDUALS, AND LEADERS. THE MUSEUM IS EXPANDING PROGRAMS TO INCLUDE PRE-AND EARLY TEENS IN GRADES 6–8 AND WILL PILOT AN IN-PERSON PROGRAM DESIGNED SPECIFICALLY TO INTRODUCE THEM TO THE ICA’S EXISTING YOUTH COMMUNITY AND OFFER OPPORTUNITIES FOR FUTURE ENGAGEMENT. THE PILOT AND ONGOING OFFERINGS WILL EMPHASIZE SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL WELL-BEING USING CONTEMPORARY ART. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT TEENS’ DEVELOPMENT OF STRENGTHENED IDENTITY, CREATIVITY, TRANSFERABLE SKILLS, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, PARTICULARLY IN RESPONSE TO THE CHALLENGES OF WELLNESS AND ACADEMIC AND SOCIAL DISRUPTION EXPERIENCED DURING THE PANDEMIC.

THE GEORGE EASTMAN MUSEUM WILL SEEK TO EXPAND ITS OUTREACH TO NEW AUDIENCES BY CREATING TWO NEW EXHIBITIONS ABOUT THE HISTORY OF PHOTOGRAPHER GEORGE EASTMAN AND PHOTOGRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY. INFORMED BY COMMUNITY SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS, THE REINTERPRETATION OF GEORGE EASTMAN WILL ENGAGE VISITORS WITH THEMES AROUND SINGLE-PARENT FAMILIES; CONDITIONS FOR THE WORKING POOR OF HIS TIME; HIS SUPPORT FOR STEM EDUCATION; AND HIS DONATIONS TO BLACK COLLEGES CONTRASTED WITH THE CHALLENGES OF ORGANIZATIONAL DISCRIMINATION. THE STEM-FOCUSED EXHIBITION TRACING THE EVOLUTION OF PHOTOGRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY WILL INTEGRATE HISTORIC OBJECTS FROM THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION. MUSEUM STAFF WILL PRODUCE AN AUDIO TOUR AND WORK WITH A TECHNOLOGY CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP INTERACTIVE DIGITAL ACTIVITIES THAT UTILIZE MOBILE APPLICATIONS. A WEBSITE WILL ACCOMPANY THE EXHIBITION, INCLUDING A VIRTUAL TOUR, EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES, AND VIDEO CONTENT GEARED TOWARD AUDIENCES OF ONLINE VISITORS, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, DOCENTS, AND RESEARCHERS.

THE NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL WORK WITH A SCHOLAR IN NATIVE AMERICAN STUDIES TO ASSESS ITS COLLECTIONS THAT PERTAIN TO INDIGENOUS HISTORY FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF NATIVE AMERICAN AND U.S. HISTORY. THE CONSULTING SCHOLAR WILL WORK WITH MUSEUM AND LIBRARY STAFF TO UPDATE COLLECTION DESCRIPTIONS, CREATE NAVIGATION TOOLS, AND TRAIN STAFF TO INTEGRATE INDIGENOUS HISTORIES, MATERIALS, AND PERSPECTIVES INTO THEIR WORK WITH COLLECTIONS AND RELATED PROGRAMMING. TWO ADDITIONAL CONSULTING SCHOLARS WILL ALSO AID STAFF IN GENERATING CARE PROTOCOLS FOR SENSITIVE ITEMS AND DEVELOPING STAFF GUIDANCE MATERIALS, INCLUDING IDENTIFYING INSTANCES WHERE OTHER SCHOLARS AND TRIBAL REPRESENTATIVES SHOULD BE CONTACTED FOR FURTHER CONSULTATION. THE PROJECT WILL MAKE A COLLECTIONS GUIDE AND DIGITIZED IMAGES AND INFORMATION ABOUT THE COLLECTION AVAILABLE ONLINE, BRINGING TO LIGHT AND MAKING ACCESSIBLE MATERIAL THAT HAS BEEN LARGELY IGNORED, MISUNDERSTOOD, AND INVISIBLE.

THE BRONX MUSEUM OF THE ARTS WILL ENHANCE A SERIES OF COMMUNITY PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO PROMOTE EQUITY AND SOCIAL JUSTICE THROUGH THE ARTS. ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON ENHANCING ACCESS THROUGH PUBLIC PROGRAMS, NURTURING LOCAL ARTISTS THROUGH COMMISSIONS AND RESIDENCIES, AND DEEPENING COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND PARTNERSHIPS. GUIDED BY A REVITALIZED COMMUNITY ADVISORY COUNCIL, THE MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE EXISTING PROGRAMS, INCLUDING CULTURAL EVENTS, STORYTELLING PROGRAMS, SENIOR PROGRAMS, AND VIRTUAL PLATFORMS WITH DIGITALLY ACCESSIBLE LEARNING MATERIALS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE FREE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SEMINARS FOR EMERGING ARTISTS, AS WELL AS OFFERING A RESIDENCY PROGRAM FOR ARTISTS TO ENGAGE WITH ISSUES EXPRESSED BY LOCAL BIPOC (BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR) COMMUNITIES THROUGH OPEN STUDIO DAYS, TALKS, AND WORKSHOPS. ADDITIONAL PROJECT RESULTS WILL INCLUDE IMPROVED MEASUREMENT INSTRUMENTS AND EVALUATION REPORTS AND PHOTO AND VIDEO PROGRAM DOCUMENTATION SHARED THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA AND THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE.

THE DENVER MUSEUM OF NATURE AND SCIENCE WILL CONDUCT A THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO ADVANCE COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP FOR LOGISTICALLY CHALLENGING LARGE BONES OF DINOSAURS IN THE MORRISON FORMATION FOSSIL COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO THESE SCIENTIFICALLY SIGNIFICANT SPECIMENS—INCLUDING HOLOTYPE SPECIMENS—FOR SCHOLARS AND THE PUBLIC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE REPAIRING, PREPARING, REHOUSING, ARCHIVAL CRADLING, AND 3D SCANNING THE SPECIMENS. IT ALSO WILL SUPPORT PURCHASING 3D SCANNING EQUIPMENT FOR LARGE SPECIMENS. THE PROJECT WILL OFFER NUMEROUS OPPORTUNITIES FOR EARLY-CAREER PALEONTOLOGISTS THROUGH A TERM PREPARATOR POSITION AND THREE PAID INTERNSHIPS THAT WILL MAKE SIGNIFICANT SPECIMENS AVAILABLE FOR STUDY FOR THE FIRST TIME. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED CARE OF THIS COLLECTION, ENHANCED COLLECTIONS ACCESS, AND A WIDER DISSEMINATION OF THE COLLECTION AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE FOR MUSEUM VISITORS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, RESEARCHERS, AND COMMUNITIES WHERE THE FOSSILS ORIGINATED.

THE TAUBMAN MUSEUM OF ART WILL DEVELOP THE “HAPPY HEARTS” THERAPEUTIC ART PROGRAM TO SUPPORT INDIVIDUALS WITH INTELLECTUAL, PHYSICAL, AND EMOTIONAL DISABILITIES IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH 17 SOCIAL SERVICES ORGANIZATIONS REPRESENTING A RANGE OF INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES AND A PROFESSIONAL ART THERAPIST TO IDENTIFY PARTICIPANT NEEDS AND DEVELOP PROGRAMS. GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS FROM RADFORD UNIVERSITY’S OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROGRAM WILL ASSIST IN DEVELOPING CURRICULA AND LEADING THERAPEUTIC ART SESSIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT TO MEASURE PROGRAM EFFICACY AND SUPPORT ITS LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL LEARN NEW SKILLS TO ENHANCE SELF-ESTEEM; DEVELOP TECHNICAL ABILITIES TO ENABLE VISUAL SELF-EXPRESSION; ENHANCE CREATIVE CAPABILITIES TO SUPPORT SELF-ACTUALIZATION; AND BUILD RELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHERS THROUGH SOCIAL INTERACTION.

THE ARMORY CENTER FOR THE ARTS WILL IMPLEMENT THE SOWING SEEDS INITIATIVE, A THREE-YEAR SERIES OF COMMUNITY-DRIVEN, MULTI-GENERATIONAL ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THE INITIATIVE WILL INCLUDE BOTH IN-SCHOOL AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL PROGRAMS CENTERING ON THE WAYS SEEDS ARE USED AND SHARED BY DIVERSE COMMUNITIES IN THE PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE. WITH THE HIRE OF A FULL-TIME ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE, THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND THE PASADENA UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT TO PLAN AND PRODUCE THE PROGRAMS FOR ADULTS, FAMILIES, AND YOUNG PEOPLE IN A VARIETY OF DIFFERENT LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH A TONGVA CULTURAL ADVISOR TO ENSURE INCLUSION OF FIRST WORLD VOICES IN THE CURRICULUM. PARTICIPANTS THROUGHOUT THE GREATER SAN GABRIEL VALLEY WILL CONNECT WITH THE LAND AND THE TONGVA COMMUNITY, LEARN ABOUT THE FLORA AND FAUNA, AND BUILD NEW SKILLS TO PROTECT NATURE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

THE NEW BEDFORD WHALING MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTIONS OF REGIONAL HISTORY BY INCREASING ITS EXISTING STORAGE SPACE. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH CONTRACTORS TO MOVE THE COLLECTION AND INSTALL NEW SHELVING. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A CURATORIAL ASSISTANT AND A PHOTOGRAPHY FELLOW TO ASSIST IN CATALOGING, PROCESSING, AND HOUSING THE COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ADDRESS A BACKLOG OF CATALOGING AND PROCESSING WORK, AND NEW SHELVING WILL ALLOW FOR ADEQUATE SPACE TO CREATE A DEDICATED AREA FOR PROCESSING MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL PROTECT AND INCREASE ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS FOR THE BENEFIT OF LOCAL RESIDENTS, REGIONAL TOURISTS, DIGITAL VISITORS, AS WELL AS STUDENTS AND SCHOLARS.

THE PORTLAND ART MUSEUM WILL PRODUCE THE EXHIBITION BLACK ARTISTS OF OREGON, WHICH WILL HIGHLIGHT AND CELEBRATE THE WORK OF BLACK ARTISTS, INCLUDING WORKS IN THE MUSEUM’S PERMANENT COLLECTION THAT HAVE BEEN HISTORICALLY UNDER-EXHIBITED AND UNDER-RESEARCHED. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A GUEST CURATOR AND THE EXHIBITION WILL BUILD UPON BOTH HER LIVED EXPERIENCE AND HER RESEARCH EXPLORING THE LINEAGE AND LEGACY OF BLACK ARTISTS IN OREGON AND THE IMPACT, HISTORY, AND PRESENCE OF BLACK ARTISTS AND ARTS COLLECTIVES IN THE REGION. A CATALOG WILL ACCOMPANY THE INSTALLATION, AND A SERIES OF PUBLIC PROGRAMS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS WILL HIGHLIGHT THE FEATURED ARTISTS’ CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE REGION AND THE NATION. PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE DOCUMENTING AND DISTRIBUTING ORAL HISTORIES THROUGH VIDEOS AND PODCASTS, ARTIST STUDIO VISITS, AND INTERGENERATIONAL ARTIST CONVERSATIONS.

THE NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM WILL ENHANCE ACCESS TO A COLLECTION OF PRINTS AND NEGATIVES DOCUMENTING THE FIRST LINE TO OPEN IN THE NEW YORK CITY SUBWAY SYSTEM. THE ROUTE 1 COLLECTION CONTAINS AN ESTIMATED 5,000 PRINTS AND 3,350 NEGATIVES THAT DEPICT THE 28 SUBWAY STATIONS AND 9.1 MILES OF TUNNELS THAT OPENED ON OCTOBER 27TH, 1904. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE TWO CONTRACT ARCHIVISTS TO CATALOG, DIGITIZE, REHOUSE, AND CREATE A FINDING AID FOR THE IMAGES. THE MUSEUM WILL USE THE NEWLY DIGITIZED IMAGES IN EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMMING IN ADDITION TO SHARING THEM THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA AND ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DISPLAY SELECTIONS OF THE IMAGES AT THE TRANSIT SYSTEM’S MAIN FACILITY, ON PUBLIC KIOSKS THROUGHOUT MANHATTAN, AND ON DIGITAL SCREENS THROUGHOUT THE SUBWAY SYSTEM, PROMOTING A GREATER PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE LOCAL HISTORY OF TRANSIT.

JAMES MADISON’S MONTPELIER WILL CREATE NON-PARTISAN PROGRAMMING TO INSPIRE AND EMPOWER PEOPLE TO BECOME MORE ACTIVE, ENGAGED, AND EDUCATED PARTICIPANTS IN AMERICAN DEMOCRACY. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FIRST AMENDMENT MUSEUM AND LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT FOUR TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SEMINARS, 18 COMMUNITY “HOW-TO” WORKSHOPS, AND STUDENT WORKSHOPS EXPECTED TO REACH 2,750 STUDENTS OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT. THE PROGRAMS WILL HELP TEACHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC LEARN HOW TO EXERCISE THEIR FIRST AMENDMENT RIGHTS OF SPEECH, PRESS, ASSEMBLY, AND PETITION. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH AN OUTSIDE EVALUATOR TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT FORMATIVE AND SUMMATIVE EVALUATION COMPONENTS. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROMOTE CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND IS CENTRAL TO MONTPELIER’S CONSTITUTION INITIATIVE, A 10-YEAR VENTURE DEDICATED TO THE NATION’S FOUNDING DOCUMENT.

THE JAPANESE AMERICAN NATIONAL MUSEUM WILL CATALOG AND CONSERVE ITEMS FROM ITS COLLECTION OF ART AND ASSOCIATED EPHEMERA OF JAPANESE AMERICAN ARTIST HENRY SUGIMOTO. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATORS TO CONDUCT CONDITION ASSESSMENTS OF PAINTINGS, WOODBLOCK PRINTS, DOCUMENTS, AND OTHER MATERIALS AND TO PERFORM CONSERVATION WORK ON THOSE ITEMS IN NEED OF IMMEDIATE ATTENTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE ARCHIVAL STORAGE BOXES, AND CONSERVATION TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT THIS WORK. MUSEUM STAFF WILL INVENTORY, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION AND WORK WITH A CONTRACTED PHOTOGRAPHER TO DIGITIZE UP TO 600 ARTIFACTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE COMPLETE INVENTORY AND CATALOGING OF THE COLLECTION, WHICH WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH THE MUSEUM’S ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE.

THE YERBA BUENA CENTER FOR THE ARTS (YBCA) WILL LAUNCH ITS YBCA CO-OP MEMBERSHIP PROGRAM, A RECENTLY PILOTED MEMBERSHIP FRAMEWORK THAT CENTERS ARTISTS AND COMMUNITIES AS INTRINSIC TO AUDIENCE BUILDING, ONGOING ENGAGEMENT, AND ONSITE PROGRAMMING. THE MUSEUM WILL CONVENE REGULARLY WITH FOCUS GROUPS TO COLLECT FEEDBACK TO STRENGTHEN THE PROGRAM BY ENSURING IT DIRECTLY SERVES THE NEEDS OF ARTISTS, AS WELL AS EXPAND OUTREACH TO A GREATER NUMBER OF ARTISTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS FROM ACROSS THE BAY AREA. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO ONGOING USE OF THE MUSEUM’S REHEARSAL, STUDIO, AND MEETING SPACES, GENERATING INCREASED COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THROUGH ART PROTOTYPING FESTIVALS, CONVENINGS, EXHIBITIONS, PERFORMANCES, LECTURES, AND SCREENINGS. BY CO-CREATING THIS PROGRAM WITH AND FOR ARTISTS AND COMMUNITIES, THE MUSEUM HOPES TO REACH THOSE WHO HAVE BEEN HISTORICALLY MARGINALIZED FROM OR UNABLE TO PARTICIPATE IN TRADITIONAL MUSEUM MEMBERSHIP PROGRAMS.

MYSTIC SEAPORT MUSEUM WILL STABILIZE AND IMPROVE THE CONDITION OF FILM NEGATIVES FROM ITS COLLECTION THAT HAVE BEEN AFFECTED BY A FORM OF SEVERE DETERIORATION KNOWN AS VINEGAR SYNDROME. MUSEUM STAFF WILL EVALUATE, SELECT, TREAT, DIGITIZE, REHOUSE, AND CATALOG THOUSANDS OF IMAGES FROM THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AND TRAIN AN ADDITIONAL CONSERVATION TECHNICIAN TO ASSIST IN CATALOGING AND RECOVERY OF THE OBJECTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATION STANDARDS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, STAFF WILL CREATE A SUSTAINABLE MODEL FOR THE ONGOING IN-HOUSE TREATMENT OF NEGATIVES AFFECTED BY VINEGAR SYNDROME AND WILL SHARE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT ONLINE AND THROUGH PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES.

THE NATIONAL BUILDING MUSEUM WILL INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY TO ITS THREE-DIMENSIONAL OBJECTS BY CATALOGING AND DIGITIZING THE COLLECTIONS AND CREATING AN OPEN STORAGE GALLERY. THE MUSEUM WILL SUPERVISE TEN PAID GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS TO ASSIST IN INVENTORYING, CATALOGING, AND REHOUSING OBJECTS, WHICH INCLUDE TOOLS, TOYS, AND MODELS, AS WELL AS WORKS ON PAPER, DRAWINGS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DIGITIZE AND UPLOAD UP TO 20,000 OBJECTS TO AN ONLINE COLLECTION DATABASE. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A DESIGN FIRM TO CREATE AN OPEN STORAGE SPACE TO HOUSE AND DISPLAY 5,000 OF THE ARTIFACTS, PROVIDING GREATER PUBLIC ACCESS AND NEW LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO HIRE A CURATOR TO CONDUCT COLLECTION RESEARCH AND CREATE INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS FOR EXHIBITION. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE THE PUBLIC THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT AND WORK WITH GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE ONLINE DATABASE.

THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART WILL DIGITIZE NEGATIVES FROM THE ARCHIVE OF HARLEM-BASED PHOTOGRAPHER JAMES VAN DER ZEE (1886–1983). THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A DIGITIZATION CONSULTANT TO SCAN AND DIGITIZE 20,000 STABLE NEGATIVES OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PROCESSING NEGATIVES IN BATCHES ACCORDING TO MATERIAL TYPE WITH PROGRESS TRACKED QUARTERLY. THE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE THE MUSEUM’S EFFORTS TO SHARE VAN DER ZEE’S ARCHIVE—MUCH OF WHICH HAS NEVER BEEN SEEN PUBLICLY—ONLINE VIA THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE, WHICH REACHES MORE THAN 37.8 MILLION USERS AROUND THE WORLD ANNUALLY. THE AVAILABILITY OF THIS WORK WILL OFFER SCHOLARS AND THE PUBLIC A MORE COMPREHENSIVE ACCOUNT OF THE HISTORY OF AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHY WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY CELEBRATING BLACK AMERICAN CULTURE FROM THE FIRST DECADE OF THE 20TH CENTURY TO THE EARLY 1980S.

THE EXPLORATORIUM WILL DEVELOP ACCESSIBLE STEAM EXHIBITS AND LEARNING EXPERIENCES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH COMMUNITY SCIENCE WORKSHOPS (CSWS), INFORMAL LEARNING CENTERS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ACROSS CALIFORNIA WORKING WITH DIVERSE YOUTH AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH CSWS TO DEVELOP 8–10 AFFORDABLE, FLEXIBLE EXHIBITS TO ENABLE STEAM LEARNING IN COMMUNITY SETTINGS AND WILL CREATE ACCOMPANYING AT-HOME LEARNING EXERCISES TO EXTEND THE EXPERIENCES. THROUGH A PROJECT WEBSITE, THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE THE EXHIBIT DESIGNS, FABRICATION FRAMEWORK, AND LESSONS LEARNED WITH THE FIELD TO ENABLE RECREATION BY OTHER INFORMAL LEARNING CENTERS AND OFFER GUIDANCE TO MUSEUMS AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS LOOKING TO EMBARK ON A COLLABORATIVE DESIGN PROCESS. THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE EXPLORATORIUM TO CONTINUE ITS EFFORTS TO DISMANTLE SYSTEMIC BARRIERS TO ENGAGING THE PUBLIC IN IMPACTFUL AND INSPIRING STEAM LEARNING AND REACHING UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES IN THE COMMUNITIES IN WHICH THEY RESIDE.

THE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF TACOMA WILL EXPAND ITS TACOMA OUT OF SCHOOL TIME INTERMEDIARY PROGRAM TO PROVIDE OVER 54,000 ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS ACROSS PIERCE COUNTY WITH ACADEMIC SUPPORT THROUGH EXPANDED LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES (ELOS). THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE 14 NEW STAFF, PARTNER WITH 73 SCHOOLS, AND CONTRACT WITH OVER 60 COMMUNITY ELO PROVIDERS TO OFFER STUDENTS SAFE, STRUCTURED, AND ENGAGING LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS OUTSIDE THE SCHOOL DAY THAT COMPLEMENT WHAT THEY ARE LEARNING IN SCHOOL. THEY WILL SUPPORT STUDENT LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT THROUGH ART, MUSIC, STEM, SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL LEARNING, PHYSICAL EDUCATION, NUTRITION, AND DRUG AND VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMMING. AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR WILL DEVELOP A MEASUREMENT FRAMEWORK AND ASSOCIATED TOOLS AT THE OUTSET OF THE PROJECT. PROJECT GOALS AIM TO ASSIST IN DECREASING RATES OF EARLY SCHOOL DROPOUTS AND INCREASING ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR TACOMA’S MOST UNDERSERVED STUDENTS AND FAMILIES.

THE OAKLAND MUSEUM OF CALIFORNIA WILL DIGITIZE APPROXIMATELY 2,000 IMAGES FROM A RECENTLY ACQUIRED PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTION OF CONTEMPORARY NATIVE LIFE SPANNING FROM THE 1980S-2018. THE DUGAN AGUILAR COLLECTION AND ARCHIVE PROVIDES A WINDOW INTO THE LIVES OF CALIFORNIA’S INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, TELLING A STORY OF REVITALIZATION AND RENEWAL BY CAPTURING TRADITIONAL LIFEWAYS IN A CONTEMPORARY CONTEXT. THE MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH A GROUP OF NATIVE COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO ENSURE THE NATIVE CALIFORNIAN PERSPECTIVE IS INSTRUMENTAL IN THE CARE, USE, DOCUMENTATION, AND ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. IN ADDITION TO THE DIGITIZATION, MUSEUM STAFF WILL CATALOG THE COLLECTION, REHOUSE IT IN A CLIMATE-CONTROLLED STORAGE AREA, AND DEVELOP A PROPOSAL TO EXHIBIT THE COLLECTION WITHIN THE NEXT FEW YEARS. THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE THESE IMAGES AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC FOR THE FIRST TIME THROUGH THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE AND AN ONLINE SEARCHABLE DATABASE.

THE WASHINGTON STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL CARRY OUT “DIALOGUE IN PLACE,” AN INITIATIVE TO ENGAGE COMMUNITY AND TRIBAL PARTNERS IN DETERMINING THE FUTURE OF HISTORICAL MARKERS PLACED ACROSS THE STATE BY THE SOCIETY BETWEEN 1900 AND 1950. THE SOCIETY WILL PARTNER WITH A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT CONSULTANT AND COMMUNITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO DEVELOP A PROCESS FOR CIVIC DIALOGUE THAT INVITES DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS TO DISCUSS THE COMPLICATED, INACCURATE, OR INCOMPLETE HISTORIES ON THE MARKERS AND DETERMINE WHETHER TO REINTERPRET, REMOVE, OR REPLACE THEM. AS A RESULT, PARTICIPANTS WILL FEEL EMPOWERED BY ENGAGING IN CIVIC DIALOGUE AND THE PUBLIC WILL HAVE ACCESS TO FACT-BASED, INCLUSIVE HISTORICAL INTERPRETATION IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. THE SOCIETY WILL USE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THE PROJECT TO PRODUCE A TOOLKIT AND TRAINING MODULES AS GUIDANCE FOR OTHER LOCAL HISTORY ORGANIZATIONS WHO WISH TO INITIATE SIMILAR PROCESSES OF CIVIC DIALOGUE AND ENGAGEMENT.

THE MERCER MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE, MANAGEMENT, AND INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF 500 OBJECTS INSTALLED IN 1916 IN ITS CENTRAL COURT, WHICH HAS BEEN PRESERVED AND EXHIBITED AS AN HISTORIC INTERIOR. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME TEMPORARY PROJECT ASSISTANT TO WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF AND EXTERNAL CONSULTANTS TO FULLY INVENTORY, CLEAN, CATALOG, AND ASSESS THE CONDITION OF OBJECTS THAT ARE FREE-STANDING AND SUSPENDED FROM CEILINGS AND MEZZANINES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE COLLECTIONS AND ASSESS LIGHTING CONDITIONS. THEY WILL ALSO CONDUCT HISTORICAL AND CONTEXTUAL RESEARCH TO INFORM FUTURE INTERPRETIVE PLANS AND ENHANCE THE KNOWLEDGE OF GALLERY GUIDES. THEY WILL MAKE NEW DATA AND INFORMATION ABOUT THE CENTRAL COURT OBJECTS PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH A WEB-BASED CATALOG. THE PROJECT REPRESENTS THE FIRST STEP TOWARD A LONGER-TERM PLAN TO ENHANCE VISITOR ENGAGEMENT WITH THIS HISTORIC COLLECTION.

BETHEL WOODS CENTER FOR THE ARTS WILL COLLECT, PROCESS, AND INTERPRET ORAL HISTORIES OF THOSE WHO ATTENDED, WORKED, OR PLAYED MUSIC AT THE 1969 WOODSTOCK MUSIC AND ART FAIR. THE PROJECT IS IN RESPONSE TO A GROWING URGENCY TO PRESERVE THESE MEMORIES, PARTICULARLY FROM MEMBERS OF MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES WHO ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN THE MUSEUM’S EXISTING ORAL HISTORY COLLECTION. THREE TEAMS WILL VISIT DIFFERENT LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT THE NATION, WITH A GOAL TO ADD 250 ACCOUNTS TO THE COLLECTION. EXPERIENCED PARTNERS WILL WORK WITH STAFF TO DEVELOP INTERVIEW OUTLINES AND PROVIDE PHOTOGRAPHS, MAPS, AND OTHER MATERIALS TO AID IN STORYTELLING AND MEMORY RECALL. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MUSEUM’S WORK IN MANAGING NEW DIGITAL ASSETS AND PRESENTING MORE INCLUSIVE CONTENT FOR PUBLIC PROGRAMS AND SCHOLARLY RESEARCH RELATED TO THIS NATIONAL REGISTER HISTORIC SITE THAT DOCUMENTS A DEFINING EVENT IN AMERICAN CULTURE.

THE WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY WILL IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR ITS COLLECTION OF OBJECTS AND ARCHIVAL MATERIALS RELATED TO FALLINGWATER, DESIGNED BY ARCHITECT FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT. THE PROJECT WILL AID IN THE INSTALLATION OF A NEW FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM, NEW HVAC AND HUMIDIFICATION SYSTEM, AND IMPROVEMENTS TO THE OVERALL SECURITY SYSTEM FOR THE PROPERTY. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH AN ENGINEERING FIRM, A LOCAL SECURITY SERVICES FIRM, AND AN HVAC CONTRACTOR TO IMPLEMENT VARIOUS COMPONENTS OF THE LARGER PROJECT. UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE MUSEUM REGISTRAR, A PAID INTERN AND A COLLECTIONS VOLUNTEER WILL ASSIST STAFF IN MOVING AND STORING OBJECTS TO A TEMPORARY STORAGE LOCATION, ENSURING THEIR CARE DURING THE PROJECT DURATION, AND RETURNING THEM WHEN THE NEW SYSTEMS ARE INSTALLED. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AND STAFF WITH INCREASED ACCESSIBILITY TO COLLECTIONS FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING.

THE CONTEMPORARY ART MUSEUM ST. LOUIS WILL CONDUCT AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT RESEARCH AND EVALUATION TO PROVIDE INSIGHTS TO EXPERIMENT WITH NEW WAYS OF ENGAGING VISITORS AND THE BROADER ST. LOUIS COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH THREE CONSULTANTS WITH EXPERTISE IN AUDIENCE RESEARCH, PROGRAM EVALUATION, AND STRATEGIC PLANNING. THE CONSULTANTS WILL ENGAGE INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL AUDIENCES AND STAKEHOLDERS IN FOCUS GROUPS AND SURVEYS TO GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT THE MUSEUM’S CURRENT STRENGTHS, WEAKNESSES, AND GAPS IN AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT. BASED ON RESEARCH FINDINGS, THE CONSULTANTS WILL PRODUCE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR OPERATIONAL AND PROGRAMMATIC CHANGE AT THE MUSEUM AND PRODUCE AN ACTIONABLE, PUBLICLY AVAILABLE PLAN TO ENSURE THE MUSEUM BEST SERVES ITS DIVERSE AUDIENCES IN THE FUTURE.

THE NEWARK MUSEUM OF ART WILL LAUNCH THE SEEING SLAVERY INITIATIVE, A PROJECT DESIGNED TO DIVERSIFY THE ARTWORKS AND INTERPRETATION OF THE MUSEUM’S GALLERIES OF 18TH AND 19TH CENTURY AMERICAN ART TO BE MORE INCLUSIVE OF UNDERREPRESENTED VOICES AND NARRATIVES. A NEW THEMATIC EXHIBIT WILL FEATURE BOTH HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY ARTWORKS AND INCORPORATE THE VOICES OF BLACK ARTISTS ADDRESSING THE CONTINUED IMPACT OF SLAVERY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF WORKS OF ART BY DIVERSE ARTISTS IN SURROUNDING GALLERIES, INSTALLING BILINGUAL LABELS IN ALL GALLERIES, AND DEVELOPING A SERIES OF NEW PUBLIC AND SCHOOL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. BUILDING ON YEARS OF SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS, THE INITIATIVE IS DESIGNED TO FURTHER THE MUSEUM’S STRATEGIC VISON TO MOVE BEYOND THE TRADITIONAL DISPLAY OF OBJECTS TO STIMULATE CONVERSATIONS AND DEEPER UNDERSTANDING WITHIN ITS GALLERIES ABOUT THE HISTORIES OF UNDERREPRESENTED POPULATIONS.

THE ROSENBACH MUSEUM AND LIBRARY WILL IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS LIBRARY HOLDINGS BY CREATING AN ONLINE AND PUBLICLY DISCOVERABLE CATALOG. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AN ASSISTANT LIBRARIAN AND COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP ASSISTANT TO INVENTORY, RECONCILE RECORDS, AND CREATE AND PUBLISH ADDITIONAL FINDING AIDS FOR 21,000 RARE BOOKS, NEWSPAPERS, MAPS; 800 INDIVIDUAL MANUSCRIPTS; AND 18,000 RECORDS REPRESENTING 210 LINEAR FEET OF MANUSCRIPTS BELONGING TO LARGER COLLECTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM LIBRARY’S DIVERSE MATERIALS THROUGH A CENTRAL ONLINE PORTAL AND WILL SERVE AS A PILOT FOR FUTURE DIGITIZATION AND LINKING OF THE ORGANIZATION’S LIBRARY AND NON-LIBRARY COLLECTIONS.

THE WALTERS ART MUSEUM WILL PRODUCE A LONG-TERM EXHIBITION AND RELATED PROGRAMMING FEATURING APPROXIMATELY 550 ARTWORKS FROM ITS ASIAN AND ISLAMIC ART COLLECTION. WITH DISCRIMINATION AGAINST AAPI (ASIAN AMERICAN AND PACIFIC ISLANDER) INDIVIDUALS AND MUSLIMS ON THE RISE, THE WALTERS COLLECTIONS OF ART BY ASIAN AND MUSLIM PEOPLES CAN BE UTILIZED TO DEEPEN PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING AND INCREASE EMPATHY. PROJECT STAFF WILL ROTATE OBJECTS IN THE EXHIBITION, MANY OF WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN ON DISPLAY FOR GENERATIONS, AND INCORPORATE WORK BY LIVING, CONTEMPORARY ARTISTS. EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND IN-GALLERY EXPERIENCES WILL ENRICH THE DISPLAY TO REACH BOTH EXISTING AND NEW AUDIENCES, INCLUDING THOSE FROM COMMUNITIES REPRESENTED BY THE ARTWORKS. STAFF WILL USE EVALUATION, COMMUNITY INPUT, AND USER TESTING TO CONTINUOUSLY GUIDE ADJUSTMENTS TO THE EXHIBIT COMPONENTS AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS.

THE ST. LOUIS KAPLAN FELDMAN HOLOCAUST MUSEUM WILL PRESERVE THE AUDIOVISUAL TESTIMONIES OF ST. LOUIS-BASED HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS, LIBERATORS, AND OTHER WITNESSES BY DIGITIZING RECORDINGS AND CREATING DIGITAL IMAGES OF DOCUMENTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND MATERIAL CULTURE IN ITS COLLECTION. MUSEUM STAFF AND PROJECT VOLUNTEERS WILL ESTABLISH A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO INGEST THE MATERIAL AND USE METADATA TO CONNECT TOPICS, EVENTS, AND INDIVIDUALS ACROSS ARTIFACTS AND RECORDINGS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, STAFF, SCHOLARS, AND RESEARCHERS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO PREVIOUSLY INACCESSIBLE PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIAL ON A FREE AND PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE WEBSITE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INCORPORATE DIGITIZED NARRATIVES INTO FUTURE EXHIBITIONS AND MUSEUM PROGRAMMING.

THE HEARD MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE, MANAGEMENT, AND LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION OF NATIVE AMERICAN MATERIALS, BOOKS, ARTIST DOCUMENTATION, AND ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS. AN INTERIOR DESIGN FIRM WILL CREATE AN EXPANDED AND EFFICIENT SPACE FOR THE STORAGE OF THE MUSEUM’S LIBRARY MATERIALS. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL NEW SHELVING SYSTEMS AND CONTRACT WITH A BOOK BINDER TO REPAIR DAMAGED COLLECTION MATERIALS. MUSEUM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF PUBLIC PROGRAMS TO PROMOTE LEARNING AND ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE GROWTH OF THE MUSEUM’S LIBRARY WITH SAFE STORAGE CONDITIONS AND RESULT IN INCREASED PUBLIC ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS FOR EXHIBITION, PROGRAMMATIC, AND SCHOLARLY PURPOSES. UPON PROJECT COMPLETION, A LOCAL TRIBAL LEADER WILL BE INVITED TO PERFORM A BLESSING OF THE NEW SHELVING UNIT AND THE NEWLY IMPROVED SPACE.

CINCINNATI MUSEUM CENTER WILL FABRICATE AND INSTALL THE EXHIBIT ANCIENT WORLDS HIDING IN PLAIN SIGHT, COMBINING ITS INVERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTION OF MORE THAN 450,000 SPECIMENS WITH CUTTING-EDGE TECHNOLOGY. USING AN INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH AND INCLUSIVE LENS, THE EXHIBIT WILL BLEND SCIENCE, HISTORY, AND TECHNOLOGY TO ENLIVEN STORIES OF THE CITY’S PREHISTORIC ENVIRONMENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PREPARING AND REVIEWING GALLERY DESIGNS, FABRICATING AND TESTING PROTOTYPES, AND BUILDING OUT THE EXHIBIT AND ADJOINING PALEO LAB. THE EXHIBIT WILL ENRICH THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR CINCINNATIANS AND OTHER VISITORS, SERVING AS AN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE GLOBAL UNDERSTANDING OF ORDOVICIAN FOSSILS.

THE BOSTON CHILDREN’S MUSEUM WILL UNDERTAKE “GETTING TO KNOW YOU,” A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AUDIENCE NEEDS AND INTERESTS. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH CONSULTANTS, COMMUNITY ADVISORS, AND A LEARNING COMMUNITY OF THREE OTHER CHILDREN’S MUSEUMS TO CREATE CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE RESEARCH TOOLS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP AN AUDIENCE MAP ACROSS THE FOUR AREAS OF THE MUSEUM’S NEW OPERATING MODEL, IDENTIFY AUDIENCE GROUPS NOT CURRENTLY BEING REACHED, DETERMINE AUDIENCE GOALS, AND CONDUCT PILOT TESTING AS WELL AS FORMAL DATA COLLECTION. THE RESULTING REPORT WILL INCLUDE A DATA-DRIVEN PROGRAMMATIC PLAN FOR FUTURE WORK AND THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE LESSONS LEARNED FOR ADAPTION BY THE PARTNER MUSEUMS AND THE WIDER MUSEUM FIELD. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO ESTABLISH A PROCESS FOR ENGAGING IN ONGOING CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE AUDIENCE RESEARCH.

DISCOVERY CHILDREN’S MUSEUM WILL REDESIGN ITS CENTRAL TOWER-CLIMBER EXHIBIT TO BE AN IMMERSIVE LEARNING EXPERIENCE FOR CHILDREN OF ALL AGES EXPLORING THEMES OF THE NATURAL WORLD. INFORMED BY YEARS OF OPERATION AND A PLANNING PROCESS LED BY CHILDREN’S MUSEUM CONSULTANTS, MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A DESIGN FIRM, A CONTRACTED FABRICATOR, AND A PLANNING CONSULTANT TO TAKE EXISTING CONCEPTUAL RENDERINGS THROUGH DESIGN, CONTENT DEVELOPMENT, FABRICATION, AND INSTALLATION. THE EXHIBIT REDESIGN WILL IMPROVE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING THROUGH ACCESSIBILITY MEASURES, SUCH AS DUAL-LANGUAGE SIGNAGE AND THE MODULATION OF SOUND AND ACTIVITIES. ONGOING STAKEHOLDER TESTING OF PROTOTYPES WILL GUIDE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, AND STAFF WILL SHARE THE PROJECT EVALUATION WITH PEER CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS.

THE LAS CRUCES MUSEUM SYSTEM WILL ADAPT A MUSEUM EXHIBIT INTO AN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE FOR SCHOOL-BASED SETTINGS. THE INDIGENOUS BORDERLANDS EXHIBIT WILL LAUNCH AT THE BRANIGAN CULTURAL CENTER IN LATE 2022, EXPLORING INDIGENOUS HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE “BORDERLANDS,” IN THE PRESENT-DAY LAS CRUCES, NM, EL PASO, TX, CIUDAD JUÁREZ, MX REGION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH LOCAL INDIGENOUS ACADEMICS AND CULTURAL LEADERS TO DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT COMPLEMENT THE EXHIBIT AND AUGMENT SCHOOL CURRICULA. THEY WILL DESIGN A TRAVELING TRUNK AS A MOBILE EDUCATIONAL KIT LOANED TO SCHOOLS FOR USE BY TEACHERS. INDIGENOUS PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE IN-CLASSROOM AND RECORDED TALKS IN CONNECTION WITH THE TRUNK. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE STUDENTS’ UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL HISTORY AND CULTURE OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES; SUPPORT TEACHERS IN HISTORY INSTRUCTION INCLUSIVE OF INDIGENOUS EXPERIENCES AND PERSPECTIVES; AND STRENGTHEN MUSEUM CAPACITY TO OFFER COMMUNITY-DRIVEN PROGRAMMING.

THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF MEXICAN ART WILL DIGITIZE AND PROVIDE ONLINE ACCESS TO A COLLECTION OF MID-20TH CENTURY MEXICAN OUTFITS AND TEXTILES WITH CULTURAL, ARTISTIC, HISTORICAL, AND ANTHROPOLOGICAL VALUE. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE SANDRA CISNEROS TEXTILE COLLECTION, WHICH WAS DONATED TO THE MUSEUM BY THE AUTHOR AND NATIONAL MEDAL OF ARTS AWARDEE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DIGITIZING 78 OUTFITS IN THE COLLECTION; SELECTING AND DIGITIZING AN ADDITIONAL 70+ OBJECTS THAT CONNECT WITH AND INFORM THE COLLECTION; AND MAKING THE IMAGES AND ASSOCIATED DATA ACCESSIBLE THROUGH THE SEARCHABLE ART SECTION OF THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE. THE MUSEUM’S CURATORIAL STAFF WILL FACILITATE THE PROJECT WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A CONTRACT PHOTOGRAPHER AND A PART-TIME INTERN. THE PROJECT WILL MAKE THIS COLLECTION ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC AND RESULT IN GREATER VISIBILITY OF MEXICAN ART, CULTURE, AND ARTISTS.

THE MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND INDUSTRY WILL REDESIGN THE TRUE NORTHWEST: THE SEATTLE JOURNEY EXHIBITION WITH A FOCUS ON INTEGRATING ACCESSIBILITY AND INCLUSIVE DESIGN PRINCIPLES. THE REDESIGN WILL INCORPORATE FINDINGS FROM A THREE-YEAR EVALUATION OF TRUE NORTHWEST AND DEVELOP AN EXHIBIT THAT BETTER REFLECTS THE LIVED EXPERIENCES IN THE PUGET SOUND REGION. TO COMPLETE THIS WORK, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT AN ACCESSIBILITY CONSULTANT AND INCORPORATE EXHIBIT ELEMENTS SUCH AS ASSISTED LISTENING DEVICES, TACTILE EXPERIENCES, AND AUDIO DESCRIPTIONS OF OBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A MORE ACCESSIBLE EXHIBITION FOR THOSE WITH DISABILITIES, WHILE ENHANCING THE CAPACITY OF MUSEUM STAFF TO INTEGRATE LESSONS LEARNED INTO FUTURE EXHIBITIONS AND PROJECTS, FURTHERING THE MUSEUM’S ONGOING EQUITY AND INCLUSION EFFORTS.

THE ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY, DOCUMENT, AND ORGANIZE ITS COLLECTION OF ARCHITECTURAL RECORDS AND OBJECTS RELATED TO ARCHITECTS DOUGLAS D. ELLINGTON AND RICHARD SHARP SMITH. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CONTRACTED CONSERVATOR TO ASSESS THE CONDITION OF ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONSERVATION. TWO PAID UNDERGRADUATE AND TWO PAID GRADUATE INTERNS WILL WORK ON THE PROJECT TO CONDUCT COLLECTIONS INVENTORY, DATA ENTRY, AND CONDITION REPORTING AND THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME PROJECT ASSISTANT TO REHOUSE AND DOCUMENT OBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED PUBLIC ACCESS TO DIGITIZED ARCHITECTURAL RECORDS THROUGH AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE AS WELL AS ASSOCIATED PUBLIC PROGRAMMING.

THE HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA WILL IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM CARE AND CONSERVATION OF ITS TEXTILE COLLECTION. A CONSERVATION RESEARCH FELLOW/ADJUNCT TEXTILE CONSERVATOR WILL WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF TO PHOTOGRAPH AND REHOUSE TEXTILES WITH ARCHIVAL MATERIALS AS WELL AS UPDATE THE ASSOCIATED COLLECTIONS DATABASE RECORDS WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF TWO PAID INTERNS. ADDITIONALLY, PROJECT STAFF WILL GENERATE CONDITION REPORTS FOR OBJECTS, IDENTIFY OBJECTS IN NEED OF CONSERVATION, AND CONDUCT CONSERVATION TREATMENTS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL ENHANCE ITS ABILITY TO USE THE TEXTILE COLLECTION TO SUPPORT ENGAGEMENT WITH HISPANIC ARTS, LITERATURE, AND CULTURE THROUGH PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS DESIGNED FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO MAKE THE COLLECTION MORE ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC BY CREATING ONLINE ACCESS TO THE ASSOCIATED DIGITAL RECORDS.

THE SCIENCE MUSEUM OF MINNESOTA WILL INVENTORY, DOCUMENT, AND DIGITIZE ITS COLLECTION OF MAYA ETHNOGRAPHIC MATERIAL FROM CHIAPAS, MEXICO. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AN ANTHROPOLOGY COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT AND A COLLECTIONS TECHNICIAN TO WORK WITH VOLUNTEERS AND COMMUNITY ADVISORS ON THE REHOUSING AND CATALOGING OF THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER AND WORK CLOSELY WITH THE MUSEO NA BOLOM AND CONSULT WITH MAYA WEAVERS FROM NEIGHBORING VILLAGES ABOUT TEXTILES, WEAVING TOOLS, AND RAW MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN STANDARDIZED DOCUMENTATION OF THE COLLECTION THAT THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE LOCALLY ACCESSIBLE THROUGH EXHIBITION AND GLOBALLY ACCESSIBLE THROUGH ONLINE PLATFORMS TO SCHOLARS, ARTISTS, AND MAYA COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE UNITED STATES AND CHIAPAS.

BROOKLYN CHILDREN’S MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS MUSEUM-ON-THE-GO (MOTG) PROGRAM, AN INITIATIVE DESIGNED TO INTRODUCE COLLECTIONS-BASED LEARNING EXPERIENCES USING A “FIELD-TRIP-IN-A-BOX” CONCEPT. THE MUSEUM WILL INCORPORATE NEW ELEMENTS TO THE EXISTING PROGRAM FOR PRE-K CLASSROOMS AND EXTEND ITS REACH TO K–3 EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CONDUCTING FORMATIVE RESEARCH AND OUTREACH THROUGH MEETINGS WITH AN EDUCATOR ADVISORY COUNCIL OF K–3 TEACHERS; CREATING 24 NEW MOTG CASES ALIGNED WITH NY STATE LEARNING STANDARDS; PROVIDING EIGHT EDUCATOR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS; AND PRODUCING A SUMMATIVE EVALUATION REPORT ON THE PRE-K INITIATIVE. THE PROJECT WILL SERVE 100 EDUCATORS AND 3,000 STUDENTS BY PROVIDING OBJECT AND INQUIRY-BASED RESOURCES FOR CLASSROOMS, AND THE MUSEUM WILL DISSEMINATE PROJECT RESULTS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES AND THROUGH ITS WEBSITE.

THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL DESIGN, PROTOTYPE, AND IMPLEMENT AN INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT THAT PROMPTS VISITORS TO USE GESTURES TO SEE HOW THEY CONNECT WITH ORGANISMS FROM AROUND THE WORLD. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CONSULTANT TO PRODUCE AUDIOVISUAL INSTALLATIONS IN THE EXHIBIT AND PROTOTYPE TECHNICAL ASPECTS, SUCH AS THE GAME ENGINE, VISUAL EFFECTS, BODY TRACKING, AS WELL AS USER FEEDBACK. ADDITIONALLY, THE CONSULTANT WILL DEVELOP A MANUAL FOR CONTENT AND TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND TRAIN STAFF ON THE SOFTWARE UTILIZED FOR THE PROJECT. THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE THE SOFTWARE SOURCE CODE AVAILABLE ONLINE FOR OTHER INSTITUTIONS INTERESTED IN DEVELOPING A SIMILAR MEDIA EXHIBIT. THE PROJECT IS PART OF A LARGER EFFORT TO MOVE BEYOND THE TRADITIONAL PRESENTATION OF ARTIFACTS BY REIMAGING AND REINVENTING THE MUSEUM’S FACILITIES, GALLERIES, AND VISITOR EXPERIENCES TO PLACE HUMANS WITHIN A BROADER CONTEXT.

THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO LIBRARIES AND MUSEUM WILL CARRY OUT A DIGITIZATION AND CATALOGING PROJECT THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND INCREASED ACCESS TO A COLLECTION OF AT-RISK AUDIOVISUAL ITEMS PRODUCED BY THE INSTITUTE OF TEXAN CULTURES. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS ASSESSMENT OF THE COLLECTION THAT IDENTIFIED CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, THE PROJECT WILL ENTAIL CATALOGING, REHOUSING, AND MOVING THOUSANDS OF COLLECTION ITEMS TO CLIMATE-CONTROLLED STORAGE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AN AUDIOVISUAL ARCHIVIST TO SURVEY THE COLLECTION AND STANDARDIZE PROJECT METADATA.  A CONTRACTED VENDOR WILL DIGITIZE PRIORITIZED AT-RISK ITEMS FROM THE COLLECTION, AND GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT ASSISTANTS WILL AID STAFF IN THE CATALOGING AND REHOUSING OF THE COLLECTION. IN ADDITION TO ADVANCING KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING ABOUT THE DIVERSE COMMUNITIES LIVING IN THE STATE OF TEXAS, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING FOR UNIVERSITY STUDENTS.

THE MISSISSIPPI MUSEUM OF ART WILL ADDRESS THE CRITICAL NEED FOR MENTAL HEALTH SUPPORT BY PRODUCING A COMMUNITY DRIVEN EXHIBITION, ACCOMPANYING PUBLIC PROGRAMMING, AND BY DEEPENING ONGOING ART THERAPEUTIC, INSTITUTIONAL PARTNERSHIPS. ANCHORED BY AN EXHIBITION EXPLORING THE HISTORICAL TREATMENT OF MENTAL HEALTH IN MISSISSIPPI, THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI MEDICAL CENTER’S (UMMC) CENTER FOR BIOETHICS AND MEDICAL HUMANITIES AND A COMMUNITY ADVISORY COUNCIL TO DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE ELEMENTS AND RELATED PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE AN ARTIST RESIDENCY; A DIGITAL STORYTELLING PORTAL; AN EXHIBITION OPENING SYMPOSIUM; ARTS EDUCATION CURRICULUM AND TEACHER TRAINING; AND MULTI-GENERATIONAL PUBLIC PROGRAMMING. TARGETING FAMILIES WITHIN THE METROPOLITAN AREA THAT ARE DEALING WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES OR ACCESS, MEDICAL PRACTITIONERS, STUDENTS AT UMMC, AND THE LARGER COMMUNITY, THE PARTNERS WILL DEVELOP AN ART THERAPY PROGRAM AND MEASURE ITS EFFECTS ON PARTICIPANTS’ OVERALL MENTAL HEALTH.

CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF ATLANTA WILL COLLABORATE WITH GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY TO PROVIDE PRESCHOOL, PRE-K, KINDERGARTEN, AND SPECIAL NEEDS STUDENTS FROM RURAL AND URBAN TITLE I PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEMS WITH CURRICULUM-DIRECTED VIRTUAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. TEACHERS AND MUSEUM EDUCATION STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING ON APPROACHES TO FACILITATE AND PROVIDE DIGITAL LITERACY LESSONS TO STUDENTS AND HOW TO ASSESS STUDENTS’ ACADEMIC PROGRESS. UNIVERSITY RESEARCH PROFESSORS WILL WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A RESEARCH BASED PRE- AND POST-ASSESSMENT PROGRAM TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING ON STUDENTS’ LEARNING OUTCOMES. THEY WILL APPLY RESULTS FROM THESE ASSESSMENTS TO CREATE AN ASSESSMENT TOOL TO SHARE WITH OTHER INSTITUTIONS IN THE STATE AND NATIONWIDE. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE DIGITAL DIVIDE BY CREATING AN INNOVATIVE, PLAY-BASED CURRICULUM FOR VIRTUAL LEARNING THAT WILL IMPROVE LANGUAGE AND LITERACY SKILLS FOR ALL TYPES OF STUDENTS.

THE NORTH CAROLINA AQUARIUM AT PINE KNOLL SHORES WILL PROVIDE CONSERVATION AND SUSTAINABILITY EDUCATION ABOUT AQUACULTURE, SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES, AND CORAL PROPAGATION THROUGH A NEW EXHIBITION AND RELATED ACTIVITIES. THE FUTURE WATERS EXHIBIT WILL FEATURE MULTIMEDIA EXPERIENCES TO SHOWCASE THE “BEHIND-THE-SCENES” WORK OF AQUARISTS, A 750-GALLON HABITAT FEATURING A SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES PROJECT, AND AN INTERACTIVE OPPORTUNITY TO ENGAGE WITH THE CORAL REARING AREA OF THE AQUARIUM. PAID INTERNS WILL PROVIDE INTERPRETATION TO THE PUBLIC, WHILE WORKING IN THE VISIBLE LABS WITHIN THE EXHIBIT. THE AQUARIUM WILL ALSO HOST A TWO-DAY SYMPOSIUM TO SHARE BEST PRACTICES IN RAISING FISH AND CORALS AND BUILD A COLLABORATIVE TEAM TO FURTHER AQUACULTURE AND CORAL REARING EFFORTS THROUGHOUT THE INDUSTRY. PROJECT RESULTS WILL BE SHARED THROUGH JOURNAL ARTICLES AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS AND VISITORS WILL HAVE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF CONSERVATION TOOLS AVAILABLE TO HELP PRESERVE AQUATIC HABITATS.

NEWFIELDS WILL CONDUCT A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT TO REDESIGN AND EXPAND ITS ONLINE ART AND HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS INTO A SINGLE, INTEGRATED COLLECTIONS PORTAL. IN ADDITION TO THE DELIVERY OF ART COLLECTION DATA AND ASSETS, THE INTEGRATED COLLECTIONS PORTAL WILL SERVE AS AN ACCESS POINT TO ARCHIVAL COLLECTION DESCRIPTIONS, ITEM-LEVEL INFORMATION, AND DIGITIZED RECORDS RELATING TO NEWFIELDS’ HISTORIC PROPERTIES AND THE INDIANAPOLIS MUSEUM OF ART’S 138-YEAR HISTORY. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT TWO FULL-TIME POSITIONS, A DIGITIZATION AND METADATA SPECIALIST AND A RIGHTS RESEARCHER, AS WELL AS A USER TESTING CONTRACTOR WHO, ALONG WITH A CROSS-DEPARTMENTAL MUSEUM TEAM, WILL DEVELOP, PUBLICIZE, AND LAUNCH THE NEW INTEGRATED COLLECTIONS PORTAL. THE RESULTING PORTAL WITH OPEN-ACCESS INFRASTRUCTURE WILL MAKE NEWFIELDS' RESOURCES MORE WIDELY AVAILABLE TO RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC.

THE CONNECTICUT SCIENCE CENTER WILL REDESIGN AN EXHIBIT ABOUT SPACE TO INCLUDE UP-TO-DATE SCIENCE, INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCES, INQUIRY-BASED PUBLIC PROGRAMS, AND CURRICULUM CONNECTIONS TO STEM LEARNING. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT THE SCIENCE MUSEUM OF MINNESOTA AS A COLLABORATIVE PARTNER IN CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT, DESIGN, PROTOTYPING, FABRICATION, AND INSTALLATION OF THE EXHIBIT. THEY WILL GEAR THE EXHIBIT TOWARD FAMILY AUDIENCES, SPECIFICALLY CHILDREN AGES THREE TO 13 AND MULTI-GENERATIONAL FAMILIES. THE MUSEUM’S PROGRAM STAFF WILL DEVELOP AND PILOT NEW LIVE SCIENCE PROGRAMMING THAT WILL COMPLEMENT THE GALLERY EXHIBITS. THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO GENERATE ENTHUSIASM AND CREATIVITY TO BOLSTER INTEREST IN SPACE, SCIENCE AND STEM CAREERS IN THE FIELDS OF ENGINEERING, NUTRITION, AND BIOLOGY.

THE INTERNATIONAL QUILT MUSEUM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA WILL PRESENT THE EXHIBITION, “BLACK AMERICAN QUILTMAKING: OUR VOICE OUR STORY.” ORGANIZED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A GUEST CURATOR, WHO WILL ALSO AUTHOR THE EXHIBITION CATALOG, THE DISPLAY WILL FEATURE TEXTILE ART BY BLACK ARTISTS. TWO DOCTORAL STUDENTS WILL SERVE AS ADDITIONAL GUEST CURATORS TO LEAD A COMMUNITY ART PROJECT FOR THE EXHIBITION FOCUSING ON BLACK EXPERIENCE, DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, AND ACCESSIBILITY IN AMERICA. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN ACADEMIC PANEL DISCUSSION, CURRICULA AND COMMUNITY ACTIVITIES FOR K–12 STUDENTS, VIRTUAL PROGRAMS FOR ADULTS AND YOUTH, AND A VIRTUAL GALLERY TOUR AVAILABLE ON ITS WEBSITE AND THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION ABOUT BLACK AMERICAN QUILTS AND QUILTMAKING FOR THE BENEFIT OF VISITING SCHOOL GROUPS, UNIVERSITY FACULTY AND STUDENTS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND ONLINE VISITORS.

THE SAN FRANCISCO BOTANICAL GARDEN (SFBG) WILL ENGAGE IN AUDIENCE RESEARCH AND A COMMUNITY-DRIVEN PLANNING PROCESS TO PRODUCE AN INTERPRETIVE PLAN FOR THE NEW GARDENS OF GOLDEN GATE PARK, WHICH INCLUDES SFBG, THE CONSERVATORY OF FLOWERS, AND THE JAPANESE TEA GARDEN. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PARTNER WITH INTERPRETIVE PLANNING CONSULTANTS AND A DIVERSE GROUP OF EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS. THEY WILL CONDUCT STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS AND COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS TO CAPTURE A DIVERSITY OF VOICES, PERSPECTIVES, AND CULTURAL PRACTICES IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PLAN. FINDINGS FROM THESE EFFORTS WILL INFORM THE REFINEMENT OF GOALS, KEY THEMES, AND THE RESULTING INTERPRETIVE PLAN, WHICH WILL IDENTIFY PROGRAMMING, SIGNAGE, AND MATERIALS THAT WILL CONNECT THE THREE SITES WITH GUIDANCE FOR INTERPRETATION THAT IS UNIQUE TO EACH LOCATION. THE RESULTING PLAN WILL HELP BUILD PLANT AWARENESS AND BOTANICAL LITERACY, WHILE INCORPORATING STRATEGIES TO REACH UNDERREPRESENTED AUDIENCES.

THE HITCHCOCK CENTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT WILL PARTNER WITH MASSACHUSETTS PUBLIC SCHOOLS TO DEVELOP A NEW PROGRAM THAT FOCUSES ON USING AN ENGINEERING DESIGN CHALLENGE APPROACH TO BUILD STEM CAPACITY IN A LARGE, UNDERSERVED URBAN SCHOOL DISTRICT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN CLASSROOMS THROUGH SCHOOL-BASED DESIGN CHALLENGES AND CREATING PROFESSIONAL TRAINING AND MENTORING SUPPORT FOR EACH TEACHER PARTICIPATING IN THE PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL SCHEDULE FIELD TRIPS FOR PARTICIPATING CLASSROOMS TO ITS “LIVING BUILDING,” A NET ZERO ENERGY FACILITY THAT HARVESTS AND RECYCLES ITS OWN WATER, USES COMPOSTING TOILETS, AND WAS CONSTRUCTED WITH RESPONSIBLY SOURCED, NONTOXIC MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE MATERIALS AND CURRICULUM FOR PARTICIPATING SCHOOLS AND ENCOURAGE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS TO EXPLORE THE INTERSECTIONS OF ENGINEERING, TECHNOLOGY AND DESIGN AND THEIR ROLE IN ADDRESSING ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGES THAT CONFRONT SOCIETY.

THE DELAWARE ART MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE THE JOHN SLOAN MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION, WHICH CONTAINS CORRESPONDENCE, DIARIES, SCRAPBOOKS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND EPHEMERA PERTAINING TO THE EXHIBITIONS THAT SLOAN PARTICIPATED IN AND ORGANIZED. THIS COLLECTION OF THE 20TH CENTURY AMERICAN REALIST PAINTER AND ILLUSTRATOR IS THE MUSEUM’S MOST EXTENSIVE ARTIST ARCHIVE AND IS FREQUENTLY REQUESTED BY SCHOLARS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME DIGITAL PROJECT MANAGER TO WORK WITH EXISTING STAFF MEMBERS TO DIGITIZE AND CATALOG OVER 14,000 ITEMS IN THE SLOAN COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE STAFF CAPACITY TO MAINTAIN THIS DIGITAL RESOURCE AS WELL AS BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO UNDERTAKE FUTURE DIGITIZATION PROJECTS WHILE MAKING THIS COLLECTION MORE EASILY ACCESSIBLE TO SCHOLARS AND TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE DENVER BOTANIC GARDENS WILL PARTNER WITH THE ARNOLD ARBORETUM AND THE MONTGOMERY BOTANICAL CENTER TO PLAN, DESIGN, BUILD, AND DISSEMINATE THREE NEW TOOLS—PLANT EXPEDITION, PLANT ORDERING, AND ACCESSIONING—FOR TRACKING BOTANICAL COLLECTIONS PLANT ACQUISITIONS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE HIRING A PROJECT COORDINATOR, RESEARCHING THE THREE PRIMARY COMPONENTS OF THE TOOLS, DEVELOPING AND TESTING THE NEW SOFTWARE, AND DEPLOYMENT AND DOCUMENTATION OF THE TOOLS. THESE NEW TOOLS WILL IMPROVE DATA COLLECTION FOR PLANT COLLECTORS WORKING IN THE FIELD, TRACK NEW ORDERS FROM HORTICULTURISTS FOR THEIR GARDENS AND COLLECTIONS, ALLOW PLANT PROPAGATORS TO PLAN GROWING METHODS FOR NEW PLANTS REQUESTED EACH YEAR, AND INTEGRATE THE PASSPORT DATA FROM ORDERS AND COLLECTING TRIPS INTO NEW ACCESSION RECORDS IN THE PLANT RECORDS DATABASE. PROJECT STAFF WILL SHARE THESE TOOLS WITH OTHER PUBLIC GARDENS AND LINK TO THE ARNOLD ARBORETUM’S LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.

THE INDIANA HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPLEMENT AN OUTREACH PROGRAM TO SUPPORT HISTORY ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS ACROSS INDIANA IN PRESERVING THEIR LOCAL STORIES. IN RESPONSE TO A STATEWIDE NEEDS ASSESSMENT, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS WITH TRAINING ON BEST PRACTICES FOR COLLECTING AND RETAINING DIGITAL CONTENT. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND DESIGN A 36-FOOT TRAILER TOWED BY A ONE-TON TRUCK THAT WILL CONTAIN EQUIPMENT TO RECORD ORAL HISTORIES AND DIGITIZE INDIVIDUAL’S PHOTOGRAPHS, PAPERS, AND OTHER EPHEMERA. THE TRAILER WILL ALSO FEATURE EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS INTRODUCING VISITORS TO THE DISCIPLINE OF HISTORY AND ITS IMPORTANCE IN UNDERSTANDING THE PRESENT AND MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT THE FUTURE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL HIRE AND TRAIN A COORDINATOR TO FACILITATE TRAVEL THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THESE MOBILE SERVICES WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF LOCAL HISTORY ORGANIZATIONS TO CREATE DIGITAL CONTENT THAT RECORDS THE DIVERSE HERITAGE OF INDIANA.

THE HISTORY MUSEUM AT THE CASTLE WILL FABRICATE A PERMANENT EXHIBITION DEDICATED TO THE HISTORY OF THE FOX RIVER VALLEY IN NORTHEAST WISCONSIN. FEATURED EXHIBIT TOPICS WILL INCLUDE THE COLONIZATION OF THE ANCESTRAL HOMELANDS OF THE MENOMINEE AND HO-CHUNK PEOPLE; RACISM IN APPLETON AND ITS LEGACY AS A DE FACTO SUNDOWN TOWN; THE ROLE OF LOCAL FOX CITIES RESIDENT SENATOR JOSEPH MCCARTHY IN FORMING A TOXIC POPULIST MOVEMENT; AND THE STORIES OF HMONG REFUGEES THAT SOUGHT ASYLUM IN THE FOX CITIES AS A RESULT OF THE VIETNAM WAR. THE RESULTING EXHIBIT WILL GIVE AN HONEST AND INCLUSIVE ACCOUNT WHILE CHALLENGING MUSEUMGOERS TO CONSIDER HOW PAST PERSONAL CHOICES AND COLLECTIVE DECISIONS HAVE SHAPED THE PRESENT.

THE MORTON ARBORETUM WILL IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE IN ITS ASIAN PLANT COLLECTIONS BY UPDATING EXHIBIT DESIGN AND INTERPRETATION. THE ARBORETUM WILL PARTNER WITH THE LOCAL EAST ASIAN COMMUNITY TO HOLD FOCUS GROUPS TO COLLECT FEEDBACK ON INTERPRETIVE APPROACHES. THE ARBORETUM WILL WORK WITH A DESIGN CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP CONTENT MEETING THE NEEDS AND EXPECTATIONS OF DIVERSE AUDIENCES. IT WILL CONDUCT A CURATORIAL EVALUATION OF THE COLLECTIONS TO GUIDE RENOVATION OF OVERCROWDED AREAS, REMOVE OVERREPRESENTED AND UNDERPERFORMING PLANTS, AND IDENTIFY PLANT SPECIES WORTHY OF INTERPETING TO VISITORS. AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR WILL CONDUCT FORMATIVE AND SUMMATIVE EVALUATIONS TO MEASURE PROGRESS IN ACHIEVING VISITOR EXPECTATIONS. THE FABRICATION AND INSTALLATION OF THE UPDATED SPACE WILL ENABLE THE ARBORETUM TO RENOVATE ITS CHINA, JAPAN, AND KOREA COLLECTIONS WITH NEW INTERPRETATION AND DEVELOP GATHERING PLACES FOR AUDIENCES TO FORM A MORE MEANINGFUL CONNECTION WITH PLANTS.

THE GEORGIA O’KEEFFE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT ART TO G.O., A NEW PROGRAM TO EXTEND ITS REACH TO CHILDREN AND ADULTS IN NORTHERN NEW MEXICO, WITH A FOCUS ON RURAL COMMUNITIES WHERE ACCESS TO ARTS EDUCATION RESOURCES IS LIMITED. THE PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THE GEOGRAPHIC AND ECONOMIC BARRIERS THAT MANY FAMILIES FACE BY PROVIDING ENGAGING LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES IN SAFE AND TRUSTED COMMUNITY SETTINGS. USING A MOBILE TRUCK EQUIPPED WITH TOOLS AND RESOURCES, THE MUSEUM’S COMMUNITY EDUCATORS AND LOCAL TEACHING ARTISTS WILL PRESENT HANDS-ON EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN NEIGHBORHOOD SPACES. THROUGH DIVERSE COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE APPROXIMATELY 10,000 CHILDREN AND ADULTS WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN ABOUT THE LIFE AND LEGACY OF GEORGIA O’KEEFFE, AS WELL AS THE DIVERSE PEOPLE AND LANDSCAPE OF NEW MEXICO THAT INSPIRED HER.

THE STERNBERG MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL STABILIZE AND REHOUSE ITS COLLECTION OF MIOCENE-AGED VERTEBRATE FOSSILS THAT DOCUMENT THE EVOLUTION OF GRASSLANDS ACROSS THE GREAT PLAINS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ASSESS AND INVENTORY THE COLLECTION, STABILIZING FRAGILE SPECIMENS AND REHOUSING THE COLLECTIONS AS NEEDED. A GRADUATE STUDENT ASSISTANT AND TWO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT EMPLOYEES WILL AID STAFF IN DIGITIZATION AND DATA MANAGEMENT. STAFF AND STUDENTS WILL ATTEND A PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCE TO SHARE PROJECT PROGRESS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED ACCESS TO SPECIMENS AND DATA FOR RESEARCHERS AS WELL AS FOR THE PUBLIC THROUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, AN ONLINE EXHIBIT, AND ONLINE DATA PUBLICATION.

THE NEW MEXICO MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AND SCIENCE WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND ACCESS OF APPROXIMATELY 1,400 OVERSIZED FOSSIL SPECIMENS, INCLUDING MANY SCIENTIFICALLY AND EDUCATIONALLY VALUABLE HOLOTYPE SPECIMENS. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE PURCHASING SPECIALIZED SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED FOR HANDLING OVERSIZED COLLECTIONS. MUSEUM STAFF WORKING WITH PAID INTERNS AND VOLUNTEERS WILL REHOUSE THE SPECIMENS USING ARCHIVAL STORAGE MOUNTS AND LONG-LASTING POLYETHYLENE PALLETS, REORGANIZE AND MOVE THE OVERSIZED COLLECTIONS TO A NEW COLLECTIONS STORAGE SPACE TO REDUCE OVERCROWDING, AND BARCODE THE OVERSIZED SPECIMEN CONTAINERS AND MOUNTS AND ADD THEM TO THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION MANAGEMENT DATABASE’S OBJECT TRACKING MODULE. THEY WILL COVER ALL OPEN SHELVES TO PROVIDE PROTECTION FROM DUST ACCUMULATION. OUTREACH ACTIVITIES WILL HIGHLIGHT THE SPECIMENS AND REHOUSING EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL BRING THE STORAGE ENVIRONMENT UP TO MUSEUM AND SAFETY STANDARDS, IMPROVING LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND INCREASING ACCESS FOR RESEARCHERS.

THE DISCOVERY MUSEUM WILL DESIGN AND BUILD A NEW EXHIBIT EXPLORING THE SUBJECT OF CAUSE AND EFFECT, TARGETING CHILDREN AGES ZERO TO 12 AND THEIR ADULT COMPANIONS. INFORMED BY AN ADVISORY GROUP OF RESEARCHERS, MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH EXHIBIT DESIGN CONSULTANTS TO PROTOTYPE, DEVELOP, AND FABRICATE UP TO 10 INTERACTIVE, ACCESSIBLE EXHIBIT COMPONENTS, HIGHLIGHTING DIFFERENT TYPES OF CAUSAL RELATIONSHIPS. TO EXTEND THESE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO A BROADER AUDIENCE, THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH PUBLIC LIBRARIES AND CHILD-FOCUSED NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, WHICH WILL HOST REPLICATED SUBSETS OF THE EXHIBIT AT THEIR SITES. THEY WILL JOINTLY DEVELOP SUPPLEMENTAL ACTIVITIES SUCH AS CHILDREN’S READING LISTS AND TAKE-HOME ACTIVITY KITS TO ALLOW VISITORS TO CONTINUE EXPLORING ON THEIR OWN. AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR WILL ASSESS PROJECT OUTCOMES, WHICH WILL INCLUDE INCREASING PARTICIPANTS’ KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CAUSE AND EFFECT MECHANISMS AND BUILDING THEIR CONFIDENCE AND PERSISTENCE.

THE MUSEUM OF GEOLOGY AT THE SOUTH DAKOTA SCHOOL OF MINES AND TECHNOLOGY WILL PROCESS A NEWLY ACQUIRED COLLECTION OF 5,000 FOSSIL SPECIMENS FROM THE RICHMOND HILLS SITES IN LAWRENCE COUNTY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL DOCUMENTATION OF THE SPECIMENS, ENTAILING INVENTORIES OF THE MATERIAL, STABILIZATION OF MATERIAL REQUIRING CONSERVATION, AND THE PROCESSING OF COLLECTED MATRIX FOR THE ACQUISITION OF NEW MATERIAL. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH THE SPECIMENS TO SUPPORT THE CREATION OF DIGITAL RECORDS AND DATA TO BE UPLOADED TO THE ONLINE IDIGBIO DATABASE OF BIOLOGICAL MUSEUM COLLECTIONS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH GRADUATE STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT, PROVIDING THEM WITH PRACTICAL TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE IN DOCUMENTATION, CURATION, DIGITIZATION, AND ARCHIVING OF MATERIALS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THIS COLLECTION WHILE CREATING TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR FUTURE PALEONTOLOGISTS AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS.

THE WEISMAN ART MUSEUM WILL CONSULT WITH INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS ISSUES OF RECONCILIATION AND DECOLONIZATION IN MUSEUM PRACTICE. THE PROJECT WILL BE INFORMED BY A COMPLETED INVENTORY OF THE MIMBRES MATERIAL HOUSED BY THE MUSEUM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO DEVELOP AN INSTITUTION-WIDE EVALUATION PRACTICE, WHICH WILL INCLUDE INDIGENOUS FRAMEWORKS AND METHODOLOGIES, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INDIGENOUS ARTIST FELLOWSHIP AND A PUBLIC CONVERSATION SERIES EXPLORING DECOLONIZATION AND INDIGENIZATION IN MUSEUM PRACTICE. THE MUSEUM WILL HOST A CONVENING TO PRESENT FINDINGS AND FRAMEWORKS TO ITS CONSTITUENT COMMUNITIES AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM AIMS TO FOSTER DEEPER RELATIONSHIPS AND REBUILD TRUST WITH INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES, SHIFT PRACTICE THROUGH POWER-SHARING AND RECIPROCAL RELATIONSHIPS, ESTABLISH ITSELF AS A PLATFORM FOR CRITICAL CONVERSATIONS AND DIALOGUE, AND BUILD ITS CAPACITY IN CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE EVALUATION METHODOLOGIES.
