THE SHADOWS-ON-THE-TECHE, A NATIONAL TRUST FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION HISTORIC SITE AND HOUSE MUSEUM IN NEW IBERIA, LOUISIANA, WILL CREATE A COMMUNITY DIGITIZATION RESOURCE CENTER TO BETTER REPRESENT, ENGAGE, AND SERVE THE COMMUNITY-PARTICULARLY THE IBERIA PARISH AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL TRANSFORM THE EXISTING VISITOR CENTER SPACE INTO A RESOURCE CENTER WITH OPEN ACCESS TO COMPUTERS, SCANNERS, AND PHOTOGRAPHY EQUIPMENT, AS WELL AS OFFER FREE TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR THE COMMUNITY ON THE USE OF THE TECHNOLOGY AND ON HOW BEST TO ORGANIZE AND DIGITIZE THEIR OWN FAMILY HISTORY MATERIAL. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THE IBERIA AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORICAL SOCIETY, THE BAYOU TECHE MUSEUM, AND THE IBERIA PARISH LIBRARY TO CREATE AND PUBLICIZE THE RESOURCE CENTER.

TO INCREASE ACCESS FOR RESEARCHERS AND OTHERS WITH AN INTEREST IN LOCAL HISTORY, THE SHILOH MUSEUM OF OZARK HISTORY IN SPRINGDALE, ARKANSAS, IS DIGITIZING ITS PHOTO ARCHIVE, WHICH CONTAINS THOUSANDS OF REGIONALLY SIGNIFICANT IMAGES. THE MUSEUM WILL BEGIN BY DIGITIZING ITS WASHINGTON COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY COLLECTION, WHICH CONSISTS OF IMAGES FROM THE 1850S THROUGH THE 1970S. THE AVAILABILITY OF A 24-HOUR, ON-DEMAND, ONLINE COLLECTION WILL MAKE IT EASIER FOR RESEARCHERS AND INTERESTED PARTIES TO VIEW AND ASSESS THE COLLECTION IMAGES AND WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO SERVE BROAD AUDIENCES BEYOND ITS GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION.

THE ILLINOIS STATE MUSEUM WILL TRANSFORM ITS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO DELIVER HIGH-CALIBER, ONLINE LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR PRE-K THROUGH GRADE 12 STUDENTS. THEY WILL DEVELOP ONLINE CURRICULA AND RELATED RESOURCES AND MATERIALS FOR EDUCATORS TO USE IN CLASSROOMS AND AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. A TEACHER ADVISORY GROUP WILL GUIDE CONTENT DEVELOPMENT, INFORMED BY RESULTS OF A SURVEY CONDUCTED WITH EDUCATORS ON VIRTUAL LEARNING. THE MUSEUM ALSO PLANS TO PRODUCE DIGITAL RESOURCES-INCLUDING VIDEOS-AND TEST LEARNING MATERIALS WITH TEACHERS ACROSS THE STATE. FINALLY, THEY WILL CREATE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES TO SUPPORT TEACHERS IN CONDUCTING THE ONLINE PROGRAMS.

THE NORTHWEST MUSEUM OF ARTS AND CULTURE IS EXPANDING ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS OF INLAND NORTHWEST HISTORY, ART, AND CULTURES WITH A LONG-TERM PLAN AND POLICIES FOR DIGITAL PRESERVATION OF COLLECTION MATERIALS. A NEW, STATE-OF-THE-ART, CLOUD-BASED, DIGITAL COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM WILL SUPPORT DELIVERY OF SERVICES TO DIVERSE POPULATIONS AND HELP ENSURE THE MUSEUM MEETS INCREASING DEMANDS FOR DATA SECURITY, ACCESS, CONNECTIVITY, EXHIBIT DEVELOPMENT CAPACITY, IMPROVED CURATORIAL WORKFLOWS, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. THIS WILL ALLOW COMMUNITIES IN RURAL EASTERN WASHINGTON, NORTHERN IDAHO, AND WESTERN MONTANA TO ACCESS THE COLLECTION FOR GENERATIONS TO COME.

THE DOSEUM WILL RE-IMAGINE ITS EXHIBITION, ?DREAM TOMORROW TODAY,? FOCUSING ON UNDERSERVED STUDENTS IN SAN ANTONIO. THE COMMUNITY-DRIVEN EXHIBITION WILL PROVIDE A SPACE FOR CHILDREN AGES 4 TO 11 TO DEVELOP KEY LEARNING AND STEM LEADERSHIP SKILLS TO APPROACH THEIR DESIRED FUTURES. IN DEVELOPING THE EXHIBIT CONTENT, THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH ACADEMIC FUTURISTS, LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERSERVED STUDENTS, STEM-FOCUSED ORGANIZATIONS, AND A COMMUNITY NETWORK OF FAMILIES CONNECTED TO THOSE ORGANIZATIONS. COMMUNITY CONVERSATIONS WILL BE CONVENED FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES THROUGHOUT THE EXHIBITION DEVELOPMENT PROCESS TO ELICIT FEEDBACK FROM KEY STAKEHOLDERS.

THE DETROIT ZOO WILL PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS SERVING YOUTH IN METROPOLITAN DETROIT TO IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM TO DEVELOP AND PRESENT REMOTE STEM PROGRAMMING FOR STUDENTS IN THIS AREA, TARGETING LOW- TO MODERATE-INCOME STUDENTS OF COLOR. STAFF FROM THE ZOO AND THREE AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS (AMERICAN INSTITUTIONAL MANAGEMENT SERVICES, ARAB COMMUNITY CENTER FOR ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL SERVICES, AND BOYS AND GIRLS CLUBS OF SOUTHEAST MICHIGAN) WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS ON VIRTUAL, INQUIRY-BASED, HUMANE STEM EDUCATION. THEY WILL THEN UTILIZE SKILLS DEVELOPED IN THE WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP AND LEAD VIRTUAL EDUCATION PROGRAMMING FOR A TOTAL OF 24 GROUPS OF 20 MIDDLE SCHOOL YOUTH.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL CREATE "TRANSFORMING SPACES" TO FOSTER A MORE INCLUSIVE, CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE SPACE FOR MISSOULA'S URBAN INDIAN POPULATION AND TO BETTER MEET THE COMMUNITY'S NEEDS. THE PROJECT WILL EXPLORE CROSS-CULTURAL, COLLABORATIVE APPROACHES TO STEM AND NATIVE SCIENCE. IN COLLABORATION WITH MONTANA'S TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, THE MUSEUM'S EDUCATION TEAM AND ADVISORY GROUPS WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES THAT ENGAGE VISITORS WITH NATIVE SCIENCE. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE TRIBAL ROLE MODELS AND PARTNER WITH TRIBAL ELDERS TO CREATE A LIBRARY OF VIDEOS FOR TRIBAL PARTNERS, K-12 SCHOOLS, AND ORGANIZATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL OFFER TEACHERS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT DESIGNED TO FULFILL THE STATEWIDE MANDATE OF INDIAN EDUCATION FOR ALL. THE EXHIBIT WILL CONNECT NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE MUSEUM VISITORS, CLOSE OPPORTUNITY AND ACHIEVEMENT GAPS, AND ENSURE THAT ALL MISSOULA CHILDREN FEEL A SENSE OF BELONGING IN MUSEUMS, HIGHER EDUCATION, AND STEM.

THE GEORGE EASTMAN MUSEUM WILL FULLY CATALOG, DIGITIZE AND PROVIDE FREE ONLINE ACCESS TO THEIR ENTIRE CINEMATOGRAPHIC EQUIPMENT COLLECTION. CONSISTING OF 1,450 OBJECTS, THE COLLECTION TRACES THE INVENTION, DEVELOPMENT, AND ADVANCEMENT OF MOTION PICTURE TECHNOLOGY, AND INCLUDES THE 1895 LUMIERE CINEMATOGRAPHE, THE 1897 EDISON KINETOSCOPE, THE 1906 ELGEPHONE, TWO-COLOR 1922 TECHNICOLOR CAMERAS, AND THE 1923 CINE-KODAK AND KODASCOPE PROJECTOR. ALONG WITH COMPREHENSIVE AND ACCURATE CATALOG RECORDS, THE PLAN WILL CREATE APPROXIMATELY 12,100 DIGITAL OBJECT FILES, CONSISTING OF A SET OF EIGHT HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL IMAGES TO FACILITATE ACCESS FOR SCHOLARLY RESEARCH. A VARIETY OF PUBLIC PROGRAMS, INCLUDING SIMULCAST AND RECORDED WEBINARS, WILL INFORM AND RAISE AWARENESS OF THE MUSEUM STAFF, MEMBERS, AND ONSITE AND VIRTUAL AUDIENCES ABOUT THE PROJECT'S PROGRESS.

THE UNIVERSITY MUSEUM AT SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY WILL IMPROVE ITS COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP BY IMPLEMENTING STAGE II OF THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS INVENTORY PROJECT. DURING STAGE II, MUSEUM STAFF, GRADUATE ASSISTANTS, AND GRANT FUNDED RESEARCH ASSISTANTS WILL INVENTORY APPROXIMATELY 10,000 OBJECTS FROM THE ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS FROM THE CONTINENTS OF SOUTH AMERICA, ASIA, AFRICA AND OCEANIA. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE IDENTIFYING AND RECORDING UNDOCUMENTED OBJECTS FOUND IN THESE COLLECTIONS, COMPLETING DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHIC DOCUMENTATION, IMPROVING BASIC STORAGE STABILIZATION, AND GATHERING CONDITION INFORMATION FOR EACH OBJECT INVENTORIED. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR INCREASED INTELLECTUAL CONTROL AND PRESERVATION OF THE MUSEUM'S ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS AND EXPAND THE ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTIONS AND ASSOCIATED DATA FOR BOTH RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

TO INSPIRE MORE YOUTH TO SEEK CAREERS IN SCIENCE, THE NORTH CAROLINA MUSEUM OF NATURAL SCIENCES IS ADDING A NEW, PERMANENT PALEONTOLOGY EXHIBITION, "DUELING DINOSAURS," AND A PUBLIC LAB THAT WILL ALLOW MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS TO EXPLORE A VARIETY OF FOSSILS USING HANDS-ON TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES. THE EXHIBITION, WHICH WILL INCLUDE THE FOSSILS OF A TYRANNOSAURUS REX AND TRICERATOPS FOUND INTERTWINED AND THOUGHT TO HAVE DIED IN AN APPARENT PREDATOR-PREY BATTLE, WILL DEMONSTRATE HOW FOSSILS ARE KEY EVIDENCE USED BY SCIENTISTS TO UNDERSTAND LIFE ON A CHANGING PLANET. STUDENTS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN INTERACTIVE EXERCISES THAT REPLICATE SCIENTIFIC PROCESSES AND PROCEDURES, AND AS THEY LEARN, SEE POSSIBLE CAREER PATHS FOR THEMSELVES AS SCIENTISTS.

THE BISHOP MUSEUM IN HONOLULU WILL DIGITIZE THE FRANCIS G. HOWARTH AND FREDERICK D. STONE HAWAIIAN CAVE ARTHROPOD COLLECTIONS, WHICH INCLUDES NEARLY 40,000 SPECIMENS AND ASSOCIATED RECORDS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A DIGITIZATION TECHNICIAN AND STUDENT INTERNS TO WORK WITH THE ENTOMOLOGY COLLECTIONS MANAGER, PURCHASING DIGITIZATION EQUIPMENT, PURCHASING NEW JARS AND VIALS TO REHOUSE THE SPECIMENS, AND COLLABORATING WITH HOWARTH AND OTHER CAVE BIOLOGISTS TO IDENTIFY SPECIMENS. THE MUSEUM WILL ENTER THE SPECIMEN DATA AND FIELD NOTEBOOKS INTO A BIOLOGICAL COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP A SERIES OF COLLECTION STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES TO INCLUDE PROTOCOLS FOR DIGITIZING FIELD NOTEBOOKS, IMAGING AND DATA CAPTURE, AND COLLECTION PLANS. A CHECKLIST OF SPECIES WILL BE GENERATED FROM THE COLLECTION DATABASE AND THE 40,000 DIGITIZED SPECIMENS WILL BE PROPERLY HOUSED, LABELED, AND STORED IN THE MAIN COLLECTION AREA.

THE TRUSTEES OF RESERVATIONS WILL IMPROVE AND EXPAND ACCESS TO THEIR COLLECTIONS AND ARCHIVES THROUGH AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CATALOGUING FINE ARTS COLLECTIONS THAT WERE RECENTLY ACQUIRED, AND PROCESSING AND CATALOGUING ARCHIVAL MATERIALS. DEDICATED CURATORIAL FELLOWS AND A PROJECT ARCHIVIST WILL BE HIRED TO COMPLETE THIS WORK. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE AN INTEGRATED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM THAT INCLUDES OBJECTS AND ARCHIVES ACROSS TWO DISTINCT MUSEUM COLLECTIONS, COMPLETE OBJECT RECORDS INCLUDING PHOTOGRAPHS FOR 75% OF EACH SITE'S COLLECTION, AND A SEARCHABLE ONLINE COLLECTIONS CATALOGUE ACCESSIBLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE LONGWOOD CENTER FOR THE VISUAL ARTS WILL INCREASE COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP AND ACCESS, AS WELL AS UNDERGO A SIGNIFICANT STORAGE SPACE RENOVATION. THE MUSEUM WILL INSTALL A NEW MOBILE ART STORAGE SYSTEM THAT WILL PROVIDE FOR OPTIMAL PRESERVATION AND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION OF 4,500 PIECES OF AMERICAN ART IN ALL MEDIA AND DISCIPLINES FROM THE 19TH CENTURY TO PRESENT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON MODERN AND CONTEMPORARY VIRGINIA ARTISTS. THE MUSEUM’S SPATIAL CONSTRAINTS HAVE BEEN A LONG-TERM ISSUE; THIS SYSTEM WILL DOUBLE THE USABLE SPACE WITHIN THE EXISTING STORAGE AREA AND ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO CONVERT THE SPACE INTO A COLLECTIONS PROCESSING AREA. BY THE END OF THE PROJECT, COLLECTIONS WILL BE FULLY REHOUSED AND STORED IN THE OPTIMAL ENVIRONMENT; STAFF WILL INCREASE EFFICIENCY AND PRODUCTIVITY WHEN ACCESSING COLLECTIONS; AND COLLECTIONS WILL BE MORE ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCH, COLLECTIONS PROGRAMMING, AND INTERINSTITUTIONAL LOANS.

THE ELGIN AREA HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL DIGITIZE 1,185 IMAGES OF UNDERREPRESENTED PEOPLE IN ELGIN AND MAKE THE DIGITAL FILES AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE AND THROUGH THE ILLINOIS DIGITAL ARCHIVES. MUSEUM VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST WITH SCANNING THE IMAGES AND UPLOADING THEM TO THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. CONSERVATION EFFORTS WILL ALSO INCLUDE PRESERVATION OF AT LEAST 100 DETERIORATING IMAGES FROM 1936-1938. THE MUSEUM COLLABORATED WITH THE GAIL BORDEN PUBLIC LIBRARY, CENTRO DE INFORMACION, ELGIN SPORTS HALL OF FAME, SECOND BAPTIST CHURCH, AND THE LAO-AMERICAN ORGANIZATION IN ELGIN TO IDENTIFY THE MATERIALS TO BE DIGITIZED.

THE IRWIN S. CHANIN SCHOOL OF ARCHITECTURE AT THE COOPER UNION WILL CATALOG, DIGITIZE, AND PROVIDE WEB-BASED ACCESS TO ITS EXHIBITIONS COLLECTION. ENCOMPASSING 45 CUBIC FEET OF ANALOG MATERIAL AND 3.23 TB OF BORN-DIGITAL RECORDS, THE COLLECTION DOCUMENTS THE SCHOOL'S DIVERSE AND INFLUENTIAL PROGRAM DATING FROM THE MID-1960S TO THE PRESENT, INCLUDING 219 EXHIBITIONS AND 32 PUBLICATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE SCHOOL'S STRATEGIC GOAL TO FOSTER AND SUSTAIN A VIGOROUS PROGRAM OF EXHIBITIONS AND PUBLICATIONS BY ESTABLISHING INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER THE COLLECTION AND ARCHIVALLY PRESERVING THE COLLECTION. IT WILL ALSO IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN PROFESSIONALS, ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, AND THE SCHOOL'S STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND STAFF.

THE LEVENTHAL MAP AND EDUCATION CENTER WILL MOUNT AN EXHIBITION TITLED "MORE OR LESS IN COMMON: ENVIRONMENT AND JUSTICE THE HUMAN LANDSCAPE," WHICH WILL SHOW HOW ENVIRONMENTAL HARM IS BORNE UNEQUALLY BY DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES. THROUGH THE EXHIBIT THE MUSEUM AIMS TO FOSTER A PLACE-BASED FORM OF ENVIRONMENTAL THINKING THAT IS COUPLED WITH SOCIAL JUSTICE. USING MAPS AS THE PRIMARY MATERIALS, THE EXHIBIT WILL DRAW ATTENTION TO THE ATTEMPTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERS TO PROMOTE EQUITABLE SOCIAL OUTCOMES. THEY WILL COUPLE THE EXHIBITION WITH EDUCATIONAL ELEMENTS FOR STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, DIGITAL INTERACTIVES, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING ACTIVITIES.

THE MICHIGAN SCIENCE CENTER WILL PURCHASE A PORTABLE PLANETARIUM THAT WILL BRING PLANETARIUM SHOWS TO MORE THAN 2,000 CHILDREN THROUGH ITS TRAVELING SCIENCE PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM PLANS TO TAKE THE PROGRAMS TO 10 SCHOOLS AND 8 LIBRARIES IN METRO DETROIT AND 6 LIBRARIES IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN. THEY WILL DELIVER THE PORTABLE PLANETARIUM SHOWS IN COORDINATION WITH THE MUSEUM'S LONG-STANDING "SCOPES IN THE CITY" PROGRAM, WHICH ALLOWS PEOPLE TO USE TELESCOPES TO SEE THE NIGHT SKY. THE PROGRAM ALSO WILL EXPOSE STUDENTS TO MICHIGAN'S GROWING AEROSPACE INDUSTRY AND HELP INCREASE THEIR INTEREST IN EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE.

EXPLORA SCIENCE CENTER AND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF ALBUQUERQUE WILL CONDUCT "ROOTS: SUPPORTING BLACK SCHOLARS IN STEAM," A PROJECT TO INCREASE EXPLORA'S RELATIONSHIPS WITH AND RELEVANCE TO ALBUQUERQUE'S BLACK COMMUNITIES AND INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR BLACK STUDENTS IN ALBUQUERQUE TO PURSUE STEAM. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO FOSTER A HOLISTIC, PLACE-BASED APPROACH TO K-16 STEAM LEARNING THAT INCORPORATES A GROWTH MINDSET AND HIGHLIGHTS THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS, PARTICULARLY BLACK STEAM PROFESSIONALS. THE MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE ON PROJECT ACTIVITIES WITH THE MEXICO BLACK LEADERSHIP COUNCIL, THE GREATER ALBUQUERQUE HOUSING PARTNERSHIP/CASA FELIZ, THE COMMUNITY SCHOOL AT EMERSON ELEMENTARY, AND SANDIA NATIONAL LABORATORIES' BLACK LEADERSHIP COMMITTEE.

THE SPENCER MUSEUM OF ART AT THE UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS WILL REDESIGN ITS WEBSITE TO PROVIDE DEEPER AND ENHANCED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR THE MUSEUM'S MANY COMMUNITIES OF LEARNERS AND RESEARCHERS. THEY WILL ENLIST THE HELP OF A WEBSITE CONSULTING FIRM TO GUIDE STAFF IN RESTRUCTURING AND REORGANIZING THE MUSEUM'S MULTIPLE WEBSITES TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY AND DISCOVERABILITY OF CONTENT. MUSEUM STAFF WILL CONDUCT BETA TESTING WITH KEY AUDIENCE SEGMENTS AND LAUNCH AND PROMOTE THE REDESIGNED WEBSITE. THE NEW ONLINE PLATFORM WILL OFFER DYNAMIC SPACES FOR ENGAGEMENT WITH ART AND IDEAS FOR UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS STUDENTS, K-12 STUDENTS ACROSS KANSAS, AND LIFELONG LEARNERS IN THE MIDWEST AND BEYOND.

THE MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE WILL IMPROVE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT AND ACCESS TO THEIR PERMANENT COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM MAINTAINS A LARGE AND COMPREHENSIVE COLLECTION OF ARTIFACTS RELATING TO THE ART, HISTORY, AND TECHNOLOGY OF THE MOVING IMAGE, COMPRISING APPROXIMATELY 130,000 OBJECTS FROM MOTION PICTURES, TELEVISION, AND DIGITAL MEDIA. THE PROJECT WILL UPGRADE THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A NEW PUBLIC COLLECTIONS BROWSER, AND CREATE 865 ADDITIONAL PUBLIC-FACING CATALOG RECORDS THAT WILL FACILITATE DIGITAL ACCESS TO A BROADER RANGE OF THEIR HOLDINGS. UPGRADED DIGITAL ACCESS OF ITS COLLECTION WILL EXTEND THE MUSEUM?S REACH TO AUDIENCES AROUND THE COUNTRY AND THE WORLD.

THE WILD CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT ?NATURAL CONNECTIONS: LIFELONG LEARNING THROUGH INCLUSIVE DIGITAL ENGAGEMENT,? A PROGRAM TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR EXPERIENCES IN NATURE THAT PROMOTE NATURE AS A BENEFIT TO MENTAL HEALTH AND SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL WELLBEING. THE MUSEUM PLANS TO CONVENE AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE COMPRISING REPRESENTATIVES OF NY STATE BOARDS OF COOPERATIVE EDUCATION, LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS, THE ROCHESTER MUSEUM OF SCIENCE, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO DEVELOP CONTENT FOR GRADES 3-6, BASED ON THE CURRENT NEEDS OF THE REGION?S RURAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS. THEY ALSO WILL ORGANIZE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS AND DEVELOP NEW VIRTUAL SCHOOL PROGRAMMING THAT INTEGRATES CITIZEN SCIENCE AND HIGHLIGHTS THE MUSEUM?S 115-ACRE CAMPUS, EXHIBITS, AND NATIVE LIVE ANIMAL COLLECTION.

THE DENVER ART MUSEUM PLANS TO IMPLEMENT CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPROVEMENTS IN ITS STORAGE AREA BY INSTALLING 40 NEW STORAGE SCREENS FOR OVERSIZED, TWO-DIMENSIONAL ARTWORKS. DEPARTMENT COLLECTIONS IMPACTED BY THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ASIAN, INDIGENOUS, LATIN AMERICAN, MODERN AND CONTEMPORARY, AND PHOTOGRAPHY. THE PROJECT CONCLUDES A YEAR-LONG EFFORT TO COMPLETE MUSEUM-WIDE STORAGE IMPROVEMENT. OVER A 13-MONTH PERIOD, THE PROJECT INCLUDES PRE-MOVE INVENTORY TASKS, PREPARING ARTWORKS FOR SCREEN STORAGE, REHOUSING ARTWORKS ON THE NEW SCREENS, CREATING NEW LOCATION SYSTEMS FOR THE IMPROVED STORAGE AREA, AND TAKING POST-MOVE INVENTORIES. STORAGE IMPROVEMENTS WILL ENHANCE ACCESS TO ARTWORKS FOR THE VISITING PUBLIC AS WELL AS FOR VISITING RESEARCHERS AND RESIDENT ARTISTS. THEY ALSO WILL INCREASE EFFICIENCY IN ACCESS AND HANDLING, INCREASE CAPACITY FOR ONSITE STORAGE OF OVERSIZED TWO-DIMENSIONAL WORKS, AND ACCOMMODATE GROWTH OF COLLECTIONS RELATED TO STRATEGIC PRIORITIES AND CURATORIAL DIRECTIONS.

THE LOUISIANA CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IS DEVELOPING A COMPREHENSIVE SET OF RESOURCES ENTITLED "WATER DIALOGUES'LIVING WITH WATER," DESIGNED AROUND ITS NEW EXHIBITS AND LANDSCAPE RESOURCES, TO STRENGTHEN THE COMMUNITY'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH WATER MANAGEMENT. THEY ARE CREATING A NEW FIELD TRIP SERIES AND WATER-BASED SCIENCE CURRICULUM, "WATER PATHWAYS" AS WELL AS AN OUTREACH PROGRAM, "STEWARD'S SHIP," TO BRING THE PROGRAM'S ENVIRONMENTAL MESSAGES TO SCHOOLS AND CAMPS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO CONDUCT A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING SERIES ON SCIENCE EDUCATION FOR LOCAL EDUCATORS IMPLEMENTING THE STATE'S NEW SCIENCE STANDARDS, IN ADDITION TO A SERIES OF LITERACY WORKSHOPS WHERE CHILDREN AGES FOUR TO EIGHT WILL WRITE "HOW-TO" BOOKS AND "WATER JOURNALS." TO FURTHER SPREAD THE ASSOCIATED ENVIRONMENTAL AND SUSTAINABILITY MESSAGES, THEY WILL ORGANIZE AN ANNUAL "WATER FEST" PROGRAM FOR THE COMMUNITY.

BRIC ARTS MEDIA BROOKLYN WILL IMPLEMENT ITS CREATIVE FUTURES INITIATIVE, SERVING PRE-K THROUGH 12TH GRADE STUDENTS THROUGH 24 ARTIST RESIDENCIES IN UP TO 12 OF THE MOST POTENTIAL-RICH, YET UNDER-RESOURCED, PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN BROOKLYN. THE MUSEUM'S TEACHING ARTISTS WILL DELIVER ARTS AND MEDIA PROGRAMMING IN CENTRAL BROOKLYN PUBLIC SCHOOLS WHERE THERE ARE NO ART TEACHERS ON STAFF, THE DIGITAL DIVIDE IS ESPECIALLY PRONOUNCED, AND THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS HAD A DISPROPORTIONATE IMPACT ON STUDENT LEARNING AND WELLBEING. STUDENTS ALSO WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN FIELD TRIPS TO VISIT THE BRIC HOUSE GALLERY AND IN FAMILY PROGRAMS WITH ARTIST-LED, HANDS-ON ART-MAKING ACTIVITIES, GAMING AND TECHNOLOGY EXPLORATION, AND LIVE PERFORMANCES.

THE FORT TICONDEROGA MUSEUM WILL UNDERGO A 28-MONTH COLLABORATION WITH INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES TO BETTER DOCUMENT THE CONTEXT, MEANING, AND CONTEMPORARY RELEVANCE OF THEIR COLLECTIONS. THIS INVOLVES TAKING A COMPREHENSIVE INVENTORY AND IMPROVING DOCUMENTATION FOR 28,600 INDIGENOUS ARTIFACTS AND THE 3,155 ARTIFACTS THAT FALL UNDER NATIONAL NATIVE AMERICAN GRAVES PROTECTION AND REPATRIATION ACT. THE MUSEUM ALSO PLANS TO BUILD AND STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE NATIVE TRIBES WHOSE ABORIGINAL LAND INCLUDES FORT TICONDEROGA, DECOLONIZE PREVIOUS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, SHARE AUTHORITY FOR THE DOCUMENTATION AND INTERPRETATION OF NATIVE CULTURE WITH PARTNERING NATIVE TRIBES, UPDATE ARTIFACT STORAGE AND STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES--INCLUDING THE ADDITION OF CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE SIGNAGE AND ACCESS PRIVILEGES--AND CREATE A LONG-TERM STRATEGIC PLAN FOR REPATRIATION, DISPOSITION, AND CARE OF NATIVE COLLECTIONS.

DISCOVERY MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH MASSACHUSETTS CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTION (MCI)-CONCORD AND CONCORD PRISON OUTREACH TO CREATE PLAYFUL LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR YOUNG, INCARCERATED FATHERS (AGES 18-24) TO SHARE WITH THEIR CHILDREN. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP A SET OF ENGAGEMENT KITS THAT WILL INCLUDE ACTIVITIES, MATERIALS, AND RESOURCES DESIGNED TO BUILD FATHERS' KNOWLEDGE OF CHILD DEVELOPMENT AND INCREASE THEIR COMFORT WITH ENGAGING IN POSITIVE EXPERIENCES WITH THEIR CHILDREN. THE PROJECT WILL SERVE 30 INCARCERATED FATHERS LIVING IN A NEWLY OPENED UNIT AT MCI-CONCORD THAT PROVIDES AN ARRAY OF SUPPORTIVE PROGRAMS RESPONSIVE TO THE UNIQUE DEVELOPMENTAL NEEDS OF MEN IN THAT AGE RANGE.

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN (BBG) WILL EXPAND ITS INTERPRETIVE MASTER PLAN TO INCLUDE A BROADER CROSS-SECTION OF PERSPECTIVES AND HELP MOVE THE INSTITUTION TOWARD ITS GOAL OF BECOMING A MORE INCLUSIVE AND WELCOMING URBAN MUSEUM. BASED ON COLLABORATIVE WORK WITH COMMUNITY ROUNDTABLE GROUPS AND CURATORIAL ADVISERS WHO HAVE CONTENT-SPECIFIC EXPERTISE (SUCH AS FOLKLORISTS AND ETHNOBOTANISTS), BBG WILL DEVELOP FOUR TO SIX PROTOTYPES OF KEY STORIES AND THEMES THAT WILL RESONATE WITH VISITORS. THEY WILL TRAIN STAFF AND DOCENTS ON INCLUSIVE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND STORYTELLING ABOUT THE GARDEN'S HISTORY AND COLLECTIONS.

THE HISTORIC OAKLAND FOUNDATION WILL DEVELOP A PROGRAM THAT ENHANCES ITS DIVERSITY, EQUITY, ACCESSIBILITY, AND INCLUSION (DEAI) PRACTICE TO BETTER SERVE ITS SURROUNDING COMMUNITY. THE ORGANIZATION WILL ENGAGE A CONSULTANT TO FACILITATE THE PROJECT IN THREE PHASES. THE FIRST PHASE WILL FOCUS INTERNALLY ON STAFF, VOLUNTEERS, AND THE BOARD TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES, DEVELOP A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF DEAI CONCEPTS, AND ESTABLISH A SOLID FOUNDATION ON WHICH TO BUILD A BROADER DEAI PRACTICE. THE SECOND AND THIRD PHASES WILL ENGAGE EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC TO BECOME AN ACTIVE PART OF THE FOUNDATION'S ORGANIZATIONAL CHANGE. THE FOUNDATION WILL DEVELOP NEW INTERNAL GUIDELINES, A TOOLKIT THAT CAN BE SHARED WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS, AND A FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM TO INTRODUCE STUDENTS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS TO MUSEUM CAREERS.

THE MARITIME AQUARIUM WILL IMPLEMENT A PROJECT TO ENERGIZE TEENS AND EQUIP THEM TO BECOME COMMUNITY LEADERS DRIVING DISCUSSION AND ACTION TO REDUCE MARINE DEBRIS. "MARINE DEBRIS PREVENTION CORPS: EMPOWERING TEEN CHANGE AGENTS" WILL DRIVE A LOCAL CULTURE CHANGE AROUND THE USE AND DISPOSAL OF LOCAL MARINE DEBRIS ITEMS. THEY PLAN TO PROVIDE A GROUP OF 100 TEENS REPRESENTING THE DIVERSITY OF NORWALK AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES WITH TRAINING AND TOOLS TO BECOME EDUCATORS AND ADVOCATES. TRAINERS FROM THE HARWOOD INSTITUTE WILL LEAD A TWO-AND-A-HALF DAY PUBLIC INNOVATORS LAB, WHICH WILL INCLUDE GROUP PROJECTS WITH APPLICATIONS TO REAL-WORLD SCENARIOS. THE EXPERIENCE WILL EQUIP PARTICIPATING TEENS TO SPEARHEAD COMMUNITY ACTIVITIES THAT WILL HAVE A MEANINGFUL IMPACT ON NORWALK'S SHORE AND WATERWAYS.

THE CONNECTICUT HISTORICAL SOCIETY PLANS TO CREATE A NEW PUBLIC-FACING INITIATIVE, THE COMMUNITY HISTORIAN PROJECT. THIS CONTEMPORARY COLLECTING PROJECT-WHICH GATHERS ITEMS OF THE RECENT PAST AS WELL AS FROM EVENTS HAPPENING TODAY-WILL DEVELOP COMMUNITY HISTORIANS TO IDENTIFY, DOCUMENT, AND PRESERVE THEIR EXPERIENCES AS RESIDENTS OF CONNECTICUT, AND SHARE THESE EXPERIENCES DURING A SERIES OF COMMUNITY PRESENTATIONS. IN COLLABORATION WITH CENTRAL CONNECTICUT STATE UNIVERSITY, THE CONNECTICUT DIGITAL ARCHIVE, AND PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN HARTFORD, NEW HAVEN, AND NORWICH, THIS INITIATIVE ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR CONTEMPORARY COLLECTING IN AND THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THE MUSEUM SEEKS TO PROVIDE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF CONNECTICUT RESIDENTS' LIVED HISTORY, IMPROVE EDUCATION AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES FOR CENTRAL CONNECTICUT STATE UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE MUSEUM AND CONNECTICUT RESIDENTS, AND BUILD A MORE DIVERSE COLLECTION AT THE MUSEUM THAT REFLECTS CONNECTICUT'S DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES.

THE MUSEUM OF ART AND HISTORY AT THE MCPHERSON CENTER WILL PRODUCE AN EXHIBIT FOCUSING ON INDIGENOUS PEOPLE AND PERSPECTIVES WITHIN CONVERSATIONS AROUND SOCIO-ECOLOGICAL CHALLENGES. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE AMAH MUTSUN TRIBAL BAND, THE AMAH MUTSUN LAND TRUST AND ITS YOUNG ADULT NATIVE STEWARDSHIP CORPS, AND THE AMAH MUTSUN RELEARNING PROGRAM AT UC SANTA CRUZ, THE EXHIBIT WILL SEEK TO CREATE SPACE FOR ONGOING CONVERSATIONS AROUND COMMUNITY AND CREATIVE ECOLOGIES TO HELP VISITORS LEARN, CONNECT, HEAL, AND GROW BEYOND SOCIETAL CHALLENGES. IT ALSO WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, DISPEL MISUNDERSTANDING, AND ADVANCE INITIATIVES OF THE AMAH MUTSUN TRIBAL BAND, WHICH SUFFERS FROM HISTORICAL TRAUMA AND MARGINALIZATION. THE 3-YEAR PROJECT INCLUDES TWO PHASES OF COLLABORATOR-DRIVEN PROGRAMMING AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY ART COMMISSIONS-THE FIRST EMPHASIZING LOCAL INDIGENOUS CULTURE, AND THE SECOND CONNECTING INTO BROADER INDIGENOUS EXPERIENCES.

THE GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY MUSEUM AND TEXTILE MUSEUM, WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO ITS GLOBAL CULTURAL HERITAGE COLLECTIONS BY DIGITIZING 4,000 TEXTILES CREATED IN THE MIDDLE EAST, ASIA, AFRICA, AND THE AMERICAS. THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE HIGH-QUALITY DIGITAL IMAGES AND COMPREHENSIVE OBJECT DATA AVAILABLE THROUGH ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND ITS ACCOMPANYING ONLINE PORTAL, WHICH WILL FACILITATE AND IMPROVE COLLECTION ACCESS BY THE MUSEUM STAFF, FACULTY, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL SHARE THE COLLECTION THROUGH AGGREGATOR SITES TO EXPAND DISCOVERABILITY OF THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL ASSEMBLE A DIGITIZATION TEAM CONSISTING OF A PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHER, AS WELL AS GRADUATE STUDENT ASSISTANTS WHO WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE WORKING IN A MUSEUM THROUGH OBJECT HANDLING, CATALOGING, AND DISSEMINATION ACTIVITIES.

SAN DIEGO ZOO WILL BRING WILD AT HEART, AN INQUIRY-BASED SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL LEARNING PROGRAM FOR ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS, TO MORE THAN 11,000 KINDERGARTEN AND 1ST GRADE STUDENTS FROM TITLE I SCHOOLS OVER A THREE-YEAR PERIOD, AT NO COST TO THE SCHOOLS. THEY WILL IMPLEMENT THE PROGRAM IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE OPENING OF THE SAN DIEGO ZOO?S NEW CHILDREN?S ZOO, WHICH IS DESIGNED AROUND A GUIDING THEME OF INSPIRING EMPATHY IN CHILDREN. IT WILL OFFER A UNIQUE EXPERIENCE TO STUDENTS NOT PRESENTLY AVAILABLE IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY SCHOOLS. THE STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN A WILD AT HEART CLASSROOM PROGRAM AT THEIR SCHOOLS AND IN A GUIDED FIELD TRIP TO THE SAN DIEGO ZOO.

THE ACADEMY OF NATURAL SCIENCES OF PHILADELPHIA WILL DIGITIZE AND PRESERVE YEARS OF FIELD RECORDINGS OF GRASSHOPPER AND CRICKET SONGS (ORTHOPTERA), MAKING THEM AVAILABLE FOR SCIENTISTS, STUDENTS, AND INTERESTED VISITORS. THESE REEL-TO-REEL AND AUDIOCASSETTE FIELD RECORDINGS FEATURE INSECTS IN THEIR NATURAL HABITATS FROM THE 1960S TO THE 1990S, INCLUDING IN THREATENED AND DISAPPEARING HABITATS IN THE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS, THE AMERICAN WEST AND AFRICA. THE PROJECT SUPPORTS THE HIRING OF A CURATORIAL ASSISTANT AS WELL AS AND 5 FULL-TIME CO-OP POSITIONS FOR DREXEL UNIVERSITY UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AS PART OF THE COLLABORATION WITH THE DREXEL UNIVERSITY WESTPHAL COLLEGE OF MEDIA ARTS AND DESIGN SOUND LAB TO DIGITIZE THE ANALOG TAPES. THE SPECIES DATA WILL THEN BE ADDED TO AN OPEN-SOURCE CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO BE USED TO INFORM FUTURE EDUCATIONAL INITIATIVES FOCUSING ON BIODIVERSITY, EVOLUTION, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND THE IMPORTANCE OF NON-TRADITIONAL COLLECTIONS.

THE MUSEUM OF ANTHROPOLOGY, HISTORY AND ART OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO PLANS TO RELOCATE AND REHOUSE ARTIFACTS RECOVERED FROM ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATIONS BY THE CENTER OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESEARCH. THE COLLECTION IS THE LARGEST AND MOST COMPLETE COLLECTION OF ARCHEOLOGICAL OBJECTS IN PUERTO RICO AND THE ENTIRE CARIBBEAN REGION. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE STORAGE SYSTEM THAT WILL HOUSE THE COLLECTION. THIS REHOUSING WILL INCREASE CAPACITY OF THE CENTER'S STORAGE AREA, SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS, PROTECT AND CONSERVE THE INTEGRITY AND ACCESSIBILITY OF COLLECTIONS, AND INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH. THE PROJECT WILL PROMOTE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTION AND WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO RESPOND TO A GROWING DEMAND FOR ACCESS TO THE OBJECTS FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH PURPOSES.

THE NEW YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL CENTRALIZE STORAGE AND IMPROVE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF THE MUSEUM'S LANDMARK AMERICAN PAINTINGS COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM SEEKS TO INSTALL 23 LARGE-SCALE PAINTING SCREENS THAT WILL HOUSE MORE THAN 400 PAINTINGS--INCLUDING MASTERPIECES FROM THE COLLECTION AND A NEW ACQUISITION OF MORE THAN 100 WORKS FROM THE ROBERT L. STUART COLLECTION THAT DOCUMENT AND INTERPRET NEW YORK CITY'S HISTORY. STUART (1806-1882) WAS A SUGAR MERCHANT AND FOUNDER OF THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY. THIS EXPANDED STORAGE CAPABILITY WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO MOVE WORKS FROM SPACES WITH INFERIOR CONDITIONS TO A NEW MODERN FACILITY THAT IS MANAGED BY THE MUSEUM'S STAFF. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE CONDITION ASSESSMENT AND PHOTOGRAPHY OF THE WORKS, THEREBY IMPROVING COLLECTIONS DATA AND ENHANCING THE ONLINE PRESENTATION OF THE COLLECTION.

THE MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE REHOUSING SUPPLIES AND APPROPRIATE HOUSING EQUIPMENT TO IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS FOR A LARGE AND DIVERSE COLLECTION OF APPAREL AND TEXTILES THAT ARE USED FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH. THE INCOMING COLLECTION INCLUDES NUMEROUS TYPES AND ERAS OF CLOTHING NOT FOUND IN THE EXISTING COLLECTION, WITH MANY ITEMS REPRESENTATIVE OF CLOTHING WORN BY MICHIGAN WOMEN AT HOME, AT SCHOOL, IN THE WORKPLACE, AND IN LEISURE ACTIVITIES FROM 1810 TO THE EARLY 1990S. THE MUSEUM PLANS TO HIRE AN EMERGING PROFESSIONAL AS A PROJECT ASSISTANT FOR THE TWO-YEAR PROJECT, AS WELL AS FOUR STUDENT INTERNS FOR EACH OF THE SIX SEMESTERS TO ASSIST WITH PHOTOGRAPHY, CATALOGING, NUMBERING, AND REHOUSING OF THE APPROXIMATELY 3000 PIECES.

THE DENVER ART MUSEUM WILL STRENGTHEN ITS EARLY CHILDHOOD (EC) ART AND CREATIVITY PROGRAMS ONSITE AND IN THE COMMUNITY. THEY WILL START BY ESTABLISHING AN EARLY CHILDHOOD PARTICIPANT ACTION GROUP THAT IS COMPOSED OF VARIOUS EC STAKEHOLDERS. THE ACTION GROUP WILL SUPPORT THE CO-CREATION OF NEW EC PROGRAMMATIC ELEMENTS OF THE MUSEUM'S ART LIVES HERE/EL ARTE VIVE AQU -- AN IN-COMMUNITY MINI-EXHIBITION PROGRAM THAT LIVES IN SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY CENTERS FOR A MONTH AND INCORPORATES TAILORED PROGRAMMING TO SUPPORT CROSS-CURRICULUM LEARNING. A NEW ONSITE EC INNOVATIVE TEACHING INCUBATOR AND LEARNING LAB WILL SUPPORT PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR EC STAKEHOLDERS AND DIRECT PROGRAMMING FOR EARLY LEARNERS IN A DEDICATED EARLY CHILDHOOD CLASSROOM.

THE SCIENCE MUSEUM OF MINNESOTA WILL UNDERTAKE A TWO-YEAR PROJECT THAT WILL INCLUDE THE DIGITIZATION OF THE WANNAGAN CREEK FOSSIL COLLECTION AND ALL SPECIMEN DATA. THE COLLECTION REPRESENTS A CRITICAL RECOVERY PHASE FOR LIFE SHORTLY AFTER THE MASS EXTINCTION THAT ENDED THE AGE OF THE DINOSAURS, INCLUDING PLANTS, VERTEBRATES, AND INVERTEBRATES. THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE A PHOTO OF EACH SPECIMEN PUBLICLY AVAILABLE AND PUBLISH DIGITAL VERSIONS OF FIELD NOTES, ACCESSION RECORDS, AND OTHER PUBLICATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR BROADER AND EASIER PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT BOTH ONLINE AND IN-PERSON. DIGITIZATION OF THIS COLLECTION WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF ITS CONTENT AND ALLOW THE PUBLIC TO LEARN FROM AND APPRECIATE ITS VALUE.

THE MCWANE SCIENCE CENTER (MWSC) WILL CREATE A NEW EXHIBITION EXPERIENCE ENTITLED "DROPPING SCIENCE: HIP-HOP INTERACTIVE" THAT WILL CAPTURE THE ELEMENTS OF THE POPULAR MUSIC GENRE USING INTERPRETIVE EXPERIENCES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE EXHIBIT CONTENT DEVELOPMENT; DEVELOPMENT OF A FORMAL EVALUATION PLAN; EXHIBIT PROTOTYPING; REMEDIAL EVALUATION, AND A FINAL EXHIBIT DESIGN PLAN. AN IMPORTANT PROJECT GOAL IS TO DEVELOP THE PROCESS FOR CREATING LASTING, RECIPROCAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE LOCAL AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY AND THROUGHOUT THE REGION, THUS CREATING AN EXHIBIT SPACE THAT CONNECTS UNDERREPRESENTED AUDIENCES TO STEM AND ESTABLISHES MWSC AS A TRUE COMMUNITY PARTNER. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A NEW INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCE THAT WAS CO-DEVELOPED WITH AND REPRESENTATIVE OF MWSC'S LOCAL COMMUNITY THAT HELPS MWSC CONNECT WITH AND ENGAGE LOCAL VISITORS IN SCIENCE THROUGH A MORE CULTURALLY AND PERSONALLY RELEVANT LENS.

THE HIGH MUSEUM OF ART PLANS TO BUILD FOUNDATIONAL SUPPORT FOR THEIR CREATIVE AGING AND LIFELONG LEARNING INITIATIVE. WITH THE EXPECTED NUMBER OF METRO ATLANTA RESIDENTS AGE 60 AND ABOVE EXPECTED TO GROW TO 1.2 MILLION BY 2030, THE MUSEUM SEEKS TO BECOME A COMMUNITY ANCHOR AND CATALYST FOR OLDER ATLANTANS TO EXPERIENCE A MORE FULFILLING AGING PROCESS-ONE DEFINED BY CREATIVITY, SOCIAL CONNECTION, AND CONTINUED GROWTH. THE PROJECT WILL HELP THE MUSEUM TO SERVE AS A HUB FOR CROSS-SECTORAL CONVERSATIONS ON ARTS AND AGING. WORKING WITH KEY COMMUNITY PARTNERS, THE MUSEUM WILL BUILD ON THEIR FOUNDATIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS TO PILOT NEW PROGRAMS, BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY, FURTHER THEIR AUDIENCE RESEARCH, AND SPEARHEAD THE FORMATION OF A PROFESSIONAL NETWORK OF ARTS AND HEALTH PROFESSIONALS TO ADVANCE THIS WORK LOCALLY AND NATIONALLY.

THE GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY WILL IMPLEMENT ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMMING FOR MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS IN NEW YORK CITY, PROVIDING THEM WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN HOW TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PROGRAM EXPANDS GREEN-WOOD'S EXISTING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND BRINGS OUTDOOR, HANDS-ON OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT TO NEW YORK CITY STUDENTS, WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS ON SOUTH BROOKLYN. THE NEW EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL SERVE APPROXIMATELY 2,000 STUDENTS PER SCHOOL YEAR. PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON ECOSYSTEMS AND BIODIVERSITY: POLLINATOR GARDENS; CLIMATE CHANGE: GREEN-WOOD AND THE "HEAT ISLAND" EFFECT; AND EVOLUTION AND ADAPTATION: NATIVE AND INVASIVE SPECIES AT GREEN-WOOD. GREEN-WOOD PLANS TO SUPPLEMENT VISITS TO THE MUSEUM WITH PRE- AND POST-VISIT ACTIVITIES THAT TEACHERS CAN USE IN THEIR CLASSROOMS.

THE CITY OF BOSTON ARCHAEOLOGY LABORATORY WILL DIGITIZE AND MAKE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE THE ARTIFACTS FROM FOUR EARLY 17TH CENTURY BOSTON ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES AHEAD OF THE CELEBRATIONS OF BOSTON'S 400TH ANNIVERSARY IN 2030. THE COLLECTIONS TOTAL APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ARTIFACTS AND DATE TO 1630-1650. THEY WERE EXCAVATED IN THE 1980S BUT HAVE NEVER BEEN FULLY INVENTORIED OR CATALOGED, MEANING THEIR FULL RESEARCH POTENTIAL HAS NOT BEEN REALIZED. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DIGITALIZE THE COLLECTIONS, CREATE ONLINE CATALOGUES AND ARTIFACT IMAGE DATABASES AND COLLECTION WEBPAGES, AND PRODUCE BOTH WEB AND IN-PERSON EXHIBITS TO MAKE THE COLLECTIONS ACCESSIBLE FOR THE FIRST TIME TO RESEARCHERS, OTHER MUSEUMS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL IMPLEMENT "SLAM DUNK," A MULTIDISCIPLINARY INITIATIVE CENTERED AROUND DUNKLEOSTEUS TERRELLI, THE LARGEST PREDATOR AND ONE OF THE FIERCEST CREATURES ALIVE IN THE DEVONIAN "AGE OF FISHES," AND FOR WHICH THE MUSEUM HOLD THE BEST-PRESERVED FOSSILS. EACH EAST CLEVELAND CITY SCHOOLS KINDERGARTEN, 1ST GRADE, AND 2ND GRADE CLASS WILL VISIT THE MUSEUM FOR EXTENDED PROGRAMMING TWICE EACH SCHOOL YEAR. MUSEUM EDUCATORS WILL VISIT CLASSROOMS THREE TIMES EACH SCHOOL YEAR. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH EAST CLEVELAND TEACHERS ON PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OFFERINGS TO INCREASE TEACHERS' COMFORT LEVEL WORKING WITH SCIENCE CONTENT. EACH SCHOOL WILL RECEIVE AN EDUCATOR RESOURCE CENTER MEMBERSHIP ALONG WITH BOOKS AND STEM MATERIALS. THE MUSEUM WILL ORGANIZE A FAMILY DAY AT THE MUSEUM EACH SPRING AND PROVIDE SCHOLARSHIPS FOR RISING 3RD GRADE STUDENTS TO ATTEND THE MUSEUM'S WEEK-LONG SUMMER CAMPS.

COASTAL MAINE BOTANICAL GARDENS WILL IMPLEMENT A 36-MONTH PROJECT, "A GARDEN THAT BUILDS COMMUNITY, A COMMUNITY THAT GARDENS: GROWING HORTICULTURE FOR A SUSTAINABLE FUTURE," AIMED AT EXPANDING HORTICULTURE'S ROLE IN THE COMMUNITY. THEY WILL ESTABLISH A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE TO ADDRESS AN URGENT REGIONAL COMMUNITY NEED FOR NEW CAREER PATHS AND TRAINED RECRUITS IN SUSTAINABLE HORTICULTURE. THE BOTANICAL GARDENS WILL LEVERAGE ITS COLLECTIONS, STAFF, FACILITIES, AND PARTNERSHIPS TO PROVIDE COMMUNITY-DRIVEN, CO-CREATED PROFESSIONAL TRAINING IN ASPECTS OF CONSUMER HORTICULTURE AND TO CREATE TRUSTED SPACES FOR COMMUNITY LEARNING. THEY WILL CREATE THREE INDEPENDENT COMMUNITY CATALYST TRACKS, FOCUSING ON EXPERIENTIAL EDUCATION FOR YOUTH, ADVANCED STUDIES IN HORTICULTURE FOR LANDSCAPERS, DESIGN PROFESSIONALS, AND OTHER PRACTITIONERS, AND COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE DEVELOPMENT FOR HORTICULTURAL THERAPY.

HIGH DESERT MUSEUM WILL GATHER EXPERTS FROM ACROSS THE REGION TO DEVELOP DESIGN PLANS FOR A NEW 4,500 SQUARE-FOOT PERMANENT EXHIBIT ENTITLED "CREATING TOGETHER", TO HELP VISITORS BETTER UNDERSTAND THE INDIGENOUS PLATEAU REGION, ANCESTRAL HOMELAND OF MANY INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES AND PLATEAU TRIBES. A COMPREHENSIVE EXHIBIT PLAN WILL BE CREATED, INCLUDING A DETAILED NARRATIVE OF THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE, DESIGN DOCUMENTS, AND A SCRIPT. THE MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH NATIVE PEOPLE FROM ACROSS THE REGION TO ENSURE INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE AND PERSPECTIVES ARE INTEGRATED INTO THE DESIGN PLANS. IMMERSIVE MULTISENSORY EXPERIENCES, NATIVE LANGUAGES, AND INTERACTIVE COMPONENTS WILL ENABLE VISITORS TO EXPERIENCE THE POWER OF THE INDIGENOUS PLATEAU WORLDVIEW, TRANSFORMING HOW THEY VIEW THE REGION AND THEIR POSITION IN IT AND CULTIVATING CRITICAL REFLECTIONS ABOUT THEIR OWN WORLDVIEWS AND DIFFERENT WAYS OF KNOWING.

THE AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM WILL UPGRADE ITS COLLECTIONS STORAGE INFRASTRUCTURE AND IMPROVE ACCESS TO OBJECTS AND ARCHIVAL MATERIAL, ALLOWING FOR THE FUTURE EXPANSION AND GROWTH OF THE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON STORAGE FOR MORE THAN 500 OBJECTS AND OVER 700 FEET OF ARCHIVAL MATERIALS THROUGH AN UPGRADE TO MOBILE STORAGE UNITS AND THE ADDITION OF PAINTING RACKS AND FLAT FILES. IMPLEMENTED OVER TWO YEARS, THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS FOR SCHOLARS, RESEARCHERS, CURATORS, AND OTHER CONSTITUENTS. IT ALSO WILL ENHANCE THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY TO CARE MORE EFFECTIVELY FOR THEIR HOLDINGS WHILE BUILDING A SUSTAINABLE FOUNDATION FOR THE FUTURE GROWTH OF THE COLLECTION.

THE MONTSHIRE MUSEUM OF SCIENCE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FAMILY PLACE WILL FACILITATE THE PROGRAM "FAMILIES LEARNING TOGETHER: STRENGTHENING A LOCAL SYSTEM OF SUPPORT FOR STEM LEARNING" FOR YOUNG PARENTS AND THEIR CHILDREN. INFORMED BY A PILOT PARTNERSHIP, THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE FAMILIES WITH HANDS-ON MATH AND SCIENCE INSTRUCTION AND INFORMAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. PROGRAMMING FOR YOUNG PARENTS AGES 15 TO 25 WILL DEVELOP THEIR RELEVANT ACADEMIC KNOWLEDGE AND CORE LIFE SKILLS TO PREPARE THEM FOR PARENTHOOD AND THE WORKPLACE. PARTICIPATING FAMILIES WILL RECEIVE FREE ADMISSION TO ACCESSIBLE EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMMING.

THE FIRST AMENDMENT MUSEUM WILL COMPLETE THE DESIGN OF A PERMANENT EXHIBITION OFFERING VISITORS AN OPPORTUNITY TO BECOME AWARE OF HOW THEY ARE USING THEIR FIRST AMENDMENT FREEDOMS EVERY DAY, TO UNDERSTAND THOSE FREEDOMS, WHERE THEY CAME FROM AND HOW THEY WORK, AND INSPIRE VISITORS TO EXERCISE THEIR FREEDOMS CONSCIOUSLY, INTENTIONALLY, AND EFFECTIVELY IN THEIR DAILY LIVES. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE A CONSULTANT TEAM IN THE DEVELOPING OF A PERMANENT EXHIBITION PLAN FOR 12 ROOMS OF THE HISTORIC GUY P. GANNETT HOUSE, DEVELOPING CONCEPTUAL PLAN INTO FINAL DESIGNS WITH COMPLETE GRAPHIC AND MULTIMEDIA TREATMENTS, INCLUDING PROTOTYPE PRODUCTION OF MULTIMEDIA COMPONENTS. THE EXHIBITION IS INTENDED TO CREATE A VISITOR EXPERIENCE THAT TRANSCENDS THE TRADITIONAL NOTION OF A HISTORIC HOUSE MUSEUM, LEAVES THE FURNITURE BEHIND, AND INTRODUCES VISITORS TO A CONCEPT MUSEUM THAT IS BOTH INSTRUCTIVE AND INSPIRATIONAL.

THE LINDNER CENTER FOR CONSERVATION AND RESEARCH OF ENDANGERED WILDLIFE (CREW) AT THE CINCINNATI ZOO AND BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL CONDUCT A PROGRAM TO IDENTIFY THE REASONS FOR LOW REPRODUCTIVE RATES AMONG POLAR BEARS IN ZOOS AND HELP IMPROVE PROPAGATION AND BREEDING MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE CAPTIVE POPULATION OF POLAR BEARS IS IN DECLINE GLOBALLY AND, IN THE UNITED STATES, ONLY APPROXIMATELY 40 REMAIN IN THE NATION'S ZOOS. WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH THE POLAR BEAR SPECIES SURVIVAL PLAN (SSP) AND ORGANIZATIONS THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES THAT HOUSE POLAR BEARS, SCIENTISTS AT CREW WILL QUANTIFY A SUITE OF HORMONES AND SIGNALING MOLECULES THAT WILL PROVIDE METRICS FOR ASSESSING AND IMPROVING POLAR BEAR REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND WELLNESS. THROUGH OPEN-ACCESS PUBLICATIONS, THE DATA WILL BE ACCESSIBLE AND USEFUL TO VETERINARY AND ANIMAL CARE STAFF, FIELD RESEARCHERS, AND SCIENTISTS HOPING TO LEARN MORE ABOUT POLAR BEAR PHYSIOLOGY AND ALLOWING FOR MORE ADVANCED REPRODUCTIVE DIAGNOSTICS AND AN INCREASE IN REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND NUMBER OF CUBS BORN EACH YEAR.

THE ARIZONA-SONORA DESERT MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THE FLOWING WELLS UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT ON "WE BEE SCIENTISTS," A PROGRAM TO ENGAGE STUDENTS IN GRADES K-6 IN REAL-WORLD SCIENCE BY LEARNING ABOUT BEES-THE MOST IMPORTANT GROUP OF POLLINATORS. THEY PLAN TO CREATE A CURRICULUM AND RELATED ACTIVITIES ALIGNED WITH THE ARIZONA SCIENCE STANDARDS. THE PROGRAM IS AN EXPANSION OF THE TUCSON BEE COLLABORATIVE, WHICH EMPOWERS COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS FROM "K TO GREY" TO CONTRIBUTE TO ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND UNDERSTANDING THROUGH THE STUDY OF NATIVE BEES. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PARTNER WITH PIMA COMMUNITY COLLEGE AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA ON THE PROGRAM, WHICH WILL INVOLVE VOLUNTEERS AND HIGH SCHOOL, COLLEGE, AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS IN DOCUMENTING THE ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY OF NATIVE BEES.

THE EARTH AND MINERAL SCIENCES MUSEUM AND ART GALLERY AT PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL EXPAND STORAGE FURNITURE CAPACITY AND REHOUSE SPECIMENS THAT ARE CURRENTLY HOUSED IN SUBSTANDARD CONDITIONS. THE COLLECTIONS ARE DOCUMENTS OF THE EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRIES OF PENNSYLVANIA AND THE EDUCATION AND RESEARCH CARRIED OUT IN THE COLLEGE SINCE 1896. NEW STORAGE SYSTEMS AND ADDITIONAL DRAWERS FOR EXISTING STORAGE SYSTEMS WILL MAXIMIZE EFFICIENCIES FOR HOUSING THE MUSEUM'S GEOLOGICAL COLLECTION AND BETTER ORGANIZE TWO COLLECTIONS STORAGE ROOMS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL DETERMINE AN EXACT COUNT OF THE OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION; CATALOGUE THEIR CONDITION; DECIDE HOW MUCH SPACE WILL BE REQUIRED TO HOUSE THEM; AND MAKE THEM ACCESSIBLE FOR EXHIBITS, PROGRAMS, RESEARCH, CONSERVATION, CARE, AND MANAGEMENT. INCREASED ACCESS TO ALL COLLECTIONS WILL FOSTER INCREASED USE OF COLLECTIONS IN EXHIBITS, RESEARCH, AND PROGRAMS OF LEARNING AND EXPLORATION.

THE INDIANA UNIVERSITY MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY WILL PURCHASE NEW COMPACT STORAGE FOR THE MUSEUM'S EXTENSIVE ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS CONSISTING OF OVER 30,000 OBJECTS AND 18,000 PHOTOGRAPHS REPRESENTING CULTURES FROM EACH OF THE WORLD'S INHABITED CONTINENTS. PROJECT STAFF WILL INCLUDE 12 PAID STUDENT POSITIONS TO ASSIST WITH UN-PACKING AND REHOUSING THE COLLECTION INTO THE NEW STORAGE SYSTEM. THE NEW STATE-OF-THE-ART COMPACT STORAGE WILL MITIGATE THE COLLECTION'S MOLD ISSUES CAUSED BY THE PREVIOUSLY INADEQUATE STORAGE SPACE. REHOUSING THE COLLECTIONS WILL ALSO HELP FACILITATE A COMPLETE INVENTORY, WHICH WILL RESULT IN EASIER ACCESS FOR RESEARCHERS AND AN ENHANCED VISITOR EXPERIENCE.

THE DELAWARE AND LEHIGH NATIONAL HERITAGE CORRIDOR, ON BEHALF OF THE NATIONAL CANAL MUSEUM, WILL CONDUCT A WALL-TO-WALL INVENTORY OF THE MUSEUM'S MAIN COLLECTIONS STORAGE FACILITY AND PHYSICALLY AND DIGITALLY IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE OBJECTS STORED THERE. THIS THREE-YEAR PROJECT WILL INVENTORY THE COLLECTIONS HOUSED AT THE MUSEUM'S OFFSITE STORAGE FACILITY, RESULTING IN NEW OR UPDATED RECORDS FOR APPROXIMATELY 10,000 OBJECTS WITH DIGITAL IMAGES. COLLECTIONS INCLUDE PERSONNEL AND FINANCIAL RECORDS FROM THE LEHIGH CRANE IRON COLLECTION, THE DIXIE COLLECTION OF 20TH CENTURY DIXIE PRODUCTS AND 16 MM FILMS PRODUCED BY BETHLEHEM STEEL CORPORATION. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME INVENTORY COORDINATOR AND TRAIN THREE INTERNS TO ASSIST WITH THE INVENTORY OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT. THEY HOPE TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE PROJECT AND OF THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS THROUGH REGULAR OUTREACH VIA SOCIAL MEDIA AND OTHER DIGITAL PLATFORMS.

THE NEW CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IS COLLABORATING WITH THE SAN DIEGO UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT TO ADDRESS A CRITICAL SHORTAGE OF FUNDING FOR THE ARTS IN SCHOOLS BY DEVELOPING A SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL LEARNING ARTS EDUCATION CURRICULUM FOR STUDENTS IN GRADES 4 AND 5. THE MUSEUM'S ARTS EDUCATION TEAM WILL WORK WITH THE SCHOOL DISTRICT'S VISUAL AND PERFORMING ARTS DEPARTMENT, TEACHERS FROM A TITLE I SCHOOL, AND AN ARTS THERAPIST TO CREATE IN-PERSON AND HYBRID ONLINE CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION, TEACHER TRAINING MODULES, AND RELATED CURRICULUM MATERIALS. THEY PLAN TO CREATE 18 ONLINE VIDEO LESSONS (NINE PER GRADE) ALONG WITH 16 TEACHER TRAINING MODULES (EIGHT PER GRADE).

NAPLES BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL DOCUMENT, PRESERVE, AND SHARE ITS GROWING COLLECTION OF ENDEMIC AND RARE TROPICAL AND SUBTROPICAL PLANT SPECIES. THE PROJECT SIGNIFICANTLY EXPANDS SEED BANK STORAGE CAPACITY TO STORE 35,000 SEEDS AND WILL ENSURE CONSERVATION OF AND IMPROVED ACCESS TO PLANT SPECIES BY DEVELOPING AS MANY AS 32 PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS, ESTABLISHING UP TO 35 STORAGE PROTOCOLS, AND CATALOGING APPROXIMATELY 150 UNDER-DOCUMENTED SPECIES. THE PROJECT SUPPORTS THE HIRING OF TWO NEW CONSERVATION ASSOCIATES AND A SEEDBANK SPECIALIST WHO WILL DEVELOP LONG-TERM SEED STORAGE AND PLANT PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS IN COLLABORATION WITH CARIBBEAN PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, ENSURING THAT PLANTS ENDEMIC TO THOSE PLACES CAN BE CONSERVED IN THEIR NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS. IN ADDITION, THEY WILL DEVELOP, PUBLISH, AND DISSEMINATE NEW SEED STORAGE AND GERMINATION PROTOCOLS MAKING THEM ACCESSIBLE TO BOTANICAL GARDENS, CONSERVATION SCIENTISTS, AND BOTANISTS WORLDWIDE.

THE CAMERON ART MUSEUM (CAM) WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT THE UNITED STATES COLORED TROOPS (USCT) SCULPTURE INTERPRETATION PROJECT TO ENHANCE CAM'S STANDING AS A TRUSTED CULTURAL GATHERING PLACE FOR COMMUNITY LEARNING, DEBATE, AND DIALOGUE. THE MUSEUM WILL TELL THE STORY OF 1,600 LOCAL SOLDIERS WHO FOUGHT FOR THE UNION AT THE BATTLE OF FORKS ROAD. THE INTERPRETATION OF THE SITE AND THE NEW SCULPTURE OF THE USCT SOLDIERS ON CAM'S GROUNDS BY NORTH CAROLINA ARTIST STEPHEN HAYES WILL SPARK DIALOGUE AND CREATE COMMUNITY CONVERSATIONS CREATING A FULLER UNDERSTANDING OF OUR COMMON HISTORY AND OUR SHARED HUMANITY. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A CULTURAL CURATOR TO DEVELOP PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO INCREASE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. PROJECT OUTCOMES INCLUDE A SERIES OF ART AND SOCIAL JUSTICE PROGRAMS TO BUILD COMMUNITY CONNECTING THE STORIES OF THE USCT WITH MODERN DAY SOCIAL JUSTICE CONCERNS.

THE COMPUTER HISTORY MUSEUM WILL CREATE FOUR ?SPOTLIGHT COLLECTIONS,? EACH CONTAINING 30 ARTIFACTS FOCUSING ON A SPECIFIC THEME RELEVANT TO THE MUSEUM?S ONGOING PROGRAMMING, TO IMPROVE ONLINE COLLECTION ACCESS AND EXPAND THE MUSEUM?S GLOBAL REACH. THE 30 ARTIFACTS IN EACH SPOTLIGHT COLLECTION WILL BE PROCESSED WITH MACHINE-LEARNING SOFTWARE, ENHANCING SEARCHABILITY AND DISCOVERABILITY WITHIN EACH SPOTLIGHT COLLECTION; USERS WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO SEARCH BETWEEN SPOTLIGHT COLLECTIONS TO FIND UNEXPECTED CONNECTIONS AND LINKS. THE SPOTLIGHT COLLECTIONS WILL BE AVAILABLE THROUGH LINKS PLACED ON THE MUSEUM?S BROADER PUBLIC COLLECTIONS SEARCH WEBPAGE. THESE COLLECTIONS WILL ESTABLISH A GO-TO SOFTWARE PLATFORM FOR STREAMLINED DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE COLLECTIONS, AS WELL AS INFORM AN APPROACH AND PROCESS FOR EXPANDING THE USE OF MACHINE LEARNING ACROSS THE MUSEUM?S ONLINE COLLECTION ACCESS PLATFORM.

THE MUSEUM OF US WILL REIMAGINE THE EXHIBIT, "RACE: ARE WE SO DIFFERENT" AND PROVIDE COMPLEMENTARY EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. CREATED BY THE AMERICAN ANTHROPOLOGY ASSOCIATION AND THE SCIENCE MUSEUM OF MINNESOTA IN 2007, THE EXHIBIT EXPOSES THE ORIGINS OF SYSTEMIC RACISM BY HELPING VISITORS VIEW THE TOPIC THROUGH THE LENSES OF BIOLOGY, SOCIAL HISTORY, AND PERSONAL IDENTITY. DESIGNED TO MEET COMMUNITY NEEDS, THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE MUSEUM'S CULTURE OF COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND SERVE AS A FRAMEWORK FOR COMMUNITY-CENTRIC ACTIVITIES, TOURS, WORKSHOPS, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A COMMUNITY CO-CURATED COMPREHENSIVE EXHIBIT CONTENT PLAN THAT INCLUDES A NEW EXHIBIT SCRIPT, UPDATED AND NEW INTERACTIVE ELEMENTS, AND A PRELIMINARY EXHIBIT DESIGN.

THE LOUISIANA ART & SCIENCE MUSEUM (LASM) WILL CONDUCT A THREE-YEAR PROGRAM, ?HEALTHY AGING WITH LASM,? WHICH WILL SERVE SENIOR ADULTS IN THE 11-PARISH CAPITAL REGION. THE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT THE PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CAPITAL AREA AGENCY ON AGING, THE EAST BATON ROUGE PARISH COUNCIL ON AGING, THE BATON ROUGE GENERAL ARTS IN MEDICINE PROGRAM, AND DR. REBECCA BARTLETT. SENIOR ADULTS HAVE FACED UNPRECEDENTED LEVELS OF ISOLATION, STRESS, AND HEALTH RISK DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL PRESENT VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON ART AND SCIENCE PROGRAMMING DESIGNED TO COMBAT ISOLATION, FOSTER MEANINGFUL CONNECTIONS, AND PROMOTE HEALTHY AGING. PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS, DISTRIBUTION OF ARTS AND SCIENCE VIRTUAL REALITY HEADSETS, AND A SERIES OF HANDS-ON ARTS WORKSHOPS.

THE MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS, HOUSTON, IN COOPERATION WITH AREA SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS, WILL DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED SET OF VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON LEARNING ACTIVITIES THAT ADDRESS ACADEMICS, SOCIAL LEARNING, CULTURAL INCLUSION, AND PROFESSIONAL TRAINING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP VIRTUAL SCHOOL TOURS, INSTRUCTIONAL ART-MAKING VIDEOS, AND TRAINING MATERIALS FOR EDUCATORS, AS WELL AS CREATE ONLINE LEARNING ACTIVITIES AND MATERIALS FOR STUDENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES. THROUGH ONLINE TRAININGS AND MULTILINGUAL MATERIALS, FAMILIES WILL GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF K-12 CLASSROOM EXPECTATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL REDESIGN THE TRADITIONAL DOCENT-STUDENT TOUR DELIVERY SYSTEM AND PRODUCE BEST PRACTICES FOR INCLUSIVE SCHOOL-FAMILY-COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP, GUIDED BY CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE TEACHING PRACTICES.

THE WICHITA ART MUSEUM PLANS TO CONSERVE IMPORTANT OBJECTS FROM THEIR AMERICAN FOLK ART COLLECTION INCLUDING WIDE-RANGING EXAMPLES FROM HUNTING DECOYS AND FISHING LURES TO FLAG TOPPERS AND EMBROIDERED SAMPLERS. PARTNERING WITH THE MIDWEST ART CONSERVATION CENTER, THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO CONSERVE WORKS BY PREMIER AMERICAN ARTISTS THAT INCLUDE A GROUP OF HIGH-PRIORITY PAINTINGS BY HOMER, ANDREWS, BELLOWS, FEKE, HENRI, KUHN AND LAWSON. THE CONSERVATION TREATMENTS ARE BASED ON PREVIOUS ASSESSMENTS AND CAREFULLY FOLLOW THE MUSEUM'S CONSERVATION PLAN. CONSERVATION WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO SAFELY EXHIBIT THESE WORKS, PROVIDING A FOUNDATION FOR SCHOLARSHIP, EDUCATION, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING IN THEIR REGION AND BEYOND. ULTIMATELY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP PRESERVE AMERICA'S ARTISTIC HERITAGE.

HUNTINGTON MUSEUM OF ART WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE ITS CURRENT NATURE TRAIL SYSTEM, PROVIDING ADDITIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR PATRONS TO INTERACT WITH AND LEARN ABOUT NATURE. THE MUSEUM PLANS TO EXPAND THE TEUBERT SENSORY TRAIL, WHICH IS SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF VISUALLY IMPAIRED INDIVIDUALS AND PEOPLE WHO USE WHEELCHAIRS, DOUBLING ITS LENGTH. AT THE SAME TIME, THEY WILL INSTALL EDUCATIONAL SIGNAGE AND OTHER CONVENIENCES TO ENHANCE THE SENSORY AND HIKING TRAILS. THE ENHANCED TRAILS WILL MAKE NATURE MORE ACCESSIBLE, INVITING, AND ENGAGING, PARTICULARLY FOR THOSE WHO FACE BARRIERS TO PARTICIPATION.

WOODLAND PARK ZOO WILL CONDUCT A PILOT PARTNERSHIP WITH BIG BROTHERS BIG SISTERS OF PUGET SOUND (BBBSPS) TO PROVIDE SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION EDUCATION, PERSONAL CONNECTIONS TO PEERS AND MENTORS, AND OPPORTUNITIES TO PRACTICE ENVIRONMENTALISM AMONG DIVERSE KING COUNTY YOUTH. BBBSPS WILL PROMOTE THE PROGRAM AND RECRUIT MENTOR AND YOUTH PARTICIPANTS. THE ZOO WILL FACILITATE THREE CONSERVATION CHALLENGES EACH YEAR FOR MENTORS AND YOUTH AND WILL HOST AN ANNUAL BIG NIGHT OUT ON ZOO GROUNDS TO EXPRESS GRATITUDE TO MENTORS. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW YOUTH AGES 9 TO 14 TO LEARN ABOUT SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL, AND TO SEE THEMSELVES AS CONTRIBUTING TO CONSERVATION AND THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITY AS FUTURE SCIENTISTS, STEWARDS, AND POLICYMAKERS.

THE PRETEND CITY CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS DISCOVERING AND DEVELOPING DIVERSITY PROGRAM BY FORMING AN INTERDISCIPLINARY ANTI-BIAS ADVISORY COUNCIL, PROVIDING INTENSIVE STAFF TRAINING ON ANTI-BIAS PRACTICES, AND EXPANDING COMMUNITY CULTURAL PARTNERSHIPS. ADDITIONALLY, COMMUNITY SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS WILL CREATE PERFORMANCES, DISPLAYS, AND CELEBRATIONS; AND THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE AN ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE PROGRAM TO SHOWCASE DIVERSITY IN EXPRESSION AND TOOLS USED ACROSS VARIOUS CULTURES. TO FURTHER EDUCATE AND WELCOME CHILDREN AND VISITORS OF VARIOUS BACKGROUNDS THROUGH STORYTELLING PROGRAMMING, THE MUSEUM'S LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE THEMATIC BOOKS ABOUT IDENTITIES, CULTURE, COMMUNICATION, AND DIVERSE ISSUES IN THE HOME.

THE MILWAUKEE ART MUSEUM WILL UNDERTAKE PROFESSIONAL DIGITAL IMAGING OF ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION, EMPHASIZING WORKS THAT ARE MADE BY, OR TELL THE NARRATIVE OF, TRADITIONALLY MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT WILL MAKE 3,000 WORKS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ON ITS COLLECTION WEBSITE, PRIORITIZING THOSE BY ARTISTS OF COLOR AND WOMEN, AS WELL AS ARTWORK THAT CONVEYS THE NARRATIVES OF INDIVIDUALS OR POPULATIONS FREQUENTLY OVERLOOKED IN THE CONTEXT OF THE ENCYCLOPEDIC MUSEUM. THIS WILL INFORM THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION DOCUMENTATION PRACTICE MOVING FORWARD, SUPPORT ONGOING CURATORIAL RESEARCH, AND ALLOW BROADER AUDIENCES ACCESS TO THE WORKS ONLINE. THE SAMPLING WILL SERVE AS THE PILOT GROUP FOR WHAT THE MUSEUM ULTIMATELY INTENDS TO BE A COLLECTION-WIDE OPEN ACCESS POLICY.

THE MISSOURI HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL PROCESS AND DIGITIZE 73 LINEAR FEET OF FILM AND PRINTS CREATED BY THE SIEVERS COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIO FROM THE 1930S THROUGH THE 1960S. THESE IMAGES CAPTURE THE CIVIC AND PERSONAL LIVES OF ST. LOUISANS DURING AN ERA WHEN THE CITY EXPERIENCED A RAPID DECLINE IN POPULATION THROUGH SUBURBANIZATION AND LOSS OF MANUFACTURING. ITEMS SELECTED FOR DIGITIZATION WILL BE BASED ON SUBJECT MATTER AND CONDITION, WITH THE MOST ENDANGERED NEGATIVES THEN PLACED IN FREEZER STORAGE. THE MUSEUM WILL EMPLOY TWO FULL-TIME, TEMPORARY POSITIONS--A PROCESSING ARCHIVIST AND A DIGITIZATION ARCHIVIST--FOR 24 MONTHS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO AND PROMOTE THE USE OF THE MATERIAL BY PUBLISHING THE INDEX, RECORDS, AND DIGITIZED IMAGES ON ITS WEBSITE, MAKING THEM FREELY DOWNLOADABLE FOR ALL.

THE VIRGINIA MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS WILL COMPLETE THE DIGITIZATION, PRESERVATION, AND DISSEMINATION OF ITS ENTIRE PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTION, INCLUDING THE NEWLY ACQUIRED COLLECTION OF 4,062 PHOTOGRAPHS REPRESENTING THE CAREER OF ACCLAIMED AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHER, AARON SISKIND. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO CREATE VERBAL DESCRIPTIONS FOR 1,000 IMAGES TO ENHANCE THE DISCOVERABILITY AND INCREASE ACCESS FOR AUDIENCES WITH VISUAL IMPAIRMENTS. THE MUSEUM PLANS TO HIRE AN ASSISTANT PHOTOGRAPHER AND A REGISTRATION ASSISTANT TO CAPTURE DIGITAL IMAGES, VERIFY OBJECT DATA, AND ENTER DATA INTO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE MUSEUM'S MULTI-YEAR INITIATIVE TO INCREASE ACCESS TO THE SOME OF THE MOST INHERENTLY FRAGILE AND LIGHT SENSITIVE WORKS IN ITS COLLECTION.

THE PALO ALTO ART CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT A MULTIFACETED COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROJECT THAT SHOWCASES THE UNIQUE PERSPECTIVES OF ARTISTS AND THE TRANSFORMATIVE POWER OF THE ARTS IN A TIME OF INCREASED ANXIETY. ?CREATIVE ATTENTION? BUILDS ON THE ART CENTER?S TRADITION OF ARTIST RESIDENCIES, EXHIBITIONS, ART EDUCATION PROGRAMS, AND OUTREACH TO THE DIVERSE MID-PENINSULA COMMUNITY. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A LICENSED THERAPIST/BOARD-CERTIFIED ART THERAPIST, THEY WILL ENCOURAGE THE COMMUNITY TO USE THE ARTS TO ADDRESS ANXIETY AND TO RECOGNIZE THE MANY MANIFESTATIONS OF THE EMOTION. IN ADDITION, THEY ARE PLANNING TO CONDUCT THERAPEUTIC ART WORKSHOPS AND ORGANIZE AN INTERGENERATIONAL FAMILY DAY. THE ART CENTER WILL ALSO DEVELOP A RELATED ART EXHIBITION IN PARTNERSHIP WITH ARTISTS, COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS, AND REGIONAL SOCIAL SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS.

THE DALLAS HOLOCAUST AND HUMAN RIGHTS MUSEUM SEEKS TO FURTHER DESCRIBE AND DIGITIZE THEIR COLLECTION. THEIR ARCHIVES CONTAIN 14,552 COLLECTION ITEMS ON THE HISTORY OF THE HOLOCAUST AND HUMAN RIGHTS IN A LOCAL CONTEXT, WITH 4,008 ITEMS REMAINING TO BE CATALOGUED. THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE A FULLY ACCESSIBLE, ROBUST CATALOG AND DIGITAL COLLECTION WHILE MAINTAINING PROPER METADATA STANDARDS. IT ALSO WILL HIRE ONE FULL-TIME, MASTER'S LEVEL CATALOGER TO CATALOG THE BACKLOG ALONGSIDE EXISTING LIBRARY AND ARCHIVES STAFF, INTERNS, AND VOLUNTEERS. ULTIMATELY, THE MUSEUM WILL FULLY CATALOG THEIR COLLECTION, WHICH INCLUDES DIARIES, LETTERS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND 3D OBJECTS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO BETTER SERVE THE PUBLIC WITH COMPLETE, SEARCHABLE ONLINE RECORDS AND ESTABLISH THE MUSEUM AS THE ONLY REGIONAL REPOSITORY OF HUMAN RIGHTS ARTIFACTS FROM THE HOLOCAUST.

HERMANN-GRIMA PLUS GALLIER HISTORIC HOUSES WILL CREATE A VIRTUAL, PANORAMIC 360 DEGREE TOUR OF GALLIER HISTORIC HOUSE, DESIGNED TO INCREASE THE WAYS PATRONS CAN ENGAGE WITH THE MUSEUM. A TEAM OF 11 SCHOLARS FROM AROUND THE COUNTRY WILL PROVIDE DIRECTION, RESEARCH, AND EVALUATION ON THE POINTS OF INTEREST TO FEATURE IN THE VIRTUAL EXPERIENCE. THE VIRTUAL TOUR WILL FOCUS ON LESSER TOLD STORIES RELATED TO THE ENSLAVED PEOPLE AND FREE PEOPLE OF COLOR WHO HELPED BUILD THE HOUSE OR WERE INHABITANTS OF THE PROPERTY. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING AN ALTERNATIVE MEANS OF INTERACTING WITH THE SPACE, THE DIGITAL REPLICA WILL PROVIDE A RECORD SHOULD THE HOME INCUR DAMAGE FROM FUTURE STORMS OR OTHER NATURAL DISASTERS.

THE HANDS ON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT AN "INSPIRED CHEFS" PROGRAM THAT RESPONDS TO COMMUNITY DEMAND FOR CHILDREN'S COOKING EDUCATION, PROMOTES EARLY STEAM LEARNING, AND SUPPORTS THE MUSEUM'S GOOD FOR YOU! HEALTHY LIFESTYLES INITIATIVE. THE INSPIRED CHEFS PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE COOKING CLASSES AND COOKING CAMPS FOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH. THEY ALSO PLAN TO ORGANIZE A NEW KITCHEN TOOLS POP-UP EXHIBIT AND REDESIGN A GARDEN SHED IN THE CHILDREN'S GARDEN ON THE MUSEUM PROPERTY TO SUPPORT SEED-TO-TABLE PROGRAMMING. COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL INCLUDE THE OLYMPIA FARMERS MARKET, NATIVE PLANT AND FOOD EDUCATORS, LOCAL CHEFS, AND STUDENTS FROM SOUTH PUGET SOUND COMMUNITY COLLEGE'S CULINARY PROGRAM.

THE INDIANA STATE MUSEUM AND HISTORIC SITES WILL CREATE A HANDS-ON, IMMERSIVE EXPERIENCE ABOUT LEGENDARY AFRICAN AMERICAN CYCLIST MARSHALL "MAJOR" TAYLOR. THE EXHIBIT WILL FEATURE A 1900-ERA LOCKER ROOM, A BICYCLE SHOP THAT DEMONSTRATES HOW BIKE DESIGN IMPACTS PERFORMANCE, AND THREE TROPHIES TAYLOR WON OVERSEAS. VISITORS WILL BE ABLE TO ASSEMBLE BICYCLES AND PARTICIPATE IN AN ANIMATED RACE. THE MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE INDIANAPOLIS PUBLIC LIBRARY'S CENTER FOR BLACK LITERATURE AND CULTURE, US BICYCLING HALL OF FAME, BIKE INDIANAPOLIS, AND CENTRAL INDIANA BICYCLING ASSOCIATION. THE EXHIBIT WILL INCREASE AWARENESS OF MAJOR TAYLOR, HIS ACHIEVEMENTS, AND HIS CONNECTIONS TO INDIANAPOLIS AND INDIANA, AND WILL PROVIDE A SHARED EXPERIENCE FOCUSED ON RACE AND OUR ONGOING STRUGGLE FOR SOCIAL JUSTICE. VISITORS CAN CONTEMPLATE AND TAKE ACTION AROUND BIKE EQUITY, ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE TRANSPORTATION, AND URBAN DESIGN, EXPLORE CYCLING AND RIDE BICYCLES TOGETHER.

THE UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA MUSEUM OF PALEONTOLOGY, WILL DEVELOP, TEST, AND DEPLOY AN IMMERSIVE EDUCATIONAL GAME ON THE TOPIC OF EVOLUTION AND COMMON ANCESTRY. THE MUSEUM WILL FRAME THE GAME WITH A NARRATIVE THAT INVOLVES TRACING THE ORIGIN OF A ZOONOTIC DISEASE (INFECTIOUS DISEASE THAT IS TRANSMITTED BETWEEN SPECIES FROM ANIMALS TO HUMANS OR FROM HUMANS TO ANIMALS). PLAYED ON THE MUSEUM FLOOR, THE ESCAPE ROOM-INSPIRED GAME WILL EXPLORE INNOVATIVE FORMATS FOR MUSEUM LEARNING AND ENGAGEMENT. IT IS BEING DESIGNED FOR FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN AGES 7 TO 12, AND BY VISITING GROUPS OF SCHOOLCHILDREN IN GRADES 3 TO 5.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH SIX HARTFORD PUBLIC LIBRARY BRANCHES, THREE HARTFORD FAMILY CENTERS, AND THE CONNECTICUT CHILDREN'S MEDICAL CENTER TO PROVIDE -HANDS-ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATHEMATICS (STEAM) - BASED PROGRAMS TO OVER 1,000 LOCAL 3 TO 14-YEAR OLD CHILDREN AND THEIR CARE GIVERS. PROGRAM DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT WILL INCLUDE PLANNING FOR FIELD TRIPS TO THE MUSEUM. ALL PARTICIPANTS WILL BE GIVEN AGE-SPECIFIC, SUPPLEMENTAL STEAM MATERIALS TO CONTINUE THEIR LEARNING ACTIVITIES AT HOME, AND FAMILIES CAN ATTEND MORE THAN ONE WEEK OF LIBRARY PROGRAMS, OR MORE THAN THREE SATURDAYS OF FAMILY CENTER PROGRAMS. THE GOAL WILL BE TO HELP URBAN HARTFORD YOUTHS FIND NEW PATHWAYS TOWARD RESPONSIBLE CITIZENRY AND FISCAL STABILITY.

ARIZONA STATE MUSEUM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE POETRY CENTER AND CENTER FOR DIGITAL HUMANITIES WILL CREATE A DIGITAL MUSEUM WITH EXHIBIT LOCATIONS IN DIVERSE AREAS OF TUCSON AS WELL AS ACCOMPANYING ACTIVITIES FOR K-12 CLASSROOMS, FAMILIES, AND ADULTS. THE COLLABORATIVE VIRTUAL OUTDOOR MUSEUM WILL USE GEOLOCATION TECHNOLOGY AND OFFER AUGMENTED REALITY ENCOUNTERS WITH CURATORS, EDUCATORS, POETS, AND COMMUNITY TRADITION BEARERS. THE VIRTUAL MUSEUM AND LINKED WEBSITE WILL INTRODUCE USERS TO COMMUNITY RESOURCES, HISTORY, AND CULTURE IN A SAFE, SOCIALLY DISTANCED MANNER. BUILT AROUND THE THEME OF COMMUNITY IN THE BORDERLANDS, THE PROJECT ENGAGES COLLABORATORS FROM THE DUNBAR PAVILION, TUCSON CHINESE CULTURAL CENTER, THE PASCUA YAQUI TRIBE'S DEPARTMENT OF LANGUAGE AND CULTURE, AND MISSION GARDEN. THESE PROGRAM PARTNERS WILL BE TRAINED IN NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND LEARN CREATIVE WAYS TO ENGAGE VARIOUS AUDIENCES USING DIGITAL TOOLS.

THE FIELD MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL PRESENT "CHANGING FACE OF SCIENCE," AN EXHIBITION SERIES TARGETING PRE-TEENS AND TEENAGERS AND FEATURING FIELD MUSEUM SCIENTISTS AND SCIENCE EDUCATORS WHO ARE WOMEN OR PEOPLE OF COLOR. OVER THREE YEARS, THE MUSEUM WILL MOUNT SIX EXHIBITIONS THAT HIGHLIGHT THE EXPERIENCES AND WORK OF MUSEUM SCIENTISTS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS IN A RANGE OF DISCIPLINES. PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE ON-SITE FIELD TRIPS AND VIRTUAL EVENTS DURING WHICH STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS WILL INTERACT WITH FEATURED RESEARCHERS. BY PRESENTING THE STORIES OF INDIVIDUALS FROM GROUPS TRADITIONALLY UNDERREPRESENTED IN SCIENTIFIC FIELDS, THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE ROLE MODELS WHO WILL SHOW THAT SCIENCE IS ACCESSIBLE AND INSPIRE A DIVERSE GROUP OF FUTURE SCIENTISTS.

HISTORY COLORADO WILL CREATE AN EXHIBITION ON THE SAND CREEK MASSACRE. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH THREE TRIBES: NORTHERN CHEYENNE TRIBE OF THE NORTHERN CHEYENNE RESERVATION, NORTHERN ARAPAHO TRIBE, AND CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO TRIBES OF OKLAHOMA. ON NOVEMBER 29, 1864, U.S. FEDERAL TROOPS ATTACKED A PEACEFUL CAMP OF CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO WHO, AT THE DIRECTION OF COLORADO'S GOVERNOR, WERE LAWFULLY OCCUPYING THE LAND ALONG THE SAND CREEK ON SOUTHEASTERN COLORADO'S PLAINS. THIS EXHIBITION WILL BE THE FIRST IN THE U.S. TO SHARE THE CULTURALLY VETTED HISTORY OF THE MASSACRE WITH THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH THE VOICES OF CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO TRIBAL MEMBERS. INTENDED RESULTS INCLUDE CONTRIBUTING TO THE REMEMBRANCE WORK ALREADY DONE BY TRIBAL MEMBERS, EDUCATING TRIBAL YOUTH WHO ARE LOOKING TO LEARN ABOUT THE MASSACRE, AND EDUCATING GENERAL AUDIENCES ABOUT CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO HISTORY.

THE LONG ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT THE SECOND PHASE OF DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW PERMANENT EXHIBITION TITLED "SALTWATER STORIES: THE SEA AND ME." THE EXHIBITION WILL ENGAGE FAMILIES AND SCHOOL AUDIENCES IN AN EXPLORATION OF THE LOCAL MARITIME TRADITIONS THAT HAVE SHAPED THE HISTORICAL, CULTURAL, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF LONG ISLAND. THEY WILL CREATE EXHIBIT FLOORPLANS AND RENDERINGS OF EXHIBIT COMPONENTS AND IDENTIFY INTERACTIVE EXHIBITION ELEMENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES, ALONG WITH RELATED CONTENT FOR THEIR WEBSITE. FINALLY, THEY WILL CREATE A PRELIMINARY MARKETING STRATEGY TO PROMOTE THE NEW EXHIBIT WITH TARGET AUDIENCES.

LINCOLN PARK ZOO WILL COLLABORATE WITH MEMBERS OF CHICAGO-AREA DISABILITY COMMUNITIES TO CO-CREATE NEW, INCLUSIVE INTERPRETIVE ELEMENTS AT UP TO THREE ZOO EXHIBITS. THESE INTERACTIVE ELEMENTS, CREATED HAND-IN-HAND WITH THEIR INTENDED AUDIENCES, WILL HELP THE ZOO PROVIDE A MORE WELCOMING AND ENGAGING ENVIRONMENT FOR ALL VISITORS. NEW ELEMENTS WILL INCLUDE MOVING BEYOND TEXT-ONLY EXHIBIT SIGNAGE TO ACCOMMODATE THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF THE DEAF/HARD OF HEARING, BLIND/LOW VISION COMMUNITIES, AND PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY, COGNITIVE, AND SENSORY DISABILITIES. ZOO STAFF WILL HOST LISTENING SESSIONS WITH INDIVIDUALS, GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND DISABILITY ORGANIZATIONS TO IDENTIFY THE EXHIBITS THAT WOULD BENEFIT FROM ADDITIONAL INTERPRETIVE ELEMENTS.

THE GRAND RAPIDS PUBLIC MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE HOUSING, ACCESSIBILITY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR 47,500 SPECIMENS IN ITS NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTION BY INSTALLING NEW STORAGE UNITS THAT MEET THE MUSEUM INDUSTRY'S HIGHEST STANDARDS. THE NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTION IS COMPOSED OF INVERTEBRATES WITH A RIGID SKELETON, BOTANICAL SPECIMENS, ROCKS AND MINERALS, BIRDS (MOUNTS, SKINS, AND EGGS), FOSSILS (VERTEBRATE AND INVERTEBRATE), MAMMALS (MOUNTS, SKINS, AND SKELETONS), AND REPTILES (MOUNTS AND SKELETONS). MOST OF THE NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTION IS CURRENTLY STORED ON OPEN, STEEL SHELVING AND IN OLD CABINETS WITH WOOD DRAWERS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW 95% OF THE MUSEUM'S NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTION TO BE STORED IN FULLY ENCLOSED CABINETS, PROTECTING SPECIMENS FROM LIGHT, DUST, MOISTURE, AND PESTS. WHEN COMPLETE, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE 34% MORE STORAGE SPACE AND ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE UNIQUE COLLECTION.

ECHO, LEAHY CENTER FOR LAKE CHAMPLAIN WILL INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO SERVE RURAL SCHOOLS THROUGH PROGRAMMING OPPORTUNITIES UNDER ITS STEM IN MOTION 2.0 PROGRAM. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH RURAL SCHOOLS, THEY WILL CONDUCT TWO YEAR-LONG TEACHER INSTITUTES BLENDING IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THEY PLAN TO DEVELOP A TOTAL OF 270 IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL CLASSROOM STEM PROGRAMS AND PRODUCE 18 CLASSROOM CURRICULUM KITS AND STANDARD-ACTIVITY ALIGNED GUIDES. AS A RESULT OF STEM IN MOTION 2.0'S ACTIVITIES, THE MUSEUM ANTICIPATE THAT 54 TEACHERS WILL HAVE ADDITIONAL CAPACITY TO DELIVER HIGH-QUALITY STEM LEARNING EXPERIENCES TO K-5TH GRADE STUDENTS IN UNDERSERVED, RURAL COMMUNITIES.

THE BOISE ART MUSEUM WILL INCREASE THEIR STORAGE FURNITURE AND REORGANIZE THEIR PERMANENT COLLECTION IN SECURE STORAGE. THE MUSEUM'S PERMANENT COLLECTION HAS GROWN SIGNIFICANTLY TO MORE THAN 4,000 WORKS, FILLING EXISTING RACKS, SHELVES, AND FILES. TO MAXIMIZE VERTICAL STORAGE SPACE IN THE ENVIRONMENTALLY CONTROLLED ART STORAGE VAULT, THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A SYSTEM OF MUSEUM-QUALITY COMPACT VERTICAL ART STORAGE SCREENS FOR 2-D FRAMED ARTWORKS, AS WELL AS TWO STORAGE RACKS FOR WORKS IN CARDBOARD SLIPCASES. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE AND INCREASE COLLECTION STORAGE WITHIN THE EXISTING BUILDING, INCREASE THE EFFICIENCIES OF MUSEUM STAFF, MINIMIZE UNNECESSARY HANDLING AND MOVEMENT OF ARTWORK, AND RESULT IN SAFER STORAGE CONDITIONS OVER THE LONG TERM.

CREATIVE DISCOVERY MUSEUM WILL CREATE AN INDOOR/OUTDOOR, NATURAL SCIENCE GALLERY DESIGNED FOR CHILDREN AGES 2 TO 12. NAMED “UNEARTHED,” THE GALLERY WILL INCLUDE EXHIBITS ON FOSSIL LAYERS, DINOSAURS AND PALEONTOLOGY, VOLCANOS AND VOLCANOLOGY, EROSION AND WEATHERING, ENTOMOLOGY, AND INSECTS. IT WILL OFFER HANDS-ON, EXPLORATORY EXPERIENCES IN NATURAL SCIENCE FOR CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES. THE NEW SCIENCE GALLERY WILL ALIGN WITH STATE EDUCATIONAL STANDARDS, PROVIDE MORE INTERACTIVE LEARNING EXPERIENCES, AND INTRODUCE CHILDREN TO REAL ELEMENTS INCLUDING DIRT, WATER, AND SAND IN AN OUTDOOR EXHIBIT THAT REINFORCES THE CONCEPTS PRESENTED INSIDE THE MUSEUM.

THE MAINE MARITIME MUSEUM PLANS TO CONDUCT A COMPREHENSIVE INVENTORY, CATALOGING, AND DIGITIZATION PROJECT IN ITS PRINCIPAL COLLECTION STORAGE SPACE, WHICH HOLDS MORE THAN 9,000 OBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE MUSEUM WITH SUBSTANTIALLY IMPROVED INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OF A LARGE PORTION OF ITS OBJECT COLLECTION, RESULTING IN INCREASED ACCESS AND IMPROVED COLLECTION CARE. A QUALITY ONLINE CATALOG WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS, PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO REACH WIDER AUDIENCES, AND EXPAND COLLABORATIVE OPPORTUNITIES WITH EDUCATORS AND CULTURAL HERITAGE ORGANIZATIONS. STAFF WILL BE ABLE TO CREATE PROGRAMMING MORE EFFICIENTLY, AND RESEARCHERS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO A MORE ROBUST AND ACCOMMODATING ONLINE DATABASE. THE MUSEUM CURRENTLY CARES FOR MORE THAN 20,000 OBJECTS, OVER 2,000 LINEAR FEET OF ARCHIVAL MATERIAL, AND THOUSANDS OF REFERENCE MATERIALS.

THE MARK TWAIN HOUSE AND MUSEUM WILL TREAT 19TH CENTURY OBJECTS FROM ITS COLLECTION THAT BELONGED TO SAMUEL CLEMENS ("MARK TWAIN") AND HIS WIFE. THE OBJECTS INCLUDE FOUR PIECES OF FURNITURE, A PIPE CASE, A WALKING STICK, AND A TIFFANY SILVER HAIR COMB. THESE ITEMS HAVE BEEN PRIORITIZED FOR CONSERVATION DUE TO THEIR PROVENANCE, AS WELL AS THEIR IMPORTANCE TO THE INTERPRETATION OF THE MARK TWAIN HOUSE AND TO THE STUDY OF MARK TWAIN AND HIS ERA. THE OBJECTS WILL BE TREATED BY THE WILLIAMSTOWN ART CONSERVATION CENTER AND WILL BE DONE IN ACCORDANCE WITH A SPECIFIC TREATMENT PLAN. AFTER THE TREATMENTS ARE COMPLETED, THE FURNITURE WILL BE PUT ON DISPLAY IN THE MARK TWAIN HOUSE, WHILE THE OTHER OBJECTS WILL BE AVAILABLE IN EXHIBITIONS AND IN CONNECTION WITH OTHER PUBLIC PROGRAMS.

THE GOLDSTEIN MUSEUM OF DESIGN AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL IMPROVE THE PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS APPAREL COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PHOTOGRAPHER AND A PREPARATOR TO PHOTOGRAPH 1,800 OBJECTS AND UPLOAD IMAGES TO THE COLLECTION DATABASE. THESE OBJECTS INCLUDE 18TH CENTURY GOWNS, PHOTOGRAPHS OF 1970S ERA GARMENTS, RECENT ACQUISITIONS, CHILDREN'S WEAR, AND WOMEN'S GARMENTS. DIGITIZATION OF THE COLLECTION WILL AID IN EXHIBITION DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING, AS WELL AS SERVE AS A RESOURCE FOR FUTURE PUBLICATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL CURRICULUM. THE IMPACT OF THE PROJECT WILL BE A WIDER VARIETY OF OBJECT IMAGES AVAILABLE TO STAFF AND THE PUBLIC THROUGH THE ONLINE COLLECTION DATABASE.

THE NEW MEXICO MUSEUM OF ART WILL INVENTORY, DIGITIZE, REHOUSE, AND RELOCATE 6,500 PHOTOGRAPHS AND 300 CONTEMPORARY PAINTINGS AND SCULPTURES TO A SECONDARY MUSEUM LOCATION SCHEDULED TO OPEN IN 2022. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE CREATION OF HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHS TO INCREASE BOTH SCHOLARLY AND PUBLIC ACCESS. FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO PURCHASE ARCHIVAL SUPPLIES AND HIRE A CONTRACT PHOTOGRAPHER AND ART HANDLERS TO HELP WITH RELOCATION TO THE MUSEUM'S SECOND LOCATION. EXPANSION INTO THIS NEW SPACE WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO INCREASE ITS STORAGE CAPACITY FOR CURRENT HOLDINGS, AS WELL AS FUTURE ACQUISITIONS.

THE MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND HISTORY -- PINK PALACE WILL CREATE AN EXHIBITION FOCUSING ON THE HISTORY OF MEMPHIS' LGBTQ COMMUNITY. THE EXHIBIT WILL RUN SIMULTANEOUSLY WITH THE TRAVELING EXHIBIT "RISE UP: STONEWALL AND THE LGBTQ RIGHTS MOVEMENT," WHICH PROVIDES NATIONAL CONTEXT FOR THE LOCAL NARRATIVE. ALONG WITH LOCAL LGBTQ HISTORY, THE EXHIBIT WILL HIGHLIGHT CONTEMPORARY OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES THAT LGBTQ MEMPHIANS FACE. IT WILL ADDRESS THE INTERSECTIONS OF THE BLACK LIVES MATTER AND TRANSGENDER RIGHTS MOVEMENTS. MUSEUM CURATORS WILL WORK WITH COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE EXHIBIT CONTENT, SECURE ARTIFACT ACQUISITIONS/LOANS, AND ENSURE THE EXHIBIT TELLS AS COMPLETE AND INCLUSIVE A STORY AS POSSIBLE.

THE NORTH CAROLINA MARITIME MUSEUM PLANS TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION LAB AT THEIR BEAUFORT LOCATION AND TO PROCESS AN ENHANCED SCOPE OF UNDERWATER ARCHEOLOGICAL ARTIFACTS WHICH INCLUDE CONTENTS TAKEN FROM SUNKEN U-BOATS AND CIVIL WAR SHIPWRECKS AND REPRESENT MORE THAN 300 YEARS OF NORTH CAROLINA MARITIME LIFE. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS CONSERVATION CAPABILITIES BY PURCHASING AN ARRAY OF NEW EQUIPMENT. A BETTER EQUIPPED LAB WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO TREAT LARGER AND MORE COMPLEX ITEMS INHOUSE AND PREPARE THEM FOR DISPLAY MORE QUICKLY. ALL CONSERVATION WORK WILL BE DONE IN PUBLIC VIEW AS A "LIVING EXHIBIT." IT WILL HIRE A PAID INTERN TO HELP WITH CONSERVATION TASKS WHILE ENGAGING THE PUBLIC IN LEARNING ABOUT CONSERVATION SCIENCE AND UNDERWATER ARCHAEOLOGY.

THE NANTUCKET HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION?S (NHA) COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE CLASSIFICATION, CATALOGING, AND REHOUSING OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL HOLDINGS THAT WERE EXTENSIVELY GATHERED, STUDIED, AND CATALOGED BETWEEN THE 1970S AND 1990S. A COLLECTIONS SPECIALIST WORKING WITH A CONSULTING ARCHAEOLOGIST WILL INVENTORY AND CATALOG THE COLLECTION OF AT LEAST 5,000 NATIVE AMERICAN STONE TOOLS, NATIVE AMERICAN POTTERY, AND HISTORIC-PERIOD CERAMIC FRAGMENTS AND COLONIAL FRAGMENTS; CREATE DIGITAL RECORDS OF THE COLLECTION; REHOUSE THE ARCHAEOLOGY COLLECTION INTO NEW MUSEUM-QUALITY ENCLOSURES AND SHELVING; AND PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO OBJECT DESCRIPTIONS, HISTORICAL CONTEXT, AND PHOTOGRAPHY THROUGH A NEW, ONLINE COLLECTIONS PORTAL. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE SPRINGBOARD FOR THE NHA TO BRING THESE COLLECTIONS AND THE STORIES IMBUED IN THE STONES, BONES, AND SHARDS TO THE FORE FOR STUDY AND EDUCATION AND FURTHER RESEARCH.

THE HUNTINGTON LIBRARY, ART MUSEUM, AND BOTANICAL GARDENS WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT THE RELEVANCE, ACCESS, AND DIVERSITY (RAD) DOCENTS PROJECT TO BUILD THE INSTITUTION?S CAPACITY TO DELIVER A SUSTAINABLE AND CONSISTENT SYSTEM OF RECRUITING AND TRAINING DOCENTS THAT REFLECTS THE NEEDS OF DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONDUCT SELF-STUDY RESEARCH TO BENCHMARK THE HUNTINGTON?S CURRENT DOCENT TRAINING PROGRAMS AGAINST PEER INSTITUTIONS, COLLABORATE WITH EXTERNAL THOUGHT LEADERS TO DEVELOP AN ACTIONABLE PLAN FOR DOCENT TRAINING, AND PILOT AND REFINE A NEW DOCENT TRAINING FORMAT. THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THE HUNTINGTON?S DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS FOR VOLUNTEER TRAINING AND VISITOR EXPERIENCE, AS WELL AS THE INSTITUTION?S MISSION TO PROMOTE EDUCATION IN THE ARTS, HUMANITIES, AND BOTANICAL SCIENCES. ?RAD DOCENTS? WILL BUILD STRONGER CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE HUNTINGTON?S AUDIENCES AND ITS COLLECTIONS THROUGH MEANINGFUL INTERACTIONS WITH VOLUNTEERS.

THE HOUSTON ZOO WILL ESTABLISH A NEW EXHIBITION ON THE GAL PAGOS ISLANDS THAT USES BEST PRACTICES IN EXHIBITION DESIGN AND INTERPRETATION TO EDUCATE VISITORS ABOUT OCEAN CONSERVATION AND INSPIRE THEM TO TAKE CONSERVATION ACTION. THE EXHIBITION WILL FEATURE SEA LIONS, GIANT TORTOISES, SHARKS, RAYS, SEA TURTLES, AND OTHER MARINE SPECIES TO ILLUSTRATE MARINE ECOSYSTEMS, HOW HUMAN ACTIVITIES LIKE PLASTIC POLLUTION CREATE THREATS TO WILDLIFE, AND WHAT PEOPLE CAN DO TO HELP. WITH THIS PROJECT, THE ZOO IS PILOTING A THOUGHTFUL AND INCLUSIVE APPROACH TO INTERPRETIVE PLANNING THAT WILL INFORM FUTURE EXHIBITS AND THE ZOO AND AQUARIUM FIELD.

THE LYMAN ALLYN ART MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY AND DIGITIZE ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION, WHICH INCLUDES APPROXIMATELY 18,000 OBJECTS SUCH AS PAINTINGS, SCULPTURE, WORKS ON PAPER, DECORATIVE ARTS AND FURNITURE, TEXTILES, AND TOYS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL LOCATE, IDENTIFY, EXAMINE, PHOTOGRAPH, AND REHOUSE ABOUT 5,000 OBJECTS, CREATING NEW OR MORE ROBUST DIGITAL RECORDS IN THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE CARE AND ACCOUNTABILITY FOR THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS FOR STAFF AND THE PUBLIC. ADDITIONALLY, THE INITIATIVE WILL UPLOAD OBJECT METADATA AND IMAGES TO THE CONNECTICUT DIGITAL ARCHIVES (CTDA) FOR LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND PUBLIC ACCESS.

THE USS CONSTITUTION MUSEUM WILL LAUNCH A SALUTE TO SERVICE INITIATIVE TO TRANSFORM ITSELF INTO A HUB FOR CONVERSATION, CONNECTION, AND COMMUNITY AROUND MILITARY SERVICE. A STRATEGIC FOCUS ON SERVICE MEMBERS, VETERANS, AND THEIR FAMILIES WILL SIGNIFICANTLY STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND HOW THE MUSEUM, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE U.S. NAVY?S USS CONSTITUTION, ENHANCES THE GENERAL PUBLIC?S UNDERSTANDING OF THE MILITARY COMMUNITY. THE MAJOR GOALS OF THE INITIATIVE ARE FOR THE MILITARY COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO SEE THE MUSEUM AS A TRUSTED SPACE FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND CIVILIAN PARTICIPANTS IN SALUTE TO SERVICE PROGRAMS TO GAIN AN ELEVATED UNDERSTANDING OF MILITARY SERVICE AND FAMILY SACRIFICE.

WESTCOTT HOUSE FOUNDATION WILL FACILITATE A SERIES OF ARTS PROGRAMS AND EVENTS THAT WILL CELEBRATE, AMPLIFY, AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE REVITALIZATION EFFORTS IN DOWNTOWN SPRINGFIELD, OHIO. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ARTIST RESIDENCIES, COMMUNITY PLANNING SESSIONS, A STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PUBLIC ART PROGRAM, THREE NEW WORKS OF PUBLIC ART, ARTSOFO (A FINE ARTS FAIR), AND THE LAUNCH OF A LIGHT-BASED ART FESTIVAL. ALL WORKS OF ART CREATED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE INFORMED BY THE CITY?S RICH HISTORY AND WILL CELEBRATE THE ARCHITECTURAL LEGACY THAT HAS BEEN SAVED THROUGH COMMUNITY LEADERS? RECENT EFFORTS. PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE THE CITY OF SPRINGFIELD, PROJECT JERICHO, GREATER SPRINGFIELD CONVENTION & VISITORS BUREAU, AND SPRINGFORWARD-A CONSORTIUM OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT, FOUNDATIONS, AND CORPORATIONS CREATED TO REVITALIZE SPRINGFIELD?S URBAN CORE.

THE CENTER FOR JEWISH HISTORY WILL IMPROVE STEWARDSHIP OF THE 35MM AND 16MM MOTION PICTURE FILM COLLECTIONS OF ITS FIVE IN-HOUSE PARTNERS: THE AMERICAN JEWISH HISTORICAL SOCIETY, AMERICAN SEPHARDI FEDERATION, LEO BAECK INSTITUTE, YESHIVA UNIVERSITY MUSEUM, AND YIVO INSTITUTE. THE FILM COLLECTIONS CONTAIN FOOTAGE OF JEWISH LIFE IN PRE- AND POST-WORLD WAR II EUROPE, SCENES FROM YIDDISH THEATER PRODUCTIONS, A U.S. ARMY SEDER IN SAIGON CIRCA 1971, AND MANY OTHER SUBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE SURVEYING FILM HOLDINGS, NOTING PRESERVATION ISSUES, AND DIGITIZING 10 REELS AS A PILOT OF A NEW DIGITIZATION PROCESS. PARTNERS WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR FILM HOLDINGS, AND RESEARCHERS AROUND THE GLOBE WILL GAIN ACCESS TO UNIQUE PRODUCTIONS. THIS PROJECT ALSO WILL LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR FUTURE DIGITIZATION AND PRESERVATION PROJECTS.

TUCSON CHILDREN?S MUSEUM WILL LAUNCH APRENDEMOS-AN EQUITABLE APPROACH TO LEARNING (EAL) PROGRAM TO PROVIDE EQUITABLE, PLAY-BASED OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERSERVED CHILDREN IN SOUTHERN ARIZONA. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS, FOSTER AGENCIES, AND OTHERS THAT SUPPORT REFUGEE POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS LOCAL FOOD AND DIAPER BANKS. A NEW POSITION OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT SPECIALIST WILL TRANSLATE EXISTING PROGRAMMING INTO SPANISH AND DESIGN AND FACILITATE NEW MULTILINGUAL ACTIVITIES. TO SUPPORT CHILDREN ATTENDING TITLE 1 SCHOOLS, THE MUSEUM WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ITS ADVENTURE LEARNING TOURS AND PRESENT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES. LOCAL TEACHERS WILL ENGAGE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING, TAUGHT BY MUSEUM STAFF AND PARTNERS FROM PLANETARY SCIENCE INSTITUTE. FOSTER AND REFUGEE FAMILIES WILL PARTICIPATE IN DISCOVERY NIGHTS, FEATURING EXTENDED HOURS AND REDUCED ADMISSION, ALLOWING PARENTS WHO WORK TO PLAY AND LEARN WITH THEIR SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN.

TRUMBULL COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPROVE THE INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY REHOUSING 15,000 ITEMS IN ITS MUSEUM COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE INVENTORYING, CATALOGING, ENTERING OBJECTS INTO A COLLECTIONS SOFTWARE PROGRAM, AND MOVING ITEMS TO THE NEWLY ACQUIRED COLLECTIONS STORAGE FACILITY AT THE OWEN MORGAN HOUSE. MUSEUM COLLECTIONS CABINETRY, EQUIPMENT, AND SUPPLIES WILL BE PURCHASED, AND A COLLECTIONS MANAGER WILL OVERSEE THE PROJECT. A CONSERVATOR WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON TRAINING FOR REHOUSING THE OBJECTS COLLECTIONS FOR 10 VOLUNTEERS TO ASSIST WITH THE COLLECTIONS MOVE, AS WELL AS CURRENT AND FUTURE COLLECTIONS-RELATED PROJECTS.

YERBA BUENA CENTER FOR THE ARTS (YBCA) WILL DEVELOP THE YBCA CIVIC COMMONS, A NEW MODEL FOR PARTICIPATION IN A MUSEUM SETTING DESIGNED TO PROVIDE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR DIVERSE COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW YBCA?S LOBBY, PLAZAS, AND OTHER COMMUNAL AREAS TO BE WELCOMING, VIBRANT, AND ENGAGING SPACES. PARTNERS INCLUDE BAY AREA ARTISTS AND CREATIVES, SAN FRANCISCO?S OFFICE OF CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND IMMIGRANT AFFAIRS, AND AN EXTENSIVE NETWORK OF SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY-BASED NONPROFITS, AS WELL AS OTHER CROSS-SECTOR COLLABORATORS.
