THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE HIRING A GRADUATE ASSISTANT, A STRATEGIC PLANNING CONSULTANT, AND AN EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS CONSULTANT WHO WILL CONDUCT INFORMATION GATHERING THROUGH MEETINGS WITH MUSEUM STAFF AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, DRAFT THE NEW PLANS, AND EVALUATE THE PLANS THAT WILL GUIDE THE MUSEUM’S FUTURE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A MORE EFFECTIVE, EFFICIENT, AND ACCESSIBLE INSTITUTION FOR THE PUBLIC.

BIG CAR WILL INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY TO ITS EXHIBITIONS AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR THE RESIDENTS OF SOUTH INDIANAPOLIS WITH A FOCUS ON REACHING THE GROWING SPANISH-SPEAKING POPULATION. THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL WORK WITH LOCAL AND INTERNATIONAL ARTISTS TO OFFER ARTIST TALKS, WORKSHOPS, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS TO SUPPLEMENT FOUR EXHIBITIONS. THE CONTENT WILL ALSO BE BROADCAST THROUGH THE MUSEUM-RUN FM RADIO STATION THAT IS ALSO AVAILABLE THROUGH ONLINE PLATFORMS. THE SOUND PIECES — SHARED IN SPANISH AND ENGLISH — WILL ALLOW PEOPLE TO HEAR DIRECTLY FROM A DIVERSE ARRAY OF NOTABLE ARTISTS FROM AROUND THE WORLD. BY REMOVING THE PHYSICAL, CULTURAL, AND LINGUISTIC BARRIERS, VISITORS AND LISTENERS WILL FEEL WELCOMED IN THE GALLERY SPACES, AND HAVE ACCESS TO BILINGUAL PROGRAMS AND MATERIALS.

THE LAFAYETTE HISTORY MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT AN INVENTORY OF ITS COLLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 4,000 ARTIFACTS AND INCREASE DIGITAL ACCESS TO THE MATERIAL. THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION INCLUDES AGRICULTURAL AND COAL MINING TOOLS, TEXTILES, ARCHIVAL DOCUMENTS, ORAL HISTORIES, MAPS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS PERTAINING TO THE HISTORY OF LAFAYETTE, COLORADO. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO HELP COMPLETE THE INVENTORY AND TRAIN VOLUNTEER AND PAID STUDENT INTERNS IN OBJECT HANDLING AND DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL UPLOAD DIGITIZED RECORDS TO AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE. ONCE COMPLETED, THE UPDATED DATABASE WILL ALLOW FOR THE PUBLIC AND RESEARCHERS TO ACCESS THE COLLECTION MORE EASILY.

MIDWEST MINIATURES MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE AND PUBLISH ONLINE THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION OF MINIATURES, INCLUDING ARCHITECTURAL SCALE MODELS, DIORAMAS, FURNITURE, AND PAINTINGS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER AND ADDITIONAL STAFF TO PHOTOGRAPH ITEMS AND CONDUCT DATA MIGRATION TO THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. INCREASED INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE COLLECTIONS CARE, INCREASE INTERNAL ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTION, AND MITIGATE THE RISK OF HANDLING THE MINIATURES FOR RESEARCH AND EXHIBITION PURPOSES. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, STAFF WILL MAKE PROJECT METADATA ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH THE MUSEUM WEBSITE.

THE AUTOMOTIVE HALL OF FAME WILL CONDUCT AN INVENTORY OF ITS COLLECTION OF AUTOMOBILES AND ARTIFACTS RELATED TO THE MOTOR VEHICLE INDUSTRY OF METRO DETROIT. ALONG WITH THE COLLECTIONS INVENTORY, THE STAFF WILL ALSO UPDATE THE RECORDS IN THEIR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND MONITOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITION OF THE COLLECTION. STAFF WILL ALSO RECEIVE TRAINING ON DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT AND UPDATED COLLECTIONS PROCEDURES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED COLLECTION STEWARDSHIP AND GREATER STAFF AND VISITOR ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTION FOR THE PURPOSES OF RESEARCH AND EXHIBITIONS.

THE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF THE EAST END WILL EXPAND ESTRELLAS DE LECTURA/READING STARS, A READING MENTORSHIP PROGRAM THAT IMPROVES SOCIAL EMOTIONAL LEARNING SKILLS, AND RESTORES AND SUPPORTS READING FLUENCY IN BILINGUAL CHILDREN THAT WERE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY LEARNING LOSS AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE GATHERING INFORMATION THROUGH COMMUNITY MEETINGS, RECRUITING AND TRAINING READING MENTORS, UPDATING THE CURRICULUM, AND PROMOTING THE PROGRAM THROUGH COMMUNITY PARTNERS. STUDENTS ENTERING GRADES KINDERGARTEN THROUGH FOURTH WILL MEET WITH THEIR READING MENTORS TWICE A WEEK IN THE FALL, WINTER, AND SPRING AT THE MUSEUM’S BRIDGEHAMPTON AND RIVERSIDE LOCATIONS. AS A RESULT, STUDENTS WILL SEE IMPROVEMENTS IN THEIR ENGLISH READING FLUENCY AND GENERAL VOCABULARY, INCREASED SELF-CONFIDENCE, AND IMPROVEMENTS IN SOCIAL EMOTIONAL LEARNING SKILLS.

HISTORIC CHERRY HILL WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE A MULTI-SITE EXHIBIT AND RELATED SERIES OF PROGRAMS CENTERED ON WILLIAM JAMES KNAPP, WHO WORKED IN NINETEENTH-CENTURY ALBANY AS A MUSICIAN, PIANO TUNER, MUSIC STORE CLERK, PORTER, AND NURSE. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD EDUCATION CENTER, THE AFRICAN AMERICAN CULTURAL CENTER, AND ALBANY BARN, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY POP-UP SITES THROUGHOUT ALBANY, CONDUCT CONTENT RESEARCH, AND WORK WITH LOCAL ARTISTS TO CREATE SITE-SPECIFIC INTERPRETATIONS OF JAMES KNAPP’S LIFE. AS A RESULT, VISITORS TO ANY OF THE POP-UP SITES WILL EXPERIENCE RELEVANT AND ACCESSIBLE INSTALLATIONS THAT FOREGROUND BLACK LIFE IN 19TH-CENTURY ALBANY AND RECOGNIZE OUR DIVERSE, SHARED PAST AND ITS LEGACIES.

THE AURORA GRAND ARMY OF THE REPUBLIC MEMORIAL MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY AND REHOUSE OBJECTS IN NEWLY PURCHASED STORAGE CABINETRY FOR ITS COLLECTIONS RELATED TO THE HISTORY OF WARTIME AND SUBSEQUENT PEACETIME EXPERIENCES OF THE COMMUNITY AND ITS VETERANS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL FOLLOW RECOMMENDATIONS IDENTIFIED IN A COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT. DURING THE REHOUSING PROCESS, STAFF WILL INVENTORY AND COMPLETE A CONDITION ASSESSMENT OF THE COLLECTION. BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE MUSEUM STAFF, MILITARY HISTORIANS, AND RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF AURORA AND THE SURROUNDING AREAS.

CHESTERWOOD, A HISTORIC SITE OF THE NATIONAL TRUST FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION, WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL MUSEUM-QUALITY STORAGE CABINETS FOR OBJECTS AND ARCHIVAL FILES, AND ALLOW SPACE FOR SCHOLARLY RESEARCH IN THE NEWLY CREATED CHESTERWOOD COLLECTIONS AND RESEARCH CENTER. AS THE FORMER HOME, STUDIO, AND GARDENS OF SCULPTOR DANIEL CHESTER FRENCH (1850-1931), CHESTERWOOD HAS THE LARGEST COLLECTION OF ART BY FRENCH, IN ADDITION TO WORKS BY OTHER ARTISTS, HISTORIC DOCUMENTS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS. THE PROJECT WILL MAXIMIZE NEWLY RENOVATED SPACE THROUGH THE INSTALLATION OF A HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE SHELVING SYSTEM, CREATING OPTIMAL AND EFFICIENT STORAGE THAT WILL ENSURE THE LONGEVITY OF THE COLLECTION AND INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY FOR STUDENTS, ARTISTS, RESEARCHERS, CURATORS, MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND STAFF.

HISTORIC SARANAC LAKE WILL CREATE CATALOG RECORDS FOR APPROXIMATELY 2,500 OBJECTS AND ARCHIVAL MATERIALS TO GAIN INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTION. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS IMLS-FUNDED PILOT PROJECT TO CATALOG RECORDS FOR APPROXIMATELY 2,000 PHOTOGRAPHS AND POSTCARDS FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS, THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE PHOTO DOCUMENTATION OF OBJECTS AND THE CREATION OF A PLAN FOR MOVING THE COLLECTION TO A NEW STORAGE SPACE. PROJECT STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CONSULTANT TO COMPLETE AND EVALUATE THE PROJECT. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE INSTITUTION WILL PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE MOVING PLAN FOR THE COLLECTION, PUBLISH CATALOG RECORDS AND IMAGES, AND INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND STAFF PREPARING FOR EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMS.

EUREKA COLLEGE’S RONALD REAGAN MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A MUSEUM VISITOR MOBILE APPLICATION THAT CONTAINS GUIDED TOURS, OBJECT HIGHLIGHTS AND INFORMATION, AND SCAVENGER HUNTS TO INCREASE INTERPRETATION OF, AND ACCESS TO, THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ACQUIRING THE APPLICATION PLATFORM, DEVELOPING CONTENT, AND TESTING AND EVALUATING THE APPLICATION. THE RESULTING INTERACTIVE MOBILE APPLICATION WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM COLLECTION, IMPROVE VISITOR ACCESS, AND PROVIDE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR EUREKA COLLEGE STUDENTS AND MUSEUM VISITORS.

THE CAYUGA MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND ART WILL COMPLETE THE RESEARCH PHASE OF THE MUSEUM’S PLANNED PERMANENT EXHIBIT EXPLORING THE COMPREHENSIVE HISTORY OF CAYUGA COUNTY. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HIRING A NEW CURATOR AND A PAID INTERN WHO WILL CREATE A NEW INTERPRETIVE PLAN WHICH WILL BE USED AS THE FRAMEWORK TO INFORM THE EXHIBIT PLAN AND FINAL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NEW EXHIBIT. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL ACTIVELY EXPLORE THE NARRATIVE OF HISTORICALLY EXCLUDED COMMUNITIES WITH THE GOAL TO CREATE AN INVITING SPACE FOR CONSISTENT ENGAGEMENT WITH REGIONAL HISTORY.

THE HISTORICAL MUSEUM AT FORT MISSOULA WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE AN IMMERSIVE EXHIBIT CENTERED ON THE WORLD WAR II ERA ALIEN DETENTION CENTER. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND THE INTERPRETATION OF THIS IMPORTANT PART OF HISTORY THROUGH RESTORING THE DETENTION CENTER BARRACKS WHERE OVER 2,000 JAPANESE AND ITALIAN MEN WERE DETAINED AT FORT MISSOULA’S DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE CAMP. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ENGAGE WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGN CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP AN EXHIBIT DESIGN PLAN, GATHER IDEAS FROM LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS, IDENTIFY ARTIFACTS OR REPLICAS FOR DISPLAY, AND CREATE INTERPRETIVE SIGNS. THE EXHIBIT WILL ALLOW VISITORS TO SEE HOW THE DETAINEES LIVED AND UNDERSTAND MORE ABOUT THIS DARK TIME IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL HISTORY SO THAT AS A SOCIETY WE DO NOT REPEAT IT.

THE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF BROWNSVILLE WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO PLAY-BASED STEM EXPERIENCES THROUGH A NEW EXHIBIT TITLED, “REACH FOR THE STARS.” THE INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT WILL FOCUS ON MIXED AIR TRAVEL SUCH AS AIRPLANES, BLIMPS, ROCKETS, AND DRONES WHILE MAKING A CONNECTION BETWEEN PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE TO DEMONSTRATE THE ADVANCEMENTS IN SCIENTIFIC TECHNOLOGY AND THE POTENTIAL THAT IT HOLDS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE WITH DOSEUM IN SAN ANTONIO TO CREATE EXHIBITION SCHEMATICS AND SERVE AS THE FABRICATION PROJECT MANAGER. BY ENCOURAGING A NEW GENERATION OF STUDENTS, MAINLY YOUNG GIRLS, TO DEVELOP AN INTEREST IN PROBLEM-SOLVING, COLLABORATION, COMMUNICATION SKILLS, AND DISCOVERY, THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE VISITORS WITH A MEANINGFUL DIRECTION REGARDING THEIR FUTURE STUDIES AND CAREERS.

JAMES MONROE’S HIGHLAND WILL CREATE A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICY AND INCREASE INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTION OF OBJECTS RELATED TO THE HISTORY OF PRESIDENT JAMES MONROE AND THE ENSLAVED PEOPLE WHO ALSO RESIDED ON THE PROPERTY. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO WORK WITH STAFF AND A POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCH FELLOW TO CREATE THE NEW POLICY. THE NEW HIRE WILL ALSO MANAGE THE CATALOGUING AND REHOUSING OF THE COLLECTION AS WELL AS AID IN THE REINTERPRETATION OF THE GALLERIES. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, STAFF WILL PRODUCE A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE COLLECTIONS GUIDE THAT HIGHLIGHTS A SUBSET OF HISTORIC OBJECTS.

THE SOUTHEAST OHIO HISTORY CENTER WILL INVENTORY ITS COLLECTION OF MORE THAN 70,000 THREE-DIMENSIONAL OBJECTS, INCLUDING TEXTILES, CHILDREN’S ITEMS, ARCHAEOLOGICAL MATERIAL, NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS, MILITARY COLLECTIONS, ARTWORK, AND ITEMS RELATING TO SOUTHEAST OHIO’S INDUSTRIAL HISTORY. STAFF WILL HIRE AND TRAIN A COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO UNDERTAKE THE INVENTORY OF THE OBJECTS, UPDATE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT RECORDS, AND REHOUSE OBJECTS AS NEEDED FOR PRESERVATION PURPOSES. INCREASED INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE OBJECTS WILL IMPROVE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT AND INCREASE INTERNAL ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTION.

THE DANFORTH ART MUSEUM AT FRAMINGHAM STATE UNIVERSITY WILL REHOUSE AND IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF OBJECTS IN ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION OF OVER 3,600 WORKS OF ART. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CURATORIAL FELLOW TO IMPLEMENT THE COLLECTION PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY PROJECT. THE FIRST PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE ARCHIVAL REHOUSING OF OBJECTS, INCLUDING SCULPTURES AND PORTRAITS. THE SECOND PHASE WILL IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF OBJECTS FOR DISPLAY BY REPLACING HANGING MATERIALS AND ADDING PROTECTIVE BACKINGS. THE THIRD PHASE WILL IMPROVE STORAGE SPECIFICALLY FOR FRAMES IN THE COLLECTION. INCREASED SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY OF COLLECTIONS IN STORAGE WILL BENEFIT STAFF, RESEARCHERS, AND COLLEGE CLASSES.

THE CASA MUSEO JESUS T. PINERO WILL UNDERGO A NEW AUDIENCE DEVELOPMENT AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROJECT TO PROVIDE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO 450 LOCAL MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. THE NEW PROGRAM WILL OFFER TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT THAT CONTAINS A DIGITAL MODULE CREATED FOR CLASSROOM USE COUPLED WITH IN-PERSON FIELD TRIPS TO THE MUSEUM. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HIRING A PART-TIME PROJECT COORDINATOR WHO WILL DEVELOP A RELATIONSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOLS AND COORDINATE IN-PERSON FIELD TRIPS, AS WELL AS FOUR PAID COLLEGE INTERNS WHO WILL BE FIELD TRIP TOUR GUIDES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN HELPING STUDENTS DEVELOP A SENSE OF PRIDE IN THEIR HISTORY AND CULTURE AND INSPIRE THEM TO DELVE DEEPER INTO THE HISTORY OF PUERTO RICO.

BUILDING ON PREVIOUS COLLECTION DIGITIZATION PROJECTS, EARLHAM COLLEGE’S JOSEPH MOORE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP A COLLECTIONS-BASED INTERPRETATIVE PLAN THAT HIGHLIGHTS THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS IN PUBLIC SPACES TO INCREASE INTERACTION WITH AND AWARENESS OF THE COLLECTION. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ACQUIRING TWO PORTABLE DIGITIZATION STATIONS AND ONE COLLECTIONS KIOSK, CONDUCTING VISITOR SURVEYS AND EVALUATIONS, AND DRAFTING AND FINALIZING THE COLLECTIONS-BASED INTERPRETIVE PLAN. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED VISITOR INTERACTION WITH THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS AND THE TECHNOLOGY UPGRADES WILL IMPROVE VISITOR ENGAGEMENT WHILE COLLECTING VALUABLE INFORMATION ON HOW THE PUBLIC INTERACTS WITH THE COLLECTION.

THE LIVINGSTON COUNTY HISTORICAL MUSEUM WILL USE FUNDS TO PURCHASE AND INSTALL ARCHIVAL STORAGE EQUIPMENT. THE PROJECT BUILDS UPON PLANNING DOCUMENTS CREATED BY A TEAM OF MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS, ARCHITECTS, AND ENGINEERS, AND WILL ADDRESS ISSUES OF OVERCROWDING AND INACCESSIBILITY OF OBJECTS IN THE CURRENT STORAGE SPACE. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, MUSEUM STAFF WILL CONSULT WITH A CONSERVATOR TO IMPLEMENT BEST PRACTICES FOR COLLECTION STORAGE. IMPROVED COLLECTIONS CARE WILL BENEFIT VISITORS AND RESEARCHERS, INCLUDING THE RESIDENTS OF LIVINGSTON COUNTY AND THE WESTERN NEW YORK REGION.

THE HEURICH HOUSE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS PUBLIC PROGRAMS IN ORDER TO REACH AUDIENCES CURRENTLY EXCLUDED FROM MUSEUM TOURS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CREATION OF SELF-GUIDED TOUR MATERIALS ACCESSIBLE VIA QR CODES, INSTALLATION OF TACTILE COMPONENTS IN THE GALLERIES, AND TRANSLATION OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE MATERIALS TO SPANISH AND GERMAN. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ENGAGE WITH A TEACHER-IN-RESIDENCE AND A PART-TIME MUSEUM INTERPRETATION CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP LESSON PLANS FOR IN-GALLERY ACTIVITIES, AND TO PLAN AND EXECUTE BETA TEST EXPERIENCES AND SURVEYS. AS A RESULT, MUSEUM VISITORS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL INTERPRETIVE PRODUCTS INCLUDING A MAP OF EXHIBIT ROOMS, VISUAL LABELS THAT INTERPRET THE MUSEUM’S EXHIBIT ROOMS, IMAGES, AND VOICE RECORDINGS TO ASSIST THE VISUALLY IMPAIRED.

THE GREAT AMERICAN SONGBOOK FOUNDATION WILL CONDUCT A DIGITAL COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT WHICH WILL RESULT IN THE PURCHASE OF A NEW DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT (DAM) SYSTEM FOR OVER 8,000 DIGITIZED COLLECTION ITEMS. STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING FOR THE NEW DAM SYSTEM AND PLAN FOR THE SCALABLE GROWTH OF THEIR COLLECTIONS, AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT WILL BE INFORMED BY STAFF INPUT AND FEEDBACK. IMPROVED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT WILL BENEFIT STAFF AND AID IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE PROGRAMMING. EXTERNAL USERS, SUCH AS RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, AND PERFORMERS WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM INCREASED COLLECTION ACCESS.

THE SCIENCE MILL WILL EXPAND THE IMLS-FUNDED PILOT PROJECT, SUMMER STEM CAREER INITIATIVE (SCI) CAMPS PROGRAM, INTO THE BIG BEND REGION OF FAR WEST TEXAS, AN UNDERSERVED RURAL TEXAS COMMUNITY. THE EXPANSION WILL CONSIST OF OFFERING IMMERSIVE SUMMER STEM CAMPS, SUPPORTED BY THE MUSEUM’S MOBILE STEM VAN INITIATIVE TO 3RD-8TH GRADE STUDENTS. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SUL ROSS STATE UNIVERSITY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP AND OFFER ONE-WEEK LONG CAMPS BASED IN REAL-WORLD STEM CAREER SCENARIOS INCLUDING CODING AND PROGRAMMING, ENGINEERING, LIFE SCIENCES, ROBOTICS, AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP. AS A RESULT, RURAL STUDENTS WILL INCREASE THEIR INTEREST IN STEM LEARNING AND SEE THEMSELVES AS PART OF A FUTURE 21ST CENTURY SKILLED WORKFORCE. STUDENT OUTCOME AND IMPACT WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH ANALYSIS OF SURVEY RESPONSES AND WILL TRACK A VARIETY OF METRICS SPECIFIC TO CAMPER EXPERIENCE.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY'S EVERGREEN MUSEUM AND LIBRARY WILL DEVELOP AN INTERPRETIVE PLAN FOR THE MUSEUM THAT INCLUDES CURRENT, COMPREHENSIVE, AND INCLUSIVE SCHOLARSHIP. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING STAFF FEEDBACK SESSIONS, HOLDING PUBLIC DISCUSSION SESSIONS, DEVELOPING AN IMPLEMENTATION TIMELINE, AND DRAFTING AND FINALIZING THE INTERPRETIVE PLAN. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE ENGAGING A MUSEUM CONSULTANT TO EVALUATE THE CURRENT MUSEUM GUIDED TOUR AND TO WRITE THE INTERPRETIVE PLAN. THE RESULTING INTERPRETATIVE PLAN WILL BE USED TO GUIDE THE CREATION OF FUTURE INTERPRETIVE EFFORTS TO MAKE THE MUSEUM MORE ACCESSIBLE AND RELEVANT FOR VISITORS, UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, AND THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY.

THE MAIDU MUSEUM AND HISTORIC SITE WILL PROVIDE A PLATFORM FOR LOCAL NATIVE AMERICANS TO SHARE THEIR PERSPECTIVE, TRADITIONS, AND CONTEMPORARY CULTURE WITH THE GREATER SACRAMENTO REGION BY REVIVING THE NIGHT OUT AT THE MUSEUM PROGRAM. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIVE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, MUSEUM STAFF WILL DEVELOP FREE MONTHLY PROGRAMS FEATURING LOCAL NATIVE ARTISTS, AUTHORS, CULTURE BEARERS, AND SCHOLARS, AND REVIEW SUBMITTED PROPOSALS FROM NATIVE ARTISTS TO CO-CURATE THREE EXHIBITS. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE COMMUNITY’S CULTURAL LITERACY REGARDING LOCAL INDIGENOUS CULTURES BY ENCOURAGING CIVIL DISCOURSE AMONG ALL COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND CREATING A SAFE AND WELCOMING SPACE FOR RESPECTFUL PUBLIC DISCUSSION. TO MEASURE THE SUCCESSFUL ACHIEVEMENT OF THESE GOALS, SURVEYS WILL BE COLLECTED AFTER EACH NIGHT OUT PROGRAM AND FROM ART EXHIBITS VISITORS TO GATHER BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DATA.

THE ROSA PARKS MUSEUM AT TROY UNIVERSITY WILL CREATE A MOBILE APP TO FOSTER DEEPER ENGAGEMENT WITH MUSEUM CONTENT, MAKE THE MUSEUM MORE ACCESSIBLE TO NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING VISITORS, AND MAKE THE MUSEUM CONTENT ACCESSIBLE VIRTUALLY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CREATING A STORYBOARD, INCORPORATING MIXED REALITY TECHNOLOGY, SUCH AS VIDEO, AUDIO, AND LIVE SIMULATION, AND ASSEMBLING A PANEL OF HUMANITIES SCHOLARS TO ASSIST WITH CONTENT DEVELOPMENT. THE APP WILL ALLOW USERS TO HAVE AN IMMERSIVE EXPERIENCE WITH PRIMARY SOURCES FROM THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION, AND GAIN A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING THAT, REGARDLESS OF COLOR, BLACK HISTORY IS THE STORY OF OUR SHARED HISTORY AND EXPERIENCES. THE APP WILL BE AVAILABLE IN DIFFERENT LANGUAGES TO PEOPLE AROUND THE WORLD.

THE SANDWICH HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL CONSERVE FIVE OBJECTS FROM ITS COLLECTION AND CURATE A SUBSEQUENT EXHIBITION AND ASSOCIATED PROGRAMMING TO HIGHLIGHT THESE CONSERVATION EFFORTS. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK WITH CONSERVATORS TO PRESERVE 3 PAINTINGS BY ARTIST ENOCH W. PERRY, AN HISTORICAL PAPER PASSPORT DOCUMENT BELONGING TO ALBERT GALLATIN HOIT, AND A FEDERAL-STYLE WOODEN DESK FROM THE EARLY 1800S. THE OBJECTS WILL THEN BE HIGHLIGHTED IN A CONSERVATION-FOCUSED EXHIBITION, ALONGSIDE OTHER PREVIOUSLY CONSERVED ARTIFACTS AND WILL ALSO INCLUDE A PUBLIC LECTURE SERIES ABOUT CONSERVATION CONCEPTS.

THE ALABAMA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL REHOUSE AND DIGITIZE ITS BEETLE COLLECTION, CONSISTING OF APPROXIMATELY 50,000 SPECIMENS DATING FROM THE EARLY 1900S. MUSEUM STAFF WILL STABILIZE, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE ENTOMOLOGICAL SPECIMENS IN IMPROVED STORAGE CABINETRY. ADDITIONALLY, STAFF WILL WORK WITH VOLUNTEERS AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO DIGITIZE COLLECTION INFORMATION AND MAKE COLLECTION INFORMATION AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH AN ONLINE DATABASE. ENHANCING THE STORAGE CONDITIONS AND INCREASING INTELLECTUAL CONTROL WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE COLLECTION. ONCE COMPLETED, THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE COLLECTION FOR SCIENTISTS, STUDENTS, AND SCHOLARS.

THE BERMAN MUSEUM OF ART WILL DIGITIZE THE ARCHIVES AND ARTWORK IN ITS COLLECTION OF ARTIST FRANÇOISE GILOT, WHO WAS A MEMBER OF THE SCHOOL OF PARIS AND THE LONG-TIME PARTNER OF PABLO PICASSO. THE COLLECTION INCLUDES 270 WORKS OF ART, INCLUDING LITHOGRAPHS AND ETCHINGS. STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING ON DIGITIZATION AND WORK WITH A PAID STUDENT COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO INPUT METADATA AND REHOUSE THE COLLECTION. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, HIGH-RESOLUTION PHOTOGRAPHS AND DETAILED METADATA RECORDS OF THE ARTIST’S ARCHIVES, PAINTINGS, AND WORKS ON PAPER WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE TO STUDENTS, SCHOLARS, EDUCATORS, AND ARTISTS.

THE CHESAPEAKE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM WILL ENHANCE THEIR PRE-K THROUGH 8TH GRADE EDUCATION OFFERINGS BY INCORPORATING INDOOR AND OUTDOOR PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS THAT ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE OF CREATIVITY AND WELL-BEING. IN COLLABORATION WITH A CREATIVITY SPECIALIST, STAFF WILL INTEGRATE THE SCIENCE OF CREATIVE WELL-BEING WITH AGE APPROPRIATE LESSONS AND USE EXAMPLES OF HISTORICAL FIGURES – FOCUSING ON AFRICAN AMERICAN AND HISPANIC INDIVIDUALS - WHO USED INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS FOR THE CHALLENGES THEY FACED. STAFF, VOLUNTEERS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL BE PROVIDED WITH TRAINING RELATED TO CREATIVITY AND WELLNESS EDUCATION. AS A RESULT, THE MUSEUM WILL OFFER BILINGUAL PROGRAMMING AND OUTDOOR SIGNAGE TO VISITORS FROM ANNE ARUNDEL COUNTY.

THE GOLD NUGGET MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT STAFF TRAINING AND DEVELOP MUSEUM OPERATIONAL MANUALS TO HELP THE MUSEUM REBUILD AFTER LOSING ITS ORIGINAL LOCATION, NEARLY ITS ENTIRE COLLECTION, AND ALL RECORDS TO CALIFORNIA’S 2018 CAMP FIRE WILDFIRE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROFESSIONAL TRAINING FOR MUSEUM STAFF, INCLUDING WORKSHOPS, CLASSES, AND WEBINARS TO BUILD INTERNAL INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY. ONCE THE TRAINING IS COMPLETE, STAFF WILL CREATE FOUR POLICY AND PROCEDURES MANUALS INCLUDING A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT MANUAL, EXHIBIT DEVELOPMENT AND INSTALLATION MANUAL, EMERGENCY PLAN, AND A VISITOR SERVICES/DOCENT MANUAL. THE PROJECT WILL GUIDE THE PROFESSIONAL OPERATION OF THE MUSEUM AND SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF EFFECTIVE AND ENGAGING EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMMING FOR MUSEUM VISITORS.

THE IMPERIAL VALLEY DESERT MUSEUM WILL USE FUNDS TO HIRE A CURATORIAL FELLOW TO WORK WITH AN INDIGENOUS KUMEYAAY CONSULTANT. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COMPLETE AN ASSESSMENT OF CERAMIC ARTIFACTS IN ORDER TO BETTER UNDERSTAND ANCESTRAL KUMEYAAY SOCIAL GROUP ACTIVITIES AS INTERPRETED THROUGH THEIR POTTERY ASSEMBLAGES. STAFF WILL UPLOAD AND RECORD THE ANALYSES INTO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE RESULTING DATASET WILL THEN BE MADE AVAILABLE FOR REQUEST ON THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, CERAMIC SPECIALISTS, TRIBAL NATIONS, AND OTHER CULTURAL SPECIALISTS.

THE SKID ROW HISTORY MUSEUM AND ARCHIVE WILL CREATE THE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT, “WELCOME TO THE VAGABOND HOTEL.” THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE INTERPERSONAL AND HOLISTIC PANDEMIC RESPONSE DEVELOPED ON-THE-FLY BY HEALTH WORKERS WHO RAN LOS ANGELES COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT’S EMERGENCY QUARANTINE AND ISOLATION SITES CREATED FOR HOUSELESS COVID PATIENTS AND PEOPLE EXPOSED TO COVID IN SHELTERS. THE MUSEUM AND A TEAM OF COLLABORATORS, INCLUDING ARTISTS FROM SKID ROW, WILL PRODUCE THEATRICAL PERFORMANCES, AN EXHIBITION, AND TRANSFORM THE GALLERY INTO A REPLICA OF A QUARANTINE AND ISOLATION SITE. SKID ROW COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND HOUSING ADVOCATES, AS WELL AS POLICY MAKERS, JOURNALISTS, SCHOLARS, AND PUBLIC AUDIENCES WILL BENEFIT FROM KNOWLEDGE GAINED ABOUT THE WAYS COMPASSIONATE PRACTICES CAN LEAD TO BETTER OUTCOMES FOR INDIVIDUALS AND SOCIETY.

SEA TURTLE INC. WILL INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY TO ITS ONSITE SCHOOL PROGRAMS BY DESIGNING A STATE-OF-THE-ART EDUCATION CLASSROOM IN ORDER TO PROVIDE QUALITY SCIENCE-BASED EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN ALIGNMENT WITH TEXAS STATE SCIENCE STANDARDS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE OUTFITTING THE CLASSROOM WITH UPDATED EQUIPMENT AND TECHNOLOGY, AND DEVELOPING CURRICULUM FOR 5TH-12TH GRADE SCHOOL GROUPS WITH A FOCUS ON THE RIO GRANDE VALLEY. THROUGH HANDS-ON, INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES, STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT AN ARRAY OF SCIENTIFIC TOPICS INCLUDING: CLASSIFICATION, ADAPTATIONS, ANATOMY, WATER QUALITY, PH, SALINITY, AND CURRENT CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS. AN EVALUATION PLAN WILL INCLUDE SURVEYING WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS TO ENSURE THAT STUDENTS LEARN ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT, WHICH WILL HELP FOSTER THE NEXT GENERATION OF OCEAN STEWARDS.

THE BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE MUSEUM AND ARTS CENTER WILL CATALOG APPROXIMATELY 2,000 OBJECTS FROM ITS COLLECTION RELATED TO THE HISTORIC BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE. FOR THE PROJECT, THE INSTITUTION WILL HIRE A PART-TIME COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO WORK WITH PAID INTERNS ON DATA ENTRY AND COLLECTIONS STAFF WILL TRAIN INTERNS ON OBJECT HANDLING AND CATALOGUING. AFTER DATA ENTRY AND PHOTO DOCUMENTATION OF OBJECTS IS COMPLETE, STAFF WILL MAKE RECORDS ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC ONLINE. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE INCREASED INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OVER THE COLLECTION.

THE SEE SCIENCE CENTER WILL INCREASE ITS ABILITY TO WELCOME VISITORS WITH DISABILITIES BY REMOVING BARRIERS IN THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT AND THROUGH A NEW INCLUSIVE CUSTOMER SERVICE STAFF TRAINING PROGRAM. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING TWO UNIVERSAL DESIGN PRINCIPLES STAFF TRAININGS FOR SEE’S ACCESS TEAM; SELECTING, ORDERING, AND INSTALLING NEW ACCESSIBLE EQUIPMENT AND FURNISHINGS; CREATING AN ACOUSTIC MITIGATION REPORT; AND DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING NEW INCLUSIVE STAFF CUSTOMER SERVICE TRAINING BASED ON UNIVERSAL DESIGN PRINCIPLES. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE ENGAGING A CONSULTANT TO SERVE AS SEE’S ACCESSIBILITY AND INCLUSION ADVISOR AND TRAINER. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A MORE WELCOMING AND ACCESSIBLE SPACE FOR ALL VISITORS INCLUDING THOSE WITH PHYSICAL AND NEUROSENSORY DISABILITIES.

INFORMED BY THE FINDINGS OF A CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, THE PINAL COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL HIRE A PART-TIME COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO WORK WITH PAID INTERNS ON PROJECT ACTIVITIES THAT WILL INCLUDE A COMPREHENSIVE INVENTORY AND AN UPDATE THEIR COLLECTIONS RECORDS.  AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, STAFF WILL IMPROVE COLLECTION STEWARDSHIP AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE COLLECTIONS CARE, INCLUDING LONG-TERM PLANNING AND DEACCESSIONING. BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE THE LOCAL COMMUNITY OF FLORENCE, ARIZONA, WHICH INCLUDES MEMBERS OF THE TOHONO O’ODHAM NATION, AND MEXICAN AND AFRICAN AMERICAN POPULATIONS.

THE SAN DIEGO CHILDREN’S DISCOVERY MUSEUM WILL EMBARK ON THE BUILDING, CREATING, AND EXPANSION PHASE OF THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLES PROJECT TO STRENGTHEN STAFF AND VISITOR'S CULTURAL APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE CITY OF ESCONDIDO’S FIRST PEOPLES, THE KUMEYAAY NATION AND LUISEÑO TRIBES. MUSEUM STAFF AND TRIBAL CONSULTANTS WILL OFFER ONSITE INDIGENOUS PEOPLES EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND STORYTELLING PROGRAMS, STAFF DEVELOPMENT AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES, AND FREE ACCESS TO THE MOBILE STEM WORKSHOPS FOR LOCAL TRIBAL SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS. AS A RESULT, THE MUSEUM WILL SOLIDIFY NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND ENGAGE INDIGENOUS PEOPLES PARTNERS TO HELP ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, AND CHILDREN AND CAREGIVERS WILL DEVELOP AN APPRECIATION FOR NATURAL RESOURCES THROUGH THE LENS OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES.

THE SCIENCE ZONE WILL FABRICATE A SERIES OF TRAVELING EXHIBITIONS, KNOWN AS FLEXCART, TO REACH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE OF WYOMING. THE CARTS ARE MOBILE AND SMALL ENOUGH TO BE PUSHED THROUGH A CLASSROOM DOOR, AND FOCUS ON TEACHING STEM TOPICS USING A HANDS-ON INTERACTIVE APPROACH. FLEXCARTS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE FOR BOOKING BY FAMILY-SERVING AGENCIES ACROSS THE STATE, AS WELL AS NATRONA COUNTY SERVICE PROVIDERS. THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF STATEWIDE PARTNERSHIPS, CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES IN RURAL COMMUNITIES WILL GET TO EXPERIENCE HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES AND MUSEUM QUALITY STEM EXHIBITS AT NO COST.

THE BREVARD ZOO WILL IMPLEMENT A 12-WEEK PAID ANIMAL KEEPER INTERNSHIP PROGRAM FOR FIVE MINORITY STUDENTS OR RECENT GRADUATES DESIGNED TO INCREASE DIVERSITY IN THE ANIMAL CARE FIELD. THE PROGRAM, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BETHUNE-COOKMAN UNIVERSITY, WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE, ONE-ON-ONE MENTORING, AND TRAINING FROM EXPERIENCED ANIMAL CARE STAFF, AND WILL SUPPORT PARTICIPANT HOUSING, TRANSPORTATION, AND STIPENDS. THIS PROGRAM WILL NURTURE EACH PARTICIPANT’S PASSION FOR ANIMAL CARE AND CONSERVATION AND INCREASE CONFIDENCE IN, AND COMMITMENT TO, THE ANIMAL CARE FIELD. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES OF THIS INTERNSHIP PROGRAM INCLUDE FUTURE EMPLOYMENT IN THE ZOOLOGICAL OR ANIMAL CARE FIELDS AND CONTRIBUTE TO GROWING A DIVERSE WORKFORCE THAT HAS A WIDER RANGE OF EXPERIENCE AND VIEWPOINTS, BETTER PREPARING THE ZOO AND THE FIELD TO ENGAGE DIVERSE AUDIENCES.

THE SOUTH DAKOTA DISCOVERY CENTER WILL ADDRESS EDUCATIONAL DISPARITIES FOR RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN THE FIELD OF STEM BY ACQUIRING A NEW USER-FRIENDLY, PORTABLE PLANETARIUM SYSTEM. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE WORKING WITH CONSULTANTS TO DEVELOP STAR SHOWS FOR K-12 STUDENTS, AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS AND SUMMER CAMPS, PROVIDE TRAINING FOR STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS, AND WORK WITH LONGSTANDING TRIBAL COMMUNITY PARTNERS ON A LAKOTA STAR KNOWLEDGE PROGRAM THAT INCORPORATES INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE. THE NEW PLANETARIUM SYSTEM WILL INCREASE THE SELF-EFFICACY OF MUSEUM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS TO DELIVER IMMERSIVE PROGRAMS AND EXPAND CAPACITY FOR AUTHENTIC CAREER EXPLORATION OPPORTUNITIES THAT UTILIZES INQUIRY- AND EVIDENCE-BASED INFORMAL PROGRAMMING IN PUBLIC, IN-SCHOOL, AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL SETTINGS. THE PROJECT WILL BE EVALUATED BY ANALYZING PRE AND POST LEARNING ASSESSMENTS AND END-OF-PROGRAM REFLECTION PROMPTS.

THE MEETEETSE MUSEUMS WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY SCANNING AND DIGITIZING ITS COLLECTION OF OVER 100 BOUND MATERIALS, INCLUDING A SCRAPBOOK OF PHOTOGRAPHER CHARLES BELDEN. BY DIGITIZING OBJECTS WITH A NEW OVERSIZE BOOK SCANNER, THE INSTITUTION WILL REDUCE THE HANDLING OF OBJECTS AND PREVENT STRAIN ON BINDINGS. THE INSTITUTION WILL ALSO MAKE THE LARGE FORMAT SCANNER AVAILABLE FOR USE BY OTHER RURAL MUSEUMS IN NORTHWESTERN WYOMING. PROJECT STAFF WILL WORK WITH DIGITAL COLLECTIONS INTERNS TO UPLOAD THE RECORDS TO A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE DATABASE.

THE FAIRBANKS MUSEUM AND PLANETARIUM WILL REHOUSE ITS ENTOMOLOGY COLLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 240,000 SPECIMENS INTO NEW ARCHIVAL STORAGE CABINETS. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE VERMONT CENTER FOR ECOSTUDIES, THE MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH VOLUNTEERS TO TEMPORARILY MOVE COLLECTIONS, REPLACE EXISTING CABINETRY, AND REHOUSE THE SPECIMENS, WHICH INCLUDE MOTHS AND BUTTERFLIES FROM AROUND THE WORLD. ADDITIONALLY, MUSEUM STAFF WILL DEVELOP AN EXHIBIT HIGHLIGHTING ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION IN RELATIONSHIP TO THE SPECIMENS. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, SPECIMENS WILL BE PRESERVED, AND RESEARCHERS AND MUSEUM STAFF WILL BE ABLE TO MORE EASILY ACCESS SPECIMENS FOR THE PURPOSES OF SCIENTIFIC STUDY AND EXHIBITION.

THE DAURA MUSEUM OF ART WILL DIGITALLY DOCUMENT AND CATALOG WORKS FROM ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION TO IMPROVE COLLECTION MANAGEMENT, PRESERVATION, AND ACCESSIBILITY FOR APPROXIMATELY 2,500 WORKS OF ART. THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION SERVES AS AN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE FOR TEACHING THROUGH THE INTERPRETATION AND EXHIBITION OF WORKS OF ART AND INCLUDES PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, WORKS ON PAPER, SCULPTURE, AND ETHNOGRAPHIC ARTIFACTS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A REGISTRAR TO CONDUCT AN INVENTORY OF THE COLLECTION, TRANSFER METADATA TO A COLLECTIONS DATABASE, AND PHOTO DOCUMENT THE COLLECTION. BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND RESEARCHERS, AS WELL AS THE SURROUNDING REGIONAL COMMUNITY.

LINDSAY WILDLIFE EXPERIENCE WILL CREATE THREE NEW AVIARY ANIMAL ENCLOSURE EXHIBITS IN THE NATURE COVE, AN OUTDOOR PROGRAM PRESENTATION AREA. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE UPGRADING THE AREA TO MAKE THE OUTDOOR EXHIBIT FULLY ADA ACCESSIBLE AND DEVELOPING INTERACTIVE SIGNAGE IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES. THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A LARGER INITIATIVE TO PROVIDE INTERACTIVE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE OF ALL AGES TO LEARN ABOUT WILDLIFE AND CONSERVATION IN A SAFE, OUTDOOR LOCATION WHERE VISITORS WILL FEEL COMFORTABLE VISITING EVEN DURING A PANDEMIC. AS A RESULT, THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE AVIARIES THAT EXCEED CURRENT CALIFORNIA FISH AND WILDLIFE REGULATIONS ON HOUSING LIVE, WILD ANIMALS, AND THE ANIMAL AMBASSADORS WILL HAVE A SAFE AND NATURAL HOME THAT WILL VASTLY IMPROVE THEIR WELFARE.

THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF ART AND SCIENCE WILL IMPROVE COLLECTION STEWARDSHIP AND ACCESSIBILITY FOR APPROXIMATELY 5,600 WORKS OF MEXICAN AND LATIN AMERICAN FOLK ART IN ITS COLLECTION. DURING THE PROJECT, STAFF WILL WORK WITH PAID INTERNS TO PHOTOGRAPH, CATALOG, AND INPUT DATA INTO A COLLECTIONS SOFTWARE DATABASE IN ORDER TO PROVIDE INTERNAL AND ONLINE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. LOCAL AND NATIONAL PROJECT ADVISORS WILL INFORM RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AND ASSIST STAFF IN REVIEWING SPANISH AND ENGLISH TEXT TRANSLATIONS RELATED TO THE OBJECTS.

THE ANTIQUE BOAT MUSEUM WILL INCREASE STAFF CAPACITY TO DIGITIZE TWO OF ITS COLLECTIONS PERTAINING TO THE HISTORY OF THE MATTHEWS BOAT OWNERS ASSOCIATION AND THE RICHARDSON BOAT OWNERS ASSOCIATION. THE MATTHEWS BOAT OWNERS ASSOCIATION COLLECTION CONTAINS APPROXIMATELY 30,000 DOCUMENTS AND THE RICHARDSON BOAT OWNERS ASSOCIATION CONTAINS APPROXIMATELY 5,000 DOCUMENTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND WORKS ON PAPER. PROJECT STAFF WILL CATALOG MATERIALS FROM THESE COLLECTIONS AND MAKE THE COLLECTIONS DIGITALLY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE WITH A SEARCHABLE COLLECTIONS DATABASE FOR THE BENEFIT OF MARITIME HISTORIANS AND THE PUBLIC.

THE KENTUCKY MUSEUM WILL COMPLETE THE REHOUSING OF ITS HISTORIC QUILT COLLECTION TO IMPROVE STEWARDSHIP OF AND ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. TO DO SO, THIS PROJECT WILL REHOUSE 126 QUILTS THAT ARE CURRENTLY STORED ON ROLLED TUBES AND PROVIDE AN ADDITIONAL 39 BOXES TO ENABLE REHOUSING OF QUILTS IN BOXES THAT ARE CURRENTLY OVERCROWDED. THE REHOUSED QUILTS WILL THEN BE STORED ON TWELVE NEW MOBILE SHELVING UNITS, CAPABLE OF HOLDING UP TO 14 BOXES EACH. INTENDED RESULTS INCLUDE SAFE HOUSING FOR THE QUILTS WHICH WILL FACILITATE EASIER ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS FOR STAFF AND RESEARCHERS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND RESULTS WILL ALSO BE SHARED THROUGH PRESS RELEASES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, AND THE MUSEUM’S NEWSLETTER.

THE SAN DIEGO CHINESE HISTORICAL MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE STORAGE CONDITIONS AND DOCUMENTATION OF APPROXIMATELY 2,000 OBJECTS FROM ITS PAPER AND TEXTILES COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS A LACK OF CLIMATE-CONTROLLED STORAGE SPACE AND THE NEED FOR IMPROVED COLLECTIONS DATA. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A PAID INTERN TO ACCESSION, DOCUMENT, DIGITIZE, AND PROPERLY REHOUSE OBJECTS COMPOSED OF SENSITIVE MATERIALS IN CLIMATE-CONTROLLED STORAGE FACILITIES. ADDITIONALLY, STAFF WILL HOST A PUBLIC PROGRAM FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO VIEW OBJECTS IN PERSON. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, OBJECTS WILL BE PRESERVED IN ARCHIVAL CONDITIONS AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE FOR EXHIBITION AND MUSEUM PROGRAMMING.

DIASPORA VIBE CULTURAL ARTS INCUBATOR WILL ADVANCE SHARED KNOWLEDGE AROUND MATERNAL FIGURE HOOD THROUGH AN EXHIBITION OF WORKS BY KATRINA COOMBS AND IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE HARVEY B. GANTT CENTER FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN ARTS AND CULTURE. THIS EXHIBITION WILL ADDRESS THE NEED IN EXHIBITING MORE FIBER ARTISTS AND TEXTILE ART, WHICH IS OFTEN RELATED TO A “HOBBY CRAFT,” AND WILL BRING AWARENESS TO THIS MEDIUM, WHILE ELEVATING THE WORK AND LABOR OF WOMEN ARTISTS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE EXHIBIT CONTENT DEVELOPMENT, COORDINATING WITH THE ARTIST ON SELECTING AND SHIPPING ARTWORKS, AND DEVELOPING PUBLIC PROGRAMS WITH THE GANTT CENTER. THE RESULTS WILL INCLUDE AN INCREASED AWARENESS OF THE WORK OF AFRO-DIASPORIC AND CARIBBEAN ARTISTS, AND A GREATER UNDERSTANDING AND FUTURE SCHOLARSHIP ON THE AFRICAN DIASPORA, THE CARIBBEAN, AND LATIN AMERICA.

THE HAITIAN AMERICAN MUSEUM OF CHICAGO WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTION RELATED TO THE HISTORY OF HAITIANS IN THE GLOBAL AFRICAN DIASPORA. STAFF WILL ESTABLISH A PRESERVATION PLAN FOR THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND LIBRARY THAT INCLUDES POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND A DISASTER PLAN. STAFF WILL THEN IMPLEMENT THE PRESERVATION PLAN AND UPDATE THE COLLECTION AND LIBRARY CATALOGS WITH MORE ACCURATE LABELS, DESCRIPTIONS AND METADATA. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, MUSEUM STAFF AND THE PUBLIC WILL HAVE IMPROVED ACCESSIBILITY TO THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION AND LIBRARY FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE HAITIAN AND AFRICAN AMERICANS, AS WELL AS STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, AND MUSEUM VISITORS.

THE NATIONAL PEARL BUTTON MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY AND CATALOG ITS COLLECTION OF OVER 10,000 BUTTONS AND OBJECTS RELATED TO THE PEARL BUTTON MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY IN THE UNITED STATES. THE COLLECTION INCLUDES PEARL BUTTONS, PAPER AND PHOTOGRAPHIC RECORDS RELATED TO THE BUTTON MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY, AND PRESERVED MUSSEL SHELLS, MANY OF WHICH COME FROM EXTINCT OR ENDANGERED SPECIES. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH VOLUNTEERS TO SORT, REHOUSE, CATALOG, AND PHOTOGRAPH OBJECTS AS WELL AS INPUT DATA INTO A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE. BY DIGITIZING COLLECTIONS RECORDS, THE MUSEUM WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS OBJECTS MORE EASILY FOR RESEARCH AND EXHIBITION PURPOSES. BOTH THE MUSEUM’S PERSONNEL AND PUBLIC RESEARCHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTION.

THE AMERICAN BOOKBINDERS MUSEUM WILL CREATE FOUR SHORT VIDEOS, EACH DESCRIBING A DIFFERENT COMPONENT RELATING TO THE HISTORY OF BOOKBINDING. THE TOPICS WILL INCLUDE THE HISTORY OF THE BOOK, THE HISTORY OF WRITING SURFACES, GUILDS, AND PRINTING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH A LOCAL SAN FRANCISCAN VIDEO PRODUCTION COMPANY TO DEVELOP THE SCRIPT, IDENTIFY IMAGES AND VIDEOS, AND PACKAGE THE VIDEOS INTO THE FINAL PRODUCT. THE VIDEOS WILL BE PERMANENTLY DISPLAYED USING A TOUCH-SCREEN INTERFACE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING FREE AND ACCESSIBLE LIFELONG LEARNING, BENEFITING PEOPLE OF ALL AGES.

THE IROQUOIS MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AN EXHIBIT OF CONTEMPORARY IROQUOIS ART AND OFFER RELATED PROGRAMMING TARGETED AT YOUTH, YOUNG ADULTS, AND ADULTS. THE EXHIBIT WILL SHOWCASE ARTWORKS THAT INCLUDE SUSPENDED INSTALLATION AND PROJECTION, WELDED STEEL SCULPTURES, COMIC-DRAMA AND CLAYMATION, GLASS WORKS, CLAY MONOPRINTS, GRAPHIC NOVEL AND VIDEO-GAME INSPIRED ILLUSTRATIONS, ELECTRONIC MUSIC, AND DOCUMENTARY PHOTOGRAPHY. RELATED PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE THE MUSH HOLE, AN OFFSITE THEATRICAL DANCE INTERPRETATION OF THE EXPERIENCE OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS; AN ONSITE POP-UP WELDING WORKSHOP; THE IROQUOIS INDIAN MARCHING BAND; AND ARTIST TALKS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL DISMANTLE CONVENTIONAL ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT WHAT CONSTITUTES NATIVE ART BY INTRODUCING VISITORS TO THE WIDE VARIETY OF EXPRESSIONS AND WAYS IN WHICH IROQUOIS/HAUDENOSAUNEE CULTURE IS REPRESENTED TODAY. HAUDENOSAUNEE CREATIVES WILL BENEFIT BY PRESENTING THEIR WORK IN A DIGNIFIED AND RECEPTIVE SETTING AND BY EXPANDING THEIR NETWORK OF OPPORTUNITIES. VISITORS WILL BENEFIT BY PARTICIPATING IN AN ENVIRONMENT OF MUTUAL RESPECT AND OPEN DIALOGUE, AND ACCESSING AN ALTERNATE LENS THROUGH WHICH TO RECONSIDER OUR SHARED PAST.

THE CASTELLANI ART MUSEUM OF NIAGARA UNIVERSITY WILL DEVELOP A TRAVELING EXHIBITION, “OLD/NEW THREADS” ABOUT THE INTERSECTIONS OF TRADITIONAL ART, ECONOMY, AND COMMUNITY-BUILDING. THE EXHIBITION WILL EXPLORE THIS TOPIC THROUGH THE CASE STUDY OF STITCH BUFFALO, A TEXTILE ARTS-BASED ORGANIZATION SERVING PRIMARILY REFUGEE WOMEN WITHIN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT A PROJECT MANAGER AND A PAID INTERN, WHO, IN CONSULTATION WITH HUMANITIES EXPERTS, WILL CONDUCT NEW ETHNOGRAPHIC FIELDWORK, DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE PANELS AND AN EXHIBIT CATALOG, CREATE SHORT-FORM VIDEOS, AND DESIGN ACCOMPANYING PUBLIC PROGRAMS SUCH AS ARTIST-LED WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND COMMUNITY CELEBRATIONS. AS A RESULT, THIS PROJECT WILL RECOGNIZE THE EFFORTS OF DIVERSE INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT IMPLEMENT THESE OPPORTUNITIES FOR DISADVANTAGED MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY IN THE REGION, AND CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVED REFUGEE PROSPERITY THROUGH INCREASED VISIBILITY AND AWARENESS.

THE XIMENEZ-FATIO HOUSE MUSEUM WILL CREATE A NEW COMPREHENSIVE MARKETING PLAN SO THE MUSEUM CAN EXECUTE MORE EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES FOR RAISING AWARENESS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL EVALUATE CURRENT MARKETING EFFORTS, RESEARCH BEST PRACTICES, AND CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE MARKETING PLAN. THE RESULTING PLAN WILL HELP THE MUSEUM ATTRACT MORE DIVERSE, INCLUSIVE AUDIENCES WHILE INCREASING AWARENESS OF THE UNIQUE AND UNTOLD HISTORY OF ONE OF THE OLDEST HOUSES IN AMERICA.

THE BOISE ART MUSEUM WILL LAUNCH AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROGRAM FOR SENIORS THAT FOSTERS CREATIVE, IMMERSIVE, AND JOYFUL EXPERIENCES WITH PROFESSIONAL ARTISTS, ARTS PARTNERS, AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS. THE PROGRAM WILL INTRODUCE THREE NEW PROGRAM WORKSHOPS DEVELOPED BY PROFESSIONAL TEACHING ARTISTS IN COLLABORATION WITH MINDFULNESS PRACTITIONERS, PARTNERS, AND MUSEUM STAFF. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH LOCAL ARTISTS AND PARTNER WITH THE IDAHO COMMISSION ON THE ARTS TO IDENTIFY THOSE WITH TRAINING FOR DEVELOPING WORKSHOPS FOR OLDER ADULTS AS WELL AS ARRANGE FOR TRAINING FOR NEW TEACHING ARTISTS. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL DEVELOP SKILLS WITHIN AN ARTISTIC MEDIUM, VIEW AND DISCUSS ARTWORKS IN THE COLLECTION, OBSERVE A BEHIND-THE-SCENES ASPECT OF THE MUSEUM, AND BENEFIT FROM WAYS THAT THE ARTISTIC PRACTICE CAN CONTRIBUTE TO GENERAL WELLBEING, SUCH AS DEVELOPING PATIENCE, REDUCING ANXIETY, AND CENTERING MINDFULNESS FOR MENTAL ACUITY, MENTAL DEXTERITY, AND OVERALL MENTAL HEALTH. EACH WORKSHOP WILL CULMINATE IN A GROUP ACTIVITY FOR REFLECTION AND CELEBRATION OF ARTISTIC ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND GROWTH.

THE GREAT BRIDGE BATTLEFIELD AND WATERWAYS MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A TWO-YEAR INTERPRETIVE TRAINING PROGRAM FOR MUSEUM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS THAT IS GROUNDED IN INQUIRY AND OBJECT-BASED LEARNING. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING TRAINING MODULES ON COSTUMED INTERPRETATIONS, INTERPRETIVE TECHNIQUES, RESEARCH METHODOLOGY, AND SUCCESSFUL WAYS TO HANDLE DIFFICULT TOPICS AND SITUATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE ENGAGING TWO MUSEUM CONSULTANTS WHO WILL PRODUCE TRAINING MATERIALS, DELIVER TRAINING SESSIONS, AND CONDUCT TRAINING EVALUATIONS TO DOCUMENT TRAINING EFFECTIVENESS. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN STAFF AND VOLUNTEER DOCENTS WHO ARE BETTER EQUIPPED TO CULTIVATE CRITICAL THINKING, CREATIVITY, COMMUNICATION, COLLABORATION SKILLS, AND AN ATTITUDE OF DISCOVERY IN MUSEUM AUDIENCES.

THE HMONG CULTURAL CENTER MUSEUM WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF ITS MUSEUM TOUR PROGRAM BY EXTENDING ITS HOURS OF OPERATION AND HIRING NEW TOUR GUIDE STAFF TO ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO REACH WIDER AUDIENCES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RECRUITING AND ONBOARDING TWO NEW PART-TIME TOUR GUIDES TO CONDUCT GUIDED TOURS FOR SCHOOLS, YOUTH GROUPS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY GROUPS; EXTENDING ITS HOURS OF OPERATIONS TO ALLOW MORE PEOPLE TO VISIT; AND CONDUCTING OUTREACH TO COMMUNITY-SERVING ORGANIZATIONS AROUND THE TWIN CITIES TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THE INCREASED TOUR CAPACITY. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN VISITORS DEVELOPING A GREATER APPRECIATION OF THE HMONG AMERICAN EXPERIENCE AND THE RICHNESS OF HMONG CULTURE AND FOLK ARTS.

THE INDIAN ARTS RESEARCH CENTER WILL USE FUNDS TO IMPROVE THE STEWARDSHIP OF ITS COLLECTION OF SOUTHWEST NATIVE AMERICAN ART, WHICH CONSISTS OF OVER 12,500 OBJECTS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL INVENTORY AND BARCODE OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION, WHICH WILL RESULT IN EFFICIENT AND ACCURATE KNOWLEDGE OF OBJECT LOCATION AND CONDITION. STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING ON THE NEW COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND INVENTORY PROCESS. IMPROVED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT WILL ALLOW STAFF TO ACCESS THE COLLECTION MORE EASILY FOR EXHIBITION AND PROGRAMMATIC PURPOSES.

THE HISTORY CENTER OF LAKE FOREST-LAKE BLUFF WILL PRODUCE AND INSTALL AN EXHIBIT EXPLORING HOW THE MIDCENTURY’S INTERPRETATION OF MODERNITY SHAPED WOMEN’S ROLES IN SOCIETY, CREATING NEW FREEDOMS WHILE RETAINING AND REINFORCING SUBSTANTIAL BARRIERS TO EQUALITY IN WORK, VOICE, AND FINANCIAL INDEPENDENCE. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE WORKING WITH AN ACADEMIC ADVISORY TEAM, AN UNDERGRADUATE INTERN, AND GRADUATE FELLOW TO IDENTIFY AND WRITE FOUR TO FIVE VIGNETTES RELATING TO EACH OF THE FOUR EXHIBIT THEMES, THEN ENLISTING THE PUBLIC FOR FEEDBACK. FINAL PANELS AND VIGNETTES WILL BE INSTALLED ALONGSIDE MOUNTED OBJECTS AND ARTIFACTS EITHER FROM THE MUSEUM COLLECTION OR ON LOAN. THE EXHIBITION WILL GIVE AUDIENCES AN ENHANCED UNDERSTANDING OF THE INFLUENCE OF THE MIDCENTURY ON THE EXPECTATIONS FOR WOMEN’S ROLES.

THE WALTER W. STIERN LIBRARY’S HISTORICAL RESEARCH CENTER AT CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, BAKERSFIELD WILL DEVELOP AN EXHIBIT OF IMAGES AND EPHEMERA ABOUT BASQUE SHEEPHERDERS IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY REGION OF CALIFORNIA, AND THEIR ARBORGLYPHS, OR STORY-TELLING ART CARVED INTO TREES. FOR OVER A HUNDRED YEARS, BASQUE IMMIGRANTS ARRIVED TO WORK IN ISOLATED CONDITIONS IN THE WESTERN DESERTS AND THE SIERRA NEVADA HIGH COUNTRY, AND WERE KNOWN FOR THEIR SKILLS AT MOVING AND WATCHING OVER VAST SHEEP HERDS. A TEAM OF STUDENT VOLUNTEERS, UNIVERSITY FACULTY, AND STAFF WILL DEVELOP THE EXHIBIT FLOOR PLAN, COLLECT PHOTOGRAPHS AND EPHEMERA PRIMARILY THROUGH THE LOCAL BASQUE CLUB, AND DEVELOP 3D MODELS OF SELECTED ARBORGLYPHS. THE MULTI-MEDIA EXHIBIT WILL PROVIDE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE BAKERSFIELD METRO AREA AND THE SURROUNDING SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY.

THE LAURA INGALLS WILDER HISTORIC HOME AND MUSEUM WILL INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY FOR VISITORS WITH VISION IMPAIRMENT OR LOW VISION IN THE PERMANENT EXHIBITION SPACE BY ADDING TWO TACTILE IMAGES. THE TACTILE IMAGES WILL ALLOW GUESTS TO EXPERIENCE A TWO DIMENSIONAL OBJECT THROUGH TOUCH, SUCH AS FEELING THE TEXTURE OF A FABRIC IN A PHOTO OR THE LAY OF THE LAND IN A MAP, AS WELL AS CONTAIN SENSORY POINTS THAT TRIGGER AUDIO CLIPS IN ENGLISH OR SPANISH. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TRANSLATING THE AUDIO INTO SPANISH, FABRICATING AND TESTING THE TACTILE IMAGES, AND INSTALLING IN THE GALLERIES. ALL VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM WILL BENEFIT THROUGH ACCESS TO A MULTISENSORY COMPONENT OF THE PERMANENT EXHIBITION.

THE DENNOS MUSEUM CENTER, ON THE CAMPUS OF NORTHWESTERN MICHIGAN COLLEGE, WILL CONDUCT A CONSERVATION SURVEY OF ITS OUTDOOR SCULPTURE COLLECTION. INFORMED BY A COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A CONSERVATOR TO CREATE A PLAN FOR OBJECT-BY-OBJECT CONSERVATION CARE. THE SURVEY WILL ADDRESS THE ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE OF THE OUTDOOR SCULPTURES AND HELP THE MUSEUM STAFF DEVELOP A LONG-TERM MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR PLAN, ORGANIZED BY HIGHEST CONSERVATION PRIORITIES. TO SHARE THE PROJECT’S PROGRESS WITH THE PUBLIC, STAFF WILL CREATE SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AS THE PROJECT PROGRESSES.

THE WOODFORD MANSION WILL GAIN INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OVER THE ARCHIVAL RECORDS IN ITS COLLECTION RELATED TO THE HISTORY OF THE HOUSE, A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK BUILDING. THE ARCHIVES CONTAIN THE ORIGINAL RECORDS OF THE MUSEUM FOUNDER, NAOMI WOOD, ALONG WITH PHOTOGRAPHS OF HOUSE INTERIORS, ARCHITECTURAL DRAWINGS, EVENTS DOCUMENTATION, NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS, AND CORRESPONDENCE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A TEMPORARY PART-TIME PROJECT ARCHIVIST TO CATALOG AND REHOUSE ARCHIVAL RECORDS AND CREATE A RECORDS MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A CONTRACT REGISTRAR TO WORK WITH THE CURATOR AND SITE MANAGER TO CONDUCT RESEARCH IN THE ARCHIVES TO IDENTIFY PRIMARY SOURCES THAT DOCUMENT ACQUISITION AND DEACCESSION HISTORIES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE PRODUCTION OF A FINDING AID TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR LOCAL RESEARCHERS AS WELL AS FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH ONLINE PORTALS AND THE MUSEUM’S WEBSITE.

HISTORIC CHERRY HILL WILL BUILD ON PREVIOUS FUNDING AND AUDIENCE RESEARCH TO COMPLETE THE FINAL DEVELOPMENT PHASE OF A NEW APPROACH TO INTERPRETATION FOR THE SITE. WORKING WITH AN INTERPRETIVE PLANNER AND DESIGNER, THE MUSEUM WILL FOCUS ON THE COMPLETION OF SCHEMATIC DESIGN AND DESIGN DEVELOPMENT. THE NEW TOUR AND ORIENTATION EXHIBITION WILL BE DIALOGIC, IMMERSIVE, AND INCLUSIVE, SHARING THE COMPLEX STORIES OF THE DIVERSE MEMBERS OF THE CHERRY HILL HOUSEHOLD AND EXPLORING THEMES, SUCH AS RACE, PRIVILEGE, WEALTH, INEQUALITY, AND SOCIAL JUSTICE--THEMES IDENTIFIED IN FOCUS GROUPS TO BE IMPORTANT TO THE MUSEUM’S TARGET AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN A FINAL DESIGN BOOK WITH PLANS, ELEVATIONS, AND SPECIFICATIONS SCHEDULES, WHICH WILL GUIDE THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE TO COME, HELPING TO RESHAPE THE INTERPRETATION OF THE MUSEUM FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF VISITORS.

THE DELAWARE CONTEMPORARY WILL EXPAND UPON ITS SUCCESSFUL AFTERSCHOOL TEEN PROGRAM, CREATIVE ARTS CLUB, BY ADDING VOCATIONAL EXPLORATION OF MUSEUM AND CREATIVE INDUSTRY CAREERS THROUGH A SERIES OF NEW LEARNING EXPERIENCES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PARTNER WITH TITLE 1 HIGH SCHOOLS IN NEW CASTLE COUNTY TO RECRUIT STUDENTS WITH LIMITED ACCESS TO ARTS OPPORTUNITIES. THROUGH CROSS-DISCIPLINARY LEARNING METHODS AND ENGAGEMENT WITH THE MUSEUM’S TEACHING ARTISTS AND A DIVERSE GROUP OF CREATIVES-IN-RESIDENCE, STUDENTS WILL CREATE THEIR OWN WORKS OF ART USING A VARIETY OF ART MEDIA, VISIT CREATIVE INDUSTRY WORKSPACES AND CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS, AND PARTICIPATE IN CIVIC ENGAGEMENT PROJECTS. THE PROGRAM WILL CULMINATE IN AN EXHIBITION AND POP-UP RETAIL OPERATION TO SHOWCASE STUDENTS’ ARTWORK. THESE OPPORTUNITIES WILL HELP STUDENTS TO DEVELOP PROFESSIONAL SKILLS, PROMOTE JOB PREPAREDNESS, BROADEN CAREER HORIZONS, AND OVERCOME BARRIERS TO SUCCESS.

THE SANTA CRUZ CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF DISCOVERY WILL INCREASE ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY BY LAUNCHING AN INSTITUTIONAL PLANNING AND POLICY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT. A STRATEGIC PLANNING CONSULTANT WILL LEAD THE PROCESS WITH OVERSIGHT FROM A PLANNING COMMITTEE. THEY WILL ALSO USE INPUT GATHERED FROM THE COMMUNITY, STAFF MEMBERS, AND MUSEUM VISITORS THROUGH SURVEYS TO INFORM THE PLANNING DOCUMENTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A REVISED STRATEGIC PLAN, UPDATED MISSION AND VISION STATEMENTS, AND A NEWLY DESIGNATED BOARD LEADERSHIP POSITION THAT WILL CHAMPION THE STRATEGIC PLAN MOVING FORWARD. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT BOTH STAFF AND VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM THROUGH THE ADOPTION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WELL-DEFINED GOALS FOR PROGRAMMING AND EXHIBITS.

THE MUSEO DEL WESTSIDE, OPERATED BY THE ESPERANZA PEACE AND JUSTICE CENTER, WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS AND MAKE THEM PUBLICLY SEARCHABLE ONLINE. THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION OF OVER 3,000 PHOTOGRAPHS, ORAL HISTORIES, AND ARCHITECTURAL ARTIFACTS DOCUMENT THE HISTORY OF SAN ANTONIO’S WESTSIDE NEIGHBORHOOD, WHICH BECAME THE PRIMARY SAN ANTONIO NEIGHBORHOOD HOUSING WORKING-CLASS TEJANOS (TEXANS OF MEXICAN DESCENT) AND MEXICAN IMMIGRANTS IN THE LATE 19TH CENTURY. MUSEUM STAFF WILL TRANSFER THE COLLECTION INTO NEW COLLECTION STORAGE AREAS AND COMPLETE THE ASSOCIATED DATA ENTRY. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOLS AND SENIOR CENTERS, STAFF WILL RECRUIT AND TRAIN VOLUNTEER DOCENTS AS WELL AS HOST WORKSHOPS TO ENGAGE THEM WITH THE USE OF THE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE IMPROVED ACCESS TO OBJECTS FOR FUTURE EXHIBITIONS AND MAKE THE COLLECTIONS PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE THROUGH THE MUSEUM WEBSITE.

THE CHARLES SUMNER SCHOOL MUSEUM AND ARCHIVES WILL STABILIZE A COLLECTION OF NEGATIVES AND PHOTOGRAPHS DOCUMENTING 40 YEARS OF WASHINGTON, DC PUBLIC SCHOOL HISTORY. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DIGITIZE A PORTION OF THE COLLECTION AS A PILOT PROJECT TO PLAN FOR THE DIGITIZATION OF ITS ENTIRE COLLECTION. INFORMED BY A COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH COLLECTIONS AND DIGITIZATION CONSULTANTS, HIGH SCHOOL INTERNS, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO REHOUSE, ACCESSION, TRANSCRIBE, SCAN, AND DIGITIZE IMAGES, AS WELL AS DEVELOP COLLECTION METADATA. THE DIGITIZATION CONSULTANT WILL DEVELOP A DIGITIZATION PLAN FOR THE MUSEUM AND PROVIDE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PROJECT TEAM. THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A FRAMEWORK FOR BUILDING THE MUSEUM’S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS DATABASE AND MAKING ITS COLLECTIONS MORE WIDELY ACCESSIBLE AS AN EXAMPLE OF COLLECTING AND PRESERVING THE HISTORY OF AN URBAN PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM.

THE R.G. LETOURNEAU MUSEUM AND ARCHIVES AT LETOURNEAU UNIVERSITY WILL ADVANCE THE MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF ITS COLLECTION BY CREATING A CENTRALIZED REPOSITORY FOR THE DIGITAL ARCHIVES TO ENSURE ADEQUATE ACCESSIBILITY AND EASY SEARCH CAPABILITIES. THE REFERENCE LIBRARIAN WILL COMPLETE A CERTIFICATION PROGRAM IN ARCHIVAL MANAGEMENT TO GAIN THE EXPERTISE NEEDED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT. THE LIBRARIAN WILL SERVE AS THE PROJECT SUPERVISOR, DRAFTING METADATA STANDARDS, AND CREATING POLICIES, PROCEDURES, TRAINING RESOURCES, AND FINDING AIDES. MUSEUM STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING TO MANAGE AND SUSTAIN THE COLLECTIONS ON AN ONGOING BASIS. THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT, STUDENT ASSISTANTS WILL CREATE WEBPAGES TO HIGHLIGHT THE PROJECT AS WELL AS SPECIAL INTEREST ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL MAKE THE COLLECTION MORE READILY ACCESSIBLE TO UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND MUSEUM VISITORS.

THE TRI-CITIES HISTORICAL MUSEUM WILL CREATE A DISASTER RESPONSE PLAN AND DISASTER RESPONSE KITS FOR THE MUSEUM AND ITS COLLECTION OF HISTORICAL OBJECTS. IN RESPONSE TO PREVIOUS INCIDENTS, INCLUDING A FIRE AT THE MUSEUM IN 2003 AND DAMAGE CAUSED BY A STORM IN 2018, THE MUSEUM WILL PLAN AND IMPLEMENT DISASTER TRAINING SESSIONS FOR STAFF. LED BY THE CURATOR OF COLLECTIONS AND A CERTIFIED HERITAGE EMERGENCY FIRST RESPONDER AND FIREFIGHTER, MUSEUM STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAININGS ON HOW TO RESCUE ARTIFACTS AND RESPOND TO DISASTERS ASSOCIATED WITH WATER, FIRE, AND OTHER INCIDENTS. STAFF WILL COMPILE DISASTER RESPONSE KITS AND WILL PLAN AND WRITE A DISASTER RESPONSE PLAN, FROM WHICH THEY CAN REPLICATE TRAINING SESSIONS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.

THE FORBES HOUSE MUSEUM WILL ESTABLISH GREATER INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTIONS AS RECOMMENDED BY ITS PARTICIPATION IN THE COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH A CURATOR AND A PROJECT ARCHIVIST TO COORDINATE THE PROJECT TO COMPLETE THE PROCESSING OF OBJECTS INCLUDING FURNITURE, CLOTHING ITEMS, HOUSEHOLD WARES, AND ARCHIVAL MATERIALS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE INVENTORYING, CATALOGING, PHOTOGRAPHING, AND DIGITIZING EACH ITEM; PURCHASING SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS FOR REHOUSING AND RESHELVING; AND RECONCILING MISSING ITEMS. THE CURATOR AND PROJECT ARCHIVIST WILL ALSO PROVIDE TRAINING WORKSHOPS ON OBJECT HANDLING AND DATA ENTRY FOR STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS. COMPLETING THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE MUSEUM’S OVERALL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT, WHILE INCREASING THE USE OF COLLECTIONS AND PUBLIC ACCESS THROUGH THEIR USE IN TOURS, PROGRAMS, AND EXHIBITIONS.

THE ART MUSEUM OF SOUTHEAST TEXAS WILL CATALOG AND DIGITIZE THE JOHN G. FAIREY COLLECTION OF MEXICAN FOLK ART, A COLLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 546 OBJECTS BY REGIONAL AND FOLK ARTISTS OF THE 20TH AND 21ST CENTURIES. THIS PROJECT BUILDS ON A PREVIOUS IMLS AWARD THAT CREATED 4.600 IMAGES OF 474 OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A REGISTRAR, PHOTOGRAPHER, AND DATA MANAGER TO PERFORM PROJECT ACTIVITIES, WHICH WILL INCLUDE ACCESSIONING, PHOTOGRAPHING, AND DIGITIZING 72 NEW ARTWORKS INTO THE COLLECTION. WITH THE COMPLETION OF THIS WORK, THE ENTIRE MEXICAN FOLK ART COLLECTION WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO VIRTUAL VISITORS AND RESEARCHERS THROUGH THE MUSEUM’S ONLINE DATABASE.

THE HISTORY CENTER OF OLMSTED COUNTY WILL ENGAGE WITH ITS COMMUNITY TO CREATE A NEW VISITOR INTERPRETIVE EXPERIENCE PLAN FOR THE GEORGE STOPPEL FARMSTEAD. WORKING WITH A PLANNING CONSULTANT AND A SKILLED FACILITATOR, THE MUSEUM WILL MEET WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS, INCLUDING LONG-TIME COUNTY RESIDENTS WHO ARE DESCENDANTS OF 19TH AND EARLY-20TH CENTURY EUROPEAN IMMIGRANTS AND MORE RECENT IMMIGRANTS TO ENSURE THE PLAN HAS BOTH HISTORICAL ACCURACY AND RELEVANCE FOR MULTIPLE AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP A VISITOR EXPERIENCE SITE PLAN THAT INCLUDES AN OVERALL NARRATIVE; DEVELOP WORKSHEETS FOR EACH INTERPRETIVE ZONE; IDENTIFY SUGGESTIONS FOR PROGRAMS, EVENTS, AND TOURS; AND CREATE TWO HAND-DRAWN RENDERINGS TO ILLUSTRATE KEY VISITOR EXPERIENCE FEATURES. THE RESULTING PLAN IS INTENDED TO RECOMMEND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS THAT WILL PROVIDE A FORUM FOR DIALOGUE ABOUT IMMIGRATION, AGRICULTURE, AND THE LEGACY OF COLONIZATION.

BOSCOBEL HOUSE AND GARDENS WILL DEVELOP AN INTERPRETIVE PLAN THAT EXPANDS, MODERNIZES, AND REVITALIZES ITS MUSEUM INTERPRETATION AND RELATED PROGRAMMING. BASED ON RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE MUSEUM’S PARTICIPATION IN TWO MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS (MAP), THE PLAN WILL FOCUS ON THE ENGAGEMENT AND EDUCATIONAL VALUE OF PERSONAL FACILITATED EXPERIENCES, WHILE INCORPORATING A GREATER VARIETY OF FORMATS AND EXPANDED ACCESSIBILITY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DETERMINING INTERPRETIVE THEMES; INVENTORYING EXISTING RESOURCES; DEVELOPING A VARIETY OF INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING MODELS WITH ASSOCIATED EVALUATION FRAMEWORKS; TESTING PILOT PROGRAMS AND IDENTIFYING ADDITIONAL RESOURCES NEEDED; AND DEVELOPING A FRAMEWORK FOR CONSISTENT, ONGOING PROGRAM EVALUATION. THE RESULTING INTERPRETIVE PLAN WILL EXPAND BOSCOBEL'S CAPACITY TO ACHIEVE ITS MISSION, BROADEN ACCESS TO ITS RESOURCES, AND SERVE THE PUBLIC MORE EFFECTIVELY.

CANTON MUSEUM OF ART WILL CONTINUE AND ENHANCE ITS MUSEUM TO GO PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES FREE, VIRTUAL EXHIBIT TOURS AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY HANDS-ON ART LESSONS TO FOURTH AND SIXTH-GRADE STUDENTS IN STARK COUNTY, OHIO. THE MUSEUM WILL ENHANCE THE PROGRAM BASED ON TEACHER FEEDBACK AND PARTNER WITH THE CANTON CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT TO ENSURE ITS REACH TO PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED AREAS WHERE IN-SCHOOL ART PROGRAMS ARE RARE. LESSONS WILL INCLUDE A VIRTUAL 360-DEGREE TOUR OF THE MUSEUM’S PERMANENT COLLECTION EXHIBIT. CLASS DISCUSSIONS WILL CENTER ON KEY ARTWORKS, EXPLORING HOW THEY CORRELATE TO CROSS-CURRICULAR CONTENT THROUGH INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES AND HANDS-ON ART-MAKING EXPERIENCES. THE PROGAM IS BASED ON STATE CURRICULUM STANDARDS IN LANGUAGE ARTS, MATH, SOCIAL STUDIES, SCIENCE, AND VISUAL ART AND WILL PROVIDE 4,400 STUDENTS WITH TRANSFERABLE PROBLEM-SOLVING SKILLS, REAL-WORLD CONNECTIONS TO SCHOOL ASSIGNMENTS, AND INCREASED ENGAGEMENT IN THE ARTS.

THE MUSEUM OF BOULDER WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY IMPLEMENTING A PILOT PROGRAM TO CONDUCT AN INVENTORY AND ANALYSIS OF ITS COSTUME COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO WORK WITH ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO PHOTOGRAPH AND EVALUATE ITEMS AND UPDATE DIGITAL RECORDS, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF STUDENT INTERNS. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS 15 PERCENT OF THE 11,000 ARTIFACTS IN THE COLLECTION, WHICH SPANS 150 YEARS OF BOULDER’S DRESS HISTORY. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A TEXTILE CONSERVATOR TO REPAIR OR PRESERVE 10 ARTIFACTS THAT RANK HIGHLY AS HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT AND ARE MOST IN NEED OF CONSERVATION THE PILOT PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOUNDATIONAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE COSTUME COLLECTION AND CREATE A BLUEPRINT FOR A FUTURE PRESERVATION STUDY OF THE FULL COLLECTION, LEADING TO ITS INCREASED ACCESS AND USE FOR STAFF, RESEARCHERS, AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS.

ARTPACE SAN ANTONIO WILL IMPLEMENT THE ARTPACE TEEN COUNCIL, A NINE-MONTH, PAID AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAM DESIGNED TO ENCOURAGE SAN ANTONIO HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS TO BECOME ADVOCATES FOR CONTEMPORARY ART AND YOUNG LEADERS IN THEIR COMMUNITY. THE PROGRAM WILL BRING TOGETHER A DIVERSE GROUP OF TEENS FROM THROUGHOUT SAN ANTONIO. LED BY PARTNER ARTISTS, ART PROFESSIONALS, AND MUSEUM STAFF, THE TEEN COUNCIL WILL PARTICIPATE IN WORKSHOPS TO LEARN ABOUT ART CAREERS AND ORGANIZATIONS. THEY WILL USE THIS KNOWLEDGE TO CREATE THEIR OWN EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMS THAT ENGAGE FELLOW YOUTH AUDIENCES WITH CONTEMPORARY ART. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, PARTICIPATING TEENS WILL GAIN HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS TO PURSUE CAREERS IN THE ARTS AND THE CITY OF SAN ANTONIO WILL GAIN QUALIFIED CANDIDATES TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE CITY’S FUTURE ARTS AND CULTURE WORKFORCE.

THE CHINESE CULTURE CENTER OF SAN FRANCISCO WILL IMPLEMENT “GENERATION CHINATOWN,” A PLACE-BASED, OUT-OF-SCHOOL, YOUTH ARTS FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM INTENDED TO DEEPEN PARTICIPANTS’ CREATIVE VOICES AND BUILD CIVIC LEADERSHIP SKILLS. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS TO CONVENE A COHORT OF 7–10 MULTIRACIAL HIGH SCHOOL FELLOWS AND PAIR THEM WITH ARTIST MENTORS. THEY WILL PARTICIPATE IN WORKSHOPS, PRODUCE PUBLIC ARTWORKS, INVESTIGATE TOPICS RELATED TO PLACE AND LOCAL COMMUNITY, ENGAGE WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND BUILD AWARENESS AROUND ISSUES OF RACE AND EQUITY. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE IMMEDIATE NEED FOR MORE CULTURALLY RELEVANT YOUTH PROGRAMMING, AS WELL AS THE ECONOMIC AND XENOPHOBIC IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ON THE CHINATOWN NEIGHBORHOOD. FELLOWS WILL LEARN IN DIALOGUE WITH ONE ANOTHER AS THEY EXPLORE HOW ARTISTS CAN ADD TO THE CULTURAL RESILIENCE OF CHINATOWN AND HELP RESHAPE NARRATIVES ABOUT THE COMMUNITY.

THE MINING AND ROLLO JAMISON MUSEUMS WILL STRENGTHEN THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY ACTING ON RECOMMENDATIONS FROM A COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING COLLECTIONS PRESERVATION, PREPAREDNESS, AND MONITORING PLANS; COMPLETING AN INVENTORY AND DIGITAL CATALOG; AND PRIORITIZING AT-RISK COLLECTIONS IN NEED OF SPECIFIC LONG-TERM CARE AND MANAGEMENT. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GREATER PHYSICAL ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTION AS A WHOLE AND IMPROVE INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION FOR THE BENEFIT OF MUSEUM STAFF, RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE ERIE CANAL MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP A NEW INTERPRETIVE PLAN AS PART OF A LARGER EFFORT TO TELL A MORE INCLUSIVE ERIE CANAL STORY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSESSING THE CURRENT PLAN TO IDENTIFY SUCCESSES AND SHORTCOMINGS THROUGH VISITOR SURVEYS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONSULT WITH A CONTENT DEVELOPER AND EXHIBIT DESIGNER TO DEVELOP A NARRATIVE AND FLOOR PLAN FOR NEW EXHIBITS THAT ADVANCE THE NEW INTERPRETATION. THE MUSEUM’S ADVISORS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL REVIEW THE PLAN, AND THE FINAL VERSION WILL REFLECT THEIR FEEDBACK. THE PROJECT WILL POSITION THE MUSEUM TO EXPAND ITS INTERPRETATION TO INCLUDE MORE SOCIAL HISTORY AS WELL AS BEING MORE WELCOMING FOR MARGINALIZED POPULATIONS AND FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN PREPARATION FOR THE BICENTENNIAL COMMEMORATION OF THE ERIE CANAL BETWEEN 2017 AND 2025.

THE KEY WEST ART AND HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPLEMENT A PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT OF ITS COLLECTION OF METAL SCULPTURES BY FOLK ARTIST STANLEY PAPIO. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH CONSERVATORS AND CONSERVATION TECHNICIANS, WHO WILL TRAVEL TO THE MUSEUM TO PHOTOGRAPH AND ASSESS THE CONDITION OF 100 SCULPTURES, IDENTIFY TREATMENT PRIORITIES, ESTIMATE TREATMENT COSTS, AND PREPARE INDIVIDUAL REPORTS FOR EACH WORK. THE CONSERVATION TEAM WILL PROVIDE AN ASSESSMENT REPORT AND TREATMENT PLAN FOR THE COLLECTION THAT ADDRESSES STEPS TO BE TAKEN TO CONSERVE THE WORKS IN STORAGE AND ON DISPLAY, INCLUDING MOUNTING AND STORAGE RECOMMENDATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A SUSTAINABLE PLAN FOR THE STABILIZATION AND CARE OF THE PAPIO COLLECTION, AND THE FINAL REPORT WILL HELP THE MUSEUM PRIORITIZE AND PLAN FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION WORK.

THE ANTHROPOLOGY MUSEUM AT CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, SAN BERNARDINO WILL DEVELOP, FABRICATE, AND INSTALL AN EXHIBIT FOCUSING ON AFRO-LATINX FOLK AND FINE ART TO CONVEY THE EXISTENCE, RESISTANCE, AND CREATIVITY OF AFRO-DESCENDANT POPULATIONS IN MEXICO AND SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTIES. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH AFRO-LATINX COMMUNITY GROUPS INCLUDING CASA COYOLILLO, UNIVERSIDAD VERACRUZANA INTERCULTURAL, AND SOMOS NEGROS DE LA COSTA TO SELECT, RECRUIT, INTERVIEW, AND COMMISSION ART FROM LOCAL AFRO-LATINX RESIDENTS; PLAN THE EXHIBIT; DEVELOP COMPLEMENTARY EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS; AND CONDUCT EXHIBIT EVALUATIONS. THE ONE-YEAR EXHIBIT INSTALLATION WILL INCLUDE A SET OF “CONVERSATION CARDS” FOR DISCUSSING AFRO-LATINX TOPICS WITH FRIENDS AND FAMILY, WHILE SUPPORTING K-12 DUAL IMMERSION CURRICULA FOR STUDENTS IN SAN BERNARDINO. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL REPLICATE EXHIBITION CONTENT ONLINE FOR BROADER ACCESSIBILITY. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARD COMBATTING ANTI-BLACKNESS THROUGH INCREASED EXPOSURE AND UPLIFT OF AFRO-LATINX COMMUNITIES.

THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A STRUCTURAL ENGINEER TO DESIGN AND PRODUCE CONSTRUCTION DRAWINGS FOR A SHELF STABILIZATION SYSTEM FOR OPEN SHELVING THAT WILL HOUSE ARCHEOLOGICAL CERAMIC WHOLE VESSELS. INFORMED BY COLLECTIONS NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN A COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, THE CONTRACTED ENGINEER WILL DESIGN SHELVES THAT WILL MITIGATE POTENTIAL PHYSICAL DAMAGES TO THE COLLECTION DUE TO VIBRATIONAL EVENTS, SUCH AS EARTHQUAKES. AS PART OF A LARGER, MULTI-YEAR PLAN, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE PLANNING AND DOCUMENTATION NECESSARY TO PROCEED WITH THE BUILDING OF THE SHELVES AND CREATION OF APPROPRIATE REHOUSING MATERIALS FOR VESSELS IN THE COLLECTION.

THE LA JOLLA HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL COMPLETE THE SECOND PHASE OF A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROJECT TO INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESSIBILITY, IMPROVE INTERNAL EFFICIENCY, AND STRENGTHEN THE MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF ITS COMMUNITY ARCHIVE. THE PROJECT WILL PRESERVE ORIGINAL MATERIALS AND CREATE CONTAINER LISTS AND COLLECTION GUIDES FOR 77 INDIVIDUAL COLLECTIONS IN 193 BOXES MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 288 LINEAR FEET. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT A PAID INTERNSHIP PROGRAM FOR STUDENTS FROM SURROUNDING UNIVERSITIES, INTENDED TO FOSTER INTEREST IN HISTORY CAREERS. CONTAINER LISTS AND COLLECTION GUIDES PRODUCED THROUGH THE PROJECT WILL BROADEN PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE MATERIALS IN THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL PUBLISH THE RESULTING FINDING AIDS IN THE FREELY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE ARCHIVE OF CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE MUSEUM’S UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE COLLECTION IS BEING USED AND IDENTIFY WAYS TO USE ITS COLLECTIONS TO BETTER SERVE THE COMMUNITY.

THE GREGORY ALLICAR MUSEUM OF ART AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL ADDRESS KEY COMPONENTS OF ITS STRATEGIC PLAN BY IMPACTING TEACHING CAMPUS-WIDE, ACCOMMODATING FACULTY AND STUDENT PARTICIPATION IN MUSEUM ACTIVITIES, AND IMPROVING CARE AND ACCESS FOR THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON STANDARDIZING STORAGE AND MOUNTING OF 717 WORKS ON PAPER AND PHOTOGRAPHS THAT ARE FREQUENTLY REQUESTED FOR TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND EXHIBITION PURPOSES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE AN ITEM-BY-ITEM SURVEY OF TARGET WORKS; A TWO-DAY WORKSHOP WITH A PAPER AND PHOTOGRAPH CONSERVATOR ON CONSERVATION STANDARD MATTING AND MOUNTING; MAT CUTTING, ASSEMBLY, AND MOUNTING; AND REHOUSING OF TARGET OBJECTS BY CATEGORY AND STANDARD SIZE. STAFF WILL TEACH PROFESSIONAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SKILLS TO PAID STUDENT INTERNS ASSISTING WITH THE PROJECT AND WILL CONDUCT ONGOING INTERNAL EVALUATION TO TRACK PROGRESS AND EFFICACY.

LONGVIEW WORLD OF WONDERS WILL DESIGN, BUILD, AND EVALUATE THE STEAM TRAIN, AN INTERACTIVE HANDS-ON EXHIBIT THAT CONNECTS CHILDREN TO THE RAILROAD INDUSTRY'S UNIQUE HISTORY AND HOW IT SHAPED THE LOCAL LONGVIEW COMMUNITY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COLLABORATING WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO DETERMINE EXHIBIT CONTENT SUCH AS EDUCATIONAL COMPONENTS AND INTERACTIVE ELEMENTS, ENGAGING AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM TO DESIGN AND BUILD THE EXHIBIT, AND CONDUCTING MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF THE EXHIBIT TO DETERMINE EFFECTIVENESS AND SUSTAINABILITY. THE RESULTING EXHIBIT WILL SERVE AS A S LEARNING OPPORTUNITY RELEVANT TO LOCAL FAMILIES AND THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY.

THE BARTLETT ARBORETUM AND GARDENS WILL IMPLEMENT THE BARTLETT ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION (BEE) PROGRAM, A PILOT PROGRAM SERVING PRE-K TO FIFTH GRADE STUDENTS IN AN URBAN, LOW-INCOME COMMUNITY. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS AT WATERSIDE SCHOOL, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF IN-SCHOOL, OUT-OF-SCHOOL, AND DIGITAL EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS. STUDENTS WILL WORK DIRECTLY WITH PLANTS, FLOWERS, AND INSECTS IN THEIR SCHOOL GARDEN, VISIT AND EXPLORE FOREST AND WETLAND ENVIRONMENTS AT THE ARBORETUM, AND DEVELOP CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS WITH EDUCATORS IN VIRTUAL PROGRAMS. BY PARTICIPATING IN BEE, STUDENTS WILL GAIN A GREATER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF THE ENVIRONMENT, AS WELL AS GREATER INTEREST AND EXPOSURE TO NATURE. THE ARBORETUM WILL WORK WITH AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR TO MEASURE HOW THE PROGRAM ENCOURAGES EXPLORATION, DISCOVERY, CREATIVITY, COLLABORATION, AND PROBLEM-SOLVING SKILLS FOR PARTICIPATING STUDENTS.

THE PIONEER TRAILS REGIONAL MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF ITS FOSSIL COLLECTIONS AND PROVIDE GREATER ACCESSIBILITY FOR BOTH STAFF AND THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON OVER 50,000 SPECIMENS FROM THE HELL CREEK SITE, WHICH INCLUDES FOSSILS THAT HELP DETAIL THE CRETACEOUS–PALEOGENE EXTINCTION EVENT AND RECOVERY. THE MUSEUM’S PALEONTOLOGY CURATOR WILL WORK WITH VOLUNTEERS AND SEASONAL CURATORIAL ASSISTANTS TO CONDUCT A COMPLETE INVENTORY, REHOUSE, AND PHOTOGRAPH SPECIMENS, AND INPUT ASSOCIATED DATA INTO A COLLECTIONS DATABASE. THE COLLECTIONS DATABASE WILL INCLUDE DIGITIZED IMAGES OF THE FOSSIL COLLECTION AND BE SEARCHABLE ONLINE FOR EASY ACCESS AND USE.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF GREEN BAY WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES RESIDING IN THREE HOMELESS AND DOMESTIC ABUSE SHELTERS IN GREEN BAY, WISCONSIN. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE MONTHLY OUTREACH PROGRAMS LED BY EDUCATION STAFF AT EACH SHELTER, MONTHLY DISTRIBUTION OF 40 SCIENCE AND ART ACTIVITY KITS TO EACH SHELTER, AND THE DISTRIBUTION OF MUSEUM MEMBERSHIPS TO FAMILIES TRANSITIONING AWAY FROM THE SHELTER RESIDENCE. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CHILDREN RESIDING IN SHELTERS WITH ACCESS TO CONSISTENT, FUN EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES AS WELL AS PROMOTE POSITIVE FAMILY INTERACTIONS, ULTIMATELY PROVIDING CHILDREN WITH A SAFE SPACE AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR CREATIVITY, LEARNING, AND PLAY.

LED BY THE WATKINS MUSEUM OF HISTORY, FIVE HERITAGE SITES IN DOUGLAS COUNTY, KANSAS, WILL COLLABORATE TO DEVELOP A SERIES OF ONLINE LEARNING RESOURCES UNITING THE HISTORIES OF THE SITES UNDER THE THEME, "SEEKING A MORE PERFECT UNION: THE ENDURING STRUGGLE FOR FREEDOM AND CIVIL RIGHTS.” BASED ON A NEWLY DEVELOPED FIELD TRIP PROGRAM AND A NEEDS ASSESSMENT OF K–12 TEACHERS, THIS SERIES OF LESSON PLANS, STUDENT WORKBOOKS, AND CLASSROOM RESOURCES WILL CONNECT STORIES THAT EMPHASIZE HOW ISSUES OF FREEDOM, RACE, JUSTICE, EQUALITY, AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY AFFECTED PEOPLE’S LIVES FROM THE MID-1800S TO THE PRESENT. THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THAT TEACHERS AND STUDENTS CONTINUE TO BENEFIT FROM THE ADVANTAGES OFFERED BY LEARNING IN A MUSEUM SETTING, IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING A MORE ACCESSIBLE OPTION FOR THOSE WHO CANNOT TRAVEL TO THE SITES.

THE BRATTLEBORO MUSEUM AND ART CENTER WILL ENHANCE ACCESS FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING AN ACCESSIBLE WEBSITE WITH AN ACCESSIBILITY PAGE AND INCLUSIVE ONLINE PROGRAMS AS WELL AS TRAINING STAFF IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING ENABLING PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO INVEST IN TECHNOLOGY THAT FACILITATES INCLUSIVE INTERPRETATION OF EXHIBITS AND ACCOMMODATIONS FOR PROGRAMS. THIS WORK IS PART OF A LARGER EFFORT TO DEVELOP AN ACCESSIBILITY PLAN WITH INPUT FROM MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY WITH DISABILITIES, AND THEN UPDATE MUSEUM OFFERINGS TO BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL BECOME A MORE INCLUSIVE SPACE.

THE LIVING COAST DISCOVERY CENTER WILL STREAMLINE ITS OPERATIONS AND ENHANCE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE BY IMPLEMENTING AN INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSTEM. THE NEW SOFTWARE WILL REPLACE SIX DIFFERENT SOFTWARE SYSTEMS AND WILL SUPPORT TICKETING, ADMISSIONS, AND GIFT SHOP SALES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON WORKING WITH A SOFTWARE COMPANY TO IMPORT DATA INTO THE NEW SYSTEM AND TRAIN STAFF ON ITS USE. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT MUSEUM STAFF BY REDUCING THE TIME CURRENTLY SPENT MANAGING MULTIPLE SOFTWARE PROGRAMS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING DASHBOARDS WITH METRICS ABOUT ENGAGEMENT WITH VISITORS, MEMBERS, AND DONORS. SUPPORTERS, FAMILIES, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, LOCAL VISITORS, AND TOURISTS WILL BENEFIT FROM A USER-FRIENDLY, IMPROVED GUEST EXPERIENCE.

THE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF WILMINGTON WILL IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE FOR SPANISH SPEAKING VISITORS AND THOSE WITH VISUAL IMPAIRMENTS BY ADDRESSING LANGUAGE BARRIERS AND ACCESSIBILITY ISSUES. WORKING WITH PROFESSIONAL TRANSLATORS, THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE BILINGUAL AND BRAILLE SIGNAGE FOR EXHIBITS AND OTHER MUSEUM SPACES. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO PROVIDE SPANISH AND BRAILLE FOR FLYERS AND MARKETING AND INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS. COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL EVALUATE THE SIGNAGE AND MATERIALS FOR EASE OF READING AND UNDERSTANDING. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MUSEUM’S ONGOING WORK TO EMBED DEAI (DIVERSITY, EQUITY, ACCESSIBILITY, AND INCLUSION) PRACTICES WITHIN ALL OF ITS OPERATIONS BY FOSTERING RELATIONSHIPS WITH ORGANIZATIONS THAT WORK WITH DIVERSE GROUPS AND REACHING NEW AUDIENCES THAT HAVE PREVIOUSLY FELT EXCLUDED FROM ITS SERVICES.

THE RICHARD M. ROSS ART MUSEUM AT OHIO WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY WILL UNDERTAKE THE PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATION OF 31 PRINTS IN ITS PERMANENT TEACHING COLLECTION. CONTRACTED CONSERVATORS WILL PACK THE PRINTS ON CAMPUS, THEN TRANSPORT THEM TO A CONSERVATION LAB. INFORMED BY A PREVIOUS COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT, CONSERVATORS WILL CLEAN, STABILIZE, AND REHOUSE THE PRINTS BEFORE RETURNING THEM TO THE MUSEUM. MUSEUM STAFF WILL RECORD CONSERVATION TREATMENTS IN THE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN STABILIZED PRINTS THAT CAN BE USED FOR EXHIBITION AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES IN SERVICE TO THE CAMPUS COMMUNITY OF STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND RESEARCHERS, AS WELL AS REGIONAL AUDIENCES.

MUNCIE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL FABRICATE AND INSTALL THE WHITE RIVER WATER TABLE EXHIBIT TO PROVIDE A LEARNING ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH CHILDREN AGES 10 AND UNDER CAN PRACTICE THE SKILLS OF COLLABORATION, COMMUNICATION, CRITICAL THINKING, AND PROBLEM-SOLVING. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM TO CRAFT THE NEW EXHIBIT COMPONENT BASED ON RECENT CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT AND SCHEMATIC DESIGN PLANNING. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF EAST CENTRAL INDIANA—A 9 COUNTY REGIONAL COALITION-- TO CREATE A CULTURE OF EDUCATION THAT PROVIDES RESIDENTS WITH AN EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT LEVEL TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN SCHOOL AND THE WORKPLACE. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH OTHER COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS INVOLVED IN THIS EFFORT TO DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK OF EVALUATION TO CAPTURE MEASURABLE OUTCOMES THAT ARE IMPORTANT TO GUIDING FUTURE EDUCATIONAL PLANNING.

THE YESHIVA UNIVERSITY MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE CENTER FOR JEWISH HISTORY TO DIGITIZE 61 TORAH BINDERS, CALLED WIMPELS. THE PROJECT WILL SERVE AS A PILOT FOR A DIGITIZATION INITIATIVE THAT WILL BRING IMAGES AND DATA FOR ALL THE MUSEUM'S HOLDINGS ONLINE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CREATING DIGITAL SURROGATES OF THESE DECORATIVE FABRIC SASHES THAT WRAP AROUND THE TORAH SCROLLS AND ARE AT RISK FOR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO ENHANCE THE ASSOCIATED METADATA RECORDS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE THROUGH AN ONLINE PUBLIC ACCESS CATALOG. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS WILL HAVE GREATER ACCESS TO THIS MATERIAL CULTURE, AND THE MUSEUM WILL BE ABLE TO DIGITALLY PRESERVE ITEMS IN THEIR CURRENT STATE BEFORE THEY SUFFER FURTHER DETERIORATION.

THE STAR GAZING ROOM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL PREPARE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR K–12 STUDENTS AND YOUTH AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL TRAIN COHORTS OF PAID, UNDERGRADUATE PLANETARIUM EDUCATORS IN INFORMAL SCIENCE EDUCATION AND ROLE MODEL ENGAGEMENT AS WELL AS CONDUCT TEAM BUILDING AND MENTORSHIP ACTIVITIES. THE STUDENT EDUCATORS WILL DEVELOP CREATIVE CONTENT AND LEAD PLANETARIUM SHOWS AND ASTRONOMY OUTREACH TO K–12 SCHOOLS AND YOUTH-SERVING ORGANIZATIONS IN THE MISSOULA REGION, INCLUDING FROM THE NEARBY FLATHEAD RESERVATION. THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL HELP CULTIVATE THE UNDERGRADUATE EDUCATORS’ SELF-EFFICACY AND SENSE OF BELONGING IN STEM AND HIGHER EDUCATION WHILE ALSO POSITIVELY INFLUENCING K–12 STUDENTS’ KNOWLEDGE OF, AND INTEREST IN, ASTRONOMY. THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE STAR GAZING ROOM’S WORKFORCE AND ENHANCE ITS ABILITY TO REACH K–12 AND PUBLIC AUDIENCES.

THE HARRY JACKSON INSTITUTE WILL COLLABORATE WITH AN ARCHITECTURAL PROFESSIONAL TO PRODUCE AN ARCHITECTURAL PROGRAM STATEMENT THAT WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF THE MUSEUM FACILITY. THE MUSEUM CARES FOR MORE THAN 5,000 OBJECTS REPRESENTING THE LIFE OF ARTIST HARRY JACKSON, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FROM ITS PARTICIPATION IN A CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) PROGRAM ESTABLISHED THE REHOUSING OF THESE OBJECTS IN A PERMANENT STORAGE SPACE AS A TOP PRIORITY. THE CONSULTING ARCHITECT WILL LEAD THE PROJECT TEAM THROUGH A SERIES OF ACTIVITIES TO GATHER DATA AS WELL AS INPUT FROM STAKEHOLDERS. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE SCHEMATIC DESIGNS, SUPPORTING THE NEXT PHASES OF ARCHITECTURAL PLANNING. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING INITIAL COST ESTIMATES, THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO ENVISION A SAFE, ENVIRONMENTALLY CONTROLLED SPACE FOR STORAGE, EXHIBITION, AND WORKSPACES TO MEET FUTURE NEEDS.

OSCEOLA HISTORY WILL CREATE A NEW, PERMANENT EXHIBIT DEDICATED TO HISPANIC CULTURE, REFLECTING THE SIGNIFICANT INFLUX OF IMMIGRATION TO THE REGION IN RECENT DECADES. THE PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE MUSEUM’S WORK SINCE 2020 TO ENGAGE THE HISPANIC COMMUNITY IN A SERIES OF FOCUS GROUPS, THE TRANSLATION OF ITS PRINTED MATERIALS INTO SPANISH, AND THE INSTALLATION OF A TEMPORARY EXHIBIT WITH THE SAME THEME ALONG WITH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND FAMILY-BASED EVENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM TO DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND CREATE INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE FOR THE NEW EXHIBIT. THE RESULTING EXHIBIT WILL REFLECT THE IMPORTANCE OF THE CULTURAL INFLUENCES BROUGHT TO CENTRAL FLORIDA BY THE GROWING HISPANIC POPULATION, WHILE ENABLING THE MUSEUM TO CREATE A STRONGER SENSE OF COMMUNITY AND BELONGING IN WHICH ALL AUDIENCES CAN SEE THEMSELVES REPRESENTED.

DAVIDSON COUNTY HISTORICAL MUSEUM WILL BRING NEW LIFE TO ITS PERMANENT EXHIBIT, “THE COUNTY SEAT COMES OF AGE,” THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF AN EXHIBIT REDEVELOPMENT PLAN. INFORMED BY RECENT VISITOR FEEDBACK, THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM TO DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND INSTALL FOUR INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT COMPONENTS. THE EXHIBIT COMPONENTS WILL INCLUDE A DEPOT VIGNETTE, AN AGRICULTURAL INTERACTIVE, AN ASSEMBLY LINE ACTIVITY, AND A DIGITAL KIOSK. TOGETHER, THEY WILL ENCOURAGE SELF-DIRECTED AND HANDS-ON LEARNING ABOUT THE HISTORY OF DAVIDSON COUNTY'S SOCIOECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND MEET THE UNIQUE INTERESTS AND LEARNING STYLES OF THE TARGET AUDIENCES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A RENEWED INTERPRETATION OF THE EXHIBIT’S EXISTING NARRATIVE, RESTORE THE EXHIBIT’S IMPACT, AND ENHANCE ENGAGEMENT WITH THE MUSEUM’S FASTEST GROWING AND MOST UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES OF PRESCHOOL CHILDREN, INTERGENERATIONAL FAMILIES, AND AFRICAN AMERICANS.

THE KODIAK HISTORY MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT A PHOTO DOCUMENTATION PROJECT IN PREPARATION FOR A PLANNED MOVE OF ITS COLLECTIONS TO A NEW STORAGE LOCATION IN THE NEXT FIVE YEARS. THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTIONS MANAGER WILL DIRECT THE PROJECT AND TRAIN TWO COLLECTIONS ASSISTANTS, WHO WILL PHOTOGRAPH OBJECTS, EDIT THE PHOTOGRAPHS, AND PERFORM COLLECTIONS DATABASE ENTRY TO TRACK THE CONDITION AND LOCATION OF OBJECTS CURRENTLY HOUSED IN THE MUSEUM’S HISTORIC BUILDING. THE PROJECT WILL DOCUMENT OBJECT CONDITIONS FOR OVER 2,300 ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION, AND THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE MOST OF THE IMAGES FREELY AVAILABLE BY ENHANCING ITS ONLINE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE.

THE PRATT MUSEUM WILL CREATE A SERIES OF PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS TO STRENGTHEN ENGAGEMENT WITH ALASKA NATIVE CULTURE-BEARERS AND FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN AND LIMITED INCOME.
