THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A DIRECTOR OF LIFELONG LEARNING EXPERIENCES, WHO WILL BE OUTWARDLY FOCUSED TO ENSURE THAT PROGRAMMING IS PRIORITIZING DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION. THE NEW POSITION WILL BE CHARGED WITH COLLABORATING WITH KEY COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP THREE TO FIVE EXHIBITS AND ACCOMPANYING PROGRAMS, CRAFTING A STRATEGIC PLAN FOR BUILDING FUTURE PROGRAM CONTENT AND PARTNERSHIPS, AND RE-ESTABLISHING THE MUSEUM AS A GATHERING PLACE FOR ALL. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO RESULT IN NEW AND RENEWED EXHIBITS, PROGRAMS, AND RELATIONSHIPS THAT ARE TRANSFORMATIVE FOR THE MUSEUM AND COMMUNITY. A PROFESSIONAL EVALUATOR WILL MEASURE THE MUSEUM’S SUCCESS AT ACHIEVING THE PROJECT GOALS.

HISTORY FORT LAUDERDALE WILL PARTNER WITH THE OLD DILLARD FOUNDATION AND LIVING MEMBERS OF AFRICAN AMERICAN PIONEER FAMILIES TO CREATE AN EXHIBIT CHRONICLING THE HISTORY OF THE SOUTH FLORIDA BLACK COMMUNITY FROM 1890 TO THE PRESENT DAY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE HOLDING TOWN HALL MEETINGS TO REQUEST DONATIONS OF ARTIFACTS FOR THE EXHIBIT AND TO GATHER COMMUNITY INPUT TO DEVELOP THE EXHIBIT STORYLINE. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO SPONSOR PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS SITES TO DIGITIZE BLACK FAMILIES’ PHOTOS FOR THEIR RECORDS AND TO REQUEST PERMISSION TO USE THEM IN THE EXHIBIT. THE MUSEUM WILL FABRICATE PANELS, IDENTIFY ARTIFACTS, AND CREATE A VIRTUAL PLATFORM FOR THE EXHIBIT. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE MORE COMPLETE REPRESENTATION AND RECOGNITION OF THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE BLACK COMMUNITY FOR BROWARD COUNTY SCHOOLS STUDENTS AS WELL AS REGIONAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM.

PRESERVATION LONG ISLAND WILL UNDERTAKE AN ASSESSMENT OF ITS INVENTORY PRACTICES TO IMPROVE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROCEDURES FOR ITS HISTORIC SITES. UTILIZING JOSEPH LLOYD MANOR AND ITS COLLECTION AS A PILOT SITE, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH A MUSEUM SERVICES FIRM TO CONDUCT A WORKFLOW ASSESSMENT, DEVELOP INVENTORY AND STAFFING PLANS, AND SUPPORT STAFF IN TESTING NEW PROCEDURES. AFTER TESTING IS COMPLETED, THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A TEMPORARY COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT TO EMPLOY THE NEW PROTOCOLS IN INVENTORYING COLLECTIONS AT OTHER PRESERVATION LONG ISLAND SITES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN INVENTORY MANUAL, INCREASED ORGANIZATIONAL KNOWLEDGE OF REQUISITE STAFF CAPACITY FOR ROUTINE COLLECTION INVENTORIES, AND GREATER PUBLIC ACCESS TO OBJECTS RELATED TO THE REGIONAL MATERIAL CULTURE OF NEW YORK.

THE ANIMAS MUSEUM WILL ANALYZE, CATALOG, AND PRESERVE ITS COLLECTION OF ANCESTRAL PUEBLO POTTERY FOR AN IN-PERSON AND ONLINE EXHIBIT. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE PURCHASING COLLECTIONS PROCESSING SUPPLIES AND EXHIBIT CASES, CATALOGING ITEMS, AND ENGAGING A CONSERVATOR TO CLEAN AND RESTORE PIECES IDENTIFIED FOR CONSERVATION CARE. ONCE THIS WORK IS COMPLETE, THE ANIMAS MUSEUM’S EXHIBIT TEAM WILL UPDATE THE POTTERY EXHIBIT IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN GALLERY AS WELL AS A CONCURRENT ONLINE EXHIBIT. OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE PROPERLY IDENTIFIED, CATALOGED, AND CARED FOR ARTIFACTS BEING MORE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC AND AN INCREASE IN THE KNOWLEDGE OF ANCESTRAL PUEBLOAN POTTERY AND HISTORY TO BENEFIT THE ANTHROPOLOGICAL COMMUNITY, INDIGENOUS POPULATIONS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

REID PARK ZOO WILL INCREASE THE OPPORTUNITIES FOR URBAN CHILDREN AGES SIX MONTHS TO 10 YEARS OLD TO ENGAGE WITH NATURE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, AND INSTALLATION OF A NATURALISTIC PLAY ZONE AT THE ZOO. TRAINED NATURE PLAY ENGAGEMENT VOLUNTEERS AND COLLEGE INTERNS WILL FACILITATE ADDITIONAL AGE-APPROPRIATE, NATURE-BASED PLAY OPPORTUNITIES IN THIS SPACE. THE INTERNS ALSO WILL RECEIVE ADDITIONAL TRAINING IN CURRICULUM DESIGN AND CREATE ACTIVITIES FOR USE IN THE NATURE PLAY ZONE. RECOGNIZING RESEARCH FINDINGS THAT CHILDREN BENEFIT PHYSICALLY, SOCIALLY, EMOTIONALLY, ACADEMICALLY, AND CREATIVELY FROM THEIR TIME SPENT PLAYING IN NATURE, THIS PROJECT WILL SPECIFICALLY BENEFIT URBAN FAMILIES WHO ARE AT A DISADVANTAGE WHEN IT COMES TO EQUAL ACCESS TO OUTDOOR PLAY BY MAKING THEIR LOCAL ZOO A PLACE TO LEARN ABOUT THE EXPLORATION OF NATURE.

THE EDWARD HOPPER HOUSE MUSEUM AND STUDY CENTER WILL WORK WITH PROFESSIONAL CONSERVATORS TO COMPLETE CONSERVATION TREATMENTS ON FRAGILE OBJECTS IN ITS COLLECTION. INFORMED BY PREVIOUSLY PREPARED CONDITION REPORTS AND CONSERVATION TREATMENT PLANS FROM AN EARLIER PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE CONSERVATORS TO TREAT AND REHOUSE BOUND MANUSCRIPTS, PAPER DOCUMENTS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS FROM THE COLLECTION. CONSERVATORS WILL DOCUMENT THE TREATMENT IN FULL PHOTOGRAPHIC AND WRITTEN REPORTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN ACCESS TO STABILIZED OBJECTS THAT CAN BE USED BY RESEARCHERS, SCHOLARS, CURATORS, AND STUDENTS STUDYING EDWARD HOPPER’S CAREER AND ART.

HISTORIC SARANAC LAKE WILL UNDERTAKE SCHEMATIC DESIGN FOR NEW INTERPRETIVE EXHIBITS PRESENTING SARANAC LAKE’S HISTORY AS AN INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR TUBERCULOSIS TREATMENT, PUBLIC HEALTH, AND SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PLAN EXHIBITS FOR AN EXPANDED MUSEUM CAMPUS THAT WILL INCLUDE THE SARANAC LABORATORY MUSEUM AND THE RECENTLY ACQUIRED HOME OF DR. E. L. TRUDEAU. BASED ON A RECENTLY DEVELOPED MUSEUM INTERPRETIVE PLAN, THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGNER, EXHIBIT DEVELOPER, GRAPHIC DESIGNER, AND CONSULTING HUMANITIES SCHOLARS TO PRODUCE A SCHEMATIC DESIGN FOR THE FIRST PHASE OF THE EXHIBIT DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. THE MUSEUM EXPANSION WILL INCORPORATE A BROADER, MORE INCLUSIVE HISTORY OF THE GEOGRAPHIC AREA, SERVING TO BUILD COMMUNITY AMONG RURAL RESIDENTS UNDERSERVED BY CULTURAL PROGRAMS.

THE RONALD REAGAN MUSEUM AT EUREKA COLLEGE WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS BY ADDRESSING RECOMMENDATIONS IDENTIFIED IN A RECENT COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT. THE MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY, ASSESS, DIGITIZE, AND CATALOG COLLECTIONS ITEMS INTO THE MUSEUM’S NEW COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE, AS WELL AS REHOUSE OBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE HIRING A PART-TIME REGISTRAR TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTATION AND CATALOG THE COLLECTION; ACQUIRING NEW COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE; AND PURCHASING COLLECTIONS REHOUSING MATERIALS. SUCCESSFUL IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE RONALD REAGAN MUSEUM FULFILL ITS MISSION AND STRATEGIC GOALS TO IMPROVE COLLECTIONS CARE AND ACCESS AND ENABLE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING.

THE HOUSATONIC MUSEUM OF ART AT HOUSATONIC COMMUNITY COLLEGE WILL UNDERTAKE A PROJECT TO INCREASE ACCESS TO THEIR COLLECTIONS BY DOCUMENTING, DIGITIZING, AND ARCHIVING 600 OBJECTS. A FINE ART PHOTOGRAPHER WILL PHOTOGRAPH, EDIT, AND PREPARE IMAGE FILES. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL UPDATE OBJECT RECORDS AND CONDITION ASSESSMENTS, ADD DIGITAL ASSETS TO THE COLLECTIONS DATABASE, ARCHIVE DIGITAL ASSETS, AND LAUNCH AN ONLINE COLLECTIONS DATABASE. THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND VISITOR ACCESS BEYOND THE LIMITED NUMBER OF COLLECTION ITEMS THAT ARE AVAILABLE FOR VIEWING DURING IN-PERSON VISITS AND REMOVE MULTIPLE BARRIERS WHICH EXIST IN ACCESSING WORKS OF ART.

VICTORIA MANSION WILL IMPROVE THE DOCUMENTATION OF ACCESSION RECORDS FOR ITS COLLECTIONS, INCLUDING FURNITURE, SCULPTURE, CARPETING, PAINTINGS, AND GLASS AND CERAMIC ARTS OBJECTS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON SYSTEMATICALLY IDENTIFYING AND CORRECTING INACCURACIES, DUPLICATIONS, AND OMISSIONS IN THE PHYSICAL COLLECTIONS RECORDS. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH TOUR GUIDES TO ASSESS THEIR NEEDS FOR DIGITAL ACCESS TO IN-DEPTH INFORMATION ABOUT THE COLLECTION IN ORDER TO ANSWER VISITOR QUESTIONS AND CONDUCT RESEARCH. THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE PROGRESS IN COMPLETING A DIGITAL DATABASE TO MAKE DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT ITS COLLECTIONS READILY ACCESSIBLE TO STAFF AND DOCENTS, ULTIMATELY ENRICHING INTERPRETATION OF THE HOUSE FOR VISITORS.

THE SANDY SPRING MUSEUM WILL REDRESS HISTORICAL INEQUITIES IN ITS CATALOGING PRACTICES BY ENHANCING THE METADATA USED TO DESCRIBE MATERIALS IN ITS ARCHIVAL RECORDS. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO UNLOCK THE BLACK HISTORY OF THE REGION, WHICH IS NOT READILY AVAILABLE DUE TO PAST RECORDKEEPING PRACTICES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A METADATA ASSOCIATE TO WORK WITH ITS ARCHIVES AND RECORDS MANAGER AND A COMMUNITY SUBJECT MATTER SPECIALIST TO UNCOVER FAMILY HISTORIES, APPLY PAGE-LEVEL METADATA, AND TRANSCRIBE MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW PEOPLE SEARCHING FOR BLACK HISTORY IN THE MUSEUM’S ARCHIVES TO ACCESS PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN INFORMATION ABOUT THE LOCAL BLACK COMMUNITY, SUCH AS LABOR REMUNERATION, SPECIALIZED SKILLS, HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE ACCESS, AND INFORMAL ECONOMIES. THE MUSEUM’S ENTIRE DIGITAL COLLECTION WILL CONTINUE TO BE AVAILABLE ON A COLLABORATIVE STATEWIDE DIGITAL PRESERVATION PROGRAM.

THE GRAND BAY COASTAL RESOURCES CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT “VISUALIZING INTERPRETIVE SPACE THROUGH INTEGRATIVE TEAMWORK” (VISIT), A NEW INITIATIVE TO DEVELOP A REDESIGN PLAN FOR ITS EXHIBIT SPACE THROUGH MULTI-LEVEL COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. THE CENTER WILL INITIATE THE PROJECT BY DISTRIBUTING A SURVEY, HOLDING FOCUS GROUPS, AND TRAVELING TO LOCAL MUSEUMS TO COLLECT FEEDBACK ON THE EXISTING SPACE. THE CENTER WILL THEN CONTRACT WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGNER TO PERFORM AN ON-SITE EXHIBIT ASSESSMENT. THE PROJECT TEAM AND EXHIBIT DESIGNER WILL CONVENE AN ADVISORY PANEL OF CLASSROOM TEACHERS, INFORMAL EDUCATORS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO PARTICIPATE IN A WORKSHOP TO CREATE THE ACTION PLAN FOR THE EXHIBIT SPACE. BY NAVIGATING THE REDESIGN PROCESS WITH COMMUNITY INPUT, THE CENTER WILL CREATE A LEARNING ENVIRONMENT THAT APPEALS TO VARIOUS AUDIENCES AND PARTICIPANTS WILL FEEL A SENSE OF PRIDE AND OWNERSHIP IN THE FUTURE SPACE.

THE CHILDREN’S MUSEUM OF NEW HAMPSHIRE WILL IMPLEMENT “BOLSTERING A CHILDCARE SYSTEM IN CRISIS,” A SERIES OF EDUCATIONAL INITIATIVES DESIGNED TO HELP PROVIDERS AND FAMILIES PROVIDE ENRICHING, ENGAGING, AND DEVELOPMENTALLY APPROPRIATE PLAY-BASED LEARNING (PBL) ACTIVITIES TO CHILDREN FROM BIRTH TO AGE 5. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE’S EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION CENTER, THE MUSEUM WILL OFFER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING FOR EARLY CHILDCARE PROVIDERS; PROVIDE HANDS-ON EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR FAMILIES AND CAREGIVERS; AND DISTRIBUTE PBL ACTIVITY KITS TO 20 EARLY CHILDCARE PROVIDERS, FOUR FAMILY RESOURCE CENTERS, AND SIX LIBRARY PARTNERS ACROSS THE STATE. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, PROVIDERS AND CAREGIVERS WILL STRENGTHEN THEIR PBL KNOWLEDGE BASE AND PREPARE NEW HAMPSHIRE’S YOUNGEST CHILDREN TO SUCCEED IN KINDERGARTEN.

THE CHARLES W. BROWN PLANETARIUM WILL EXPAND THE NUMBER OF ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES IT OFFERS TO SCHOOL GROUPS AND THE PUBLIC, WITH A FOCUS ON EXPLORING THE SCALE OF BOTH SPACE AND TIME IN THE UNIVERSE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE EXPANDING THE NUMBER OF PRE-RECORDED PLANETARIUM SHOWS OFFERED, ADDING ORIENTATION EXHIBITS TO THE PLANETARIUM LOBBY, AND INTRODUCING DAYTIME TELESCOPE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES. BOTH PROFESSIONAL AND STUDENT STAFF MEMBERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN CONFERENCES AND TRAINING ACTIVITIES INTENDED TO SUPPORT THEIR ACTIVE FACILITATION SKILLS. THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE LENGTH OF TIME VISITORS SPEND IN THE PLANETARIUM, DEEPEN THE QUESTIONS AND CONVERSATIONS THAT OCCUR AT EVENTS, AND HELP WITH ENGAGEMENT AND CONTENT RETENTION.

THE VIRGINIA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL ENHANCE ITS SCIENCE EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES BY TRANSFORMING AN EXISTING UNDERUTILIZED LABORATORY INTO A NEW EXPLORATION LAB. THE LAB WILL INCLUDE NEW MICROSCOPY TOOLS THAT WILL AID MUSEUM EDUCATORS AND CURATORS IN PROGRAMMING FOR SCHOOL GROUPS AND HOMESCHOOL FAMILIES. MUSEUM CURATORS ALSO WILL USE THE LAB TO TEACH HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENTS AS WELL AS CITIZEN SCIENTISTS IN THE VIRGINIA MASTER NATURALISTS PROGRAM. THIS SPACE ALSO WILL SERVE AS A FACILITY FOR VISITING SCIENTISTS AND HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE INTERNS CONDUCTING SPECIMEN-BASED RESEARCH WITH MUSEUM CURATORS. MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC WILL BE ABLE TO OBSERVE ONGOING LAB ACTIVITIES AND ATTEND RELATED MUSEUM PROGRAMMING FOR INTERGENERATIONAL EXPLORATION AND HANDS-ON LEARNING.

THE VERDE VALLEY ARCHAEOLOGY CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT A COLLECTIONS DIGITIZATION PROJECT TO INCREASE ACCESS TO ITS SINAGUA TEXTILE COLLECTION. THE SINAGUA WERE A PRE-COLUMBIAN CULTURE THAT OCCUPIED A LARGE AREA IN CENTRAL ARIZONA INCLUDING THE VERDE VALLEY. THE CENTER WILL PURCHASE PHOTOGRAPHY EQUIPMENT, ESTABLISH A DIGITIZATION LAB, AND HIRE A FREELANCE PHOTOGRAPHER TO CREATE DIGITAL IMAGES OF THE TEXTILE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL EXPAND THE CENTER’S ONLINE VIRTUAL MUSEUM AND ENHANCE THE ARCHAEOLOGICAL RECORD AND METADATA BY ADDING 1,500 ENTRIES INTO THE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE PRESERVATION OF THE FRAGILE TEXTILES, WHILE PROVIDING BROADER ACCESS FOR SCIENTIFIC STUDY, RESEARCH, ANALYSIS, AND EXAMINATION. THE EXPANDED ONLINE CONTENT WILL BENEFIT MUSEUM STAFF AND THE PUBLIC BY PROVIDING THEM WITH A BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATIVE AMERICAN CULTURE AND HISTORY OF THE VERDE VALLEY.

INFORMED BY REPORTS FROM ITS PARTICIPATION IN THE COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) PROGRAM AND THE MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP), THE L.C. BATES MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE A CONSERVATOR TO CONDUCT PRESERVATION TREATMENTS ON 23 INDIVIDUAL 1800’S BIRD MOUNTS AND ONE MOUNTED SAILFISH. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CENTRAL KENNEBEC HERITAGE COUNCIL, THE MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT A WORKSHOP ON THE TOPIC OF CARING FOR NATURAL HISTORY SPECIMENS. VOLUNTEERS AND INTERNS WILL ASSIST WITH PROJECT ACTIVITIES, AND THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE RELATED PROGRAMS FOR RURAL STUDENTS AND FAMILIES, SUCH AS DOCENT-LED TOURS OF THE COLLECTION AND THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN FROM A CONSERVATOR AT WORK. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE A WRITTEN EVALUATION AND THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE PROJECT RESULTS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA AND NEWSLETTER UPDATES.

THE BRICK STORE MUSEUM WILL ADDRESS ISSUES OF ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION AND OVERCROWDING BY REHOUSING OVER 100 FRAMED ARTWORKS IN A NEW STORAGE SYSTEM. AN ART STORAGE CONTRACTOR WILL REMOVE THE OUTDATED STORAGE SYSTEM AND INSTALL NEW ART STORAGE SCREENS AND FURNITURE. DURING THE REHOUSING PROCESS, MUSEUM STAFF WILL TRACK THE MOVEMENT OF THE COLLECTION AND ENHANCE INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION BY DIGITALLY CATALOGING THE NEW LOCATIONS OF OBJECTS IN THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS DATABASE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION AND IMPROVED INTERNAL OPERATIONS FOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT.

THE ART CENTER OF THE BLUEGRASS WILL EXPAND ITS FREE FIELD TRIP PROGRAM AND PROVIDE ARTS EDUCATION EXPERIENCES TO 4,000 ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS IN RURAL CENTRAL KENTUCKY. IN COLLABORATION WITH TEACHERS AND SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS, THE ART CENTER WILL DEVELOP PROGRAMS THAT SUPPORT THE K–8 CURRICULUM OF PARTNER SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN BOYLE, LINCOLN, MERCER, AND GARRARD COUNTIES. BY SUPPLEMENTING THE FIELD TRIPS WITH TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT, THIS PROJECT WILL REDUCE FINANCIAL AND GEOGRAPHIC BARRIERS THAT PREVENT MANY STUDENTS IN THE REGION FROM ACCESSING ARTS PROGRAMS. STUDENTS WILL GAIN AN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF FUNDAMENTAL ART CONCEPTS, AN INCREASED INTEREST IN AND APPRECIATION FOR THE ARTWORK ON DISPLAY IN THE MUSEUM, AND INCREASED CONFIDENCE IN THEIR OWN ABILITIES AS ARTISTS.

THE DENNOS MUSEUM CENTER ON THE CAMPUS OF NORTHWESTERN MICHIGAN COLLEGE WILL IMPROVE THE CARE OF ITS COLLECTION THROUGH REHOUSING AND INVENTORY UPDATES. INFORMED BY A RECENT MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORT, THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL FIVE COMPACT SHELVING UNITS AND REORGANIZE THEIR STORAGE SPACE TO OPTIMIZE COLLECTIONS CARE FOR APPROXIMATELY 165 OBJECTS FROM MICHIGAN AND THE MIDWEST. MUSEUM STAFF WILL CREATE NEW ARCHIVAL BOXES AND MOUNTS AS NEEDED AND UPDATE INVENTORY RECORDS. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE CURATORIAL EASE OF ACCESS FOR RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXHIBITION PURPOSES, WHILE PROVIDING EXPANSION SPACE FOR FUTURE COLLECTIONS, REHOUSING, AND OTHER COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL SHARE PROJECT UPDATES AND RESULTS ON SOCIAL MEDIA AND IN THE COLLEGE NEWSPAPER.

THE WHEELWRIGHT MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN WILL UNDERTAKE A PROJECT DESIGNED TO IMPROVE ARCHIVES STEWARDSHIP AND ACCESS. THE MUSEUM?S ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS CONTAIN OVER 510 LINEAR FEET OF CORRESPONDENCE, RESEARCH AND FIELD NOTES, MANUSCRIPTS, PHOTOS, AND FILM FROM FOUNDER MARY CABOT WHEELWRIGHT AND NUMEROUS OTHER PROMINENT SCHOLARS OF NAVAJO CULTURE. THE PROJECT WILL USE FUNDS TO PURCHASE AND INSTALL NEW COMPACTOR STORAGE UNITS PROVIDING ADEQUATE SPACE WITH ROOM FOR THE FUTURE GROWTH OF COLLECTIONS. MUSEUM STAFF ALSO PLAN TO INCREASE DOCUMENTATION OF THE ARCHIVES? RECORDS IN THE MUSEUM?S NEW DATABASE, WHICH WILL BE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE, AND CREATE ARCHIVAL FINDING AIDS FOR FASTER ACCESS.

THE CHINESE CULTURE CENTER OF SAN FRANCISCO WILL CREATE A SEVEN-MONTH EXHIBITION, ENTITLED ?XIANRUI: CATHY LU,? AND COMMUNITY YOUTH ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM, EXPLORING RELEVANT TOPICS THAT REFLECT ON THE STATE OF ASIAN AMERICAN IDENTITY AND XENOPHOBIA FACING THE COMMUNITY. PROGRAMMING WILL BE CO-DESIGNED WITH THE COMMUNITY YOUTH CENTER AND LEAD ARTIST CATHY LU TO SERVE CHINATOWN YOUTHS, AND THE CHINESE CULTURAL CENTER OF SAN FRANCISCO WILL PROVIDE FREE ADMISSION AS WELL AS BILINGUAL-PRINTED POSTCARDS AND BROCHURES. THIS PROJECT WILL FEATURE ARTISTIC WORK THAT HIGHLIGHTS YOUTH STORIES, WHICH WILL ENGAGE THEIR CREATIVE VOICE, GIVING THEM CRITICAL AND INVENTIVE TOOLS TO RE-EXAMINE THEIR NEIGHBORHOOD AND CREATE SUPPORTIVE AND FACILITATED SPACES TO WORK TOGETHER.

THE DUNES CENTER WILL PROVIDE IN-CLASS INSTRUCTION AND FIELD TRIP ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON COASTAL RESTORATION AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION ON WATER QUALITY FOR OVER 300 5TH-GRADERS AT GUADALUPE?S KERMIT MCKENZIE INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL. THROUGH SCIENCE EXPERIMENTS AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES, STUDENTS WILL LEARN HOW ECOSYSTEMS FUNCTION AND EXPLORE WATERSHED CHARACTERISTICS. INTENDED TO SUPPLEMENT CURRENT LOCAL SCIENCE EDUCATION AND REACH UNDERSERVED, RURAL, LATINX STUDENTS, THE ?EXPLORE THE COAST? PROGRAM WILL HELP STUDENTS UNDERSTAND HOW HUMAN ACTIONS CAN AFFECT THE ENVIRONMENT, PROMOTE POLLUTION PREVENTION IN THE COMMUNITY, AND ASPIRE TO HIGHER EDUCATION IN THE FIELD OF SCIENCE.

THE MARINE DISCOVERY CENTER, A NEW, INTERACTIVE 16,000 SQ. FT. EXHIBITION SPACE WILL REPLACE FEIRO MARINE LIFE CENTER?S EXISTING 40-YEAR-OLD FACILITY. THE PLANNING OF THIS ACCESSIBLE EXHIBITION EXPERIENCE WILL PRIORITIZE ENGAGING VISITOR CONNECTIONS TO THE OCEAN ENVIRONMENT BY IMPROVING SCIENTIFIC LITERACY SKILLS, INCREASING AWARENESS OF HISTORICAL AND RECENT REGIONAL TRIBAL KNOWLEDGE, ENCOURAGING STEWARDSHIP ACTIONS IN THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT, AND DEVELOPING DEEPER UNDERSTANDINGS OF IMPORTANT LOCAL SPECIES. THE MARINE DISCOVERY CENTER IS A JOINT VENTURE OF FEIRO MARINE LIFE CENTER, THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA)?S OLYMPIC COAST NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY, AND OLYMPIC COAST NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY FOUNDATION.

THE PEALE CENTER FOR BALTIMORE HISTORY AND ARCHITECTURE WILL PILOT A PAID ARTS APPRENTICESHIP INITIATIVE FOR MARGINALIZED YOUNG ADULTS IN THE LOCAL BALTIMORE COMMUNITY. PARTICIPANTS WILL LEARN ART HANDLING AND INSTALLATION, CURATORIAL, EDUCATIONAL, COMMUNICATION, AND PROFESSIONAL SKILLS TO PREPARE FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT IN THE CULTURAL SECTOR. ENCOURAGING GROWTH THROUGH EXPOSURE TO NEW EXPERIENCES AND COLLABORATION, THE PEALE?S ACCOMPLISHED ARTS APPRENTICESHIP PROGRAM WILL HELP EMERGING PROFESSIONALS MOVE CONFIDENTLY INTO THE NEXT PHASE OF THEIR CAREERS. INFORMED BY A SCALED TEST OF THE PROGRAM, THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR FUTURE PROGRAMS AND INNOVATIVE USE OF THE MUSEUM?S SPACE.

KIDZEUM OF HEALTH AND SCIENCE WILL PARTNER WITH SPRINGFIELD, ILLINOIS SCHOOL DISTRICT 186 TO CREATE A TWO-WEEK STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ART, AND MATH) RESIDENCY FOR APPROXIMATELY 1,000 SECOND GRADERS IN THE DISTRICT. THE RESIDENCY WILL TAKE PLACE AT KIDZEUM DURING THE 2021-2022 SCHOOL YEAR. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE A CURRICULUM CREATED BY TEACHERS, SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS, AND MUSEUM STAFF, FEATURING A COLLABORATIVE STEAM PROJECT THAT BUILDS ON KIDZEUM EXHIBIT CONTENT. LITERACY, PHYSICAL EDUCATION, MUSIC, SOCIAL STUDIES, AND SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL WELLNESS WILL ALSO BE INCLUDED IN THE CURRICULUM AS THE KIDZEUM TESTS THE HYPOTHESIS THAT MUSEUMS CAN BENEFIT YOUNG LEARNERS AND THEIR FAMILIES BY SERVING AS A PLACE FOR LONGER TERM, IMMERSIVE EDUCATION PROGRAMS. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE WILL PROVIDE PROJECT EVALUATION AND SUBSEQUENT REPORTING.

THE REHER CENTER FOR IMMIGRANT CULTURE AND HISTORY WILL CREATE, PILOT, AND EVALUATE FIELD TRIPS AND IN-CLASS LESSONS FOR OVER FIVE HUNDRED 2ND AND 8TH GRADE STUDENTS. ENGAGING WITH THE STORIES OF THE HISTORIC BAKERY ON SITE, THE REHER CENTER PROGRAMMING WILL CONNECT STUDENTS TO IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCES FROM LOCAL COMMUNITIES OF THE MID-HUDSON VALLEY, BOTH PAST AND PRESENT. THE REHER CENTER WILL WORK WITH EDUCATORS, TEACHERS, AND AN EVALUATOR TO GENERATE AGE-APPROPRIATE TOURS AND DIGITAL LESSON PLANS ON THE TOPIC OF PRESENT DAY AND HISTORIC IMMIGRATION IN THE HUDSON RIVER VALLEY THAT WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF THEIR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. STUDENT RESPONSES TO THE PROGRAMMING WILL BE DISPLAYED IN AN EXHIBITION ON SITE.

THE DELAWARE CONTEMPORARY WILL CREATE A RESIDENCY PROGRAM FOR ARTISTS TO PROVIDE TEENS WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND ARTS ENTREPRENEURSHIP OPPORTUNITIES. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL TITLE-1 DESIGNATED HIGH SCHOOLS, APPROXIMATELY 100 STUDENTS WILL ENGAGE IN ARTS EDUCATION AND EXPLORE MUSEUM AND CREATIVE INDUSTRY VOCATIONS. STUDENTS WILL ENGAGE WITH CREATIVE AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS TO GENERATE INDIVIDUAL AND COLLABORATIVE ARTWORKS, AS WELL AS PARTICIPATE IN THE PLANNING AND EXECUTION OF A CULMINATING EXHIBITION, POP-UP RETAIL OPERATION FOR WORK PRODUCED IN THE PROGRAM, AND TWO LARGE-SCALE SOCIAL ACTIVITIES AT THE MUSEUM FOR TEENS FROM ACROSS THE REGION. PROGRAMMED WORKSHOPS WILL HELP STUDENTS TO DEVELOP CROSS-DISCIPLINARY SKILLS IN PREPARATION FOR CAREERS IN CREATIVE INDUSTRIES.

THE MUSEO Y CENTRO DE ESTUDIOS HUMANISTICOS AT UNIVERSIDAD ANA G. MENDEZ - RECINTO DE GURABO WILL DOCUMENT AND MAKE NEARLY 5,000 OBJECTS IN THEIR COLLECTION DIGITALLY ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT INCLUDES OBJECT PHOTOGRAPHY, DATABASE UPDATES AND WEBSITE INTEGRATION OF THE COLLECTION, WHICH CONTAINS PAINTINGS, SCULPTURES, PRINTS, FOLK ART, ARCHEOLOGICAL ARTIFACTS, AND HISTORICAL OBJECTS AND DOCUMENTS. A TWO-DAY SEMINAR ON THE USE OF THE ONLINE PLATFORM WILL ALSO BE OFFERED TO MUSEUM STAFF, UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND PROFESSORS, AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A VIRTUAL EXHIBITION WITH ANOTHER LOCAL UNIVERSITY MUSEUM.

THE IDAHO MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AT IDAHO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL DIGITIZE AND MAKE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ONLINE IMAGES AND INFORMATION RELATED TO OVER 300,000 CATALOGED ITEMS IN THEIR COLLECTION, WHICH CONTAINS MATERIAL FROM SITES SPANNING THE LAST 13,000 YEARS OF PREHISTORY IN SOUTHEASTERN IDAHO. THE NEW ONLINE INTERFACE WILL ALLOW EDUCATORS, RESEARCHERS, AND STUDENTS THE ABILITY TO EXPLORE THE COLLECTION THROUGH CATALOG INFORMATION, 2D OR 3D IMAGERY, SCANNED DOCUMENTS, AND INTERPRETIVE NARRATIVES, AND IT LEVERAGES EXISTING MUSEUM DATABASE INFRASTRUCTURE TO INCREASE ACCESS TO IDAHO?S NATURAL AND CULTURAL HERITAGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND NAGPRA CONSIDERATIONS.

THE TRUMBULL COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL WORK WITH THREE LOCAL, VOLUNTEER-RUN ORGANIZATIONS TO CONDUCT INSTITUTIONAL PLANNING EXERCISES BASED ON PREVIOUSLY COMPLETED SITE-VISIT REPORTS, PURCHASE CONSERVATION SUPPLIES TO REHOUSE ARCHIVAL MATERIALS, BEGIN AN ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING PROGRAM, AND DESIGN DIGITIZATION PROTOCOLS. THIS CONTINUATION OF INTER-INSTITUTIONAL GRASSROOTS COLLABORATION WILL INCREASE CAPACITY WITHIN THESE ORGANIZATIONS TO CARE FOR THEIR COLLECTIONS AND PROVIDE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO THEIR STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS. COLLECTIONS DIGITIZED DURING THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE CREATION OF AN ONLINE HUB, THE ?TRUMBULL COUNTY COLLECTIONS ACCESS NETWORK,? THAT LINKS TRUMBULL COUNTY COLLECTIONS RESOURCES FOR RESEARCHERS AND RESIDENTS.

ECOEXPLORATORIO: MUSEO DE CIENCIAS DE PUERTO RICO'S IN-STEM: AN INCLUSIVE STEM MUSEUM EXHIBITION PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STEM EDUCATIONAL MATERIAL SPECIFICALLY FOR AUDIENCES WITH VISUAL AND HEARING DISABILITIES. IN ADDITION TO AN INCLUSIVE SUMMER MOON TO MARS EXHIBIT, THE MUSEUM WILL OFFER TOURS WITH AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGES (ASL) INTERPRETERS AND ADAPTATIONS FOR THE VISUALLY IMPAIRED. ACCESSIBLE ONLINE, THE MUSEUM WILL PRODUCE TEN STEM ACTIVITY VIDEOS. BY BEING INCLUSIVE OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, SPECIFICALLY FOCUSING ON PEOPLE THAT ARE DEAF OR HARD OF HEARING AND BLIND OR VISUALLY IMPAIRED, THE MUSEUM SEEKS TO PROMOTE LIFELONG ACCESS TO STEM EDUCATION.

THE TRITON MUSEUM OF ART WILL CATALOGUE AND DIGITALLY DOCUMENT NATIVE AMERICAN ART AND ARTIFACTS HELD IN THEIR COLLECTIONS. REPRESENTATIVE OF A VAST ARRAY OF INDIGENOUS MATERIAL CULTURES CIRCA 900 TO 1990 FROM THE SOUTHWEST, CALIFORNIA, AND THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST, 350 OBJECTS WILL BE INVENTORIED BY STAFF AND A COLLECTIONS INTERN. THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE POSSIBLE FUTURE EXHIBITION PLANNING, RESEARCH, OBJECT LOANS, AND ASSESSMENT FOR CONSERVATION TREATMENTS. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL MAKE INFORMATION ABOUT WORKS IN THE COLLECTION MORE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC, INCLUDING NATIVE AMERICAN LINEAL DESCENDANTS AND TRIBAL REPRESENTATIVES IN CONCERT WITH THE NATIVE AMERICAN GRAVES PROTECTION AND REPATRIATION ACT (NAGPRA) PROGRAM.

THE COUSE-SHARP HISTORIC SITE WILL DIGITIZE AND MAKE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE THE APPROXIMATELY 11,000 AT-RISK AND UNSTABLE CELLULOSE NITRATE NEGATIVES AND 500 FRAGILE GLASS PLATE NEGATIVES IN THE COUSE FAMILY PHOTO COLLECTION, MANY OF WHICH DOCUMENT LIFE IN EARLY 20TH CENTURY TAOS AND GREATER NORTHERN NEW MEXICO. THE DIGITIZED IMAGES AND INFORMATION WILL BE DISCOVERABLE ONLINE, BRINGING THE TOTAL NUMBER OF DIGITAL IMAGES FROM THE COLLECTION TO APPROXIMATELY 22,000, AND THEY WILL BE MADE ACCESSIBLE TO STUDENTS, ARTISTS, SCHOLARS, AND THE GREATER TAOS COMMUNITY. THE PHOTOGRAPHS WILL BE A CRITICALLY IMPORTANT RESOURCE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE LUNDER RESEARCH CENTER FOR THE TAOS SOCIETY OF ARTISTS, A COUSE FOUNDATION INITIATIVE CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION AND SCHEDULED TO OPEN IN MID-2021.

HISTORIC CHERRY HILL WILL CREATE HISTORY IS NOW, A TEEN INTERPRETER PROGRAM AND HISTORY LEARNING LAB. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE TRAINING LOCAL TEENS TO CONDUCT TOURS AT CHERRY HILL, OFFERING TEENS MENTORING OPPORTUNITIES, AND PROVIDING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT EXPERIENCES, INCLUDING A SERIES OF CULTURAL SENSITIVITY, DIVERSITY, EQUITY AND INCLUSION TRAININGS. THE TEEN COHORT WILL ALSO LEARN FROM SENIOR CITIZEN VOLUNTEER INTERPRETERS TO PROMOTE INTERGENERATIONAL LEARNING. FOLLOWING TRAINING IN HISTORICAL METHODS, MATERIAL CULTURE, COMMUNICATION, AND OUTLINES OF U.S. HISTORY THROUGH IMMERSION IN CHERRY HILL?S STORIES AND TOUR DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR, HISTORIC CHERRY HILL WILL PARTNER WITH ALBANY?S SUMMER YOUTH EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM TO EMPLOY TEENS AS INTERPRETERS.

THE MCCORMICK BRIDGEHOUSE & CHICAGO RIVER MUSEUM WILL CREATE A MOBILE CART WITH HANDS-ON, IMMERSIVE EXPERIENCES AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS TO EXPAND PROGRAMMING TO THE OPEN-AIR PLAZA IN FRONT OF THE MUSEUM. TO EDUCATE VISITORS ABOUT THE CHICAGO RIVER ECOSYSTEM, THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER THREE LIVE SCIENCE EXPERIENCES UTILIZING THE MOBILE OUTDOOR CART, WHICH WILL INCLUDE A 3-D MODEL OF A WATERSHED. ADDITIONALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTRACT WITH PHOTOGRAPHERS AND A GRAPHIC DESIGNER TO GENERATE CONTENT FOR EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS AND CURRICULUM. BY CREATING A MOBILE CART WITH HANDS-ON, IMMERSIVE EXPERIENCES AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, THE BRIDGEHOUSE MUSEUM WILL REACH MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCES ON THE PLAZA, WHICH EXTENDS ONTO THE CHICAGO RIVERWALK.

THE LUCILLE BALL DESI ARNAZ MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY, REHOUSE, AND DIGITALLY CATALOGUE APPROXIMATELY 4,500 OBJECTS THAT CHRONICLE THE LIVES AND CULTURAL CONTRIBUTIONS OF AMERICAN ENTERTAINERS LUCILLE BALL AND DESI ARNAZ. SPANNING NINE DECADES, THE COLLECTION HOLDS PHOTOGRAPHS, CREATIVE PAPERS, AUDIOVISUAL RECORDINGS, SCREEN-USED WARDROBE, AND PERSONAL EFFECTS OF THE COMEDIANS. IN STEWARDING THE COLLECTION, THIS PROJECT WILL AID IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMS AS WELL AS INCREASE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION FOR STAFF, MUSEUM PATRONS, STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE PUBLIC TO FOSTER AN APPRECIATION FOR THE HISTORY AND CRAFT OF COMEDY.

THE UNIVERSITY AND JEPSON HERBARIA AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY WILL DEVELOP A SERIES OF VIRTUAL WORKSHOPS THAT PROMOTE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND DISCOVERY IN THE FIELDS OF BOTANY, ECOLOGY, AND CONSERVATION BIOLOGY. THE WORKSHOPS AND ACCOMPANYING RECORDINGS WILL ADDRESS CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES. GEARED TOWARD LIFELONG LEARNERS, RECORDINGS OF THE LECTURE PORTIONS OF THE TWELVE WORKSHOPS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ONLINE AND FREE OF CHARGE. THE WORKSHOPS AND VIDEOS WILL PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY, MUSEUM-BASED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT DEMONSTRATE THE VALUE OF MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND HOW THOSE COLLECTIONS ARE USED IN RESEARCH AND EDUCATION. BY BRINGING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TO A BROADER AUDIENCE, THIS PROGRAM WILL EDUCATE PARTICIPANTS ABOUT HOW EACH MEMBER OF A COMMUNITY CAN CONTRIBUTE TO LOCAL EFFORTS TO PROTECT NATURAL RESOURCES.

IN THE SECOND PHASE OF ITS MASTER INTERPRETIVE PLAN, THE MUSEUM OF NORTH IDAHO WILL INVITE MORE COMMUNITY VOICES TO THE TABLE TO UPDATE ITS EXHIBITIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE WITH THE COEUR D?ALENE TRIBE, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, HISTORICAL SOCIETIES, K-12 SCHOOLS AND UNIVERSITIES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH A SERIES OF COMMUNITY MEETINGS AND PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS. IN RESPONSE TO COMMUNITY FEEDBACK, INTERPRETIVE DESIGN AND EXHIBIT FABRICATION CONSULTANTS WILL DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE EXHIBITS, INCLUDING THOSE IN THE NEW EXHIBITION HALL. BY INCORPORATING COMMUNITY FEEDBACK AND STRENGTHENING LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS, THE MUSEUM WILL BRING PUBLIC VOICES TO THE EXHIBIT CONTENT AND MAKE THE MUSEUM MORE RELEVANT TO ITS CURRENT COMMUNITY AND VISITORS.

THE NOBLE MARITIME COLLECTION WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING TO 300 FIFTH THROUGH EIGHTH GRADE STUDENTS IN LOCAL UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN 24 SESSIONS OVER THE COURSE OF A SCHOOL YEAR AT THE MUSEUM, IN THE STUDENTS? CLASSROOMS, AND AT LOCAL SHIPYARDS IN STATEN ISLAND, NEW YORK. IN COLLABORATION WITH SIX BUSINESSES FROM THE LOCAL MARITIME INDUSTRY AND FOUR PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN STATE ISLAND, THIS PROGRAM AIMS TO PROMOTE STUDENT UNDERSTANDING OF THE CONTEMPORARY AND HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCE OF THE LOCAL MARITIME INDUSTRY. MUSEUM EDUCATORS WILL LEAD ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING TOURS OF THE MUSEUM?S EXHIBITIONS, VISITS TO LOCAL SHIPYARDS, AND ART, MUSIC, AND WRITING PROJECTS. EACH STUDENT WILL RECEIVE A COPY OF THE WORKBOOK THAT ACCOMPANIES THE PROGRAM, DESIGNED TO BUILD APPRECIATION FOR LOCAL MARITIME HISTORY AND HERITAGE.

THE WALTER ANDERSON MUSEUM OF ART WILL PURCHASE STORAGE FURNITURE NEEDED TO SECURELY REHOUSE AND PROTECT THEIR PERMANENT COLLECTION. A PRESERVATION NEEDS ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED IN 2019 REVEALED THAT THE MUSEUM VAULT LACKS ADEQUATE STORAGE SPACE, PROPER STORAGE FURNITURE, AND SUFFERS FROM OVERCROWDING AND LACK OF ACCESS. BY PURCHASING AND INSTALLING NEW STORAGE FURNITURE, THEY WILL BE ABLE TO PROPERLY STORE TWO DIMENSIONAL ARTWORKS THAT ARE CURRENTLY HOUSED IN LESS-THAN-IDEAL SITUATIONS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL EXPAND EXISTING VAULT CAPACITY AND CREATE NEW OPEN STORAGE FOR CERAMICS TO INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS AND MAXIMIZE THE USE OF THEIR EXISTING SPACE.

THE MARITIME AQUARIUM WILL ADDRESS THE CHALLENGE OF MAKING VIRTUAL PROGRAMS ACCESSIBLE TO LEARNERS WITH SPECIAL NEEDS THROUGH ITS IMPROVE FOR ALL (IMPROVING VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES FOR ALL AUDIENCES) PROJECT. OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD, THE AQUARIUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH SEVERAL COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND ACCESSIBILITY EXPERTS TO CREATE 12 NEW VIRTUAL PROGRAMS FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH INTELLECTUAL, DEVELOPMENTAL, AND PHYSICAL DISABILITIES. THROUGH THIS EFFORT, THEY WILL DEVELOP BEST PRACTICES FOR IMPLEMENTING VIRTUAL PROGRAMS FOR THESE AUDIENCES AND CONDUCT A PILOT WORKSHOP TO TRAIN MUSEUM EDUCATORS IN THESE PRACTICES. RESULTS WILL BE EVALUATED THROUGH CLASSROOM OBSERVATIONS, STUDENT AND TEACHER SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUPS, AND INDIVIDUAL INTERVIEWS.

THE DAVID WINTON BELL GALLERY AT BROWN UNIVERSITY WILL IMPROVE ITS ABILITY TO INVENTORY, TRACK, MAINTAIN AND FACILITATE THE USE OF ITS ART COLLECTION WITH AN UPDATED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE. SEARCHABLE RECORDS WILL ENSURE IMPROVED ACCESS AND STEWARDSHIP TO BROWN?S ART COLLECTIONS, AND SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS YEAR-LONG PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED USE OF THE COLLECTIONS BY FACULTY, STUDENTS AND PUBLIC USERS. THE NEW COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE WILL DOCUMENT HISTORIES AND UPDATES REGARDING OBJECT CARE AND AID IN EXHIBITION PLANNING. AS A DIGITAL RESOURCE, THE DATABASE WILL ALSO ENCOURAGE ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT WITH THE COLLECTION AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING FOR STUDENTS.

THE ALABAMA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA WILL REHOUSE, DIGITIZE, AND IMAGE THE HISTORIC INVERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGY AND TYPE COLLECTIONS. THE PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTION IS ONE OF THE LARGEST COMPONENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA MUSEUMS COLLECTION, CONSISTING OF AT LEAST 500,000 SPECIMENS, REPRESENTING 500 MILLION YEARS OF TIME. FOUR GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY?S MUSEUM STUDIES PROGRAM WILL BE RECRUITED TO ASSIST THE PROJECT, PROVIDING CAREER DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES. ENHANCED ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTIONS WILL BENEFIT MUSEUM AND UNIVERSITY FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENTS AS WELL AS NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MILTON PUBLIC LIBRARY AND THE MILTON SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND PREVENTION COALITION, THE FORBES HOUSE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE PROGRAMS FOR AN EXHIBIT EXPLORING THE FORBES FAMILY’S INVOLVEMENT IN THE 19TH CENTURY OPIUM TRADE AND ITS RELATION TO TODAY’S OPIOID EPIDEMIC. PROGRAMS WILL BE DESIGNED FOR ADULTS, SCHOOL GROUPS, AND TEACHERS IN CONSULTATION WITH STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING CHINESE SCHOLARS, LOCAL CHINESE RESIDENTS AND RECENT IMMIGRANTS, AND EXPERTS DEALING WITH THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC IN MASSACHUSETTS. PARTICIPANTS WILL GAIN AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE HISTORY OF ADDICTION AND THE CHINESE PERSPECTIVE ON THE OPIUM TRADE, AS WELL AS AN APPRECIATION FOR CIVIC RESPONSIBILITY AND ACTION.

THE MUSEO DE ARTE, MAYAGUEZ AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO WILL REHOUSE THE PAINTINGS OF MARCOS IRIZARRY, AN ABSTRACT PUERTO RICAN ARTIST. THE PAINTING COLLECTION IS A HIGH CONSERVATION PRIORITY FOR REHOUSING DUE TO THE LARGE DIMENSIONS AND UNIQUE CONSTRUCTION OF THE PAINTINGS AND THE ENGRAVING MURALS. STARTING WITH THE MOST VULNERABLE PAPER AND PAINTINGS IN THEIR COLLECTION, THE MUSEUM WILL PERFORM PROFESSIONAL ASSESSMENTS AND ACQUIRE MUSEUM-QUALITY STORAGE FURNITURE FOR CONSERVATION AND SAFE ACCESS. IRIZARRY?S PERMANENT COLLECTION INCLUDES MORE THAN 1,152 OBJECTS, PAINTINGS, WORKS ON PAPER, MURALS AND 300 DOCUMENTS FROM THE ARTIST'S CAREER.

THE ROSS ART MUSEUM AT OHIO WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY WILL INCREASE STORAGE CAPACITY TO REDUCE OVERCROWDING OF UNFRAMED ARTWORKS; IMPROVE PHYSICAL OBJECT SAFETY IN GROUND-LEVEL STORAGE; AND ORGANIZE THEIR COLLECTION BY SIZE, MEDIUM, AND ARTIST. THE PROJECT IS A CULMINATION OF RECOMMENDATIONS MADE FROM RECENT COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) AND MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORTS. INCREASING THEIR STORAGE CAPACITY AND OPTIMIZING ORGANIZATION WILL RESULT IN BETTER CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF THE MUSEUM?S EXISTING ARTWORKS, AS WELL AS PROVIDE THE MUSEUM WITH NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGAGE ARTISTS AND ALUMNI THROUGH CONTINUED ACQUISITIONS.

THE GREAT AMERICAN SONGBOOK FOUNDATION (GASF) WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE MEREDITH WILLSON PAPERS BY PROCESSING, INVENTORYING, AND REHOUSING MORE THAN 100,000 DOCUMENTS AND 42 SCRAPBOOKS BELONGING TO THE COMPOSER, LYRICIST, AND WRITER. A PROCESSING ARCHIVIST WILL BE HIRED TO COMPLETE THIS WORK WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A GRADUATE INTERN, RESULTING IN AN UPDATED ONLINE FINDING AID AND THE CREATION OF FORMAL ARCHIVAL PROCESSING PROCEDURES FOR USE BY STAFF AND INTERNS. IN COLLABORATION WITH PROJECT PARTNERS, GASF WILL ALSO PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE DIGITIZATION PLAN FOR THE COLLECTION. AS A RESULT, GASF WILL STRENGTHEN ITS CAPACITY FOR PROCESSING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS AND IMPROVE THE DISCOVERABILITY OF THE MEREDITH WILLSON PAPERS BY STUDENTS, MUSIC SCHOLARS, WRITERS, AND OTHERS INTERESTED IN HIS WORK.

IDENTIFIED AS PART OF A MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORT, THE SHEBOYGAN COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY AND MUSEUM WILL INVENTORY AND DOCUMENT TWO-THIRDS OF THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTION THROUGH RECORDING CRITICAL OBJECT DATA AND PROCESSING RECENT ACQUISITIONS. CAPTURING THE HISTORY OF SHEBOYGAN COUNTY?S INHABITANTS, THE PERMANENT COLLECTION CONTAINS OBJECTS SPANNING THE ENTIRE DEVELOPMENT OF SHEBOYGAN COUNTY, DATING FROM 10,000 B.C.E. TO THE PRESENT. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTION ASSISTANT TO CATALOGUE AND RE-HOUSE THE MATERIALS, WHICH WILL LEAD TO GREATER ACCESSIBILITY TO OBJECTS FOR BOTH THE PUBLIC AND MUSEUM STAFF THROUGH IMPROVED DIGITAL RECORDS AND INCREASED USE OF OBJECTS WITHIN EXHIBITS.

THE DYCKMAN FARMHOUSE MUSEUM WILL CREATE A NEW INTERPRETATION PLAN THAT INVESTIGATES THE STORIES OF THE PEOPLE THAT WERE ENSLAVED BY THE DYCKMAN FAMILY AND IN, WHAT IS NOW, THE INWOOD NEIGHBORHOOD OF UPPER MANHATTAN. THE OVERALL INTERPRETATION OF THE HISTORIC SITE, PROGRAMMING, AND EXHIBITIONS WILL BE INFORMED BY AN INTERPRETATION CONSULTANT, AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE OF PROFESSIONALS WITH EXPERTISE IN AFRICAN AMERICAN AND CULINARY HISTORY, AND FEEDBACK FROM THE COMMUNITY TO CREATE A PLAN THAT WILL BRING AN INCLUSIVE HISTORY TO ALL VISITORS, FOSTER A SENSE OF TRANSPARENCY, AND DRAW IN VISITORS WHO HAVE NOT YET SEEN THEMSELVES REPRESENTED IN THE CURRENT NARRATIVE.

THE JIM CROW MUSEUM OF RACIST MEMORABILIA AT FERRIS STATE UNIVERSITY WILL UNDERTAKE A COLLECTIONS DIGITIZATION PROJECT TO INCREASE ACCESS TO MUSEUM CONTENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE UPGRADING TO A NEW CLOUD-BASED COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM THAT ALLOWS PUBLIC ACCESS, MIGRATING EXISTING COLLECTIONS DATA TO THE NEW SYSTEM, ADDING NEW DIGITAL ASSETS TO THE COLLECTIONS DATABASE, AND CREATING A DIGITAL EXHIBIT AND VIRTUAL GALLERY TOURS. THE NEW, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE AND ASSOCIATED DIGITAL EXHIBIT AND VIRTUAL GALLERY TOURS WILL ENABLE SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, AND COMMUNITIES WHO MAY NOT LIVE NEAR THE MUSEUM TO ACCESS THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS CONTENT.

THE MUSEUM OF CRAFT AND DESIGN WILL CREATE AND DISTRIBUTE FREE, MULTILINGUAL INSTRUCTIONAL ART KITS (MOBILE MAKEART KITS) TO OVER 9,000 PEOPLE IN THE BAY AREA, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON REACHING CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN COMMUNITIES ACUTELY AFFECTED BY COVID-19. THEY WILL COLLABORATE WITH LOCAL BIPOC (BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR) ARTISTS TO CREATE THE MAKEART KITS AND PARTNER WITH LOCAL LIBRARIES, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND OTHER MUSEUMS TO HOLD MAKEART KIT DISTRIBUTION EVENTS. THESE HANDS-ON ART EXPERIENCES WILL ENCOURAGE CREATIVITY, CONNECTION, AND KNOWLEDGE OF CRAFT AND DESIGN, IN ADDITION TO SUPPORTING THE WORK OF PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS AND PROVIDING EMPLOYMENT AND EXPOSURE FOR BIPOC ARTISTS AND DESIGNERS.

THE DUNGENESS RIVER AUDUBON CENTER WILL DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND INSTALL UPDATES TO THREE OF THE CENTER?S EXHIBIT AREAS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ENGAGING SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS FROM THE CENTER, THE JAMESTOWN S?KLALLAM TRIBE, THE OLYMPIC PENINSULA AUDUBON SOCIETY, AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO CREATE THE FOLLOWING THREE AREAS: AN ALCOVE DEVOTED TO INTERPRETING THE SALMON WHO CALL THE DUNGENESS WATERSHED HOME; A LARGE-SCALE, THREE-DIMENSIONAL RELIEF MAP OF THE DUNGENESS WATERSHED; AND A CHILDREN?S DISCOVERY AREA. THE UPDATED EXHIBIT AREAS WILL BE MORE SCIENTIFICALLY ACCURATE AND WILL SHOW TRAILS, ROADS, HISTORIC TRIBAL VILLAGES, AND WATERSHED RESTORATION SITES; ILLUSTRATE LANDSCAPE FEATURES FROM HIGH COUNTRY TO THE STRAIT; AND SUPPORT THE ECOSYSTEM EXHIBITS.

THE SKID ROW HISTORY MUSEUM AND ARCHIVE (SRHMA) WILL CREATE THE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY ARTWORK SERIES ?STATE OF CRISIS/COMMUNITY OF RESILIENCE.? THE GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO EDUCATE AUDIENCES?SCHOLARS, JOURNALISTS, AND THE PUBLIC, INCLUDING SKID ROW RESIDENTS, THAT?DESPITE THE PREVAILING PERCEPTION?SKID ROW HAS A RICH HISTORY OF GRASSROOTS CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND INNOVATIVE COMMUNITY-GENERATED SOLUTIONS TO SOCIAL PROBLEMS. LED BY A COMMUNITY CURATOR, A SKID ROW LEADER WITH VAST PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE OF THE NEIGHBORHOOD, AND A TEAM OF ARTISTIC COLLABORATORS, SCHOLARS AND RESOURCES, INCLUDING SRHMA?S ARCHIVE, THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE AN SRHMA EXHIBITION, ACTIVATED BY THEATRICAL AND MUSICAL PERFORMANCES, AND PUBLIC CONVERSATIONS.

THE AMERICAN SADDLEBRED MUSEUM WILL CATALOG AND ORGANIZE THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION OF OVER 2,600 BOOKS, MAGAZINES, AND VIDEOS ON A SPECIFIC BREED OF HORSE, THE AMERICAN SADDLEBRED. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A PART-TIME LIBRARIAN WHO WILL INVENTORY AND CATALOG THE COLLECTION USING AN ONLINE DATABASE THAT IS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AND LAUNCH A PUBLIC AWARENESS CAMPAIGN REGARDING THE COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP PRESERVE THE COLLECTION AND MAKE IT AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC, EQUINE SCHOLARS, AND INDIVIDUALS RESEARCHING EQUINE OR FAMILY HISTORIES, AND ALIGNS WITH THE MUSEUM?S STRATEGIC PLAN TO INCREASE EASE OF ACCESS AND CREATE GREATER AWARENESS OF THIS SPECIFIC BREED OF HORSE.

THE ST. JOSEPH MUSEUMS WILL HIRE A STORAGE SOLUTIONS CONTRACTOR TO INSTALL CUSTOM-BUILT COMPACT AND ROLLED STORAGE SYSTEMS TO PROPERLY HOUSE AND CARE FOR THEIR LARGE AND DIVERSE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM IS HOME TO MORE THAN 200,000 OBJECTS, PHOTOS, ARCHIVAL MATERIALS, AND BOOKS, WHICH SUPPORT ITS MISSION TO PRESERVE AND INTERPRET THE STORIES OF THE ST. JOSEPH COMMUNITY AND ITS CITIZENS. THE NEWLY INSTALLED STORAGE HARDWARE IS SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO ALLOW FLEXIBILITY FOR THE FUTURE GROWTH AND ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTION, ENSURING SPACE FOR ANY NEW ITEMS THAT ARE DONATED, WHILE ALSO ALLOWING THE MUSEUM TO SAFELY STORE, PRESERVE, AND MAKE THEIR ARTIFACTS ACCESSIBLE FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

TUDOR PLACE HISTORIC HOUSE AND GARDEN WILL ASSEMBLE AND SHARE A COLLECTION OF RESOURCES RELATED TO THE ENSLAVED INDIVIDUALS WHO LIVED AND WORKED AT THIS AND ASSOCIATED PROPERTIES TO PRESENT A MORE COMPLETE AND ACCURATE PORTRAYAL OF THEIR LIVES, THE HISTORY OF TUDOR PLACE, AND URBAN SLAVERY IN WASHINGTON, DC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A PROJECT MANAGER TO COLLECT RESOURCES RELATED TO ENSLAVED PEOPLE AT TUDOR HOUSE AND PARTNER INSTITUTIONS, CONNECT WITH DESCENDANTS OF ENSLAVED INDIVIDUALS, AND CREATE A TEMPORARY EXHIBIT AND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING INCORPORATING THE NEWLY COLLECTED SOURCES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, TUDOR PLACE WILL ENGAGE AND SERVE A MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCE THROUGH TOURS AND LECTURES THAT BROADEN THE UNDERSTANDING OF URBAN SLAVERY IN THE CONTEXT OF AMERICAN HISTORY.

THE CENTER FOR BURMA STUDIES AT NORTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY WILL UNDERTAKE A DIGITIZATION PROJECT FOCUSING ON ITS TEXTILE COLLECTION. THE PROJECT WILL BE DIVIDED INTO TWO STAGES: THE FIRST TO PROFESSIONALLY PHOTOGRAPH THE TEXTILE HOLDINGS, AND THE SECOND TO FINISH THE DIGITIZATION PROCESS BY CREATING DOWNLOADABLE STILL IMAGES, UPDATING DESCRIPTIVE METADATA USING DUBLIN CORE, AND MAKING THE EVENTUAL PRODUCTS FREELY AVAILABLE ONLINE. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO HIRE A GRADUATE ASSISTANT TO PHOTOGRAPH THE OBJECTS AND CATALOG THEM. THE RESULTING DATABASE WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO THE TEXTILE COLLECTION, WHILE IMPROVING THE LONG-TERM CARE OF THE OBJECTS BY MINIMIZING THE NEED FOR PHYSICAL CONTACT.

THE SHARON HISTORICAL SOCIETY AND MUSEUM (SHSM) WILL IMPLEMENT A TWO-YEAR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROJECT TO IMPROVE STEWARDSHIP OF AND ACCESS TO THE FRANCES MOREHOUSE KELSEY ARCHIVES. THE KELSEY ARCHIVES CONTAINS A VARIETY OF HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT VISUAL AND TEXTUAL MATERIALS WHICH ILLUSTRATE TWO ASPECTS OF HISTORY IN THE TOWN OF SHARON: THE ACTIVE LIFE AND CAREER OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY PHOTOGRAPHER, FRANCES MOREHOUSE KELSEY (1914-1999), AND THE MAJOR EVENTS, INDIVIDUALS, LOCATIONS, AND MILESTONES IN THE TOWN OF SHARON?S HISTORY DURING THE MID TO LATE TWENTIETH CENTURY. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE HIRING A NEW ARCHIVIST TO PROCESS, INVENTORY, REHOUSE, AND PRODUCE A DIGITAL FINDING AID FOR THE KELSEY ARCHIVES WHICH WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO A DIGITAL ARCHIVAL SEARCH AGGREGATOR TOOL ACCESSIBLE TO MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC, ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, AND STUDENTS.

THE JOSEPH MOORE MUSEUM (JMM) AT EARLHAM COLLEGE WILL EXPAND ITS ROLE AS A COMMUNITY PARTNER IN RICHMOND, INDIANA, AND THE BROADER REGION, BY UNDERTAKING A COMMUNITY ASSESSMENT PROJECT AND ACCOMPANYING PILOT COMMUNITY COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP. THIS PROJECT IMPLEMENTS A STEP-BY-STEP STRATEGIC APPROACH TO ASSESSING COMMUNITY NEEDS AND ESTABLISHING ONGOING COMMUNITY DIALOGUE JOINTLY, DRAWING ON THE INSIGHTS AND EXPERIENCE FROM LEADERS IN THE MUSEUM FIELD, COUNTY LEADERS IN PHILANTHROPY/SERVICE, PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, WHILE TRAINING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN BEST PRACTICES OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. PROJECT OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN INCREASED SENSE OF COMMUNITY OWNERSHIP OF THE MUSEUM, DIVERSIFICATION OF THE MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD AND MUSEUM INCOME STREAMS, TRAINING FOR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, WRITTEN DOCUMENTATION OF COMMUNITY NEEDS, A CO-CREATED ENGAGEMENT PLAN, AND A WHITE PAPER FOR THE COMMUNITY AND MUSEUM FIELD.

THE GADSDEN ARTS CENTER AND MUSEUM (GACM) WILL PARTNER WITH THE TALLAHASSEE MUSEUM AND ARTIST MARY L. PROCTOR TO CREATE ?I AM JUST THE MESSENGER", A YEAR-LONG EXHIBITION OF WORK BY MISSIONARY MARY PROCTOR. THE EXHIBITION RECORDS, PRESENTS, AND PRESERVES THE WORK AND STORY OF ONE OF THE LAST LIVING ARTISTS REPRESENTED IN GACM'S SOUTHERN VERNACULAR ART COLLECTION, A SELF-TAUGHT ARTIST AND WOMAN OF COLOR. "I AM JUST THE MESSENGER? WILL BE INFORMED BY INTERVIEWS WITH AND PRESENTATIONS BY THE ARTIST, SHARED THROUGH INTERPRETIVE ADULT AND SCHOOL PROGRAMS, AND ARCHIVED THROUGH AN ORAL HISTORY AND EXHIBITION VIDEO. THE EXHIBIT WILL ADDRESS THE NEEDS TO INCREASE WOMEN ARTISTS REPRESENTED IN THE GACM PERMANENT COLLECTION AND TO INCREASE SCHOLARSHIP ON WOMEN ARTIST OF COLOR.

THE IROQUOIS INDIAN MUSEUM WILL CREATE ?THE ART OF CONNECTIVITY,? AN EXHIBITION OF CONTEMPORARY HAUDENOSAUNEE ARTWORK TITLED MATERIAL SHIFT AND A PARTICIPATORY OUTDOOR SCULPTURE BASED ON THE GEORGE WASHINGTON/CANANDAIGUA TREATY WAMPUM BELT. DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH TWO MOHAWK ARTISTS, THE PROJECT SUPPORTS THE MUSEUM?S EFFORT TO INCLUDE IROQUOIS PERSPECTIVES AND INPUT INTO ALL COMPONENTS OF ITS OPERATIONS. ?THE ART OF CONNECTIVITY? WAS DESIGNED TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF VISITORS WORN DOWN FROM THE RESTRICTIONS AND CONCERNS OF THE PANDEMIC TO RE-ENGAGE WITH PLAYFUL DISCOVERY AND TO FIND INSPIRATION FOR THE FUTURE THROUGH INTERACTIVE AND SELF-DIRECTED EXPLORATIONS OF IROQUOIS ART AND CULTURAL PHILOSOPHIES.

LUX ART INSTITUTE IS EXPANDING THE REACH OF THE VALISE PROJECT, A UNIQUE ARTS OUTREACH PROGRAM THAT BRINGS DESERVING STUDENTS A HANDS-ON ART MAKING EXPERIENCE THAT INTERSECTS WITH DAILY ACADEMIC SUBJECTS. WHILE THE VALISE PROJECT CURRENTLY PROVIDES ONSITE, VIRTUAL, AND DIGITAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR DISADVANTAGED YOUTH IN NORTH COUNTY SAN DIEGO, LUX AIMS TO EXPAND ITS IMPACT BY REACHING STUDENTS ACROSS THE ENTIRETY OF SAN DIEGO COUNTY. TO COINCIDE WITH THIS EXPANSION, LUX WILL COMMISSION A NEW VALISE, DESIGNED BY AN ACCOMPLISHED CONTEMPORARY ARTIST, ACCOMPANIED BY CURRICULUM RELEVANT TO THE STUDENTS? LIVES AND DAILY LEARNING. THE VALISE PROJECT WILL GROW, BRINGING NEW CRITICAL THINKING, PROBLEM SOLVING, AND CREATIVE STRATEGIES INTO THE LIVES OF UNDERPRIVILEGED STUDENTS ACROSS SAN DIEGO COUNTY.

THE ARLINGTON HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL UNDERTAKE A PROJECT TO COMPLETELY INVENTORY, DIGITIZE, AND REHOUSE 1,352 OBJECTS THAT ARE CURRENTLY THE MOST AT RISK FOR POTENTIAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT ISSUES. THIS SUBSET OF THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS INCLUDES ALL FRAMED WORKS ON PAPER, PAINTINGS, AND LOCALLY SIGNIFICANT OBJECTS. THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL USE FUNDS TO PURCHASE AND INSTALL ROLLING SHELVING UNITS, WHICH WILL INCREASE STORAGE CAPACITY AND ALLEVIATE OVERCROWDING OF COLLECTIONS. DIGITIZED ITEMS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED METADATA WILL BE ADDED TO THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND UPLOADED TO AN ONLINE PLATFORM PERMITTING INCREASED ACCESS FOR EDUCATORS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE MILWAUKEE COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL CREATE A DIGITIZATION PLAN AND DIGITAL COLLECTION POLICY FOR ITS ARCHIVAL COLLECTION TO SUPPORT STEWARDSHIP AND INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH AN EXTERNAL DIGITAL ARCHIVES CONSULTANT TO ASSESS THE SOCIETY?S COLLECTION AND DETERMINE DIGITIZATION PRIORITIES. FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO OFFER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE MUSEUM?S ARCHIVAL STAFF, HELPING TO BUILD THEIR CAPACITY FOR FUTURE DIGITIZATION ACTIVITIES. THE FINAL DIGITIZATION PLAN WILL BE TAILORED TO THE SOCIETY?S NEEDS AND STRATEGIC GOALS AND WILL BENEFIT RESEARCHERS AND INDIVIDUALS WHO USE THE MUSEUM?S ARCHIVES.

THE CHRISTA MCAULIFFE CENTER FOR INTEGRATED SCIENCE LEARNING AT FRAMINGHAM STATE UNIVERSITY WILL IMPLEMENT A TEAM MENTORSHIP AND PROJECT-BASED LEARNING PROGRAM FOR LOCAL HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS ARE TASKED WITH CREATING CAMPAIGNS (EXHIBITS, VIDEOS, AND PRESENTATIONS) THAT INCREASE AWARENESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGES HELPING PARTICIPANTS TO DEVELOP KNOWLEDGE, ANALYTICAL AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS, AND ETHICAL VIEWPOINTS THAT GUIDE THEIR ACTIONS ON LOCAL AND GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES. PROJECT OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE STUDENT-CREATED EXHIBITS, VIDEOS, AND PRESENTATIONS THAT INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF THE INTERCONNECTED RELATIONSHIPS AMONG COMMUNITY, ECONOMY AND THE ENVIRONMENT; APPRECIATION OF THE IMPACTS OF PERSONAL ACTIONS BOTH LOCALLY AND GLOBALLY; AND, EVENTUALLY, CHANGES IN BEHAVIOR.

THE HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL SOCIETY OF CLAY COUNTY WILL CONTRACT WITH TEXTILE AND PAINTING CONSERVATORS FOR AN ON-SITE, ITEM-BY-ITEM SURVEY OF THEIR COLLECTION, WHICH INCLUDES PAINTINGS BY REGIONAL ARTISTS AND TEXTILES FROM IMMIGRANT AGRARIAN COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS CONTEMPORARY ITEMS. THESE OBJECTS WERE IDENTIFIED IN A 2019 COLLECTIONS ASSESSMENT FOR PRESERVATION (CAP) REPORT AS THE MOST AT-RISK ITEMS. THE CONSERVATORS WILL ASSESS THEIR CONDITION AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE NEXT STEPS IN THEIR CARE WHICH WILL EVENTUALLY ALLOW THESE OBJECTS TO BECOME MORE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH RESEARCH AND EXHIBITIONS. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL INCLUDE COLLECTIONS CARE WORKSHOPS CONDUCTED BY THE CONTRACTED CONSERVATORS FOR LOCAL MUSEUM-STUDIES AND PUBLIC-HISTORY UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS.

MONROE COUNTY?S SENECA PARK ZOO WILL MODERNIZE THE GUEST EXPERIENCE IN THE ZOO?S ANIMAL HOSPITAL TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY AND PROMOTE VISITOR ENGAGEMENT. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS EXISTING BARRIERS TO VISITOR PARTICIPATION AND ENGAGEMENT BY UPDATING THE EDUCATIONAL GRAPHICS AND INCORPORATING NEW TECHNOLOGY INTO THE EXHIBIT TO CREATE A MULTISENSORY EXPERIENCE THAT ENGAGES VISITORS OF ALL EDUCATION LEVELS, INTERESTS, AND ABILITIES. THE MODERNIZED ANIMAL HOSPITAL WILL BENEFIT THE ZOO?S 400,000 ANNUAL VISITORS AND HELP ACCOMPLISH ITS STRATEGIC GOALS OF COMPELLING STORYTELLING AND PROVIDING EXCEPTIONAL EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES TO INSPIRE CONSERVATION ACTION.

THE KURT VONNEGUT MUSEUM AND LIBRARY (KVML) WILL UNDERTAKE A PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE CARE OF AND INCREASE ACCESS TO THEIR COLLECTIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INTEGRATING A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, PARTNERING WITH IUPUI (INDIANA UNIVERSITY - PURDUE UNIVERSITY INDIANAPOLIS) UNIVERSITY LIBRARY CENTER FOR DIGITAL SCHOLARSHIP TO DIGITIZE THE COLLECTION, CREATING FIVE VIRTUAL 3D MUSEUM EXPERIENCES, AND FUNDING AN IUPUI PAID COLLECTIONS INTERNSHIP. PROJECT RESULTS INCLUDE A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE THAT ENABLES THE KVML'S COLLECTION TO BE ACCESSED BY THOSE WHO ARE UNABLE TO ATTEND IN PERSON, SUCH AS STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, SCHOLARS, AND LEARNERS OF ALL AGES.

THE WESTCHESTER CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP FULL STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ART, AND MATH) AHEAD, AN INTEGRATED, MODULE-BASED SEQUENCE OF HANDS-ON STEAM WORKSHOPS ADAPTABLE FOR BOTH IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL TEACHING FOR HIGH-NEED 2ND TO 6TH GRADE STUDENTS AT THOMAS CORNELL ACADEMY IN YONKERS, NY AND WATERSIDE SCHOOL IN STAMFORD, CT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT, PREPARATION, DELIVERY, AND EVALUATION TO CREATE PROGRAMS THAT ARE REPLICABLE AND SUSTAINABLE WHILE LEVERAGING THE MUSEUM'S RESOURCES TO DEMONSTRATE HOW IT CAN SUPPORT THEIR COMMUNITIES IN NEED DURING UNPRECEDENTED TIMES. FULL STEAM AHEAD ANTICIPATES REACHING 300 STUDENTS FROM LOW-INCOME AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED FAMILIES.

THE KLEHM ARBORETUM & BOTANIC GARDEN WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT TWO MOBILE PLATFORMS THAT ENABLE VISITORS TO USE THEIR SMARTPHONES TO PARTICIPATE IN A MOBILE TOUR AND A SCAVENGER HUNT ACTIVITY TO ENCOURAGE LIFELONG LEARNING AND INCREASE PARTICIPATORY INTERPRETATION. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE STAFF TIME TO ADOPT TWO DIFFERENT MOBILE PLATFORMS, CREATE SIGN MATERIALS, AND ACQUIRE TABLETS TO ENSURE VISITORS WITHOUT SMARTPHONES CAN ALSO ACCESS THE ACTIVITIES. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP CONTENT HIGHLIGHTING THE FEATURES OF UNIQUE PLANTS AND TREES FOUND WITHIN ITS LIVING COLLECTIONS. CURATED TOURS WILL INCLUDE QUIZ AND TRIVIA ELEMENTS THAT WILL BUILD KNOWLEDGE OF PLANT LIFE AND OTHER USEFUL INFORMATION, WHILE SCAVENGER HUNT ACTIVITIES WILL BE MORE HANDS-ON AND INVESTIGATIVE AND WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR DIFFERENT AGE GROUPS.

THE WYOMING STATE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT AN EXHIBIT PLAN DEVELOPED WITH CONTENT EXPERTS FROM ACROSS THE STATE TO PRODUCE A PREHISTORIC WYOMING EXHIBIT. THE EXHIBIT WILL EXPLORE THE PREHISTORY OF WYOMING, WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS ON THE AGE OF DINOSAURS, AND WILL SERVE THE NEEDS OF THE MUSEUM?S THREE MAIN VISITOR GROUPS?LOCAL FAMILIES, OUT-OF-STATE TOURISTS, AND STUDENTS ON FIELD TRIPS?AS DETERMINED THROUGH FORMATIVE SURVEYS AND VISITOR FEEDBACK. VISITORS WILL LEARN ABOUT THE GEOLOGICAL FORCES THAT SHAPED THE WYOMING LANDSCAPE VISIBLE TODAY, EXAMINE THE DIFFERENT PLANTS AND ANIMALS THAT HAVE CALLED WYOMING HOME THROUGH THE AGES, AND DISCOVER THE HISTORY OF FOSSIL HUNTERS IN WYOMING.

THE NORTH COUNTRY CHILDREN?S MUSEUM?S SWARTZENTRUBER AMISH HOME EXHIBIT WILL ESTABLISH A UNIQUE AND AUTHENTIC CULTURAL EXPERIENCE FOR HANDS-ON, MINDS-ON LEARNING FOR CHILDREN 12 AND UNDER AND THEIR FAMILIES IN A RURAL, LOW-INCOME COMMUNITY. THE SWARTZENTRUBER AMISH HOME EXHIBIT WILL BE A REPLICA HOME AND ?OUTDOOR? WOOD SHOP, CARRIAGE, CLOTHESLINE/WASHING AREA, AND CHICKEN COOP. THE EXHIBIT WILL HELP VISITORS GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE DAILY LIFE EXPERIENCE OF THE SWARTZENTRUBER AMISH, FOCUSING ON CHILDREN?S ROLES IN THE FAMILY, AND WILL BE CREATED WITH SCHOLAR DR. KAREN JOHNSON-WEINER, LOCAL AMISH BUILDERS AND CRAFTSMEN, AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM, AND MUSEUM STAFF. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A UNIQUE AND AUTHENTIC CULTURAL EXPERIENCE THAT WORKS TO DISPEL NEGATIVE STEREOTYPES AND MISINFORMATION ABOUT AN IMPORTANT AND GROWING COMMUNITY.

THE DISCOVERY CENTER, OPERATED BY THE UNITED STATES SPACE FOUNDATION, WILL PARTNER WITH THE PIKES PEAK LIBRARY DISTRICT TO IMPLEMENT SMALL STEPS, GIANT LEAP: STEM ADVENTURES FOR LITTLE SPACE EXPLORERS, A FREE EARLY LITERACY PROGRAM DESIGNED FOR CHILDREN AGES 3-6 THAT SEEKS TO ENGAGE THE TARGET AUDIENCE OF LOW-INCOME AND MILITARY FAMILIES, POPULATIONS CURRENTLY UNDERSERVED BY THE DISCOVERY CENTER. THE PROGRAM IS AN INTERACTIVE STORYTELLING EXPERIENCE WITH AN ASSOCIATED HANDS-ON CRAFT THAT OCCURS TWICE MONTHLY, ONCE IN PERSON AND ONCE VIRTUALLY, AND IS DESIGNED TO ENABLE EARLY LEARNERS TO GROW IN LITERACY VIA THE LENSES OF SCIENCE AND SPACE EXPLORATION WHILE DEVELOPING VITAL SOCIAL SKILLS AND SELF-ESTEEM.

DIASPORA VIBE CULTURAL ARTS INCUBATOR (DVCAI) WILL TRANSITION THE PUBLIC PROGRAMMING SERIES, CARIBBEAN CROSSROADS TEAS, TO A VIRTUAL PLATFORM TO CONNECT GEOGRAPHICALLY DIVIDED COMMUNITIES WHERE DIASPORIC CULTURAL ENGAGEMENT AND REPRESENTATION IS LIMITED WHILE ENCOURAGING NEW, YOUNG, AND DIVERSE PARTICIPANTS TO THINK OF THEMSELVES AS PATRONS OF CONTEMPORARY ART. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PURCHASING EQUIPMENT, IMPROVING DVCAI?S WEBSITE TO INCREASE ITS ONLINE PRESENCE, AND HIRING PAID INTERNS TO SUPPORT ADAPTING AND PRESENTING THE PROGRAMS ON A NEW VIRTUAL PLATFORM. THIS PROJECT WILL DIVERSIFY DIGITAL CONTENT AVAILABLE ABOUT AND FROM CARIBBEAN, LATINX, AND AFRO-DIASPORIC ARTISTS WHILE CONTINUING TO SERVE ARTISTS, COMMUNITY, SCHOLARS, AND RESEARCHERS.

THE MUSEUM OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE AT A.T. STILL UNIVERSITY OF HEALTH SCIENCES WILL REHOUSE AND PHOTOGRAPH ITS ROUGHLY 120 REGULAR AND OVERSIZED HISTORIC TEXTILES COLLECTION TO IMPROVE THE CARE AND ACCESS OF THIS COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT INCLUDES FUNDING MUSEUM PERSONNEL AS WELL AS PURCHASING THE SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS REQUIRED TO REHOUSE AND PHOTOGRAPH THE COLLECTION ACCORDING TO COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ASSESSING, PROPERLY STORING, CATALOGING, DIGITIZING, AND MAKING AVAILABLE ONLINE THE OBJECTS IN THIS COLLECTION. THE IMPACT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE INCREASED ACCESS AND CONTINUED PRESERVATION OF THE HISTORIC TEXTILES COLLECTION THAT WILL BENEFIT OSTEOPATHIC STUDENTS, PRACTITIONERS, HISTORIANS, AND ENTHUSIASTS.

THE RICHARDSON FAMILY ART MUSEUM AT WOFFORD COLLEGE WILL IMPROVE THE PRESERVATION OF ITS FINE ARTS COLLECTION BY REHOUSING 237 WORKS OF ART, WHICH WILL REQUIRE PURCHASING AND INSTALLING MUSEUM-STANDARD STORAGE FURNITURE?INCLUDING A HIGH-DENSITY STORAGE SYSTEM EQUIPPED WITH THREE MOBILE PAINTING RACKS, ONE MOBILE SHELVING UNIT, AND ONE FIVE-DRAWER FLAT FILE CABINET. IMPROVING STORAGE CONDITIONS WILL PROTECT THE COLLECTION FROM POTENTIAL HAZARDS, MAXIMIZE PRESERVATION, AND RESOLVE ACCESS ISSUES. THE REHOUSING PROJECT ALSO WILL ALLOW ITEMS FROM THE COLLECTION TO BE USED FOR CLASS STUDY OR EXHIBITION, DIRECTLY BENEFITING THE STUDENTS AT THE COLLEGE AS WELL AS MEMBERS OF THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY.

THE MOSES LAKE MUSEUM AND ART CENTER WILL DEVELOP PLANS TO REDESIGN THREE PERMANENT HUMAN HISTORY EXHIBITS TO ADDRESS THE NEED FOR A MORE INCLUSIVE HISTORICAL NARRATIVE AND SPANISH-LANGUAGE ACCESSIBILITY IN THE MUSEUM. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE UPDATING THE EXHIBITS TO TELL A MORE COMPLETE HISTORY OF THE REGION, INCLUDING ELEVATING THE PREVIOUSLY EXCLUDED VOICES OF INDIGENOUS, LATINX, AND OTHER COMMUNITIES WHO HAVE BEEN A KEY PART OF THE AREA HISTORY, AND CREATING BILINGUAL SIGNAGE AND MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE ENGAGING WITH CONSULTANTS, SCHOLARS, AND COMMUNITY LEADERS TO REFINE AND DRAFT THE NEW NARRATIVE AND WORKING WITH AN EXHIBIT DESIGN FIRM TO DRAFT THE NEW PLANS. OUTCOMES WILL BE PLANS FOR EXHIBITS THAT TELL A RICHER, MORE INCLUSIVE HISTORY OF THE REGION IN SPANISH AND ENGLISH THAT WILL BENEFIT VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM INCLUDING RESIDENTS OF MOSES LAKE AND GRANT COUNTY AND TOURIST.

THE DENNOS MUSEUM CENTER AT NORTHWESTERN MICHIGAN COLLEGE WILL ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF OVERCROWDING IN THEIR COLLECTIONS STORAGE AREA WHICH WAS IDENTIFIED THROUGH A 2020 MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PURCHASING FIVE HIGH-DENSITY ART RACKS WHICH WILL REHOUSE 17 LARGE PAINTINGS?RANGING FROM 20TH CENTURY AMERICAN WORKS TO THOSE BY BRITISH AND INDIAN ARTISTS. THE PRIMARY RESULTS WILL BE AN INCREASE IN STORAGE SPACE FOR FUTURE ACQUISITIONS, THE REORGANIZATION OF OVERSIZE WORKS, AND ALL OF THE PAINTINGS WILL BE CATALOGED AND THEIR NEW STORAGE LOCATIONS RECONCILED IN THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.

THE UNIVERSITY MUSEUM AT NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL INVENTORY THE ETHNOGRAPHIC AND HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS HOUSED IN KENT HALL TO INCREASE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS AND ALLOW FOR USE IN TEACHING, RESEARCH, EXHIBITION, COLLABORATIVE OUTREACH, AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A GRADUATE ASSISTANT TO SYSTEMATICALLY RECORD LOCATIONS, OBJECT INFORMATION, AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION INTO A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE TRAINING OF FUTURE MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS AND ALLOWING CLOSER CONNECTIONS BETWEEN COLLECTIONS AND THE STUDENT, FACULTY, STAFF, AND LOCAL COMMUNITY MUSEUM AUDIENCES.

THE MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS WILL PROCESS AND DIGITIZE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS CENTRAL TO THE MUSEUM?S ARCHIVES ON THE EXPERIENCES OF THE CHINESE IN THE UNITED STATES. A PROJECT TEAM WILL PROCESS, TIME CODE, AND CONVERT THE STORIES FROM AN ANALOG FORMAT, PRESERVING THEM FOR FUTURE USE. THEY WILL CREATE A SYSTEM FOR CROSS-REFERENCING THE STORIES IN ALL THREE OF THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS DATABASES. TO EXPAND PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS, THE CONTENT WILL BE AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH THE MUSEUM?S ORAL HISTORY ARCHIVE.

THE MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM AND GARDEN WILL IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FREE COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS AND SPANISH-LANGUAGE MUSEUM TOURS. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO EXPAND THE MUSEUM?S REACH AND INCREASE ENGAGEMENT WITH ITS EAST HARLEM NEIGHBORHOOD AND NEW YORK CITY?S LATINO POPULATION. THE MUSEUM WILL HOLD 10 WORKSHOPS AT COMMUNITY PARTNERS? LOCATIONS, AT WHICH STAFF WILL OFFER AN INTRODUCTION TO THE MUSEUM. PARTICIPANTS WILL ATTEND A SPANISH-LANGUAGE TOUR OF THE MUSEUM DURING ONE SATURDAY EACH MONTH. EACH TOUR WILL HAVE A THEME THAT WILL HIGHLIGHT LATIN AMERICAN AND CARIBBEAN INFLUENCES ON 19TH CENTURY NEW YORK CITY.

THE ALUTIIQ MUSEUM, KODIAK?S TRIBAL REPOSITORY AND CULTURAL CENTER, WILL HOST A TRIBAL SUBMIT TO DISCUSS DIFFICULT SUBJECTS IN RECENT ALUTIIQ HISTORY AND CREATE AN EXHIBITION INTERPRETING THAT HISTORY. TRIBAL REPRESENTATIVES WILL EXPLORE RECENT ALUTIIQ HISTORY WITH TRIBAL SCHOLARS AND FACILITATORS. THEY WILL ADVISE ON THE TOPICS TO BE SHARED AND SUGGEST HOW TO APPROPRIATELY SHARE THEM. THOSE DISCUSSIONS WILL INFORM UPDATES TO THE ALUTIIQ MUSEUM?S INTERPRETIVE PLAN AND CREATE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT MORE FULLY DOCUMENT ALUTIIQ HISTORY. THE MUSEUM WILL ARCHIVE THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND DEVELOP THE MEANS TO PROVIDE A FULLER, MORE TRUTHFUL ACCOUNT OF THE ALUTIIQ EXPERIENCE.

HISTORIC SARANAC LAKE WILL IMPLEMENT A PROJECT DESIGNED TO GAIN INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL OVER ITS COLLECTION IN PREPARATION FOR A MAJOR EXPANSION INTO THE HISTORIC HOME ADJACENT TO THE MUSEUM. THE PROJECT REPRESENTS THE NEXT STEP IN THE MUSEUM?S RECENTLY COMPLETED COLLECTIONS PRESERVATION PLAN. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CREATE CATALOG RECORDS FOR APPROXIMATELY 2,000 PHOTOGRAPHS AND POSTCARDS FROM THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS. THEY WILL REHOUSE AND REORGANIZE OBJECTS AS NEEDED AND GIVE INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS UNIQUE IDENTIFIERS. THEY ALSO WILL CREATE GUIDELINES FOR APPROPRIATE STORAGE IN THE NEW LOCATION BASED ON DATA COLLECTED IN THE CATALOGING PROCESS. THE CATALOG RECORDS WILL MAKE IT EASIER FOR MUSEUM STAFF TO RESPOND TO REQUESTS FROM RESEARCHERS AND TO BETTER UTILIZE COLLECTION IMAGES FOR EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMS.

THE PRATT MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT ?FINDING HOME IN HOMER: PARTNERING TO END YOUTH HOMELESSNESS??A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT AND EXHIBIT THAT FOCUSES ON HOMELESSNESS AMONG YOUTH. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SCHOOL DISTRICT AND COMMUNITY LIAISONS, THE MUSEUM WILL IDENTIFY AND WORK WITH 15-20 YOUTH (HIGH SCHOOL THROUGH AGE 25) WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED HOMELESSNESS. THE YOUTH WILL BE ARTISTS-IN-RESIDENCE AT THE MUSEUM, CREATING ORIGINAL WORK ABOUT HOMELESSNESS WITH GUIDANCE FROM MENTOR ARTISTS.  THE PARTICIPATING YOUTH WILL DEFINE THEIR OWN INTERPRETED EXHIBIT ABOUT THE CAUSES, BARRIERS, ASSUMPTIONS, LIVED EXPERIENCES, STIGMAS, AND POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS TO HOMELESSNESS. A CULMINATING EXHIBITION AND RELATED PROGRAMS WILL SHARE THE YOUTHS? PERSPECTIVES AND ARTISTIC INTERPRETATIONS AND INCLUDE A CALL TO ACTION FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND OTHER VISITORS TO BE PART OF THE SOLUTION.

THE CAYUGA MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND ART WILL IMPLEMENT ?PROCESSING THE PAST: DIGITIZING CAYUGA COUNTY?S PHOTOGRAPHIC HISTORY??A COMPREHENSIVE INVENTORY AND DIGITIZATION PROJECT THAT WILL COMPLETE AN UNFINISHED INVENTORY OF THE MUSEUM?S PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 7,000 STILL IMAGES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CATALOG PHOTOGRAPHS, MATCHING THEM WITH EXISTING RECORDS AND VERIFYING HISTORICAL ACCURACY IF NECESSARY. NEXT, THEY WILL SCAN AND DIGITIZE THE IMAGES TO MAXIMIZE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND CREATE A DATABASE TO ALLOW FOR INCREASED ONLINE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION BY RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC. THEY WILL CREATE A PROCEDURES MANUAL FOR FUTURE INVENTORY PROJECTS, ADHERING TO PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS FOR COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP.

THE LIVING ARTS AND SCIENCE CENTER, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS SERVING RESIDENTS OF THE EAST END AND NORTH LEXINGTON NEIGHBORHOODS IN LEXINGTON, KENTUCKY, WILL IMPLEMENT THE COMMUNITY LEAD (LEARNING, ENGAGEMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT) LABS PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND CAPACITY TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES BY INCREASING ACCESS TO AND USE OF THE MUSEUM?S MAKER SPACE AND INNOVATION LAB. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP PROGRAMS FOR THOSE SPACES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR THAT ENGAGE CHILDREN, TEENS, AND ADULTS IN EXPLORATION, PROJECT-BASED LEARNING, AND COLLABORATIVE PROBLEM SOLVING. IT ALSO WILL DEVELOP A PROGRAM TO INVOLVE TEENS IN WEEKLY HANDS-ON CAREER EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES AND INTEGRATE NEW ACTIVITIES INTO EXISTING PROGRAMS, INCLUDING AN AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAM FOR MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, FIELD TRIPS FOR ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, AND BADGE-EARNING WORKSHOPS FOR GIRL SCOUTS.

HOT SPRINGS COUNTY MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT THE 1920 MIDDLETON SCHOOLHOUSE IMMERSION PROGRAM AND ONLINE CLASSROOM PROJECT. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEVELOPING CURRICULA BASED ON LIFE AND EDUCATION DURING THE 1920S IN RURAL WYOMING, WHICH WILL IMMERSE STUDENTS AND VISITORS IN AN AUTHENTIC 1920S SCHOOL ENVIRONMENT WITH SCHOOL SUPPLIES, CLOTHING, AND BOOKS FROM THE ERA. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A NEW HANDS-ON LEARNING EXHIBITION IN THE SCHOOLHOUSE FOYER HIGHLIGHTING RURAL WYOMING SCHOOLS. IT ALSO WILL CREATE A WEBSITE THAT WILL INCLUDE FREE ONLINE CURRICULA, AN AUDIO/VIDEO TOUR, AND AN EDUCATIONAL VIDEO. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT WYOMING SCHOOL CHILDREN, THE NEIGHBORING WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION, LOW-INCOME AND RURAL POPULATIONS, AND MINORITY POPULATIONS IN THE TOWN OF THERMOPOLIS AND SURROUNDING COUNTIES.

ADKINS ARBORETUM WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS DATA AND REACH A BROADER PUBLIC AUDIENCE BY EXPANDING THE DEPTH OF INFORMATION AVAILABLE ABOUT ITS LIVING COLLECTIONS. THE ARBORETUM WILL REFINE PROTOCOLS FOR MAINTAINING ITS NEW OPEN SOURCE LIVING COLLECTIONS DATABASE, ADD A PROCESS FOR RESURVEYING THE COLLECTIONS, AND CREATE A COLLECTIONS MANUAL AS A SHAREABLE RESOURCE AND REFERENCE FOR STAFF. THE DATABASE WILL INCLUDE PLANT-ANIMAL INTERACTION INFORMATION, WHICH WILL ALLOW STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS TO DEVELOP PROGRAM CONTENT AND SERVE AS A GREATER RESOURCE TO THE PUBLIC.

HISTORIC CHERRY HILL WILL WORK WITH A CONSULTING INTERPRETIVE PLANNER, DESIGNER, AND EVALUATOR TO DEVELOP A FRESH PLAN FOR THE SITE?S INTERPRETATION. THE PLAN WILL INCORPORATE INSIGHTS FROM A NEWLY FORMED COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD, AUDIENCE RESEARCH, AND A PANEL OF INTERPRETIVE SPECIALISTS AND SCHOLARS. THE NEW PLAN WILL BETTER ADDRESS AND ENGAGE TARGET AUDIENCES, INCLUDING HERITAGE TOURISTS, MILLENNIALS, IMMIGRANTS, AND REFUGEES. THE MUSEUM?S STAFF AND TRUSTEES WILL WORK WITH A TEAM OF CONSULTANTS TO IDENTIFY RESONANT THEMES, INTERPRETIVE MESSAGES AND MODALITIES, AND POTENTIAL TECHNOLOGIES FOR USE IN A NEW INTERPRETIVE PLAN AND INTRODUCTORY EXHIBITION TO THE HISTORIC HOUSE. THE PLAN WILL HELP RESHAPE THE MUSEUM FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF VISITORS.

PROVIDENCE CHILDREN?S MUSEUM WILL EXPAND AND REFINE ITS CULTURAL CONNECTION PROGRAM, WHICH BRINGS DIVERSE ARTS AND HUMANITIES ORGANIZATIONS FROM ACROSS RHODE ISLAND TO THE MUSEUM ON A MONTHLY BASIS TO ENHANCE THEIR WORK WITH YOUNG CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. ARTS ORGANIZATIONS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH MUSEUM STAFF ON TRANSLATING THEIR CONTENT INTO FAMILY-FRIENDLY PRESENTATIONS AND TO CO-DEVELOP IN-DEPTH LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES AND EVENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE FREE TICKETS OR VOUCHERS TO FAMILIES TO ATTEND AN UPCOMING EVENT AT A FEATURED ARTS ORGANIZATION. BY TAPPING INTO THE MUSEUM?S TEAM OF EXPERTS IN CHILD DEVELOPMENT, ARTS AND CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS WILL LEARN HOW TO CREATE ACCESSIBLE EXPERIENCES AND OPEN DOORS TO NEW AUDIENCES OF YOUNG CHILDREN.

THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA?S ALABAMA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL REHOUSE AND DIGITIZE THE CHERMOCK BUTTERFLY COLLECTION. THE COLLECTION CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 30,500 SPECIMENS, INCLUDING SOME 18,500 PINNED AND 12,000 PAPERED, ALL DATING FROM THE 1930S TO 1960S. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PURCHASE CORNELL DRAWERS AND UNIT TRAYS TO PROPERLY REHOUSE THE COLLECTION. UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF A PROJECT DIRECTOR, THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL INVENTORY THE COLLECTION AND CREATE DIGITAL IMAGES AND RELATED LABELLING. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT AND CARE OF THE COLLECTION AND MAKE IT ACCESSIBLE TO BROAD AUDIENCES.

THE DUBUQUE MUSEUM OF ART WILL UPGRADE ITS COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE THROUGH A FOUR-PHASE PROJECT THAT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ANALYZE AND CONSOLIDATE COLLECTION DATA INTO A MASTER FILE, AND PHOTOGRAPH AND DIGITIZE THE ITEMS. FROM THERE THEY WILL EDIT AND UPLOAD THE IMAGES INTO A NEW ONLINE DATABASE, TRAINING THE STAFF ON HOW TO USE THE NEW SOFTWARE. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO AND FOSTER ENGAGEMENT WITH THE MUSEUM?S GROWING COLLECTION OF AMERICAN ART, INCLUDING HOLDINGS OF WORKS BY GRANT WOOD AND EDWARD S. CURTIS.

THE ART MUSEUM OF SOUTHEAST TEXAS WILL PROFESSIONALLY PHOTOGRAPH AND DIGITIZE THE JOHN G. FAIREY COLLECTION OF MEXICAN FOLK ART, WHICH INCLUDES TEXTILES, SCULPTURES, VESSELS, TOYS, GLASSWARE, AND MASKS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION AND CREATE CATALOG RECORDS FOR EACH ARTWORK, AS WELL AS LAUNCHING A WEBSITE TO PROVIDE ONLINE ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION. THE DIGITIZATION WILL INCREASE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF THE COLLECTION, ALLOWING LOCAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITIES TO BENEFIT FROM KNOWLEDGE OF ITS OBJECTS.

THE PORT TOWNSEND MARINE SCIENCE CENTER WILL COMPLETE AN EXHIBITION MASTER PLAN AS PART OF A LARGER FACILITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECT. THE EXPANDED AND RENOVATED FACILITY WILL CREATE AN ACCESSIBLE, UNIFIED, COHESIVE EXHIBITION EXPERIENCE WITH STRONG CONTENT LINKAGES AND SEAMLESS INDOOR-OUTDOOR INTEGRATION THAT GIVES THE FEELING OF A JOURNEY INTO THE SALISH SEA. THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING THE EXHIBITION MASTER PLAN WILL INVOLVE FORMATIVE EVALUATION, INCLUDING SITE VISITS, SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUPS, AND CONSULTATIONS WITH PROFESSIONALS. REPRESENTATIVES OF KEY STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, INCLUDING EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS, VOLUNTEERS, MARINE CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS, AND OTHER SALISH SEA ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS WILL PROVIDE INPUT ON THE PLAN CONCEPT AND EXHIBITION CONTENT. THE CENTER INTENDS TO INSPIRE RESPONSIBLE STEWARDSHIP OF GLOBAL OCEANS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF IMMERSIVE, INFORMATIVE CONTENT.

THE STEARNS HISTORY MUSEUM WILL UPDATE THE CATALOG SYSTEM FOR ITS ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS BY MIGRATING DATA TO A NEW CATALOG MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND CREATING A WEBSITE INTERFACE AND NEW CONTROL LANGUAGE AND FILTERS TO MAKE THE CATALOG MORE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE. THE DIRECTOR OF ARCHIVES AND ARCHIVIST WILL SUPPORT THE MIGRATION AND CLEAN-UP OF METADATA INTO THE NEW SYSTEM. THREE WORK-STUDY STUDENTS FROM ST. CLOUD STATE UNIVERSITY WILL TAKE THE MIGRATED METADATA FROM THE ARCHIVAL CATALOG AND BUILD A DIGITAL CATALOG WITH IDENTIFIERS FOR E-COMMERCE. THE NEW CATALOG WILL SUPPORT A NEW REVENUE STREAM FOR THE MUSEUM BY MAKING IT EASIER FOR PATRONS TO ORDER PHOTOS AND PRINTS VIA THE MUSEUM?S WEBSITE.

THE WYCK HISTORIC HOUSE, GARDEN, AND FARM WILL GROW ITS HOME FARM CLUB BY EXPANDING ITS OPEN HOURS AND INTRODUCING A SERIES OF CULINARY WORKSHOPS. THE HOME FARM FOODWAYS PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE THE MUSEUM?S HISTORICAL COOKBOOKS AND TOOLS, CREATING AN OPPORTUNITY FOR PARTICIPANTS TO EXPERIENCE THE MODERN-DAY BENEFITS OF HISTORIC METHODS OF FARMING AND COOKING. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT COMMUNITY WELLNESS BY ADDRESSING FOOD INSECURITY, BOLSTERING SOCIAL RELATIONSHIPS, AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO GREENSPACE.

THE OLD STONE HOUSE AND WASHINGTON PARK WILL EXPAND ITS PERMANENT EXHIBITION TO INCLUDE A DIGITAL COMPONENT THAT ACKNOWLEDGES THE MUSEUM?S PRESENCE ON THE LAND OF THE LENAPE. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND ASSESS THE IMPACT OF THE DIGITAL EXHIBITION AND CORRESPONDING EDUCATION PROGRAMS. MUSEUM EDUCATORS WILL PRESENT HANDS-ON CLASSES AT THE OLD STONE HOUSE USING REAL AND REPLICA ARTIFACTS AND OTHER LEARNING MATERIALS THAT SUPPORT THE DIGITAL EXHIBITION CONTENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES ALSO WILL INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN THE 1.5 ACRES OF GARDENS THAT CONTEXTUALIZE THE LENAPE HERITAGE OF THE SITE USING NATIVE AND USEFUL PLANTS. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE MUSEUM?S 45,000 ANNUAL VISITORS, INCLUDING 6,000 STUDENTS IN GRADES K?12, AS WELL AS THOSE WHO ACCESS MUSEUM?S WEBSITE.

THE MINING AND ROLLO JAMISON MUSEUMS WILL IMPLEMENT A PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTIONS. STAFF WILL CLEAN, INVENTORY, PHOTOGRAPH, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION ACCORDING TO BEST PRACTICES. THEY WILL ASSESS THE PRIORITY FOR PROCESSING OBJECTS BASED ON THE VULNERABILITY OF THE ARTIFACT, ALIGNMENT WITH THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTIONS POLICY, AND USEFULNESS TO RESEARCHERS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS OVERCROWDING, A BACKLOG OF UNCATALOGUED ARTIFACTS, AND IMPROVE INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION TO PROVIDE GREATER ACCESSIBILITY FOR MUSEUM STAFF, RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE WHALING MUSEUM AND EDUCATION CENTER WILL CONDUCT ?BIG BONED,? A NEW PROJECT CENTERED ON THE PERMANENT DISPLAY OF A FULL-SIZE WHALE SKELETON. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION, MARKETING, AND EVALUATION OF AN EXHIBITION AND PROGRAMMING DESIGNED TO BENEFIT A GENERAL AUDIENCE OF 20,000 INDIVIDUALS ANNUALLY. A MARINE BIOLOGIST WILL OVERSEE THE FABRICATION, TRANSPORTATION, AND INSTALLATION OF THE WHALE SKELETON AND EXHIBITION COMPONENTS. ?BIG BONED? WILL ENHANCE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND APPRECIATION FOR THE KEY ROLE WHALING PLAYED IN THE COUNTRY?S MARITIME HERITAGE, STRENGTHEN UNDERSTANDING OF WHALE BIOLOGY, AND SENSITIZE THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE NEED FOR WHALE CONSERVATION.

THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO?S CENTENNIAL MUSEUM AND CHIHUAHUAN DESERT GARDENS WILL INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY AND COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP OF ITS HERBARIUM THROUGH DIGITIZATION ACTIVITIES. A PROJECT MANAGER WILL LEAD EFFORTS IN BARCODING, IMAGING, AND GEOREFERENCING 26,897 SPECIMENS FROM THE SOUTHWEST UNITED STATES AND MEXICO. THE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE ACCESS TO PHYSICAL SPECIMENS AND DIGITAL IMAGES OF SPECIMENS AND ENABLE DISCOVERY AND USE OF BIODIVERSITY DATA BY RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, ARTISTS, AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT MANAGER WILL DEVELOP AN EXHIBITION AND PROGRAMMING TO CELEBRATE THE LOCAL HISTORY OF SCIENCE, PLANTS, AND ART.

AS PART OF A MAJOR EXPANSION PROJECT, THE DUNGENESS RIVER AUDUBON CENTER ON WASHINGTON?S OLYMPIC PENINSULA WILL DEVELOP AN INTERPRETIVE DESIGN PLAN FOR ITS EXHIBITIONS AND EDUCATIONAL SPACES. A TEAM WILL DESIGN A WILDLIFE OBSERVATION ROOM WITH WILDLIFE WATCHING EQUIPMENT AND REFERENCE MATERIALS AND A CHILDREN?S DISCOVERY AREA WHERE GROUPS CAN GATHER AND LEARN. THE PROJECT IS LED BY THE CENTER WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THREE FORMAL PARTNERS: JAMESTOWN S?KLALLAM TRIBE, OLYMPIC PENINSULA AUDUBON SOCIETY, AND NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY. COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS WILL PROVIDE INPUT, EVALUATION, AND REVIEW THROUGHOUT THE DESIGN PROCESS.

THE ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT ?REDEFINING THE ARTIST?S GARDEN: THE LANDSCAPE OF ALICE AUSTEN?S STUDIO,? A PROJECT TO SHOWCASE THE IMPORTANCE OF PHOTOGRAPHER ALICE AUSTEN?S ROLE IN GARDENING SOCIETY ON STATEN ISLAND AND ITS IMPLICATIONS FOR VICTORIAN WOMEN?S SOCIAL HISTORY. A GROUP OF SCHOLARS WILL ADVISE THE MUSEUM ON CONTEXTUALIZING, EXPANDING, AND UPDATING THE MUSEUM?S INTERPRETATION OF MS. AUSTEN?S USE AND DOCUMENTATION OF THE HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT LANDSCAPE SURROUNDING HER HOME, REVISE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, AND BUILD COMMUNITY SUPPORT FOR PRESENTATION OF AUSTEN?S HISTORY THROUGH PUBLIC PARK SPACE.

THE HOUSATONIC COMMUNITY COLLEGE?S HOUSATONIC MUSEUM OF ART WILL IMPLEMENT A COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP PROJECT TO INCREASE STORAGE SPACE FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE ACQUISITIONS AND ENSURE PROPER CARE AND PRESERVATION OF ITS COLLECTIONS. DUE TO LIMITED STORAGE SPACE, THE MUSEUM WILL INSTALL NEW MODULAR UNITS IN A RECONFIGURED STORAGE AREA FOR FRAMED WORKS ON PAPER. THEY ALSO WILL RELOCATE ARTWORKS WHILE THE NEW UNITS ARE INSTALLED. AFTER INSPECTING AND EVALUATING EACH PIECE, STAFF WILL DEVELOP A CONDITION REPORT AND ENTER IT INTO A DATABASE THAT WILL REFLECT DONATION PROVENANCE, APPRAISAL VALUATIONS, INSTALLATION AND EXHIBITION HISTORIES, LOANS, AND CURRENT LOCATIONS.

THE CORONADO QUIVIRA MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH EXPERTS IN DIGITAL MEDIA, INSTRUCTIONAL TECHNOLOGY, AND SANTA FE TRAIL HISTORY TO DEVELOP A DIGITAL TOUR EXPERIENCE THAT WILL GUIDE MUSEUM VISITORS THROUGH AN IMMERSIVE TOUR OF THE TRAIL USING 360-DEGREE IMAGING, DRONE VIDEOGRAPHY, 3D TERRAIN SCANS, MUSEUM ARTIFACTS, AND VIDEO INTERVIEWS OF TRAIL LANDOWNERS. IT WILL ALLOW VIEWERS TO EXPERIENCE WALKTHROUGH LOCATIONS, WHICH CURRENTLY HAVE ALMOST NO PUBLIC ACCESS. THE DIGITAL TOUR WILL PROVIDE A MORE GEOGRAPHICALLY CONTEXTUALIZED UNDERSTANDING OF THESE HISTORIC MACRO-ARTIFACTS. THE SOCIETY WILL SHARE THE CONCEPT WITH OTHER MUSEUMS TO ENABLE THEM TO CREATE SIMILAR DIGITAL TOURS FOR THEIR COMMUNITIES.

THE YORK COUNTY HISTORY CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE STORAGE PLAN TO MOVE ITS ARCHIVES FROM AN EXISTING SPACE TO A STATE-OF-THE-ART STORAGE AREA. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE HIGH DENSITY STORAGE UNITS THAT WILL PRESERVE THE GREATEST NUMBER OF DOCUMENTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND OTHER ARCHIVAL MATERIALS IN THE SMALLEST AMOUNT OF SPACE POSSIBLE, WHILE ALSO LEAVING ROOM FOR 10 TO 20 YEARS OF COLLECTIONS GROWTH. THE PROJECT WILL DOUBLE THE SPACE FOR RARE BOOKS AND DOCUMENTS AND CREATE A NEW COOL STORAGE ROOM THAT WILL EXTEND THE LIFE OF PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT POSITIONS THE MUSEUM TO BETTER SERVE VISITORS AND RESEARCHERS.

THE GREAT AMERICAN SONGBOOK FOUNDATION WILL IMPLEMENT THE ?PRESERVING THE SOUNDTRACK OF OUR LIVES? PROJECT, DESIGNED TO DEEPEN USER ENGAGEMENT WITH THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A MUSIC LIBRARIAN TO PROCESS AND CATALOG A PORTION OF THE PARAMOUNT THEATRE COLLECTION?A COLLECTION OF MORE THAN 150,000 ITEMS DOCUMENTING THE MUSIC AND HISTORY OF WEST COAST RADIO STATIONS FROM THE 1920S TO 1950S. RESEARCHERS, PERFORMERS, AND THE PUBLIC WILL HAVE ACCESS TO THE CATALOGUED RESOURCES VIA THE MUSEUM?S WEBSITE. STAFF WILL CREATE A DETAILED PROCESSING MANUAL GROUNDED IN APPROPRIATE THEORY AND PRACTICE TO SUPPORT FUTURE PROCESSING OF THE MUSEUM?S ENTIRE COLLECTION.

THE VERMILIONVILLE LIVING HISTORY MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT THE HISTORIC VERMILIONVILLE ARTIFACT CATALOG PROJECT TO ACCELERATE THE CATALOGING AND DIGITIZATION OF APPROXIMATELY 2,000 ARTIFACTS ACCESSIONED OVER 30 YEARS. STAFF WILL CONDUCT A THOROUGH, PROFESSIONAL INVENTORY OF ARTIFACTS, INCLUDING CONDITION REPORTS. THE INVENTORY WILL PROVIDE DATA FOR DECISIONS ABOUT PRESERVATION PROJECTS AND THE POTENTIAL DEACCESSION OF ARTIFACTS FROM THE COLLECTION. THE INVENTORY REPRESENTS A FIRST STEP IN MAKING THE COLLECTIONS MORE ACCESSIBLE, AS STAFF WILL USE THE INFORMATION TO CREATE AN ONLINE DATABASE FOR THE LOUISIANA DIGITAL LIBRARY, GIVING RESEARCHERS AND PEOPLE OF ALL AGES, BACKGROUNDS, AND INTERESTS ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION.
